Fantastic game play loop, variety of maps, and you can choose the difficulty to match how you want to play. I wish there were more achievements for the highest difficulty but that's not a big downside. The multiplayer aspect of the game makes the game play loop easier since you can pull resources from other communities and carry more resources between locations but you can always bump up the difficultly if its too easy (still a huge plus to be able to play with other players). All in all, I would say this is like an 9/10 experience since the end game (the legacy missions) isn't really that fun.
The community system is pretty neat but other than that this game is soulless and empty, only recommend if you don't get bored from stabbing and shooting zombies for 100 hours.

I played this game for almost as much time on the Microsoft store and then I bought it on Steam since most of my games are on here.

The good :
I do enjoy the base building aspects but only in certain spots you can do so and changes can only be done in a specific manner (i.e. your starter base in the bottom of the home has a bedroom, beds in another room, and an even larger room that appears to be the bathroom, but you cannot make any use of it)
Large variety of weapons you can use
Stealth is fun but can't be used on humans, Ferals, or Juggernauts, they can always see you for some reason.
Large maps to explore.

The Bad
Lighting in the game is poor, and the flashlight is subpar at best
While the maps are somewhat large, they can also be very repetitive since there is little variety in each one and it can be tedious to travel around. (for example, another survivor group can be in a house on one playthrough, but they are in a different one on the next time, but the buildings are still the same)
You'll get radio calls from other survivors for help, and they love to be on the opposite side of the map. Often, you can't make it there in time and they take it rather personally.
You can't really affect the environment since it's stationary (for example, you can't board up windows, you can't remove things off the road that are in the way, etc.)

The Ugly
Your companions are dumb as shit. There's no way to sugar coat it. And oddly they have always been that way since I first started playing after it was launched. More often than not they are more of a burden than an asset. Let me give an example that has happened to me more than once. ~After travelling to the other side of the map to assist a group, I run over a toxic bloater that appears out of freaking nowhere (more on that later), car is trashed, I am injured and need plague cure, base isn't too far, I start running for my life back. Running in a zig zag pattern since if you try and run in a straight line while being pursued they will superman launch themselves on your back (picture when Leia Mary Poppins her way back to the starship in The Last Jedi) and proceed to nom nom nom you to death since even with full stamina they can still catch you. Which in itself is annoying because they can be facing me, I'm swinging a weapon at them, and they teleport in back of me and proceed to nom away. Anyway, I make it back to base, I run through the door and pass 4 of my companions then make a b-line for the stash to get the cure I had made ahead of time. While scrolling to the appropriate tab, I'm jumped by the same Zeds that were chasing me and they proceed to nom me to death while the companions I just passed stood there watching it all happen. Not to mention the companions that were posted for defence on the walls. (this was the Red Talon base that was fully upgraded)~
Zeds appearing out of nowhere and in places they cannot get to. I used stealth to clear a house looking for stuff, I go to the livingroom, Check the things that are highlighted, room empty, off of the room is a bathroom, I go there, clear that, on the way back I hear something coming from outside (sounded like a zombie moving), i go back in the livingroom to look out one of the windows and I'm jumped by a plague zombie that was somehow laying on the floor who then proceeds to enjoy me for lunch. There is one entrance to the room, none of the windows are broken, how the hell did you get in there after I cleared it!!?
Another instance of really dumb companions. I go to a radio call, they want me to clear a location and unfortunately want to go. I get close to the spot, I'm using max stealth (I use that skill for all my companions in Nightmare+ diffculty) They are behind me, as I near the door to the medical clinic. The companion with me gets close to a Zed that appears out of nowhere again, they turn to the newest member of the zombie paratrooper brigade and then bang! bang! bang! with their shotgun. For the love of.... I run like hell since waves and waves of zombies are coming. They on the other hand, have other plans. I stop, look back, and return to where we were since they are nowhere to be seen. They are surrounded by zombies and have smartly put the shotgun away and are in the process of trying to fend off hordes of zombies in what could best be explained as a Post Apocalyptic Leeroy Jenkins moment using only a combat knife. I decide to take the L for completing the quest and wait for the failed mission to inevitably appear. Silver lining though, I got to loot their shotgun from their body because some of us know how to be stealthy Becca!!

This is a pretty cool game. It has multiple characters that you can and must switch between that also have management in terms of maintaining their health after damage they take and which type, where also through switching you can go and do different tasks with each one where if a character gets damaged or sustains an injury you can go to the field hospital and until they recover play with an other character which not just is convenient but adds to the suspense and management aspect of the experience.

It has other managerial aspects like ones pertaining to base building and maintenance through gathering ... resources by which you upgrade your settlement and I think gear too. There are outposts that you can reclaim and the game also has some RPG elements relevant to the individual characters like for instance Cardio / Wits / Fighting / Shooting (and specialization in those fields) and a in game radio which you can use actively in game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3163600872

Gameplay itself is decent like aspects of action that relate to shooting and melee are okay and there are finishers, just as there is a day and night cycle for that extra immersion and scares. Game feels initially a bit clunky and IMHO could use some polish to make the characters feel a bit heavier or just to polish up the gameplay because today we have been spoiled when it comes to some games and how their gameplay plays and feels like, but the responsiveness of movement is good enough. It is obviously a survival game which with management aspects is really cool because I like tinkering like that in my games. Gathering resources, surviving, building a base and expanding it and exploring.

Now as I periodically continue playing I might come back to complement my review like suggestion with other details that I think are somewhat important to mention but I came here to mostly say that the perception of the game for whatever reason to me didn't seem all that great at first since I've known about this game for already a long time but didn't think much of it until now I have tried and I must say that I like it because of the aspects mentioned above. 

Of the more action oriented zombie survival or action games that I've played recently this one takes my fancy and I very like the idea behind it and to a great extent the execution (heh, [i]''execution"[/i]) of this one which again gameplay wise feels a bit basic or "unpolished" but the ideas behind it are good as is the gameplay in general kind of sufficient to keep you at it for a bit I would reckon.

TL;DR: I have put hundreds of hours into this game, it has its bugs but overall is a great Zombie Survival game. If you like killing zombies and having a community of survivors working together to survive in the apocalypse, this is the game for you. 

On Xbox I have played this game for years pouring hundreds of hours into it, I was ecstatic to find out it was available on steam as well. I remember when the game released and it did not have nearly as much as it does today (as of Feb. 2024). The team is constantly updating and adding things to keep the game fresh, along with added difficulties to make you really plan and think before you act. 
Instead of having a specific "character" you play as, the characters are randomized and their stats are all different. Any given survivor has skills that you improve by doing the particular action, which eventually will evolve into an advanced skill upon growing in proficiency. This is randomized as well, to an extent. The survivors all start with Running, Fighting, Shooting, etc to improve. Then there is a final slot which will either have an interest, such as Driving, or a survival skill, such as Mechanics or Gardening. The randomization of the stats and evolution of what they are proficient in truly make each survivor as different of an individual as any one person in the world. Probably one of the most stand-out parts of this game is the reality of you not knowing who your fellow survivors would be or what they'll be good at. Maybe one of them will be good with bladed weapons and a professional architect. Another might be into Movie-Trivia and Heavy Weapons. Furthermore, every survivor has a "Hero" affiliation, so the more that you use this particular survivor, they eventually become the state of "Hero". When they reach Hero, they get an added bonus to their traits, and gain the option to become the Leader of the the group, which opens their respective Hero missions. This goes from being a Warlord, to being a Trader or Builder, and more. Additionally, whomever your Leader is will unlock unique base-building options. The versatility is essentially endless. The only thing I would change about this personally, is the addition to make your original starter survivors fully custom to give you the thought of "this is my family, friends, and/or myself" instead of being random strangers. 

The first thing you do upon gathering your firsts 3 survivors is finding your first (generic) base. For the most part, all first bases are generally the same. Each map has different layouts and base options (my favorite is the center of Trumbull Valley) each with their own pro's and con's. You gain influence (currency of the game) by doing things from killing hordes of zombies, taking out infestations, completing missions, and much more. To get into bigger and better bases, buy things from traveling traders, and recruit other surviving allies to accompany you on your journey, you need Influence. On top of having your personal base that you choose to build up in your own unique way, you can also claim outposts anywhere on the map (that doesn't have a Plague Heart) that offer your community different bonuses like site-wide power, water, a place to swap survivors while you're out exploring, lots of options as with everything else in this game. 

When it comes down to it, I could go on and on about how much I adore this game, even with all of the bugs and glitches it has had in the past. This series deserves a 10/10, and I am hopeful for a State of Decay 3 in the future. I will absolutely be on the pre-ordering train. 

If you've stuck around this long, I hope I helped sway your decision:)

Overview:
State of Decay 2 immerses players into a post-apocalyptic world overrun by zombies, challenging them to survive, thrive, and build a community amidst the chaos. Developed by Undead Labs and published by Microsoft Studios, this sequel to the popular State of Decay franchise builds upon its predecessor's foundation while introducing new features and improvements.
Gameplay:
The core gameplay revolves around scavenging for resources, managing a group of survivors, and defending against hordes of zombies. Players must make tough decisions regarding resource allocation, base building, and community management, as every choice affects the group's survival. The addition of multiplayer co-op adds an extra layer of depth, allowing players to collaborate with friends or strangers to tackle the challenges of the apocalypse together.
World and Atmosphere:
The game's open-world environment feels dynamic and dangerous, with each area teeming with threats and opportunities. From abandoned towns to rural farmlands, every location offers unique challenges and rewards. The atmosphere is appropriately grim and foreboding, with eerie ambient sounds and detailed environments that enhance the feeling of isolation and vulnerability.
Survivors and Progression:
State of Decay 2 boasts a diverse cast of survivors, each with their own skills, traits, and personalities. Managing these survivors and fostering relationships within the community is key to long-term success. As players progress, they can develop their base, unlock new facilities, and upgrade their survivors' abilities, providing a satisfying sense of progression and customization.
Combat and Action:
Combat in State of Decay 2 is visceral and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and tactics to dispatch the undead threat. Whether stealthily sneaking past zombies or engaging in intense firefights, the game offers a range of playstyles to suit different preferences. The addition of vehicular combat adds an exciting dimension to the action, allowing players to mow down hordes of zombies or make a daring escape when overwhelmed.
Technical Aspects:
While State of Decay 2 delivers an engaging and immersive experience, it's not without its flaws. Some players may encounter technical issues such as frame rate drops, bugs, and occasional glitches. However, frequent updates and patches from the developers have addressed many of these issues over time, improving the overall stability and performance of the game.
Conclusion:
State of Decay 2 successfully captures the essence of survival in a zombie-infested world, offering deep gameplay mechanics, a richly detailed world, and hours of addictive exploration and action. Despite its technical shortcomings, the game remains a compelling choice for fans of the genre, providing countless opportunities for emergent storytelling and cooperative play. Whether braving the apocalypse alone or with friends, State of Decay 2 offers an unforgettable journey through the end of the world.

Pros: 
5 large, unique map/environments.
Easily intuitive gameplay loop * base building mini game.
Diverse bases and 'survivors'.
4 types of community leader to chose from to diversify gameplay.
Difficulty scaling is very good; ease yourself in on lower difficulties, and play harder to have a real challenge!
Tons of unique loot, cosmetics etc that can all be earned in game.
No aggressive MTX loot store.
GTA style driving.
Basic survivor/base/vehicle/weapon maintenance.
Easy to learn, hard to masters. 
Potential for some really memorable gaming moments!
Interesting 'community pool' mechanic where you can essentially level and equip survivors on other maps, send them to your pool and recruit them/use them to get a boost in another higher difficulty map.
Even with decent gear and guns etc, you still have to play smart and not get overwhelmed.

Cons:
Not as complex as other survival games.
Friendly AI kind of sucks (avoid taking them with you on hard missions).
Easy cheese mechanics (drive car, park, stand on top, shoot).
Gameplay loop is quite simple and can get tedious.
Maps are large and tedious to traverse without a car (which are rare/break loads in highest difficulty).
Repetitive missions and minigames. 
Curve isn't too bad, but once you get your biggest base and loads of guns things get much easier.
Will take hours of your life from you!

It's got a lot of problems.
1) while playing with a keyboard and mouse often times the mouse inputs won't be recognized which results in being unable to aim or fire your weapon, swing your melee weapon, etc.
2) it spams you with alerts, constantly. A new quest every 15 minutes, at a minimum, plus other alerts which are often times not voiced.
3) the writing is really not great. Some very cringy one-liners and some obnoxious others.
4) night time sucks.
5) I needed several mods to actually somewhat enjoy this game because of the bad design (like useless flashlights) and tedium but it is still obnoxious.

SoD2 brings very much the same experience as the first one but improves it a bit. The game play is solid as ever, but there still are some minor things that tick you off. Like there is no way of unlearning skills, so you can't just forget things and learn new ones. Also the characters still can't climb rocks of any kind.

The thing I like about this game is the how you need survivors with different backgrounds and educations to build your base. Also the weapon handling is in this game is solid. I mean firing a gun and blowing a Z's head is so satisfying. I also both love and hate the inventory system. It is very simple, but it also means that your inventory gets full very fast. Which means you have to empty your bag between every house. Which is realistic if you find a lot of stuff. So take it as you will. The crafting system is also very simple and I can't really complain about it. One hint I can give is that- don't safe your guns and ammo in this game. You'll have plenty of both. Use your weapons. All of them. Same with resources and currency. I haven't had a problem that I'm out of something. Just remember to invest in resource storage in your base.


One main problem is that when you play the main campaign and really start doing quests... As soon as you promote a Leader for your group and start doing those quests, the game just suddenly ends. This game really needs a friend to play with so you two can help each other to clear out the Plague Hearts from the map ( not that they are too hard to clear, just get some distraction, use few explosives and your gold ), establish a base that you want and gather survivors. Playing alone in this game gets old pretty quick. At least after you finish the main campaign ( which happens way too quickly ).

SHORT STORY: How it all went down.
I did the mistake of playing the Sheriff story line and didn't even realize that this final quest would just end my game. I lost one of my vehicles lost my base and had to select if I wanted to continue my Colony, which I did. The map reset, so I basically was forced to start a +Game after completing the main story line. But I wanted to just continue playing the same map.


CONCLUSION!
If you like the zombie genre, SoD2 is a must buy as it's a very entertaining game with maps to explore, lots of zombies to kill, survivors to find and recruit and stories to tell. It's more fun to play with a friend as these games usually are, but I still find myself playing it alone and doing just basic things in it as I do love the game play.

Its a great game honestly driving car, searching, blowing up zombies, expanding your base, and completing missions. although after playing it for around 45 to 40 hours it starts getting repetitive. a simple solution to this is to play with friends, Im not even joking playing with friends is 10X funner and even if you don't have friends you can play with random people in the radio tab. even if this does not help you can play daybreak or heart land. and if that still does not help you can install mods using nexus or other mod sites. mods also make the game funner and easier.

This game is very well put together mechanically.
The gameplay feels really solid and the systems the game revolves around help bring it all to life.
This game is immerisve and enjoyable, or it would be if not for the story. That is, it has no story.

The story this game gives you is "random character X wants to do this thing" and "neighbouring group Y wants you to do this for them", in the grand story of "destroy these things".
I  had great fun in my first playthrough, breaking the plaguehearts and helping my fellow neighbours and survivors. Moving into more expansive base locations and investing in upgrades to help us keep going.
Then I destroyed them all. All that was really left was to move on to the next map. 
I did that, and... I picked a new map. Kept my supplies, survivors, and it was literally just the same task over again.

This game is grossly repetitive with a story that has no conclusion. Maybe it's a statement, but it's unsatisfying. There's nothing to supplement it, if that is what's happening.
There's limited time equipment earned through challenges, 'unique' randomized events, and a multiplayer mode.
This is the wrong format for a roguelike, but it seems to be what they're trying for anyway. 
I would refund this game, if I hadn't gone over the 2hr limit of gameplay. It took me 17 hours to realize that the story was a facade, nothing behind it to follow. Just endless random events and "smash the plaguehearts" before moving to yet another new map. Not because it makes survival sense, but rather because you've ran out of *things to do*.

Alas, I cannot, so as a die hard lover of the original State of Decay - I am disappointed with their sequel. Original State of Decay was begging for open world multi-player when it came out. So we have it now - and its okay.  Is good enough??..no, they really did not go as big as they should have with it, considering how badly it was begged for. They made us multiplayer where you are just a host slave.  What we wanted was a big ol' open world map we could ALL play together on. They have added rewards for assisting other players in their game but nothing special. State of Decay One is a little more offensive graphically, but its identical game. The multiplayer is nice but if you dont like being tethered to a host - youll not be missing out if you just get the first game, which is a classic at this point. 

The game play is still very repetitive - it is painstakingly repetitive. i advise to custom set difficulty to LETHAL action, DREAD community, STANDARD resources and turn on aim assist so you have an actual challenge at all. There is not much to break up the soon mundane activity that consists of you searching a home, taking stuff out of draws with a search functions, and taking the supplies you find back to your camp. Repeat.


This game also has sudden FPS drops after playing for a while even four years after release and their last update was adding Christmas sweaters for players. Why yall not love your game either? Do better in #3

super fun with friends, some things are done very right, otherwise once you beat the game a few times on solo, each map, then there is no replay-ability for the game, suggest waiting for state of decay 3 to come out

Completely engrossed from minute one. Exactly what I was looking for. No interest in fiddling with how many sticks I have and where this one section of wall should go. Upgrade facilities and designate roles, but no tedium. The open world system is very interesting. High risk, medium reward. Your excursions outward are tough and you have to do a little light planning for them. The sense of danger and discovery out there is real. I can't recall a single other "zombie" game where there are actual roaming packs of them that actually roam. I don't like the timed missions that pop up for specific settlers - they are rarely available to take them on (like I've been driving one person for a while, they are tired and injured so I literally have to put them in the infirmary - thus abandoning the mission. Yes, it comes back they say, but this system just adds stress where there need not be any extra). You get constant random radio prompts, sometimes they pop up on the opposite side of the map past TWO plague hearts. I get that its random, but those missions should stay available for at least a couple of in-game days and MUST stay available if you switch out the character to let them rest. That's reasonable and makes sense for the story. Change it now! The curve balls, however, are cool so far. I can't say what the long game will be like but this game made a fantastic opening impression.

Let me start off by saying, there is no "its okay" recommendation for steam. So overall I found the game to be okay. Fun with a friend. Some mechanics and clunky moments in gameplay can be irritating but overall was a fun time. Maybe I'd play the main game alone, but no way would I play Heartland alone. Since 2.4% of players have the achievement for finishing it (at time of posting this), I don't expect many people to stick with the brutal difficulty in which that DLC offers. The Plague Wall certainly needs to be nerfed in how much of a damage soak they are. Every explosive I could possibly muster and endless amounts of ammo spent to push through, all while fighting off hordes and endless specials. All to get a bland nothing ending was super disappointing. 

Overall I'd give this game a whopping 6/10 for base game. 4/10 for Heartland (mostly due to the end). 

Side note: The need to use an xbox account to even play this was beyond taxing. I have this on steam, I shouldn't need xbox/microsoft on top of that to be able to play with friends.

This is easily my go-to time killer.  I have beaten it a ridiculously number of times.  Its very fun, and never gets old.  COOP is absolute trash, as it only allows friends to aide you and not actually effect your game.  COOP is more of feature than a design, so I don't consider this a slight against the game itself.  There reviews would be better if it just didnt have it.  What drives me crazy, is that there is obviously a much better game here than what we have. I cannot think of a single game more deserving of a triple A treatment than State of Decay.  This isn't to say the game isn't fun, because it absolutely is fun, it just feels like it could be better with a little more money behind it. Its unbelievable that there hasn't been a clone yet.    Its basically, GTA with base building and zombies.  It doesn't waste time with building every little details, like Valheim, or 7 Days, but instead just allows you to furnish and upgrade your base.  This is much more satisfying but after a few play thrus, it does feel a bit limited.  Combat is intense, and exploring is loads of fun.  The only real complaint I have is that the story feels disconnected and barely part of the game.  This is a big departure from the first game, that was more story driven.

You know the old feeling you used to get when you'd play a good game and you lose all track of time entirely? 

This is one of those games.

The game mainly revolves around you making your own story. Build up your own community of survivors as you form a base camp. Gather vehicles, guns, munitions, building materials, meds and food.  Don't forget to create outposts and make upgrades as you explore and do quests. Zombies mutate and grow if you don't have a plan to stop them.

Addicting and great fun. Difficulty can be adjusted to your liking so it's not too easy or hard. Has seen lots of improvements especially on the performance side, I remember this game being very empty, buggy and unoptimized at launch. Shame about the way they set up progression for coop play but its still a super solid singleplayer game.

Highly recommend.

While this is a great game, it is sadly, not a two part series about White Collar's Tim Dekay becoming governor.

State of Decay 2 stands tall in the realm of zombie survival and settlement management games, offering an immersive and strategic experience where every decision weighs heavily on your survival. The game excels in delivering a true-to-life portrayal of the challenges one faces in a post-apocalyptic world.

What sets State of Decay 2 apart is its commitment to making every choice matter. From resource management to selecting community members, the impact resonates, shaping the fate of your enclave. The constant pressure of scarcity and the looming threat of the undead elevate the strategic depth, keeping players on their toes.

The pinnacle of the game's excellence lies in its settlement management system. The intricate balance of fortifying your base, ensuring resources are sufficient, and maintaining morale creates a dynamic ecosystem. It's a true test of strategic acumen, and the stakes are always high.

While the solo experience is gripping, the cooperative gameplay adds another layer of enjoyment. The synergy required to survive and the shared responsibility of managing the settlement deepen the immersion.

However, a slight downside surfaces in the form of the grind associated with the Daybreak mode. For some players, this aspect might feel repetitive and time-consuming. Nonetheless, it's a minor hiccup in an otherwise stellar game.

In conclusion, State of Decay 2 emerges as the epitome of zombie survival and settlement management. Its immersive gameplay, strategic depth, and the weight of consequential decisions make it a standout title in the genre, offering a gripping solo or cooperative experience.

I was in a discord call with my best gamer pals, They were playing this game, they even talked to me about it. at first I wasn't really that into it, simply because finding good survival zombie games are pretty hard to find. I love survival build based games, so zombie games are naturally within my category of games to enjoy. I was immediately convinced to buy the game the moment my friends were talking about collecting hoodies as well as limited edition hoodies in the game. I exclaimed "I WANT THEM HOODIES." I love supporting games and developers so naturally I bought the game as well as the DLC SOUNDTRACK for the game. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I got sucked into the game immediately. There are 3 Game Modes within the game: Campaign, Heartland, and Daybreak. Before playing CO-OP with friends and hop into other friends worlds and them into yours game you do have to play the Campaign mode (which is the main story mode) and build your own community FIRST. Also its Cross-play with XBOX players as long as you have an XBOX ACCOUNT AND THE XBOX APP downloaded on your PC, that way, XBOX friends (Same with Steam Friends) can easily hop into your world and you into theirs. I STREAMED us playing together on TWITCH yesterday. The game is fantastic going solo but even more chaotic fun with Friends! The story, dialogue, and voice acting was amazing, which allowed me to feel more attached to the survivors within my community, especially the first set of duo, that you first pick that has unique duo dynamic story with each other. I love that you can play any and all survivors within your community including the ones that you recruit. After you beat the story for the first time, or even if you don't beat a story mode the first time but still want to make another new campaign you get limited options of characters to choose from, it will become completely random from now on. The soundtrack is awesome. I honestly never heard of "State of Decay" until yesterday. Makes me want to buy the first "State of Decay" so I can play it. Thank you to the Developers for making something engaging and Fun!
This game is very fun !! I recommended you play with friends to make more fun !

I just turn down the in game music, put on some Bach or Debussy and float about, I love it! So i guess it is my favorite game anyway.

In my opinion is a must-play for fans of zombie survival games. It offers a thrilling and immersive experience of managing a community of survivors in a post-apocalyptic world. The game has improved a lot since its original release, with better graphics, more content, and fewer bugs. The new map, Providence Ridge, is a welcome addition that adds more variety and challenge to the gameplay. 
The game also includes two expansion packs, Heartland and Daybreak, that provide more story and co-op modes. State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is a game that will keep you hooked for hours with its addictive and rewarding gameplay. It is one of the best zombie games out there and deserves a 5-star rating.

Quite simply, this is one of the best zombie apocalypse games out there. The survival component is very subtle, especially when you play on high difficulty. Sometimes, you are so tense that your heart beats faster. The community-building aspect is very interesting as well. Side-quests are much more diverse and meaningful. The previous game was also great, and I didn't think the second part would be such an improved version. However, there is still room for improvement, and hopefully, we'll see that in Part 3. In particular, increasing the variety of zombies would be nice (especially animal zombies). Also, the ability to create a larger community would make the game more interesting. In short, this game is 100% worth every cent paid.

Constant crashing every hour or two, buggy zombies that animation lock you even though you dodge or weren't in their hit radius, lethal is more annoying spamming ferals at you than actually being hard, and after losing my character for the last time due to a trio of ferals even with scent block and a maxed out character I decided to finally quit this hot garbage of a game that hasn't been bug fixed in likely years.

Ok, so I'm going to try to be as thorough as possible while also trying not to be too long, 

tldr: the game is a lot of fun with some glaring problems.

Starting the game prompts the player to log in to an Xbox Live account. This alone almost prompted me to return the game. The player must log in, but the box that appears for the log-in freezes all controls on the main menu. Force quitting the game after logging in and then opening the game forces the prompt again. I had to alt-tab into another application to get my cursor back to start the game, then quit, then reopen to solve this issue. After the Initial log in it isnt needed again. (at least not to my experience so far.)

Game Play.
The game itself is amazing and fun. The UI is easy to use on keyboard and controller. Getting headshots on zombies is one of the most satisfying things I have done in any video game and the weapons and weapon-breaking system is a massive improvement over the first game. They added enough new content to keep the game interesting while also bringing back the zombie types of the previous game. That said there are a few issues with the gameplay that don't seem like features but instead make getting places in the game feel infuriating and slow. The zombie spawns seem both localized and like a larger system.

 A player could stealth kill zombies all the way down a street only to find all of those zombies have respawned almost immediately behind them making any level of trying to prepare by clearing an area pointless and also leading to zombie ambushes from areas once thought to house at least a little safety. However one could also see a special infected and that special infected will stay in that area until they are killed yet still have the chance of spawning behind the player in that previously cleared area (mostly just screamers and on occasion hordes, with at least 2 instances of this happening with juggernauts). This can also happen while driving and taking a look at the map with a few occasions driving on the open road to slow down and open the map to hit a bloater that wasnt their previously or ram through a horde.

 Plague hearts and juggernauts seem to have varying healthpoints some plague hearts take up to 10 direct explosives and multiple magazines while some just take a few magazines from a mid-damage weapon. The same goes for the juggernauts taking either a few shotgun reloads or needing to refill ammo after it tanked hundreds of rounds to the face. That isn't to say that defeating either of these isn't extremely rewarding, finally taking them down is a huge shot of dopamine however is frustrating to have to retreat mid-fight because that 200 rounds of ammo and case of explosives you brought for it weren't enough.

 I'd like to talk about mission prompts and quest markers. These are essential in an open-world game where pissing off a group of people can make them hostile and completely change the course of gameplay sometimes don't appear While completeing missions there were times where I was told a mission was failed but before that there was no prompt, marker, or indication it even started. A mission that asked to investigate a cleo drop only to not indicate where that was in the whole map and disappearing, a timed mission prompt to take out a hostile gang only for there to be no map marker. Timed missions without timers so that players cant really prioritize what to do first. one of the most egregious missions being a mutated plague heart that had a 1000 meter perimeter around it that harmed characters while inside it with no real indication of why it was happening with characters continuously saying "There must be some way to weaken that plague heart." Only after losing two characters did i get the mission prompt to bring mutated plague samples to one of my allies to find a weakness (RIP Romero, who after he and Josiah nearly died to the plague heart fight went back in alone with explosives and a pistol heroically finished the job losing his life in the process.)

Problems.
While I haven't seen much in terms of glitches I can say that this game crashes a lot. there have been about 10ish crashes and total freezes in my 38 hours of playing the game. most of them being as I left base. a few of them happened as I approached mission objectives and a few were while I had the game paused and was using the bathroom. The crashes are usually at low-intensity moments so it hasn't gotten my characters killed or harmed progress just a frustrating thing to use the bathroom and come back to a frozen game. There are some moments where while driving (both slow and fast) sound will cut and the screen goes black and everything stutters for a moment as if the game wants to crash or it is loading.

All around this is a great game but still has a lot of flaws. I had a lot of fun playing this game as well as its predecessor. I do highly recommend picking up this game next time it is on sale. with that said I do want to talk about the last aspect of the game and tie it in with the previous one.

The endgame.
The game allows the player to pick a leader and this leader has an end goal. That goal is achieved via doing that character's missions and of course ends with a final fight. (I chose the sheriff so the final fight was against a gang wanting to take over the town) That final mission is permanent. However, that is the only part of the prompt that I could read as I freaked out trying to close it as zombies attacked my car that crashed after the pop-up explaining the final mission took away my controls. Essentially, on the way to the final mission, they have a marker that once reached triggers an end game "point of no return" screen that comes up without real warning, and doesn't pause the game so if your driving the car will keep moving, and any zombies will still be chasing you. The whole thing is about a paragraph and the options to cancel or continue are press and hold prompts. Why they thought this was a good idea to have on the way to the mission in unsafe areas instead it pausing the game or it being somewhere at your base where someone could read the whole thing is beyond me.  
Now tying it back to the first game, after completing the story the player is given free roam again. the new objective to survive as long as possible, kill zombos, have fun. In this game, The player is given the opportunity to go back into the game with the whole community and the gear and stuff from the previous run but can also choose a new map and starter base. This is so cool and amazing and gives the game so much more content.. If you're ready for it. If you aren't and you can't afford the base size you need then you kinda get stuck with too little room. It isn't much of a problem but it would be nice to be able to go back and prep first.

It's a very good game and i have played way more hours than Steam thinks, but they were before the infestation update, which is ok, but also changes the game into a rush rush timer game which i'm not overly fond of, i just enjoyed scavenging and dealing with Zeds and the Specials and taking on the Plague Hearts when i felt like it. The new update changes that a lot by making it so the moment you are spotted by a heart, a timer looms over you, i also really enjoyed just thrashing about it my dlc car, squashing Zeds and it was ok to do, now having a car is kind of a death sentence unless you want to alert every single plague heart on the map.

As i said it's ok but i really enjoyed the other version way more and now i don't play it at all, so i think new players to it will like it, i just hope with the third game they take into account the overall population of their community's voice and not ignore them and not only listen to those who played on the harder difficulties. 

Even making the infestation update something that only affected the harder difficulties would of been better than losing a lot of players lol.

i always like zombie apocalypse theme game. and  this is really a successor for the state of decay 1. with more in depth community interaction.

The game is loop based; You'll have your team of survivors, develop your base, recruit more people, maybe lose some people, and eventually eliminate a threat in an area before moving on to a new one. There isn't an end game.

     The gameplay itself is OK, but leaves a lot to be desired, especially when it comes to limited base/community building. The combat is pretty good though. It gets pretty difficult, even on the lower difficulties. The gameplay does get boring after a while, though, that's a big turn off for most people. Not much of an endgame, and the loop just gets boring.

There isn't really a proper co-op as well; Yeah you can get in a game with someone, but if you're not the host you can't do much other than kill zombies.

The game also forces you to do some Microsoft log in. I don't have a big problem with this because I'm a big Xbox guy but I can see where this can be annoying,

     One thing that warrants my respect is the fact that the game came out in 2018 and still gets updates, even during the confirmed development of state of decay 3. That's awesome.

State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is the expanded and improved version of the original State of Decay 2 zombie survival game that was released in 2018. This new Juggernaut Edition adds tons of new content and improvements that make the overall gameplay experience even better.

In terms of visuals, the graphics have been enhanced with better lighting effects, sharper textures, and improved animations. The world feels more vibrant and detailed, from the dense forests to the abandoned towns you'll be scavenging through. Audio wise, the sounds of zombies groaning and ambience noises like wind blowing through the trees further immerse you into the post-apocalyptic setting.

Gameplay is still focused on resource management, base building, recruiting community members, and exploring the open world, but it's deeper than ever. There are more options for base locations now, each with their own benefits. Combat puts an emphasis on stealth and strategy to avoid deadly zombie hordes. There's also a bigger variety of missions that unfold procedurally, keeping things interesting across multiple playthroughs.

The further you progress, the tougher choices you'll have to make to ensure your community survives against the relentless waves of zombies, hostile human enclaves, and dwindling resources. The new difficulty modes offer brand new challenges for veterans of the series looking for a stiffer test of their survival skills. All of this contributes to an addictive, tense and rewarding gameplay loop.

Overall, State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition takes what was great about the first game and expands on it tremendously. Both newcomers to the series and returning fans will find plenty to sink their teeth into with its compelling survival sandbox gameplay. If you're a fan of zombies or survival games, this is definitely one worth picking up.

this game is probably one of the GOATS of zombie games, however it doesn't play nice with newer hardware (i have a 7800 XT, 7800X3D and 32 GB DDR5 and i had a massive stuttering problem) . if you want to enjoy this beauty on newer system go to %appdata% find state of decay 2 go to engine.ini and use these commands r.Streaming.FullyLoadUsedTextures=1
r.Streaming.HLODStrategy=2
r.Streaming.LimitPoolSizeToVRAM=1
hope this helps and happy hunting

I've given this a thumbs down half a dozen times and Steeam INSISTS I post a proper review.

Game crashes and freezes AI/dialog for no apparent reason.   Characters decide to jump off cliffs and injure themselves.  Melee attacks just don't hit sometimes and there doesn't seem to be a way to prep a melee attack, waiting for a zombie to come into range.  Guns are much better in that heads have a large hitbox and zombies are pretty deaf to gunshots.  Not to car horns or the clinking of objects as you rummage around too quickly.

Honestly, I wouldn't have given this a thumbs down except that Steam insists on nagging me, constantly, for reviews.

EDIT 1: I just started a new settlement after the game crashed on my last one.  I went up a billboard tower to scout out the surroundings.  Upon going down the ladder, my character decided to then drop off the edge.  This was a slow process that wouldn't seem to allow me to cancel.  So she dropped, broke her legs, and we don't even have a settlement yet to heal her up.  Great.  The followers with me, they surely wouldn't walk off the cliff after they just saw what happened to her, right?  Yeah, no, time to delete this settlement.  FFS.  Almost a 4 year old game and the jank is this powerful.

EDIT 2: OH FFS!  So I went into manage communities; a nifty way to keep track of the different runs you have going.  I clicked on the one I want to delete, believing this would select the community so that I could click on a button to delete it.  NOPE! Come on, Microsoft.

State of Decay 2 hits the sweet spot for a PvE + Multiplayer Cooperative zombie apocalypse survival game. The game play loop is relatively simple but manages to stay entertaining. There are several different maps to play on, each with their own variety of bases your community can occupy. These bases have a multitude of different building options based on slots available, and most bases have some kind of built-in slots. Each community you play will be different, although you can bring back a few of your favorite past survivors to start a new game if you like. Four different leader archetypes provide options for specific community directions as well. Traders and Sheriffs focus on the broader community of survivors outside your own base, trying to help everybody. Builders and Warlords focus on your own community and being independent. 

The campaign is where I have spent over 40 hours now, which does have a narrative tutorial but after that it's up to you how to proceed with your community. The game generates missions for some of your community survivors which do have a coherent narrative, and the various other groups all have some story behind them. It's enough to make it feel not completely random and pointless without dragging you along in a pre-defined narrative. That said, there is a story-based mode I haven't played yet but it's there if that's your thing. 

There have been a few bugs but they have been very few and far between for me. The only game breaking bug was getting stuck in an open container I couldn't close, had to alt+f4 out. No other incident has forced me to close the game in 40+ hours. 

Overall I'm very happy with the purchase, it's a lot of fun!

- Game gets incredibly repetitive after a while. Quests to help neighbours feel like chores, and the nature of the quests does it absolutely no favours (bring us X resource, help us kill a zombie, help us kill a dude). It's not uncommon that a neighbour would ask for a resource, then you loot the very 1st building on their own property, and find that resource they were looking for. WTF are they doing in there all day? Thinking up busy-work to keep you occupied with, and then cry when you don't wait on their every beck and call? 
+ I'll admit, bumping the difficulty up to Dread was fun for a while, I am not even mad that I got stomped (ammo ran out and 1000 infestations set up around my base, R.I.P.). I found it challenging to change how I approach the game to account for the difficulty spike, and this was a relatively rewarding experience, however the monotonous nature of the game inevitably rears its ugly head. 
- The campaign is terribly disappointing. The characters are 1 dimensional, and the campaign is just the base (boring) gameplay with a couple of extra steps. Quincy and Helena shows a glimmer of personality, but the rest are just "stock personality packs". There's literally no point in spurning any of the neighbours/characters since they are so 1 dimensional, you don't need to worry whether or not a character might betray or slight you. You just help them, and then they might as well start calling you Jesus from now on lmao.
-- Follower AI is really dumb. I usually just take a follower with to haul extra loot, or to tank zombozos for me, that's it. I also don't understand why you're limited to employing 1 follower at a time, like what's the point of any vehicle with more than 3 seats? Also, though the pick-ups are cool and all, I cannot for the life of me understand why followers always insist on sitting on the back where the wettest of noodles can cling to the car and launch them off with a nanogram of effort.... Why can't I take the entire squad out to deal with a plague heart/wall, or just cruise around and wreck some zombozos? The followers at base are also just utterly useless. All they do is make noise and consume resources, and offer a paltry loot haul every now and then. Also: when I'm looting, they just stand around and look at me. WHY DON'T THEY HELP LOOT? You can't even say they're on point/lookout, since on numerous occasions I would loot while follower just stands around, and a ninja zomb would come up to me and bite me in the dick, just to have them look on in an apathetic stupor exclaiming: "Watch out, there might be zeds around", like really? Zombies? In the zombie apocalyptic wasteland? 
-- Inventory management is HELL. 40 bullets take up a slot the same as a god damn GENERATOR? Nah, I'm not buying it. Ammo and equipment could have had different inventory slots. Limiting us to 8 slots (save for loadout and pockets) is HELL. I do not enjoy blowing every single item in my inventory to scratch at a fraction of the plague wall's health, just to tuck my tail between my legs to drive back to base and restock, just to go chip away at another slither of its health-pool again. (Sure, set up an outpost nearby, ye ye, but tell me in all honesty: is this fun and rewarding gameplay? Blow your load, run 10m, restock, come back, and do it again for 20 times? or GOD FORBID you need to drive 2 km back to base because you ran out of this or that?)
-- Don't even get me started on the plague heart/wall triggering mechanic. I could spend 10 minutes clearing out the entire lot around the plague heart/wall, but as soon as I breath on the heart/wall, a million zombies just materialise out of NOWHERE. The plague wall triggering mechanic is AIDS AF: same logic as before, but now Scotty beams a fkn juggernaut and GOD FORBID a feral right on top your face along with 50 of their best friends. Where tf were they like a minute ago? Do zombies in this game tunnel? Nah, this mechanic is stupid at worst - implemented VERY poorly at best, and crafty gameplay is not rewarded.

One could say my expectation of the game experience is too high, but to that I say my disappointment is proportionally high. HARD pass for anybody looking for a rewarding and enriching gameplay experience.

If it ain't broke... don't fix it?

State of Decay 2 is an open-world zombie survival game from Undead Labs. As a sequel to their 2013 game, SoD2 (released 2018, Juggernaut edition on 2020) takes a lot from its predecessor - sometimes to a fault. However, this also means that everything that made the first one great is here too!

The best: First and foremost, the soundtrack is absolutely gorgeous. State of Decay 2 is a blast to play, which is all you can ask from a game. The graphics make the world look endearing and the FIVE (!!) different maps, together with the progressively more challenging difficulty settings, are enough to keep you coming back. The two DLCs that come with the Juggernaut edition are a fantastic addition to the game, both Heartland adding a deeper story and Daybreak featuring a base defense game mode. Being able to play all of those, as well as the base game, online - with friends or strangers - is a nice feature for those interested.

The bad: Being so similar to the first State of Decay, to the point of having its original map and it being the best one, makes the game feel unoriginal at times. SoD2 is narratively very weak, with basically no plot in the main game whatsoever, and having to go to the DLC to experience some sort of actual storyline feels... weird.

Conclusion: State of Decay 2 is a fun but flawed game. I'd highly recommend its purchase, more so during sale season, while keeping its pros and cons in mind. Its numerous features (base building, community management, world exploration, survival elements...) are guaranteed to keep the player entertained for dozens of hours - and get them ready for the upcoming third State of Decay!

Like most big studio games, this one had allot of promise and a great premise... and then...

There's a good deal about this game that I do like, so credit where it's due.  It does give an interesting spin on the zombie apocalypse as well as some decent base building options.  Combat is interesting, but nothing to write home about.  The graphics are overall pretty good and it does give you a sense of dread, especially when you're scavenging at night.

Now for the bad.  Like most big studios these days, they had to virtue signal to all the right groups and what we wound up with were Guatemalans, all of whom ate the ugly tree, placed in the rural areas of... well, someplace that I think is supposed to be the US.  Throw in a generous portion of bugs and half handled AI programming and you get State of Decay 2.

If you're going to get the game, do it when it's discounted as this isn't worth the sticker price.  Also, be aware that since they're working on the 3rd game, the chances of them actually fixing some of the LONG standing bugs that have been around since the beginning, are slim to none.

Absolutely awful to play multiplayer on
The game gives each player individual storages to loot, however, player 2 consistently gets much less of them to loot. Leading to them not having as much/as good of gear as the host.
The loot grabbed from the world is individual and is separate between players with the exception of the big bag loot items needed for the communities, with any you deposit as player 2 being donated to the host. This leads player 2 to not be able to craft anything in the community and the host has to do it for them.
This is the massive issue with the multiplayer where is wants you to work together to progress but one player just gets left behind.
Another issue is that (I don't know if this was my game bugging or an intended feature) but I am not able to heal myself over time in the hosts game where I play another character to let the other one heal. I left one character at the base for about 3 in game days and they were still injured.
These issue mean that in order for both people to progress you have to swap between games.

Other than the multiplayer the game is just a copy+paste of the first one but worse, there is no overall story and the gameplay loop gets boring quick.

I love the game. Amazing zombie game, its such a perfect base for what a zombie game should be. Its significantly better than the launch state it was in. Its fun, surprisingly deep, and has mechanics that work so well together. Problem is, its still quite glitchy. Talking to characters doesn't always work, models freaking out, physics freaking out, weird stuff happens that feels like the game is seriously broken in some spots, or its a charming jank (sometimes). It happens just often enough that it needs serious addressing from the Devs. I keep running into glitchs that end a session, and due to the way quests work, that quest is now gone until it randomly pops up again next session. At that point I want to move on to something else than deal with this frustration after an hour session. The curveball system is so brilliant, adds such emergent gameplay variation to the overall gameplay loop it keeps it pretty fresh. That feels like something all zombie games should have. Inventory managemant is a pain in the ass. Im a loot goblin and I cant help myself grabbing everything I can. I seriously wish a small vial of plague cure doesnt take up the same amount of room as a portable generator - there needs to be more variation in loot size, weight isnt enough for this style of system.  I run into inventory management issues enough that if I dont have an extra survivor with me its a serious drag. Maybe higher difficulties use this to its fullest, but my example is still valid for loot size differences. SoD3 needs to seriously overhaul inventory management in a game thats like 80% looting. Even a truck, it should be able to store an intense amount of stuff but its only 4 extra slots, which is huge but feels like its not right. I am highly anticipating SoD3 and wish the studio and these devs the best of luck.

This game is definitely good for 30-40 hours, but then there is nothing special to do in it since there is no endgame, where after clearing the plague hearts, all that remains is to loot those locations that were not looted and kill zombies. One of the possibilities is to transfer your community to another map, but there the main thing is clearing hearts and then it’s not clear what to do. There are two modes - Heartland (plot) and Daysbreak (holding positions from zombies), which you can also play for a couple of hours and that’s it. There are no other modes, for example, survival between other players, but although it would be possible to make PVE and PVP modes.
In general, I recommend it, but it does not have a full-fledged endgame and new modes that could drag the player on for 50 hours or more.

Game Title: State of Decay 2
Genre: Survival, Horror, Storage Management
Platform: PC Windows

[TL;DR] Must-Knows:

Visually stunning/unique:
It definitely has good visuals, but there is always room for improvement

Immersive audio and soundtrack:
Yes, when the music pops off - it definitely immerses you into the environment right away.

Engaging story/narrative:
The premise is to build a community, loot and discover new places that would benefit you and your community. You will encounter others who need help and would become allies or enemies. It is up to you to decide. There isn't a huge story line behind people just trying to survive. 

Gameplay mechanics:
The fighting mechanics can be clunky but not too noticeable. Walking, running, looting, entering cars and home through doors or windows have been smooth. Driving is super fun in this game. I typically go for off road trucks to get to places faster and run over a ton more zombies.

Responsive and intuitive controls:
Very responsive to keyboard commands. I believe you should be able to use a controller with this so that makes it good for those users as well.

Challenging but fair difficulty:
It can be quite challenging depending on your difficulty due to storage management demand, community demand, etc. However, playing it on the easiest mode is not tedious and does allow you to get accustom to building and other things so when you are ready for more, just go to your settings page while in the current map and community, then boost up that difficulty and good luck! 

Plenty of content to keep you playing:
Loads of things to do, but it can get slightly redundant after a while but the character switch does help shift that perspective. It is one of those things where you are the music maker and the dreamer of dreams. DO WHAT YOU WANT :) 

Runs well/optimized for your system:
Yes, it doesn't take much to run this game.

Few/no game-breaking bugs:
No bugs or anything encountered so far.

"State of Decay" is an absolute gem in the survival game genre. The game beautifully captures the essence of survival, making every choice matter. The mechanics of scavenging for resources, fortifying your base, and developing your characters' skills add layers of depth to the gameplay. There's an incredible sense of accomplishment as you see your decisions directly impact the survival and growth of your community. 

In summary, "State of Decay" is a must-play for anyone who enjoys a challenging and immersive survival experience. Its unique blend of strategy, storytelling, and survival mechanics makes it a standout title in the genre.

Still one of the best zombie survival games out, and receiving tons of constant love and updates from the dev team many years later. The whole "community" angle of this game really sets it apart from the rest, having a crew of survivors who each have their own unique skills that level over time lets you tailor your community to your  play style. Also love/hate the fact that you can't save or reload, meaning choices matter in this game, and if a survivor dies... you can say good bye. My only ongoing gripe is, the pace of both the zombie spawns and random missions is way too fast. You can clear the are around your base and the same zombies will literally be respawned in three minutes. But, you just learn to ignore them. Missions, however, are a bit more brutal as missing some of them create hostile settlements. I've tried many times on harder difficulties, and I have no idea how people do it. Good luck.

I wish their was a neutral rating. It is a great concept, and can be very fun. It also can be very frustrating when you lose a character due to derp AI. I am a huge fan of permadeath strategic games that punish you for wrong moves. I am not a fan of going into a room, getting a camera full of wall and having my character nearly die before I can get vision on what is actually there. Controls can be a bit wonky as well. Hitting the button to climb on top of a van to get a momentary break from fighting a horde and watching your character jump up and down instead can be infuriating. There is much to love about this game, but the lack of polish this long after release is a big downside.

The beginning of the game can be great., Scavenge, kill zombies, recruit people and start to meet the neighbors. The problem is, there is little else. Zombies respawn infinitely around you, so clearing an area is pretty much useless. Plague Hearts, in my opinion, are just not fun at all to deal with. It does not matter if you spent hours killing every zombie within 69 miles of the plague heart, the second you injure it, a pack spawns right outside the building and come rushing in. Strategy has no place here, unless you consider leaving a vehicle right outside a window so you can climb on top of it strategy. Really just bring explosives, blow up the heart, and gtfo before the horde spawns on your head is the only logical way of dealing with these. The end game is boring and offers little beyond your leaders story and killing plague hearts. 

 If they added some sort of depth to the endgame, tightened the controls, and had persistent zombies who roamed around the map chasing noise and activity this would be such a good game. As it is, it can be fun, but as is it is mediocre at best.

The good side is that the devs continue to update and add to this game. The bad, the things they add are not always fun. I recently gave this game another go to see what all had changed. Unfortunately, its just more of the same. Honestly the best strategy to this game, on hard difficulty settings at least,  is to rush all the plague hearts in the first week of game time and end it before it can scale up. I love difficult games, but I like fun difficult, not spawn super plague heart infused, black plague heart buffed hordes on my head over and over again difficult. The promise is there with this game, they just took it in a direction that I personally did not like.
Aside from the completely lame difficulty based achievements and achievements forcing people to play Daybreak, which honestly is not even popular among the community. It's a fairly decent game.

It's state of decay, but more, and with an arm tied behind its back. 
Melee combat has been severely dumbed down, don't like it. Other than that though, it doesn't fix any other game mechanics that weren't broken, but OTOH doesn't really improve on anything except broadening the scope with some varied maps. Curveballs have serious potential but are very poorly implemented C+, well worth a look if it's on sale.

I am having fun, and this is one of the decent only zombies games out there focused on a sandbox-y survival zombie game, but the game itself is.. not good enough?

A big step up from the previous title, it's decent for what its trying to accomplish, but State of Decay 2 doesn't quite nail the [b]multiplayer[/b] component and it's systems, while alright, not customizable or deep enough for someone really wanting to bite in. I understand the devs' vision but I think a player-first approach would've been more fun.

And by that I mean allowing full player customization, character creation, free base building and not limited to "squares open in a homebase", ability to choose any spot/house as home base, and a fully customizable custom difficulty (instead of 3 sliders for zombies, supplies, survivors). There might be more complaints but this is all I can currently think of writing.

Multiplayer works with host-only progress and all joining the host can only kill zombies, and help grab [b]some[/b] loot. After sessions, returning to your main-host base you receive small rewards based on your multiplayer sessions. This causes extreme boredom for anyone not the host, my brother who plays with me, does essentially one-note gameplay of slaying zombies and looting the 2/7 chests color coded for him. He can't recruit new survivors for his base/save, rest up his survivors in my infirmary, or use any of my survivors. I understand trolls may be a reason for these restrictions, but they could've allowed for host options that deny-allowed certain aspects.

The gameplay itself, is mostly good, the thirdperson gameplay (and this is my complete personal bias) would've been more exciting had the gunplay been incorporated in a more Resident Evil way; but the melee combat would probably suffer from doing it that way because the melee combat is ok, just being a bit janky with swings sometimes missing zeds despite clearly hitting. It's fine, mostly.

Music is good, the game is ugly (especially so if you focus in), the writing is a bit hit and miss, the sandbox is also a bit shallow (ESPECIALLY SO on lower difficulties), Microsoft sign-in is a complete plague, and [b]I haven't played the other gamemodes other than the first one but I can't imagine the quality changes too much[/b] apart from some surprises in the storymode.

Not a bad game, maybe for someone starved for an OK zombie survival sim, but I wish it was better. Here's hoping for State of Decay 3.

| What I Like | 
- Addicting and fun gameplay loop
- Extremely fun and challenging lethal difficulty
- Extremely fun with you and 1-3 friends in a multiplayer session

- Permadeath increases stakes especially on higher difficulty making many situations intense

- Xbox crossplay

| What I Don't Like |

- At times too much going on at once
- Grind to keep grinding
- Voice acting can be mixed 

| My Score |
9/10 - Engaging and just really fun zombie survival game that many people will fairly dismiss as a boring loot simulator but to someone willing to hop on with a group of friends, this game offers some of the most fun you'll have with a multiplayer survival game and for me personally created some great memories and turned this game into something my friends and I keep coming back to
awesome

State of Decay 2 is at best a mediocre game and at worst a heavily repetitive zombie looter-shooter. While I recommend the game, it is a [b] very weak recommendation [/b]. Only buy on sale when you're craving some mindless zombie genre fun.

Pros:
- Maps are relatively decent, pretty nice variety between them for the most part
- Difficulty actually matters, the higher difficulties are punishing but if you can survive it makes it much more rewarding
- Looting actually matters, don't have food? People will get very unhappy at the base and quickly. No ammo? Better hope that crowbar is durable to last while you scrounge for more ammo
- Graphics are okay at best

Cons:
- "Story" elements aren't really fleshed out that well. While you're probably not buying the game for the story, don't expect anything more than C level zombie flick writing.
- Characters say the same 10 or so lines with the same 4-5 voice actors
- Zombie variety is nice at first, but quickly wears on you after your first play-through
- The AI isn't very intelligent in the game, pretty easy to have a follower get themselves killed by doing asinine tasks

6/10 (we really need better zombie games)

State of Decay 2, developed by Undead Labs, offers a compelling but somewhat uneven survival experience in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by zombies. The game builds on the foundation of its predecessor, introducing new features and cooperative multiplayer while grappling with some persistent issues.

One of State of Decay 2's strengths lies in its emphasis on community building and resource management. Players are tasked with establishing and maintaining a group of survivors, each with their unique skills, as they navigate a world teeming with the undead. The procedural generation of characters and the complexity of base management add a layer of depth to the survival mechanics.

The cooperative multiplayer, allowing players to join forces in the struggle for survival, is a welcome addition. Collaborative efforts to scavenge resources, defend against zombie hordes, and explore the expansive map enhance the social dynamics of the game. The sense of shared responsibility fosters a unique multiplayer experience within the survival genre.

However, State of Decay 2 is not without its flaws. The graphics, while serviceable, can feel dated, and the animations occasionally lack polish. The game also suffers from technical issues, including occasional frame rate drops and glitches, which can detract from the overall immersion.

Combat, a crucial aspect of the game, can be both satisfying and frustrating. While the variety of weapons and the visceral nature of zombie encounters provide moments of intensity, the melee combat mechanics can feel clunky at times, impacting the overall fluidity of the experience.

Despite these drawbacks, State of Decay 2 succeeds in creating a tense and atmospheric survival setting. The ever-present threat of zombie hordes and the need to make difficult decisions for the survival of the community contribute to a sense of urgency and immersion. The developers' commitment to post-launch support and updates also demonstrates an ongoing effort to refine and expand the game.

In conclusion, State of Decay 2 offers a satisfying survival experience with a focus on community dynamics and cooperative play. While technical issues and some rough edges persist, the game manages to capture the essence of surviving in a zombie-infested world, making it a notable choice for fans of the survival genre.

[h1]Updated: Dec 2023[/h1]
They're still updating and releasing new free content for this game. On one hand, that is great. But, on the other hand, most of the new content is making the game more busy and more difficult.

You can still adjust sliders to tune the difficulty and how busy you want your experience, to a degree. But, I get the feeling the game is being pushed more towards a "better with friends experience" as opposed to just playing solo.

That might not sound like a bad idea.. But, the games implementation is not a "fully fledged co-op experience", more it is only a "friend can drop in and out" to help you for a while.


[h1]Updated: Dec 2021[/h1]
All the updates, fixes, additions over the years have truly made this game something special. Even after all my hours and with my current survivor community passing day 50 I still find the game interesting. Coming across new weapons, vehicles, and finding out of the way locations.

Collecting the bounties that get swapped around on a per monthly basis is a game in of itself.  So, the longevity is almost limitless.

My buddy talked me into getting this game on a whim, and DAMN is it good! I really enjoy the open-world aspect of it. In a few ways, it reminds me of Fallout, especially the base maintenance mechanic where you have to keep the base stocked up on resources that either can deplete or be passively earned by acquiring outposts. Combat is really good, however you can easily get swarmed, especially if you're trying to tackle Plague Hearts (which are your main objective in the story-line). You're able to recruit people to your community, take control of any member in your community, and locate friendly survivors, as well as kill them. Survivors located usually will have some side quests for you to do from time to time to keep you busy, and "Curveballs" keep things interesting by either lowering the difficulty as a benefit, or increasing the difficulty to pose a challenge.

TL;DR: would totally recommend this game, the Campaign is definitely worth the $29.99 asking price and your time in single-player, just be careful of host-guest tethers if you play co-op, this game doesn't allow much in the way of free-roam: performance reasons...

I loved the first iteration of this game, and I didn't even know there was a second, till they released it on GFN a few weeks back. I must say it was overall a pleasant surprise. It lost some of the ancestors' legacy, but it ended up as a decent game after all anyway.

I'm not a big fan of "live gaming" where you are required to log in through another service (Microsoft live account in this case) or you are denied access completely, no matter if you paid for the game already. This is not right and should stop already, however, this is a good survival game, decently dynamic to keep you entertained for hours, until you finally get bored by repetitive scenarios, yet they still might play a bit differently from your previous experience.

There is no plot, you just survive with your mates and mates sometimes die, so don't focus on developing just one character in your group of survivors. Play as you feel like it, there really are not many restrictions to force you to do something you don't like.
The quests are mostly not very interesting, nor rewarding but you gotta do them to unlock more of the content. It's a stealth/survival semi-strategy combat-focused game as the main genre, so until you stop having fun killing stuff and collecting sh*t you will be having a blast. Stealth is overall working, but even without specialization the Z's basically will not see you unless you go stealth in front of them directly, you can pass through the middle of the herd just by being crouched which is pretty disappointing.

I recommend starting immediately on at least dred difficulty, because that actually feels like "normal". Playing on a lower diff will inevitably ruin your late-game experience because it will feel easier over time.

I love this game!! 1200 hours and still going. The dev's keep updating and changing this game to make it better! this has been happening since it was released. The dev's truly listen to the community and are always having update videos. Multiple communities, saving your players so you can use them in different games. The play ability is endless.  The  different difficulty settings make it a different game for each. I can't say enough. For the base money I bought this for I have gotten back 10 fold in enjoyment. Plus there is not really another game like this.

Controls a little like GTA with inferior vehicle physics.  Multiplayer needs an in-game communication method.  Cheating is pretty rampant.  You have to exercise some self control to avoid getting duped items from PUG players.  
All things considered, it's well worth it. 10/10

Gameplay loop is stupidly simple. You start with a few guys and you control them one at a time, scavenge for stuff, do some randomly assigned missions, bring stuff/people home to grow your community, and then switch out for a different guy when your current character gets tired.. also there's zombies and co-op.

The lack of story compared to SOD1 makes it seem more like a story generator ala Rimworld if anything.. which i guess is 2 steps forward, 1 step back for most people. Eventually your people get overpowered, clear out the current map, run out of stuff to do, and then you reroll some new guys to maybe start out on a different map.. again, like Rimworld.

Some people can find that it gets repetitive pretty quickly, but if you're not one those people, you'll absolutely love this game.

EDIT: several years later and i still pop back in from time to time. definitely a quintessential zombie game at this point.
