Other reviews already stated the mechanic gameplay of this game so I'm just gonna sum up my total encounter of quirks and bugs I've found so far in game:

COOP
1. Currently have encountered at least once sudden disappearance of zombies, both on screen and map, though the bug consistency between host and client differ: Sometimes he sees it in his map but not in my map, other time it's vice versa.
2. Server latency can suddenly lag for a bit, sometimes resulting in the client getting kicked out from the host world leaving them to fend of hordes and getting massacred if they didn't manage to get away in time. I can verify that the host experienced that sudden lag the same time as I did in-game so it was most likely not a connection issue.
*EDIT*
3. Well look at that, you can find invisible zombies lurking around where ONLY the host can see it, imagine that when encountering the next invisible plague juggernaut (none so far, too bad).
4. Some achievement are broken as it doesn't register even after doing the said task like Human Contact (play Daybreak coop games with other living person). This is most stressful as this part of the game is the most important (for me) thing!
5. Game have frequently disconnect me when playing on others' world nowadays, that was after the recent 60MB update me think.


SOLO *EDIT*
1. .... eh, it's fun I guess.
2. Trying to win Lethal mode is more down to having enough firepower and luck when it comes to dealing with the Plague Heart (I'm still trying to win at least 1 time, or maybe 4 times just for that damn achievement).


Overall I just hope I won't encounter any game breaking bugs or just literally get screwed by XBOX Live issue like those others that encountered it, that could really change one review to another form somehow *cautious stares to the unknown*

*EDIT*
At this review time the game had been consistently updated to keep the game somewhat fresh, with the introduction of new bounties in each cycles and new difficulty scale setting to tailor to your own taste. Not much can be commented for co-op/multiplayer side of thing since haven't tried to play it with others after my last review update, but overall the game is stable enough to enjoy while it last....

*LATEST EDIT*
So this game has new thing added in every game session called Curveball now, which added additional buff or debuff kind of thing for certain duration that you either can take advantage of or try to avoid as much as possible....

I played many more hours of this on the xbox app back when I had game pass. It may seem like a casual zombie shooter, base builder game, and it is, but it's got complex mechanics in there too that really let this game stand out. 

The huge draw for this game, for me, is the plague heart system or siege system. The map is covered in plague hearts, and if you alert them from killing zombies in their territory or making a lot of noise, they will awaken. Once awoken, they send out infesting hordes to capture sites surrounding them. Their goal is to locate your base, and when found they will start setting up siege infestations at sites surrounding your base. If these particular siege infestations get too severe, (from hordes reaching it and adding to its zombie population) they begin sending siege hordes to attack your base. Watching hordes act this way gives a sense of urgency to act and stop their spread. Destroying the plague hearts stops them spreading altogether in that area. It's a great mechanic, and sets this apart from other games.

Only one major complaint. The base building isn't as in depth as I wish it was, it's a little too simple. But it does force you to make tough decisions on how to allocate the space you have. You can't really personalize your base, you just pick what facilities it has. Which is fine, but I feel if you could personalize the little details and actually build whole sections or even expand your base, it would make the game a lot more enjoyable.

The main game mode doesn't focus on a narrative campaign, just many little side missions to do along the way. But there is a 10 hour long separate campaign mode you can play. I haven't tried it out yet though. There's also a siege defense mode where you just defend against waves of hordes. I haven't tried this yet either so I can't really comment on it.

[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

The Juggernaut Edition breathes new life into the State of Decay 2, offering improved graphics, diverse game modes, and a never-ending zombie survival experience. The absence of a traditional ending makes it hard to pinpoint the time to beat. Estimating playtime is subjective, but a realistic range could be anywhere from 80 to 150 hours for a more casual engagement, 300 to 500 hours for a moderate level of interest, and potentially up to 800 or more hours for those deeply engaged in the game. The duration will vary based on individual preferences and how compelling players find the overall experience.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

One of the standout features is its focus on community building and resource management. Players establish and maintain a base, recruit survivors, and ensure the survival of their community in the face of the relentless zombie hordes. The game seamlessly blends action, strategy, and simulation, creating an immersive and engaging experience. The heart of the game lies in its dynamic and interconnected systems. Unique skills, traits, and personalities of survivors influence how they contribute to the community. Balancing the needs of the survivors, managing resources such as food, medicine, and ammunition, and making tough decisions when faced with moral dilemmas add complexity to the gameplay. This strategic depth keeps players invested in the fate of their virtual community.

One of the most significant challenges for newcomers is the various types of "super-zombies," including Screamers, Juggernauts, Ferals, and many other massive and challenging zombie adversaries that the players discover and learn about as they get to know the game. Dealing with these hulking monstrosities requires careful planning and a well-equipped group of survivors at higher difficulty levels, adding an extra layer of challenge to the already intense gameplay for those who like a challenge. However, lower difficulty levels and the specific difficulty sliders let the players tailor their experience. The game offers both cooperative and competitive multiplayer modes, allowing players to team up with friends to tackle the challenges of the apocalypse. Cooperative play enhances the game's community-building aspect, while the competitive portion introduces a new dynamic to the survival experience.

[h1][b]Presentation[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

Visually, State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition sees a notable upgrade over the original. Unreal Engine 4 powered enhanced graphics, this modern engine contributes to a more immersive and detailed world. From the run-down buildings to the gruesome zombies, the game's aesthetics capture the grim atmosphere of a world devastated by the undead. The improved lighting and environmental effects also add to the overall visual appeal. Accompanying the improved visuals is an admirable sound design. The groans of zombies, the creaking of abandoned structures, and the occasional distant gunfire create a tense and ominous ambiance. The soundtrack complements the game's mood, punctuating moments of action and providing a fitting backdrop to the desolate landscapes.

However, the engine-specific limitations become apparent while traversing the world. The zombie types are not vast, and the characters you play with and meet look very similar. There's still much variation in what you see in the world and is nothing to worry about. There's a good variety of maps to pick from, with each map boasting unique landscapes and vistas to make things fresh when transferring a community from one map to another or when a specific map becomes monotone. One of these engine limitations is that you can only acquire a single follower to help you with your tasks. Other examples include only a limited number of survivors rendered in the community, with the rest loading in accordingly as you switch between them, the render distance limitations, lengthy loading times, performance stability issues, etc.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

The heart of State of Decay 2 lies in the so-called Standard Zone, providing the ideal community-based gameplay experience. Here, players must navigate the challenges of a zombie-infested open world, managing a group of survivors, establishing a base, and securing resources for the community's survival. In Daybreak mode, players join forces as Red Talon soldiers to defend a facility against waves of increasingly challenging zombies. Daybreak introduces a separate currency, prestige, which players earn and use to unlock valuable items for use in the main game. It's a thrilling departure from the standard community gameplay, offering a focused and intense cooperative challenge that only lasts for a single session without lasting consequences.

Heartland introduces a compelling narrative-driven experience to the State of Decay 2 universe. This mode unfolds in a unique map with distinct characters, providing a more structured storyline. Players embark on a journey to discover the secrets of Trumbull Valley, encountering new challenges and characters along the way. Heartland injects fresh life into the game, offering a different perspective and a more guided narrative for those who crave a story-centric experience. The characters in Heartland have their fundamental backstories and feel like real people compared to less important community members, who are just a number in the community simulation portion of the game. Still, I wouldn't consider this as a proper story mode but it does keep the interest.

[h1][b]Technicalities[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 10/20[/b]

There are quite a few technical quirks with the game. Based on the Unreal Engine 4, performance issues found among other games built with this engine are present here. Whether you installed the game on HDD or SSD, traversal stutter and frame-time hiccups persist. Some maps are more stable than others, and strategically picking a map can significantly improve the stability and fluidity of the game. While UE4 boasts many strengths, the consistent stuttering isn't merely a minor inconvenience but a persistent presence. Fortunately, technologies like G-Sync prove helpful in relieving smaller stutters, but significant ones remain glaringly obvious. With each and every zombie and NPC constantly simulated, and due to the engine's single-threaded nature, the strain on the CPU is super high, making this game one of the most CPU-limited games you'll ever play, as the CPU must keep up with various complex simulations. Expect a lot of FPS fluctuations.

The online gameplay experience is far from seamless and often falls into the realm of frustration. Connectivity issues are evident in the Daybreak mode especially, which becomes a challenging endeavor when played online unless you're the host or in close proximity to the host, as the game's matchmaking doesn't consider the distance between the players, often matchmaking people from various locations on the planet with each other, creating a cluster of super high ping where everyone's flying around, and player inputs get delayed by seconds. Thankfully, this occurrence is rare, but depending on the region, one might have a better or worse experience.

[h1][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 75/100[/b]

State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition - successfully builds upon the foundation laid by its predecessor, offering a refined and compelling gameplay experience. With its complex gameplay mechanics, improved visuals, and the addition of new content and regular updates, Undead Labs has created a game that caters to both fans of the series and newcomers alike. If you're a fan of survival games with a rich blend of action and strategy, the State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is a must-play in the ever-expanding world of post-apocalyptic gaming.

[h1]🧐 My Opinion 🧐[/h1]
I loved the 1st State of Decay because I got drawn into its apocalyptic atmosphere and its relatively straightforward gameplay that was very well-balanced.

SoD2 is bigger, more varied, with better visuals, but it lost a bit of its ancestor appeal. It's still a good adventure, and it's hard to pinpoint exactly what's missing. Maybe it's a bit less oppressive and dark. Maybe it's a bit more mechanical and less organic in the progression and missions. Maybe it pushed too much on the irrealism and it broke my suspension of disbelief.

Thus said, I still had quite a good time with it during my 70 hours.

I did 2 runs and the "Story" addon.

For my 1st run, I picked the difficulty 2 out of 5 ( = "Standard") as recommended by the game for newcomers. I was a bit overwhelmed by the learning curve at 1st, but after ~10 hours, everything became way too easy and I was impatient to beat the map. For example, the "hordes" of zombies often had... 3 zombies in them ! >_<

For my 2nd run, I picked difficulty 3 out 5 ( = "Dread") and despite being still a bit too easy 90% of the time, it puts decent pressure on me, without being too stressful or annoying.

From their description, the levels of difficulty 4 & 5 just looked like horrible chores by making the gameplay very slow and unfun by making the combat too dangerous (and thus you have to avoid it). I've seen some people enjoying it, though, so your mileage may vary. :-)

The main beef I had gameplay-wise was the main goal : you have to destroy all plague hearts on the map to beat it ( = the source of the plague). In difficulty 2, there are already 10 of them, and in 3, there are 13. That made the game feel too repetitive. It'd have been better to have way fewer of them, but made them a bit more difficult & interesting to attack & destroy.

The story mode, called "Heartland", doesn't actually have much of a story, so I was disappointed. However, it offers a few new things and some slightly different gameplay tuning and the ride wasn't bad.

A quick tip : take the cop & the ex-convict for the story mode, as the ex-convict can craft a badass machinegun that will greatly help you to beat the map without being too much of a hassle.

I saved scummed (by copying the files on my HD) to avoid losing my team members. I think this is mandatory because it requires a bit of practice to handle the most dangerous zombies and without reloading it'd mean losing hours of game time for 20 seconds of violent unexpected riping... ;-)

[h1]💖 Pros 💖[/h1]
- Decent variety of small missions (more than in SoD1)
- The special zombies are interesting
- The base construction is straightforward enough but still requires a bit of planning & management
- Each character has a unique ability and you have to plan how to use it, and how to build your team to get the best abilities for your goals
- Quite a decent arsenal, bringing interesting gameplay variations & management
- The game is still actively worked on
- Curveballs : they added that in the last couple of months, and I'd have been quickly bored to death without them ; they are random events, temporarily making the zombies stronger or more dangerous, or even giving you some beneficial effects ; they bring variety in a game that direly needed it

[h1]💀 Cons 💀[/h1]
- Most of the management rules are totally unrealistic and an immersion breaker
- The zombie respawn rate is insane : you can literally looks in a direction, see no one, then look back, then look front again, and get a couple of new zombies ; in most situations, this makes cleaning up a zone totally pointless (except in buildings where the respawn is disabled once you have visited everything -- unrealistic again)
- Your companions are often useless, especially when a zombie is chowing you hard
- Barely any story, even in the story-mode addon
- No difficulty option in the story mode ; overall, it's very close to 3 out of 5, with a few things set on 2 and a few other ones set on 4
- The SOD1 beeping grenade from SoD1 that could blow up 10+ zombies at once is only available at a high cost ; this was likely the most fun thing from SoD1 : you could do great zombie fireworks, while requiring a bit of skill to achieve


[h1]🤔 Technical Notes 🤔[/h1]
I got a lot of framerate issues with the game (it was unstable, or low without the GPU being at 100%), but maybe it was because of the drivers of my Radeon 6800 XT that don't like the Unreal Engine 4.
I also got a bunch of crashes while playing in Fullscreen, so I had to switch to Fullscreen Window.

Review at Patch: Update 34.1 (Original Review at Update 18)
Hours Clocked: 524.2 (Original Review at 164.0 Hours)

I enjoy open world zombie survival games but many feel so similar that having one stand out becomes harder and harder to find. SoD2:JE is one that stands out.

Familiar mechanics like base building, food, water and skill trees make the usual appearance. Unlike similar games, rather than focus on micromanaging such things, you have a daily count of materials you expend. For quick bursts of stamina you can eat snacks, but otherwise food is more of a strategic resource.

This also ties into base building and another mechanic, outposts. Want to up your daily food production? Claim a restaurant and it provides a boost daily. Building your base in predefined slots might make the more creative builder types unhappy, but there is still plenty of customization to tailor your community to your liking and play style.

This ties into another mechanic, leadership. Electing a leader not only provides perks and drives the story forward, but certain leaders have unique improvements to suit the roles of Builder, Sheriff, Warlord and Trader.

As for the members of your community, you can dismiss them, recruit them and most importantly, switch between them. Why would you need to do this? Rather than make you lose time sleeping, or have down time because of injury or infection, you can swap between members of your community. This means not only do you skip downtime, but each member can be built to meet needs.

Some problems with this can be members that are flat out bad (stat wise), trouble makers, and other liabilities. What kind of liabilities? For starters, death is permanent so if one get infected and turns? Yeah, you're going to have to shoot them (mercy kill), exile them, find a cure, or just hope they don't turn. 

As for the main game play, you will find yourself scavenging for loot, completing missions both for yourself and community members, as well as missions from other settlements. Tasks like supply runs, maybe some backstory/lore missions, infestation clearing, etc.

There are lots of ways to go about killing zeds too. From swords to machine guns, there is a weapon to fit every play style. Of course the zeds won't go easy on you, but with several difficulty levels, you can have a cozy Shaun of the Dead game, or a World War Z game where every encounter can get out of hand.

Overall recommendation is that I recommend State of Decay 2:Juggernaut Edition.

Update Comments: Still one of the best Zombie Games out there.

This is one of the games that I most enjoy playing nowadays. I have about 400 hours of gameplay at the moment of this review.

I am still playing it at the time of this review to get 100% achievements as I do enjoy chasing them.

The game is a unique Community Survival game. You can play on very easy mode or VERY HARD, and it can be really hard, even with mods. Some freaks are really challenging.

Even though there is no Steam Workshop (which is a bummer), there are plenty of mods on State of Decay 2 Modding Discord server or through Nexus Mods.

The multiplayer could be better. There is no server hosting, so you join the ongoing community of another player. You can help him to complete missions and by doing so you earn rewards that you receive them when you join back your "world".  It's a single player game with an option of another player joining your match to give you a hand.

Then you'll easily fit in here. The whole random open world setting which pushes your survivors to the limit with the unrelentless dead clawing at your gates with challenging gameplay is very well done. With 5 large maps to explore and conquer, you could easily spend days or weeks in each map building up your community and maxing out your bases before moving on to the next. I really like how you can save your survivors and communities to use them in future playthroughs.

With the latest Curveball update it throws even more random events at you to enjoy with new challenges. Solid melee and gunplay mechanics and mowing down hordes of freaks is always a good time. Alongside the chunky campaign mode (lots of unlocks, achievements, progression etc), you also have 2 other well made gamemodes called Heartland and Daybreak (earn prestige so you can unlock special things in the campaign mode) to spend countless hours on. Also has a great soundtrack and nice modding support!

I wish there were more games like this. Looking forward to State of Decay 3!

Also, just a great game.

Awesome zombie game, big improvement over the first one.

Sound effects and music are awesome, like the first one. The character's voice acting is nice.

Graphics are a great improvement over the first game. The characters, the zombies, the world, everything looks awesome. They added a lot of detail to the buildings, bases, etc. However, the UI was a bit of a letdown. Don't get me wrong, it looks great, but the note book-like UI of the first one was great for immersion.

Gameplay continues to be really fun and engaging as the first one. They improved a lot of the mechanics (like the outposts, survivor skills, bases, etc.), removed some that were annoying (like the influence, limited community inventory, etc.), but also some that were nice (like the special missions to cheer up/calm down the survivors, the world evolving when you weren't playing, etc.). Overall great improvement, a lot of new mechanics, weapons, skills, cars, etc. The new maps, the new bases, the new types of outposts, the plague hearths, the survivor quest lines and leadership, etc. a lot of new and great additions to the game. And the devs keep adding new features (like the curveballs), cosmetics and content with every update, for free!!😁

The main game is similar to the Breakdown (in the first game), sandbox mode where you start with a community and survive, without story but your own, and after that you continue to another map. The campaign is the Heartland mode, where you visit the map from the first game and face a new threat. And the "siege mode" from Lifeline (in the first game), now has its own mode, Daybreak, where you defend a position from many waves of zombies to earn points which you can use to buy equipment and recruit special survivors from this mode in the main game.

The main game is great, with all the different maps and bases, and all the new mechanics, it doesn't feel repetitive like the first one.
The heartland story is great, visiting the map of the first game, learning the fate of some of the old characters was a nice touch. 
The daybreak mode is very challenging and fun. However, once you completed it a bunch of times, it becomes really boring and repetitive. Grinding this mode, for unlocking all the achievements, the equipment and to get points to use it in the main game, gets really tedious.

There are some bugs, nothing game-breaking, some of them are hilarious to experience.

In short, awesome zombie game, I completed it several times, and still keep coming back to play and have fun with every update. 100% recommended.

I pre-ordered this game. So the amount of time on Steam is not even close to how much I have really played it. And I fucking I love it. Saying that, what is this game? 

SoD2 is a sequel to SoD, you don´t have to play the first game, but with the release of DLCs dealing with the zone of the first game (Trumbull County) the experience gets even better if you are a franchise veteran. 

In SoD2, you can control any members of your community of a zombie apocalipse survivors, try to stay alive and, making the world "livable" again. This is represented by the four types of leadership and the Plague Hearts you destroy to make the area less lethal.The leaderships also imply goals, like Trader, Builder, Sherif and Warlord, and they all, in a more or less involved way, deal with other survivor communities that spawn out on the map.

You spend your time collecting resources, improving your base and doing missions/quests, both for your objective (leadership), community members and other communities. Those missions range from collecting items and destroying zombies, to check on state of other communities. THere is plenty to make you busy all the time on this game, even if is a great game to chill. 

Yeah, to chill. While sorrounded by flesh eating (your flesh, mostly) zombies. The pace of the game is great, the music is amazing, the controls are responsible and really fun (and funny) to drive cars. And the game can be frantic as well. The zombies are nothing to laugh at. The special zombies can be extra deadly, and the hostile human communities can be a pain to deal with (but at least on this case, you have to get close for them to start shooting). 

The game is fun and relaxing, and I can´t get enough of it. Can´t wait for SoD3, specially if they go with the same aproach: improving an already good idea, making it more organic, fun and also relaxing, while adding complexity and lore.

- Amazing as it is, the game still receives support and updates, all those years after launch.

This has got to be my favorite zombie survival game. It's relatively open world and gives you the freedom to really do whatever you want. Choices (are you a Rick type leader? or a Negan?), cars (with upgrades), home base (upgrades), lots of guns, melee, zombies...so many zombies. This game is very addictive. The curveball update is very awesome, It adds thrill especially when you encountered the special hearts like black heart. It makes you plan every action you have to make because your character that you are using has only one life, no re spawn. If your character dies, it dies. The plague heart  or the enemy computer is intelligent specially in the hardest difficulty, lethal one (30 plague hearts). You always need to secure your territory or outpost or else it will be captured by the plague and all the benefits from that outpost will be gone. The awakened heart will make siege outpost and it will grow eventually if you did not handle that early on. This siege outpost will bring tons of zombies and it will corner your base. The only way to stop this is to kill the heart that controls it, but wait, if you kill that heart another heart or 2 will be awake and will join forces to siege your base. What if there are 5 plague hearts that are awake? Oh no.!! I will recommend this game to those who love strategical zombie game.  You will love it. Labor of love for the win. HAHA

You can also make the game brutally unfair with infinitely spawning enemies that can hear you from a mile away and eat you for breakfast if that's your cup of tea. I highly suggest the first thing you do is disable curveballs if you are new to the game or trying a higher difficulty. I had my first lethal run ruined by getting a black heart curveball right at the start. Anxiously awaiting the next game from this developer.

I decided to write this review because I felt like that most of the other reviews for this game don't really describe the game itself very well, and I wanted to get more in-depth with that.

Firstly, I must say that there are a lot of negative aspects about this game, but there are also many positive aspects that make this game very unique.

The reason I give this a positive review is solely because I want Micro$oft to think that this game is a success, so they put more effort into State of Decay 3, which, for the love of god, I really need to have a better SoD2!

[h1]Regarding the positives..[/h1]
I really enjoy the perma-death feature of the game, losing a character is always an emotional event of frustration mixed with desparation. Because if you are like me, and play on nightmare or lethal difficutly only, then every charater is sorely needed.

I really enjoy the fact that you can build your characters up, by leveling them and by obtaining different types of skills, if the character doesn't already have a full skill-set, and then specialize each skill, to yet again, be presented 2 - 3 specializations to each base skill that will improve it further, which give bonuses to either the character itself, or abilities to build better infrastructure at your base, or to craft better items.

I really enjoy the looting aspect of the game as well. I'm about 300 hours in, and I still keep finding guns that I've never seen before. The variety of guns is a real treat in this game! On top of that, the game always makes you fight for more resources, you are almost always at the point of needing more of everything. A lot of survival games get very boring after the beginning, because once you have enough meds and ammo, the whole survival suspense just dies off, whereas in this game (at least on higher difficulty), you are always short on ammo. I love the situations where I tell myself "fuck, I only have 15 rounds of ammo, or only 1 painkiller left, I need to make due with what I have".

Building up your base and obtaining outposts is also fun. Playing on higher difficulties especially, there is always a certain balance of each mechanic of the game that has to be maintained (Food, Ammo, Meds, Materials, Fuel, Morale of your group, relations with other groups, gaining Influence (which is your currency), and much more), as well as many types of strategies that you can try to follow to find your own optimal way. And the better you understand how all these mechanics tie into each other, to more you will understand the game itself in order to succeed. Because all it takes, is to neglect one of these aspects, and your group can quickly be doomed and get to the point of no-return.

For example, you awaken too many plague hearts too early, the game sends out too many infesting hoards, which will then attack your base, in an almost tower defense/wave defense type style, without you having enough resources to fight it off, and thus risking it to spiral down into not being able to gather enough recources & maintaining the balance of the mechanics of the game I mentioned above, because you don't have enough resources to begin with.

On top of that, the devs have been supporting the game with free updates that contain more content for years, which is commendable.

All of this honestly makes for great replayability.

[h1]Regarding the negatives..[/h1]
Probably the worst coop you will ever experience in any game out there. Because the person who joins the host, isn't even part of the survivor group itself, no, they have their own "hidden" group of people that doesn't actually exist in the game and is basically safe from any effect of the world.

On top of that, you don't even share the same loot-locker, host and coop partner both have their own private locker, only accessible to them.

And neither do you share the same loot objects, which means, one person may not have anything to loot in a house, and has to stand around watching the other person loot, without being able to help. Which means you have a "host" and you have a person that acts as a "pack-mule", and nothing else.

And if all of that isn't already bad enough, the game also features theatering.. something you might would expect from an early 2000's game. This means that if you get too far away from the host, the game will teleport you to them.. Just unbelievable that they even considered implementing this.

It just ruins every kind of immersion you could possibly have, and simply kills the actual cooperative play.

Sadly, the issues don't end in coop, and there are plenty more in the core game itself.

Meele combat can get very clunky, with your character not reacting properly to your inputs of trying to dodge, or to change direction to swing at another zombie. Often times your character won't even attack the zombie your are facing, or even try to attack one that is behind other zombies that are in front of you, and that your character can't even reach.

Hit detection is an absolute nightmare, the amounts of times I have swung at a zombie without my attack connecting with them, despite my weapon visibly going through their body, is just unreal. It happens VERY frequently, especially when fighting in doorways or other corner- situations.

Something else that happens very frequently is that zombies will just straight up warp onto your back, dealing large amounts of damage. I have had zombies that were on my side or even facing me, who started doing their "grab" animation and suddenly warped on my back.

When driving cars, hoards of zombies will sometimes also spawn right in front of you, literally, just pop-in, with no time to evade them, destroying your car in a way that wasn't your fault whatsoever.

I've even had several occasions where zombies were inside of rocks, with no way to attack them, so they would just yell, and call in endless amounts of zombies from everywhere.

Ladders are broken. Your character will sometimes just walk straight off without even attempting to climb it, and simply injure or straight up die falling. And so many times I have simply been trying to get closer to the edge of a building to get a better shot at the 3 blood-ferals that were about to end my life, when my character just does their stupid animation to jump off the edge when I never even intended to jump off. Just remove the damn "vaulting down" animation from the game and let me freely walk on a roof or raised structure without the fear of the game screwing me over.

The way how zombie spawning works is also lame. They don't naturally re-populate an area that you just cleared by walking in from somewhere, they will straight up spawn back in, so they can absolutely spawn behind you in areas that should be inaccessible.

Being in a car is also quite annoying, it's like you're in this spawning orb that will just spawn zombies within a circle as you go. And you can never just stop to check your map.

Some quests are also bugged. I had a quest where I was supposed to drive a character back to my base, and he just wouldn't get in. He'd rather kill himself in the hoards of zombies that were swarming in, than to get into my car.

Also, don't ever enlist followers. The game won't let you know when they have blood plague, and they will just die without you knowing. Characters are also hell-bent on fighting anything while they follow you, so they will stay and fight and get swallowed by a hoard of 20 zombies rather than to run as you do.

Your NPC group is just braindead as well. I have been mauled to death by a feral right outside my base, while my group was letting me die. I had zombies inside my base that would chase me down and just run past my group members who were doing nothing. Even had to fight off a mission-type zombie attack on my base, while my group members where just inside the buildings doing nothing.

How can a game be so good and unique and so bad at the same time? I do not get it.

This game remains difficult for me to review.  I really, really want to like it there is a lot about this game that is very fun, satisfying, and rewarding.  But at same time there are a lot of little things that just barely miss the mark and as a result I always find myself walking away from the game after a few sessions and not coming back to the same campaign.  I primarily play this game solo and I have a feeling a lot of the things that bug me work a lot better when you run this as a duo or a small group.

I think the biggest thing that irks me is the rate zombies spawn and respawn on the map.  They infest the map rapidly, and respawn way too quickly.  It's great to create a feeling the zombies are always advancing on you and closing in around you, but in terms of the core gameplay loop it makes the game unnecessarily grindy and somewhat limits the playstyles you can run with.  For instance I want to send out a character that's good in combat to sweep out an area, then send in a mule character to haul everything back.  Problem is unless you claim the area as a base or outpost everything repops almost instantly, not only when you try to return with the second character but also when returning with the first character, the roads are all clogged with zombies and plenty of enemies that will wreck your vehicle.  Getting around quickly becomes a real and constant hassle.  Yes, I know there is a difficulty slider that affects the rate zombies spawn but this is a problem on all but the lowest difficulty levels (even on normal they repop too fast).

Likewise missions pop up and expire way too fast given the chore travel in the game is.  And for some reason you lose rep and npcs get mad at you if you don't complete their request that you never agreed to do in the first place.

There's just a lot of little things like this that make the game... well I mean the game is meant to be grindy but these little things make the grind less pleasant than it should be.  Outpost and morale management, hauling things to and from outposts, maintaining vehicles, it's a lot of things that combined keep me from really enjoying the game.

Because honestly the rest of the game is fantastic, there are so many positives to various game mechanics but somehow it just doesn't keep me going for very long.  It just feels like the game's pacing is always a bit off, maybe it's really meant more for coop play than singleplayer.

Not going to tell anyone not to play this game because the hours I've spent have been enjoyable.  At the end of the day though this is a game I'm probably never going to get that deep into (to be clear it's not a difficulty issue it's primarily a pacing issue).

This game really hits home for me as the most unique open world zombie apocalypse game ever. Bravo Undead Labs.

I've put many hours of time into this game (Most from first playing on Xbox) and it keeps me coming back. I love almost every aspect of this game with only having three main gripes with the game. 

THE CONS -

The first being an almost total lack of a cohesive story line. There are many missions (lengthy and short) the game gives you, especially with with the leader missions you do later on in the game being most unique. But these just aren't nearly good enough to pass as good story telling. I will give props to the radio chatter you hear every once in while in game. That at least feels like Undead Labs are building some Lore to their games.

The second being the repetitive missions. It's easy after a while of playing to notice how every mission asks the same tasks of you. Deliver supplies to this enclave. Help find a missing person. Defend a person or an enclave. These missions often lack substance and can be sometimes be quick to complete. This problem stems from my previous complaint of this games lack of story and role thereof being filled with mostly forgettable side (sometimes fetch) missions.

And the third (It's kinda not really a complaint) being my over obsessive pondering on how this game could be improved or expanded upon (Which could also be defined as a positive and I will just touch on it later on as a positive).

Now onto the what I think this game does well.

THE PROS -

The Difficulty. Hear me out when I say this game is very unforgiving. Much like an actual apocalypse should be. 
Perma-death characters, out of control hordes of zombies, scary unique zombie types, blood plague infection, community & base upkeep, Timed missions, and deadly hostile enclaves all contribute to make this game as realistic (I guess with the exception of the unique zombie types) as possible. Plus a nice scaling range of five difficulties with a toggle-able slider allows you to experience your perfect zombie apocalypse.

The Zombies & Combat. While not being perfect, the combat is free flowing and feels great and rewarding. Undead Labs did a great job making zombie encounters realistic with their sight and sound mechanics. Fighting either melee or ranged keeps you on your toes and is probably the most important mechanic you want to master if you want to survive. Every encounter encourages you to play differently and be smart about it. Whether it be killing a hoard of zombies, taking down a juggernaut, or dealing with a hostile enclave; You'll find the combat never bores and always keeps the tension high.

The Cars. By far the most OP asset in the game, cars are the things that have saved my butt more times than I can count while playing. While essentially taking the role of this games quasi fast travel. It is an absolute blast just mowing down zombie hordes with your ungraded apocalypse vehicle. While being a little bit buggy at times, they definitely made driving fairly easy to navigate and appropriately integrated to playing the game.

The Community & Bases. Probably the most unique aspect of this game, managing your community and bases and improving them little by little adds some needed flavor of strategy to State of Decay 2 that just feels right in a zombie apocalypse situation. While being limited in its mechanics, it never the less plays an massive part in surviving, thriving and of course provides a much needed sense of home/relief when you're up against a wasteland of undead.

The Customization. State of Decay 2 allows for a myriad of customization options for your characters, your base, and even having plenty of weapons to play with. For characters it's their traits, skills, and clothing (yes, I know Traits and skill can and will be randomly generated). Although I do admit it would be pretty sick if they added a character creation menu where you could create your own perfect OP character (Name, Traits, Skills, etc.) as an separate experimental option before starting a game. (or even buying the option of it from any given game from your radio for an appropriately expensive influence cost to create). Tangent over. For bases, each map has many unique bases to play on and choose what to build to suit your strategy (I do wish every map had at least two 8+ survivor end game bases however). And having variety of cool unique weapons in a game should go without saying. Gotta show off your swagger. Am I right?

The Free Updates. I am completely baffled that Undead Labs has given State of Decay 2 many updates and still continues to this day. They could have released this game, done some bug patches, added some DLC's, and just reaped the profits from there on out without ever coming back to this game. It is truly a testament of how much Undead Labs cares for this new series they have created as well as the community that continues to support them.

Finally, The Potential. This is where I kind of had a gripe about but understand it takes time to expand everything fundamentally in this game. Undead Labs wants to do this game justice and In a way the State of Decay games are pioneering a new type of sub-genre of survival games that I hope only gets more and more intuitive in every way. I could type out almost endless ideas of how Undead Labs could improve upon the type of zombie apocalypse formula they have created but this review is already pretty long.
 
Before concluding, I wanted to give a quick shout out to the music in this game. It's truly amazing how awesome its sounds. It really fits the the rustic, dreary, and intrepid feeling It adds to the game. 

Overall, I highly enjoy playing State of Decay 2 and give it a strong 8/10. This game won't be for everybody and that's okay. Undead Labs have made something really special with their State of Decay Games and I'm optimistically excited for their third installment of this series. No matter how long it takes.

This game is so close to being exactly what I want. But there are just too many things that leave it as an exercise in frustration.

We got rid of the diverse cast of interesting characters from the first game for a randomly generated list of people incredibly similar. If you could fully customise these people it wouldn't feel so bad, but eh..
Multiplayer is terrible. You are only a guest in someone else's game. You can't build for them, you can't share loot, and worst of all, each storage container in the game is separated and colour coded so only the correct player can loot them. You can't even explore the map individually (like one of you stays at home to defend and one goes out to loot) because you're rubber banded together.
Disappointing over all

2023 Update: After many years I decided to try this game again, and quite frankly it's not any better. You can now customise the clothing of your characters, but nothing else. You cannot design your own character, but you can randomly generate one over and over infinitely, which is basically the same thing but takes longer and is more frustrating.

The reason I quit however was the plague hearts. Dear lord the plague hearts.

I got into a new campaign to see 90% of the map covered in red plague heart goo. I had three radio calls back to back, but didn't pay attention to them as the three (I kid you not) plague hoards that descended on us infected two of my people. We were maybe 8 minutes in? None of us had guns yet.

So how do you cure this? Well you need plague goo dropped from plague zombies. 5 plague goo to be exact, which has a drop rate of about 1 from every 10 - 20 Zombies you kill. I had to kill about 75 zombies to get enough of the cure for my people. Tedious doesn't even begin to cover it

Of course, in that time I'm not helping the neighbours, so they're sending snarky messages about how selfish we are for not dropping everything to sort out whatever issue they're facing is. They left the map due to this apparently. And I've not been searching for food, medical supplies, building materials, fuel or ammo for my own community.

I finally managed to get everybody cured, I even found a vehicle (which was surprisingly difficult for some reason) and then set out to get supplies. The moment I F4ed was after I had literally just dropped off my first bag of medical supplies. I then immediately got a radio message saying we'd just been robbed of our medical supplies.

I was so infuriated by this I instinctively closed my eyes and had to take a breath. I opened them again to see my man getting attacked and infected by a plague zombie which seems to have spawned out of nowhere. Rather than kill another 50 zombies to cure him I decided I'd rather just not play anymore.

There are some very simple fixes that could make this game great. I really don't know who the target demographic is. It's a miserable experience, if they make a third game in the series I won't buy it

It's a great successor. Just as addicting as the first one but this time with a possibility to play with a friend. I also liked the red talon units since that allowed one to get some really really overpowered characters going :) Heartland is pretty bugged. You might end up having to completely restart the progress as the main-quest wont continue.
edit: so i decided that the first review was a bit short and there are a couple of things I'd like to point out: 
- gameplay wise the sod2 is Much better. especially combat is absolutely amazing compared to the first one. dont know how to describe it better than to say that the combat is much more fluid. very enjoyable and what makes out some of the additcting part.
- story-wise it's much worse in my opinion. The main "story" doesnt even really have a story, it's pretty much a sandbox in which you get some things to do but basically it's move to a zone, destroy 18 plague hearts, move on. so that's a huge downgrade. It's not much better in heartland, you do get a story but it just feels worse than sod1. 
- The feeling of urgency is gone. I understand that a lot of people hated that in sod1 but I kinda liked it. In sod2 there is no urgency to do anything. Base defense is ultra easy. You rarely get attacked at all. I think in my 170+ hours and all the playthroughs it happened maybe twice, when i gave granade launcher to the people. 

So to sum everything up: Story part is awful, basically just a sandbox. Gameplay is incredible.
It's a really good zombie apocalypse game, it's worth your time.

This could have been a great exploration/looting/building/survival game but there are too many design issues.
I just give few examples of instances of things I find extremely frustrating.
- Your companions should NEVER be allowed to initiate fight against anything; they are far too dumb for that. They should just fight what is attacking them and what you are already fighting. They are very good at awaking plague hearts, btw.
- In Heartland, when I finally recruited captain Logan, I was happy but this did not last. Indeed, as soon as he was recruited, Logan started running across the country to go to my base. I could not stop him. I eventually went to my base, expecting to find him there. Nobody. I eventually got this laconic message "Captain Logan did not make it". Very frustrating.
- I just abandoned a difficult game, where I was finally starting to control things, thinking that the worst was behind me. Then, playing my leader, I went to a friendly community to sell some stuff. Alas, I clicked on "threaten" instead of trade". Here, there is no confirmation and no way to undo this misclick (in a menu), nor anything visual thing (like red color) to remind you that this option can be devastating. My leader was killed and my only friendly community became hostile. Terrible UI design!
With -obviously currently missing- polishing, this game could be great. But all the (not so) small design issues make it frustrating. Thus, the negative review.

Update 2023-10-08: in only my 3rd or 4th game, i got caught by the Warlord end-game loop bug (which you can read about elsewhere by searching the web). I was honestly tempted to thumbs-down the game over this, mainly for political reasons just cuz MS-owned AAA studios shouldn't be shoveling broke garbage at us and leaving it broke for years on end -- even tho MS themselves have of course done this with their core products forever -- but.....

After actually writing out the criticism (rant :P), and thinking the whole thing through, I realized that because the "best" workaround for the bug basically involves just playing the game more, and getting more prime loot, which is all you are really trying to do anyway, it's relatively forgivable. Still annoying but ... anyway ...

Original review follows.

=--------------=

The most TWD-like of the zombie-survival games I've played. (Though I have not played DayZ.)

You have to maintain your colony in terms of several different kinds of key resources, which, at first will mean scavenging but eventually you can secure some outposts etc. to get daily income of certain resources. You come back from excursions sometimes with fun new toys or new friends, and sometimes with broken toys or dead friends. Until you are well-established, there is no "take" without a decent amount of "give" in terms of effort. You will be on the move constantly, switching between different characters on your team to have adventures, while the ones you just brought back, almost dead, recover.

The driving is very GTA: fairly cartoony and your passengers only have to start the "i'm getting in the car" anim and you are good to haul ass out of there. There's a pretty cool implementation for ORV/ATVs as well. If you try driving your basic hatchback on those "you can't drive here"-style rocks -- you know the kind, that have zero physics "give" -- you will not have good results, but if you use a vehicle more appropriate for that terrain you can cross them better.

Combat is decently fleshed-out, melee, ranged, stealth, traps, throwables, etc. Enemies are the typical zombie-game mix of commons and specials.

Once you complete the relatively sandboxy campaign -- it's ultimately just about killing a number of well-defended targets, so, if you have the equipment and knowhow to do that quickly, you can -- you get to move your survs to Legacy Pool so you can use them to start a new game, or bring them into other games with their existing skills, cool equip, and a powerful new-game buff you get for winning. Note they exist as a real "entity", not just a copied save; i.e. if you move them out of the pool and they die, they're gone for good.

Heartland is an SP expansion and Daybreak is a MP, co-op siege mode where you hold off waves and get cool rewards and unlocks including for the main game.

Great fun overall but there are some gripes... Not showstoppers for me personally -- #1 almost was -- but ymmv.

1) you need xbox for windows login. this almost stopped me, because MS memberships are just this burdensome thing they keep changing ever 2 years and I never use. Finally they go "ok we'll just have windows login to the Net and all your stuff is under that", but I'm old school, and even though of course windows constantly "calls home" while your PC is on, I feel it's invasive to have to [i]personally[/i] log in to MS net every time I use my PC. Again YMMV. But I think the PC Game Pass thing kinda convinced me. Didn't know it existed. Why? Because MS messaging is terrible.

2) SoD1 people don't seem to like that certain missions can only be done by certain survs. It can be aggravating at times but it can also motivate the narrative ... when you send someone back out who has been beaten up and awake for 3 days already just because the mission just popped up and you are a greedy opportunist.

By the way chars do level relatively fast compared to other games. Like, you spend about an hour playing, doing a nice stealth scav run with one of your survs, they will come back with most basic skills maxed and advanced skills well-leveled. This is all good because ... well ... sometimes they die even faster. :P

3) Others have mentioned they don't like that when you play co-op campaign, you are basically playing on the other person's save. Your community doesn't benefit. I'm not even sure if you keep the items your holding. I would presume you do. TBH tho I'm not even sure if you play as "yourself" or one of their survs. In any case I have had plenty of fun in SP and it doesn't concern me.

4) Vehs get stuck a lot. The off-road thing I mentioned earlier is one aspect, but also, if you crash into certain things, you can get pinned and sometimes need another veh to get the first one unstuck. Again, it just motivates the narrative. :) It's frustrating at first but you will probably quickly figure out how to unstick them, out of necessity. :P

5) I'm finding Nightmare kinda overtuned and Lethal can only be worse. I'm new and of course there are still L2P issues but my tactics are decent and it's just not as fun. It would be different if your follower AI scaled up with the difficulty. It does not. They cannot keep themselves alive unless it's just against a few zeds. Roughly how one Redditor put it: "count on them to do the most suicidal thing at any given moment, and you will be OK". Frustrating because, on paper they have the skills and firepower. Just really bad AI coding afa how to engage zeds. If only the NPCs were 1/4 as good as the zeds are, at simply chasing down a target and killing it....

At a point in NM, the game throws 3x freaks at you. Three simultaneous ferals is basically a kill squad, and if you care to stay alive the gameplay loop now changes from fun and accomplishment to a lot of raiding and fleeing. Wipe a horde, do 15s of inventory management -- i.e. healing, rearming, picking all your goodies off the corpses of your former 'mates, fixing/refueling your busted vehs -- and voila another horde will be closing in on you when you look up. There is no sense of really making an incursion and securing an area, even after you have ostensibly done so by killing a bunch of hearts. :|

There's a delicate balance between difficulty/realism/tedium and I'm finding these choices not to my taste. By the way, at this point, the "kill squads" have eaten like 10 of my dudes, and the difficulty did [i]not[/i] ramp back down because I am now "doing not so well". :| 

End-game loop:

1. try to do stuff, but your most competent survivors keep dying cuz the game keeps putting them in OTT situations. (That's right: the game, not you, the player. LMAO.)

2. keep making the remaining [i]survivor[/i]-survivors clean the latrine at the base, to up morale, so they're not sad about the other ppl dying.

10/10 would have maxxed-out Red Talon operators clean latrines again. I mean, out in the field they just die anyway.

I really want to like this game. I created about 5 communities before I realized this game frustrates me more than I enjoy playing it. I did play on Dread difficulty. And I tend to be a little bitch about losing party members in games like this, where they just die forever. I like to save scum and just watch things grow. 

But every time I started a new game I would get about 5 hours in or so and I would have a survivor die. The circumstances in which they would die were very chaotic. Mostly it felt like I could have dealt with the situation better. But it was not fun and very quickly things get out of control.
After about the 5th new game, I just decided I need to roll with the punches better.  I finally continued after a survivor died and I realized Its not that bad losing a single survivor. But a few more days of playing I lose another two survivors in another extremely frustrating situation and I am done playing. 

It was the fucking exploding plague zombie curveballs that did me in. I HATED playing with that modifier. Some of the other ones I played against were annoying as well. But the explosions destroyed my vehicles, would ruin melee combat and quick takedowns, and drain me of my health resources. I would be ambused by ONE plague zombie and everything turned to shit and I somehow lose two survivors and my vehicle.
I did not take the time to see if I could turn them off because I was unable to keep up with the pace of the game. Between missions popping up and expiring, fighting off infestations, making your base feel useful, trading off survivors in the infirmary, constantly navigating inventories and menus, I never felt like I could get organized. Maybe thats just me.
Also, it feels almost impossible to stop anywhere while driving. Even to just look at the map. I know its a zombie game but it feels suffocating. Maybe I should re-think what I want to play, lol.
And FORGET about doing anything during night time. The night is pitch black and with your map being hindered by plague hearts, you can get lost in a second. Flashlights and headlights are also not great.
In combat situations when you are at a disadvantage and on the run, you can also get overwhelmed very quickly. I absolutely suck at this game. But one zombie can fuck your whole plan up. If you lost your vehicle and you need to run back home you had better hope you brought meds and snacks. You will never not run into a zombie which will always bring more. When you turn around to shoot a zombie, there will be another one attacking from the side or rear forcing you to keep running. Attacking and running drains stamina, and once its drained zombies are programmed to ruin you. 

There is a bug that I constantly ran into when searching and interacting at the base where my character would be stuck in a falling animation. It sometimes put my character into the dying animation. 
I accidentally clicked on the, "threaten enclave" button, because I am a dumb ass. But I was instantly swarmed by 3 or 4 people and murdered without a chance. I wish there was more of a buffer between that taking place so I could have felt prepared. Or a, "Are you Sure?" 
From the little I payed attention to about the curve balls, I like the idea. But I feel like It shouldn't be default mechanic, or at least not so early on. Or the option to turn it off, if its no there. But totally and completely FUCK the exploding plagues. 

I was not satisfied with how much progress It felt like I was able to make compared to how much I would lose due to my mistakes or unfair mechanics. The micromanagement felt shallow and inventory management can be a pain. Most of the times I would leave to scavenge or do a mission, I would make very slim progress before something went awry and I would have to return. The Immersion was not great and customization isnt really here. You can kinda immerse yourself if you really try. I really like the ability to enter almost any house. the variety of loot actually felt pretty decent at least early on. And I appreciate the different trade able goods. Even without any pictures. 
Melee Combat was good enough. It felt good, but neglected. And i bet with more love it could be the best thing about this game and that isnt a knock on any other part of this game. I just wanted more from it, and I was doing it more than anything else. 


This game is still really cool but I am just unable to enjoy it the way I want to, is all. I respect the developers for making this real and still working on it. These mechanics and ideas are pretty solid and I think with more time It would make for the ultimate game. I feel sad to uninstall this game and am mixed on whether or not I would recommend.
I will say this.. I think it would be much more fun playing with friends. And I would be more willing to play through these frustrations if I were. But unfortunately I have no friends to speak on this.
I basically want the State of Decay that my mind has created, Thanks to you guys.

Pros

Cons
⦁ Sometimes the voices are so loud. The character voices become annoying after a while. It sounds artificial sometimes.  
⦁ The ai is a little jank sometimes. 
⦁ Very dark. Needed to raise gamma a little bit. 
⦁ Inventory management is fun, but once you have too many items it just sits there in your inventory. 
⦁The game sometimes feels like chore simulator after you finish your first play through. How many lands can you colonize from the Zomboids until the game becomes boring?

Conclusion: 8/10. If you have nothing else to play this game is for you.

There is some fun to have with it for a while, however the game makes all it can to stop the fun all the time, making you go back and forth around the map wasting time most of the time. 

* Sometimes the game keeps throwing missions at you while in the middle of a mission and another one will come up, sometimes an urgent one, and then another...
* When in the middle of driving or fighting dialog/radio messages will come up and if you miss it there is no log to read it again.
* Finding survivors with the skills you need is a pain in the proverbial and gets tiring fast.
* Killing zombies in a game full of them is a waste of time once a character has had its progression completed, there is no point to killing zombies other than the freaks who give you a bit of influence. One would think that in a zombie game the devs would make killing zombies fun...
* Driving around can be fun at times, however cars break easily both by hitting zombies and the excessive amount of road obstacles which seem placed to stop you from having fun and to force you off-road, which can be fun except that the poor physics in the game can lead to the car breaking for hit-box nonsense reasons. To have more resistant cars you need a survivor with knowledge of Mechanics, and an auto shop workshop... things that after completing two maps I haven't been able to find/produce.
* The game gets very repetitive after a while and there is no real purpose after finishing a map other than being a completionist.

State of Decay 2 is a fun zombie survival game. There's a good amount of content (it'll probably take you around 30-40 hours to finish your first playthrough) and, for those who like to be challenged, there is good replay value via increasing the difficulty and starting again. It still has some bugs (mostly minor and I haven't personally encountered any game-breaking ones) but has fixed a lot of the issues that were present in the first State of Decay.

I'll be blunt. This is not some epic RPG that will enthrall you in its story. It's not purely about surviving hordes and you generally won't have enough resources to make it purely an action game. However, this is one of the most fun games in its genre and offers plenty of stuff to do so that you'll get your money's worth. Honestly, the only glaring flaw to this game is that the multiplayer sucks (there are plenty of threads discussing it so I won't elaborate here - but it's safe to say that State of Decay 2 is intended to be a single player game).

It's a good game and I definitely recommend it if you enjoy zombie survival games. Definitely snatch it up if it goes on sale (I bought the Juggernaut Edition for $8).
I just saw this game and i buy it and giver me what i expected i recommend this game to anyone playing Zombie game

I played through a campaign on Xbox Game Pass couple years ago and picked up the game on Steam now. Linking accounts didn't carry save progress or legacy pool for me, only achievements. SoD2 is one of the best zombie survival games I've played and by the looks of things, the Juggernaut edition is even better.

The multiplayer experience is also better than some reviews, especially the very short ones, make it sound like. You can still develop character skills, get loot and deposit them to your own supply locker, use basic base facilities like crafting and repairs and trade with enclaves. Your entire community is essentially an off-screen guest in your host's campaign, but you need to return to your own campaign to fully manage recovery of survivors and you can only gain influence, not standing, for guesting. In short, you can do almost everything you'd do in your own campaign and all players get a bit more out of the world with easier takedowns and more loot per location. I can't really see it as anything other than win-win, but if you're expecting to form a joint community with another player, that's not really possible, although you could still share valuable resources like blood samples by hopping between campaigns.

The only actual obstacle we experienced in multiplayer so far was having to spend some time to investigate and disable VPN to make multiplayer sessions possible. No other errors here. Most users experiencing them probably have something blocking the connection on their end instead of the service being actually bad.

This game is an absolute pleasure to play.  I only got it when I found out that the developers, despite working on a sequel, are still making updates and constantly adding to the game.  Just that convinced me to give it a try, and just 1 hour in I was hooked.  It's challenging, but no overly much, and it's the near perfect blend of GTA Zombies and Survival Adventuring that I was looking for.  

The survival aspect is not nearly as punishing as other survival games I've played, and I'd classify it as "having survival elements" to it rather than a full on survival game.  The base building is pretty simple, and the UI is very convenient and some would say rigid, but it's great if you don't want constructing a homestead to be the main time sink in your game.  

I love the foraging aspect, and while the combat takes a little getting used to, there's always something to do and always a need to venture out into the apocalypse to gather needed materials.  

I was warned that DIE is present in the game, and it is.  Most of the Str8 YT Mayals are zombified, apparently.  All that's left are Stronk Whamen o' Colour and their DIE Nu-Mayal Purse Puppies, and everyone is Alphabet.  Seems every 3rd storyline is either uniting or avenging an Alphabet couple.  But as far as affecting the actual gameplay, it doesn't very much.  Sure, given that the Type B's outnumber the Type A's almost 5 to 1, it'd be nice if there was some advantage or disadvantage to playing either, but that would be ACTUAL Diversity, and of course we can't have that.  

But in the day to day actual playing, IMO it's tolerable, and doesn't detract too much from the relaxing experience that is the rest of the game.  

I recommend picking this up on sale if you can, and I'm now looking forward to the sequel.  However, if you're one of those people who simply has had enough of the ESG virus infecting your escapism, well, I'm sorry to say that this game is just as infected as the world in the game.  I'd offer that the game is still fun to play, but there's literally no escape from THE MESSAGE.
Tig Ol' Bitties.

The multiplayer aspect is BAD in so many ways.
Gameplay consists of busywork for OTHER survivor groups who apparently seem to fail miserably at the most basic tasks to keep themselves alive, and god forbid you don't play good samaritan, as they'll pack their shit up and leave, only to be replaced by another group who'll immediately start radio-spamming you for handouts as well.

The control-scheme for keyboard and mouse is jank at best, default binding your dodge (C) next to V, that'll open your map for some reason, preferably mid-combat.
Aiming is also fiddly with X (or was it Z???) being your Zoom for guns with scopes but the crosshair is so chunky and phat, that you'll be relying on "Gunslinger" letting you aim-lock with SPACE.

It's an absolute mess.

"Curveballs" added in the newest update doesnt add much other than letterboxes constantly popping up on your screen while you're playing, informing you that some random person is stealing your stuff, or that some zombies now explode on death.
These popup boxes will keep nagging you with random intervals.

It's jank, and hard to find fun without friends.

Why don't I recommend? Easy, woke garbage. 

Make the hillbillies gay in the first game? Hysterical
Make the hillbillies also have an obviously not mixed daughter? Now you're just making stuff up lol.

Mexicans everywhere!? Realistic. Especially when I use to live in places like these areas.
African Americans everywhere? In this part of the country? Not so realistic. You'd be hard pressed to find more than 1-5 families in these areas IRL.

"Blah, blah, blah socialism is good" from random companions? Disgusting
BLM crap? No thanks. I don't support terrorist thieves. 
"Punched Nazis" trait? rofl
Of all the hundreds of traits they put into the game, not one single trait that has anything to do with faith or spirituality. No Bibles to find. No perks or facilitates related to worship or prayer. 

And a lot more than I care to mention of other nonsense and woke PC garbage. But seriously, if you're going for equality, how is this so obviously skewed towards leftist ideology? You'll fill the game with political current day nonsense but you won't add in things that damage your fragile world perspectives? 

Aside from that there are a lot more they could have and should have been done with this game. But here are some more issues...

Brought back Trumbull Valley in a whole new version of the game? Heartland was great! Then you guys retcon Heartland events by blowing everyone up off screen? You guys should work for Disney! The end of Heartland and the events after it was made to feel so pointless, even before you retconed the whole thing. 

Started the game out in the tutorial of being able to have relationships with your fellow survivors but it's nothing more than RP in your head after the tutorial. Went with the boyfriend and girlfriend starters and it never goes further than that. Aside from a few remarks around base like "hey sexy!" that's it. Missed opportunity to setup RP related events and traits. 

Daybreak. Oh, Daybreak. Dubbed one of the worst DLC's of all time by many for good reason. 1 map you'll have to play a lot more than you would like to, to unlock things you're not quite sure are worth the trouble. Between people sabotaging your match, dropping out, being generally incompetent, possibly mentally challenged, and the overwhelming amount of zombs the game throws at you... you'll be grinding those points a long time. 

Game itself is great. They have come out with a lot of free updates and that's one of the best things. But they want to keep pushing "the message" in with the game and it makes the game lesser for it. The 90%-95% of us that play the game and don't have anything to do with that stuff, don't want it in our game. Thankfully mods exists to remedy this problem. Just hope this doesn't continue on to the next chapter of this franchise.

It's been many years since the release of SoD2, and over that time it's received many patches, though the cadence has now slowed as the team shifts to working on SoD3. In that time they've finally sorted out a great many problems, improved the core gameplay loop, and produced an enjoyable game.

The game has a very strong gameplay loop: Start by managing a small cadre of survivors in finding shelter, collecting small amounts of supplies, and building better facilities. Recruit additional survivors, move to a new location, expand your loop with better resources.

To deal with the fatigue of "Everywhere you go is just killing zombies," SoD2 introduces the notion of Plague Hearts—epicenters of zombie activity that make zombies infectious and cause them to congregate in hordes. You must go into infected buildings to defeat Plague Hearts, and without destroying them, parts of the map remain unsafe, so you are forced to leave your base and collect the weapons necessary for these dangerous encounters. Fighting a plague heart also agitates zombies in the area, so you must be ready to finish the job. This prevents the "bunker" mentality of just hunkering down in your safe base, and makes you go interact with the rest of the world.

The use of leader roles gives you avenues for pursuing specific kinds of play, depending on whether you want to prosper through trade, reconstruction, collaboration, or domination. Finishing a game and making a successful survival community lets you start with benefits in your next game, so you're encouraged to keep playing new games. Since you can now keep a stable of survivors and call them to join your community, you now have ways to get your best survivors back into play and fill specific gaps in your skill set, though you can always recruit outsiders too.

There are still a few lingering bugs. Infected characters sometimes suddenly die long before their infection timer elapses. Geometry holes provide places where vehicles become stuck and then, due to a physics error, become destroyed, forcing you out on foot or possibly even injuring or killing your characters. Even so, multiplayer is stable, whether you're doing wave defense against zombies or dropping in on a friend's encampment to lend a hand (or steal their stuff).

Built on the UE4 engine, SoD2 has decent graphics, and the voice work is fun and sometimes charming. Replayability is high, especially as you pursue special weapons and items through the game's special Bounty Broker system, which challenges you to complete certain tasks for rewards.

Of specific note, level design on the maps for this game is extremely good. The levels generate a sense of flow, giving you a clear idea of the directions that you want to explore and go, but also reward going off the beaten path. Environmental messaging creates choke points or trains you to use roads and to go around obstacles in an intuitive way that never requires pop-ups or intrusive UI; it's all tutorialized through the gameplay. The game rewards taking prominent landmarks and discovering important sites, but also challenges you to carefully choose where to set down roots as you'll slowly exhaust resources in your area. This creates a constant pressure for you to be on the move and to upgrade to new places, which keeps you active instead of waiting for the next day to start at your home base.

Overall, the game experience has become a net positive, and I enjoy this game even years after its initial release.

Interesting and unique game that's worth a play. If you expected co-op you'll be disappointed but as far as aingle-player players are concerned it's pretty interesting. Learning the game doesn't take long and at any point you can switch the difficulty of a specific category such as survivability, limiting the amount of resources you can find or you can choose community dfficulty which makes your allies consume more resources requiring you to scavenge more or keep a small group together.

One thing that irks me is the mobilie-like wait times where you have to wait said time while an item is crafted or a building contructed.

The game story-wise is very lacking and drops off almost instantly. This game is mostly to be taken as a survival sandbox rather than an adventure story.


Should also add that the item/storage system, including swapping items between characters, should be greatly improved. So, I really like this game and will give it a definite thumbs up and recommend it.  I like the graphics, the survival aspect (which has a ton of depth to it, especially the base and community building).  The action is pretty good too.  The variety of undead is pretty good and challenging.  It's fun to just roam around and explore.  The game can be a hair buggy...but in it's current state...I think it's pretty rare.  Overall a very enjoyable game.

That being said, I'd definitely like to see some changes on State of Decay 3 though.  Number one is no more curveballs that DON'T GO AWAY.  The Black Heart curveball sucks.  For a casual gamer, it's overly difficult, even on the lowest settings.  I'm kinda torn on the perma death things.  It ads a ton of tension to the game....but if you make just one stupid mistake, it could cost you a character that you really love.  The next thing I'd change is making it easier to upgrade your base.  After 35 hours of playing, I still have yet to get a survivor that can do construction.  Construction is super important to base building.  I would also love to see actual scopes on the weapons that work.  Some weapons come with scopes, but you can't actually see the scope view.  Very annoying.  

There are some other niggling problems here and there, but again, I do recommend the game to anyone who likes survival horror.
