Updated Review:

When I first played SoD2 a little over a year ago, I was [b]not[/b] impressed. The game was buggy and unstable, I was plagued with XBox login errors, and the overall game just wasn't that great. Essentially, it was a step down from SoD1 but with better graphics.

Fast forward to 2023, and I decided to dust it off and try it again (I'm a sucker for Zombie killing). I'm glad I decided to give it another try, because it feels so much better. The game didn't crash on loading, my screen wasn't spammed with XBox login errors, and it feels like it is running much smoother. While the game itself does get repetitive, there is now enough content to keep me busy while usually having fun. The "Curveball" update was a nice touch and the expanded areas are fun to experience.

It's taken 34 Patches, but I'd say it's a 7 or 8 out of 10 and I'm glad to change my review to "recommend."

I have hundreds of hours in this game when I bought it on Microsoft's Store. Just bought it again on Steam! It's a really fun sandbox with tons of different ways to build out your bases. It's so much fun trying to beat harder difficulty levels too to get perks to start new games with.

It's a different take in survival simulation. It only focuses on community building, resource collection and resource management. From a strategy perspective, this felt more similar to Frostpunk put on a much smaller scale. I think this game is a blend between full strategy building and survival simulation games. Add zombies to the mix and you have something to do in between your main task "community survival". I did enjoy the game. More modes and maps would make this game fun.

This is a fun, enjoyable game. Weird way to start a negative review, I know. The experience is enjoyable, and with the feature updates they've done since release, there's really quite a bit to do and it's quite enjoyable. I have hundreds of hours into this game, and will likely put in hundreds more.

So why the Do Not Recommend? Simple. My 12 hour Dread community that will no longer load. This is a known issue that has been happening since release, you can find various forum posts about it since the game was brand new. I've tried all the troubleshooting, using the community as a client in a multiplayer game, verifying Steam files, even downloading the Community Editor and removing each of my survivors in turn. It still won't load. This is an AAA game by an AAA developer which is still listed for an AAA price, and a lost save game represents potentially hundreds of hours of work lost, so this is completely unacceptable and utterly poisons my ability to recommend the game. Yes, you'll have a good time, but that can be taken away at any time, leaving you with nothing. The developers are aware but haven't fixed it because they don't respect the consumer or their time and I cannot in good faith recommend giving them money.

I know I'm screaming against the void, I know that the game has incredibly positive reviews, but if even one person sees this and doesn't buy it will have been worth it. We need to hold developers accountable for their software actually functioning on the most basic of levels.

This game scratched an itch I knew I had, but was never able to satisfy.

If you play on the right difficulty setting for you, the game is tense and nerve wrecking, but at the same time an absolute blast to play. You can at the same time be sneaking through the dark with a flashlight, scrounging for medicine to save one of your group members from perma-death by infection, and also toss a zombie over your shoulder and flatten it's head with a sledgehammer.

And now that I've done almost all there is to do in the game, I just hope I can find something like this again. 😅

I enjoyed State of Decay one. I saw State of Decay 2 was on sale for a decent sale price and figured why not. The first few hours were entertaining gathering the materials, but after a while the game mechanic felt bland. In short, some may find this game very fun while some may get bored after a few hours.

The [b]gameplay and controls[/b] are similar to the first. The movement of the characters seem a little more fluid than the first, but there isn't much added in regards to content after that. The premise allows the player to choose between two partners. They start in a mini-intro mission that introduces the player slowly to the game. Eventually, the player establishes a base and the fun increases. The menus, options, and potential to build a community can be a little overwhelming at first, but over the time the player familiarises themselves with the necessities to keep things going. There are a decent amount of variation to the missions which include contacting new neighbours, helping them, doing bounties, taking out zombie hot spots (sort of to clear areas to claim them), and random missions that will come and go. Again, all are fun for a short time, then everything sort of feels repetitive after the fact. The fighting and shooting portion is fun, and the player can do some "finisher" sort of actions. This area does feel limited as only one zombie at a time can be attacked.

Players are allowed to grow their communities by adding almost any NPC into their fold. Some NPCs will come with a set of skills. In order to acquire new skills the player has to set out in the world to explore and find books in order to gain new skills or knowledge. This part is cool which allows for greater base upgrade. It comes to a point though where a decent amount of variation is needed for the player to achieve any sort of progress or upgrades within the base. The open world exploration is fun and feels like there is always something to check out. The difficulty (even on easy) can get tricky and will provide players with a challenge. The multiplayer is certainly a cool feature, but feels quite limited. Depending on who is hosting will determine who gets progress for their community. Some players on the reviews didn't seem to like this.

The [b]visuals and graphics[/b] are a slight upgrade from the previous game. Everything that needs to be there is there, but not much more has been added. The variation in the enemies is certainly cool and their FXs are quite decent (especially the juggernaut). I felt like this area of the game is mediocre at best. The [b]sounds and music[/b] are also okay. Again, not much to go on about here either than everything that is required to be included is there.

Overall, not a bad game, not a great game. In my personal opinion I don't feel like I could recommend this game. I got bored of it pretty quickly, even with the multiplayer feature and ability to travel to different maps. The driving mechanism hasn't improved at all since the first - which is sort of key to getting around the map. Don't think you'll be climbing any hills. The game seems limited in its attempt to keep players engaged, and once the fun of exploring, gathering, and base building is done - doesn't seem like there is much purpose to keep playing. If this appeals to you, especially on sale, I'd say go for it. Otherwise, I'd say save your money.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I'll keep this short because there's already plenty of amazing reviews covering everything that really needs to be talked about, so I'll just stick to why I love the game, and why I think it's worth giving it a shot, and what to expect in terms of multiplayer and singleplay.

The game is definitely built to be primarily a single-player focused game with the ability to have multiplayer assistance. 

Basically if you plan to play with a friend, it works like this; You have your own world with your own populated community of survivors. If you wish to join a friend you join their world with their community as one of your survivors from your community. Meaning you bring everything with you on that survivor you choose to play as in their world. You are then tethered to the host player Via a large AoE vicinity. The purpose of multiplayer seems to be there to help the hosts community, not to be there to build one with them. Once your character is hurt or needs rest you have to go back to your world and switch character to then rejoin them. 

It's not all bad as you still have full access to the game with your host, it's just an unnecessary hindrance to the player having to play that way, the games multiplayer would be much better if you could build a community with your friend, starting the world together, but it's still worth giving it a shot as long as you are aware of these things. It's still a very fun game to chill and play with a friend. 

I hope SoD 3's multiplayer will be more like we always wanted

If there was a neutral option I would pick that instead, but as I am forced to make a choice I will be choosing negative as I am leaning slightly more in that direction.

Now firstly I want to say that despite this games many flaws, I do still find it enjoyable and if you like the idea of a zombie open world sandbox then this game is probably worth picking up when its on sale.

Now as to why this review is negative.

BUGS! So many bugs, game froze me out of controls when I tried to access vehicle storage, I have encountered countless minor bugs from the controls locking up in certain situations to my set way-point deciding to move itself, certain weapons seem to bug out when equipped with mods, there are countless others.
I spent a little time looking around the forums and it seems that a lot of these bugs have been there for a long time, and the developer just doesn't bother to address them, instead opting to focus on minor content updates.

Requires you to login through an Xbox live account in order to play in single player. 

Is slightly WOKE. Is a small and subtle thing but in a country where something like 60% of the population is white people the majority of survivors seem to be Black, Asian or Hispanic. Makes me wonder if the zombies in this game prefer to eat white people, does that make them racist zombies for excluding minorities from their dinner menu? Or were they eating the "junk food" first and saving the good stuff for last?
Aside from that, out of all the tutorial characters, there is only one white male, who just so happens to be written in as the good for nothing friend that always needs bailing out and will probably be the guy to get you all killed. He is also the only character written in a negative way, Kinda feels a little discriminating against the white men with that one. Thankfully other than that i have not noticed anything else.

Lastly, there are a lot of things in this game that will make you question the general competence of your community of survivors as well as the development team, The majority of unique outposts (landmarks) are totally garbage and offer only negligible benefits, one of them (provides power) is actually rendered obsolete by the builder legacy boon (free power and water) which makes every other legacy boon kinda look like garbage by comparison, for some reason adding one additional bed to your bedrooms causes your bedroom to have a daily materials upkeep cost, some of the bases that have built in defence towers have them set up facing the least useful direction, most bases have buildings that the survivors simply can't utilise in any way such as the farm on one of the maps which has a building half full of junk and a few beds set up, beds which your survivors simply can't use for whatever reason, and instead of clearing out this building to make more sleeping space (or anything really) you have to cram more beds into the other identical building that is being used as a sleep-space which makes everyone unhappy because of the cramped sleeping conditions.
Most, if not all bases also have a whole bunch of unused outdoor space that is either empty or home to useless garbage that takes up valuable space that your survivors can't clear or make use of because reasons?. Cannot prepare feasts or make coffee without having a survivor that has a perquisite skill.
Yeah, there are a lot of things that will make you scratch your head in bewilderment while playing this game.

I could go on, probably all day, but if you are reading this, you should get the idea already.
You spend so much time and effort on a community and then out of nowhere something happens to causing the game to crash every time you enter that particular community.

[B] State of Decay 2[/b] is the sequel to SOD yose and it is a huge disappointment to someone who played the first game such as myself.

- Strong sense of DÉJÀ VU

It's not bad. There are some problems with it though, and it's just a bit of a frustrating experience for a few reasons.

I just now put the game down for good (I think), because I did a mission not knowing what to expect and my newest follower, whom I recruited in the last mission, was killed by a plague juggernaut. I know plague versions are more powerful than their normal iterations, but with 2 followers in tow, I must have gone through 60 rounds of shotgun shells and .357 magnum all in the dome, and he still didn't go down. He grabbed one of my followers and since I was exhausted, I couldn't save her. The follower that I JUST recruited. And since the game does the Dark Souls thing, you can't savescum.

Now I get the design philosophy of constant saving, but when some really unfortunate shit like this happens, maybe I want to savescum. But I can't, so I just lost a follower who really rejuvenated my interest in continuing the run. And so I think I'm just kinda done. That's unfortunate, but I guess I can always do another run in a different location. It is a fun gameplay loop. And I should mention that without plague versions of special zombies, you're very unlikely to ever lose a follower, especially to the blood plague.

That actually brings me to the next point: destroying plague hearts is actually quite easy. It's fun, too - which is good, but the challenge really isn't there unless you royally screw up. I lost a follower because when I was attacking a plague heart, I stopped to attack the zombies that began to swarm us. This is a critical mistake. All you have to do is bring 2-3 explosives to the plague heart and throw them in sequence, and that brings it down 80% or so. A few more rounds from a shotgun or whatever, and it's destroyed. But the important thing is, it destroys all zombies in the immediate area.

You might think this creates some tense situations where the swarming zombies are a major obstacle in your way, making it difficult to destroy the plague heart. But no, not really. It takes less than 10 seconds to destroy a plague heart with explosive. And you can do it this way every time. There's not, like, different versions of plague hearts or anything.

So the game is in the weird space where it's sort of hardcore, in the sense that you can lose followers permanently, but the overwhelming majority of the time it's a distant threat. Which is fine, really. Like I said, I would prefer if they gave you the option to savescum. Like maybe you can savescum but you have to make some kind of sacrifice of resources or something like that. I don't know, but losing my follower immediately after recruiting them because of a canon event where I had to battle a plague juggernaut was extremely frustrating.

But frustrations aside, the game is a good timekiller. You'll typically be doing the same kind of missions over and over and unless you increase the difficulty on the slider, you won't have too difficult of a time amassing resources and whatnot. Vehicles are also pretty easy to continually maintain once you get your base running.

Another potential flaw: I personally don't see the difference in effectiveness between melee weapons. It's easy enough to get your melee combat skill up, and the superheavy weapons don't seem much more effective than the normal or even light ones.

The variety of guns and detail put into their descriptions is really good.

Overall, this is a good game. I would say it's worth 10 bucks or less. If it's more than that, just wait for the sequel.

[h1] SoD2 is a low stress sandbox survival game. [/h1]
I say low stress mainly for the lack of hunger and dehydration elements. I don't even think I saw a different weather pattern other than sunshine and darkness. (Go play DayZ if you want to die from the cold weather in the first ten minutes. I play that too) This game allows players to focus on community crafting, leader building, and zombie smashing. And it's fun. If you crank up the difficulty though this game gets tough!

[b] GRAPHICALLY [/b] the visuals are top-notch. The distant scenery is well put together. The lighting effects as the sun rises and sets will sometimes give me pause. I don't have a high end tower anymore (i5-6600, NVIDIA 1660 Ti) but I can run all the graphics on ultra with no performance issues.

Actual [b] GAMEPLAY [/b] is seamless. You'll be driving through the entire map using various vehicles left on the road usually in need of fuel or repair. Not one loading screen or any wait times no matter how fast you go. A zed horde in your way is no match for an up-armored vehicle barreling down the road. A satisfying squish awaits the zombie in your way. Be careful as each zombie that paints your car red will damage it slightly. 

[b] CHARACTER [/b] development is worth the effort. Each settler has four core stats that upgrade with the respected performance. Don't want to FIGHT, then your fighting skill stays low. CARDIO is the easiest to build as you'll want to run everywhere anyway. With each settler you recruit, there are hidden traits that you discover. Some good, some disruptive. Populating the community you like is [i] VERY [/i] possible. Don't like how this guy turns out? Exile him! Finally guided that leader to greatness? Take them to the next map to start a new community with the benefits they offer.

[b] MISSIONS [/b] will pop up as you play. Some are rescuing a trapped survivor that may join your community. Some are related to your community leader's leadership focus. Do, or do not the missions. They will expire if neglected. The missions won't just pile up like a long to do list. There is a core mission and that's [spoiler] to rid the map of the plague cores that cause the zombies to remain. [/spoiler] 

[b] COMBAT [/b] will vary based on your playstyle. Wild gunplay will suffer due to a lack of ammo or the durability of firearms. Ammo is craftable and with the right settler in your community you can make what you need. Weapons are repairable at a cost. Melee weapons suffer the same durability issues but are much more quiet with their use. Stealth is effective at any stage of the game and the stealth kill weapons do not degrade. Animations are fun to watch but a lengthy tackle and smash can be interrupted by a nearby attacker. So many ways to kill zombies with so many weapons to choose from make it well worth the scavenger hunting.

[i] At the time of this review I only have been playing one map. I started over a few times once I got a hang of how the game plays. [/i]

Gather 'round, young'uns!

Ol' Gramps has got a tale to spin for ya.

I remember the time when games were just a few pixels on the screen, but let me tell ya 'bout this "State of Decay 2" thingamajig.

Back in my day, we didn't have none of them fancy-schmancy graphics, but lemme tell ya, this game sure looks purdy.

The world's gone to the dogs, with them zombies runnin' around.
Now, I've seen my fair share of critters in my time, but these brain-eaters are somethin' else!

Here's a funny story: One day, I sent young Billy out to scavenge some supplies.
The boy's quicker than a rabbit in heat, but he ain't the sharpest tool in the shed, if ya catch my drift.

He comes back, all excited-like, saying he found some "gourmet food".
Imagine my surprise when he pulls out a can of cat food!
Called it "zombie apocalypse delicacy"!

I told him, "Billy, that ain't for humans!"

But ya know what? With a sprinkle of salt, it ain't half bad!

Anyhow, back to this game.

If ya like bossin' folks around, buildin' bases and fendin' off them zombies, this here is the game for you.

But lemme warn ya – don’t get too attached to your survivors.
It's heartbreakin' when one of 'em becomes zombie chow.

And for Pete's sake, don't send 'em out to get food alone.
You might just end up with a pantry full of cat chow!

In conclusion, "State of Decay 2" gets two thumbs up out of three from ol' Gramps here.

Woulda been three, but I lost a thumb in a, uh, "scavenging accident".

Anywho, happy zombie huntin' and remember: cat food ain't that bad with a bit of ketchup!

while i enjoy that this company is still supporting the game with new content, wish they would do the same with fixing bugs 

bugs that have been in the game since launch have not been adressed at all and instead they add even more bugs  with each new update, which most of them will get fixed at some point but not the ones that ruin this game.

bugs that have never been fixed in the game for years:

-molotov or any fire explosives will explode in mid air and burn you instead of the zombies. this happen because is like you are hitting a invisible wall.  

-barely touching objects with your car will make  your car get stuck and explode.  this ruin your experience in the hardest difficulty 

-if you run while looting in buildings your character will get stuck in a jumping animation. this again ruin your experience when you are in the middle of running from a horde and get you killed in the hardest difficulty.

-checking your inventory will sometimes make your character spin in circles. you can quickly fix this by jumping, however in the middle of fighting a horde and you are trying to switch between weapons can get you killed because of this bug in lethal mode.

-the latest update (curveball update ) broke the  story missions in trumbull valley.   you load the game and the missions will not happen or they are broken, with the npc spawning in their base or in your base instead of the place that the mission take place. which will count as a instant mission failed because the game think you are running away from the mission area.

-not being able to call traders  or assist from your enclaves.  all this can be fixed with closing the game and reload your save though.

-game constantly crashing. this one i dont know what is the trigger, it can be anything between driving around,  fighting too many zombies or just destroying a plague heart make the game crash.

in the current state of the game i cant recommend this game, is a huge mess  and again, i love that the game is still getting  support, but come on guys... fix the bugs please.

[olist]

I had fun, but I just wish the game was overall better and more diverse, maybe a more fleshed out base building aspect. I can ignore the bugs and the simplistic story, but it all gets old pretty quick.

Honestly this game is pretty sick. I love how you can customize the difficulty of your community, of the map, and of the zombies all separately. You can't carry much stuff at once and ammo is pretty scarce. Like, you can find plenty of ammo but if you wanna use guns, you run through it fairly quickly. My only issue is the carrying capacity is pretty small, but its understandable as its trying to be somewhat realistic which is totally reasonable. You can't sleep through the night though, that kinda sucks. You can't sleep away any time at all actually. For some reason the night time feels way longer than daytime. All the random missions feel kind of the same though. Honestly I'd rate this game a solid 8/10. The only issues I have with it are mainly due to my own play style and preferences, nothing to do with bugs or crappy game mechanics. You can't heal or cure infection while in a vehicle which is kinda dumb, your carrying capacity is very limited, like items that stack in your storage do not stack in your backpack. Ammo of course stacks on you but most items do not. And the few items that do stack in your backpack have a very small stack size. Like for ammo, a stack is 40 rounds, and it can be increased to a max of 60 I believe with character skill upgrades. That's not much considering you only have a max of 12 inventory slots on your character, and not all have 12 slots, it depends which backpack you have and your characters skills. the backpacks range from 6-8 inventory slots, and pockets range from 2-4 slots. But you can always have a primary weapon, secondary, a melee and a close combat melee which I believe you cannot un-equip the close combat melee weapon but you can swap it out for other ones. You don't need to eat or drink for your own character, you have no hydration or hunger stats, just health, stamina and infection. The only use for food and water is to keep the morale up in the community which is essential. On a harder difficulty for the zombies, the hordes are everywhere bruh, you can't escape them, its wild. They're also increased in health, damage, size and more freaks or mutated ones. I don't know what the hard difficulty for the community is like as I haven't done that. And harder difficulty for the world just means more plague hearts which are the sources of the zombies that can infect you, you gotta take those out to secure outposts if they're in range of the plague heart. Overall its a pretty solid game, definitely not an easy one. I would highly recommend this.

Amazing zombie apocalypse game. This game has evolved over the years with consistent updates and patches to keep it fresh and entertaining.

Easy to learn, hard to master. I was mildly obsessed with State of Decay 1 when it came out and I have been playing SOD 2 since its release. I played 1 and 2 on Xbox before I bought my PC, and on PC alone I still have about 230 hours. It's embarrassing to admit but after all the hours put in, I am still bad enough at it that I have to watch others play to get any idea of how to survive. The work the developers put into the game is obvious and they have continued to add new features the community wanted even years after development. There is always something to do when you are trying to survive the apocalypse so even with a lack of a strong story line after the intro I am constantly finding ways to entertain (read: stress) myself. 

SOD 3 is likely a couple years away still but with all the love that's been put into the game post production I am still highly entertained. I don't think finding new and creative ways to kill the variety of zombies will ever become tiresome. I happily paid for the full product rather than waiting for it to go on sale because I appreciate all the work that has been put into it. 5/5 stars.

[h2]Summary[/h2]
My feelings on this game are NEUTRAL. Decent amount of fun, but a lot to be frustrated about.

[h2]Pros[/h2]
- Diversity in weapon types
- Flexibility in play style
- It's fun to mow through hordes of zombies
- Base building is pretty fun

[h2]Cons[/h2]
- Clunky controls. You really have to get used to the dodge mechanic at first (not hard. just not super responsive, but iframe window is pretty large)
- Melee can be frustrating at times
- Certain "better" cars have awful controls
- Coop is badly set up. You are a "helper" and not actually playing the game together. You are stuck to the main player.
- You will constantly get "stuck" (thank god for the unstuck command on the radio)
- Lots of bugs that can be frustrating in combat situations
- Many achievement bugs (achievements that have clearly been done do not get counted)

Possibly one of the best zombie survival community management games out there, if it weren't for ONE issue.

[h1]This game has a really bad problem with zombies spawning behind you[/h1]

Zombies will constantly spawn behind you, around corners, and anywhere out of sight in your immediate vicinity, anytime you or an object or zombie around you makes "noise". No difficulty setting stops this from happening. The only thing that the difficulty settings change is the frequency and number of zombies that the game will spawn behind you.

This artificial difficulty means that you need to constantly spin your head around in order to not be caught unawares by a zombie spawning behind you. You can't tactically go room to room to clear out buildings or open areas because the moment you generate any noise the game will spawn zombies behind you.

Even on medium to high difficulty, you can very easily get into an endless loop of zombie spawning behind you, you turn around to deal with the zombie, but the noise of you dealing with the zombie causes more zombies to spawn behind you again.

And if you're thinking about getting to a car to escape the endless "zombie spawns behind you" loop, SURPRISE! A bloater spawned on the road in the path of the car while you were going through the animation to get into the car.

Checking the road before getting into the car is useless. Tactically clearing out a building is useless.

[u][b]Zombies will constantly spawn behind you.[/b][/u]

Looking back update:

This game seriously affected my life by how addicting it was. It wasn't a fun addiction, more like a drug addiction, where you're just kinda holding off the side effects. 
Truth is, the game has lots of potential. Gameplay is very good, zombies are fun to kill and feel dangerous in the lethal zone and it's extremely addictive. 
However, the glitches, the lack of any personality or story, or interesting characters or anything memorable to discover is lacking. It's a big open empty sandbox with zombies and some characters that look different but feel pretty much the same. 
With future updates, I truly hope they release more content in the form of some more interesting quests that don't feel like chores, maybe hire a writer that could truly fill this sandbox with some interesting lore and story. 

"Lethal Zone update"
My expectations were low but damn.. this game is completely broken on Lethal zone. Bugs that were already pretty bad on nightmare are even worse in Lethal. I just don't get how every player is talking about this and has been talking about it since launch but the devs still don't fix it. It's always the same shit:
-Zombies spawning in front of you and behind you out of nowhere. Completely kills immersion and planning/scouting ahead. 
-You go in to search a house and a blood feral spawns in the next room or just 20 zombies out of nowhere, even though you scope the house from the outside and there's nothing in there. 
-Hordes spawn in front of you when driving and bust your car up.
-The morale counter is broken, the math never adds up. Why put stats as a feature if they can't even do simple math?? 
-Don't even get me started on the NPCs. Any fight with a human is dogshit. They're basically immortal and you're down in two shots. One time they occupied one of the settlements i wanted and then i came to kill them and I couldn't even touch them. Headshot.. with a sniper.. 10 times.. nothing..

In general there are lots of small bugs that just add up and make this game unplayable in this mode. Feels like playing the original dark souls with permadeath. I hope they fix it and i'll give it another try in the future but right now it's broken.


(Old review)
At one point you're barely scrapping by, fighting two hordes with one badass survivor not knowing if the next time you get hit it's over. Mowing through zombies with a heavy hammer and scoring headshots. The finger bitting tension and thrill of perma-death and nightmare zone are crazy good. 

And at another point, your car blows up from driving through a horde that spawned a meter in front of you, a juggernaut hits you from 20m away and kills your survivor, zombies visibly spawn out of thin air, enclave enemies that headshot you from behind walls... 
Getting attached to the characters you invest your time into developing that have no personality besides the one you imagine they have, most survivors are just ugly af, feels like 5 voice actors for all of them - common to have three survivors that sound the same in your community. 

Basically speaking, if the game works, it's a great game but very often it doesn't. It goes from tough but fair to fuck you, you died, you suck, have fun dipshit.

Free Weekend Demo and Played for 19 hours.

Its a Post Apocalyptic-Survival-Zombie-Management Game

A good recommendation that I will buy after this demo.
I saw my friend get brutally ripped in half by a juggernaut

The game is very mid. 

Melee combat sucks. It's almost like a turn based system. You swing and if you are in the correct distance it connects, otherwise you just miss.  Sometimes you may swing a little early, but the animation takes a while to load up, and in that time the enemy could be right in your face but your swing still misses. It's pretty awful if you ask me. You cannot fight two at a time, it will only hit the one zombie...I've only been able to hit multiple zombies maybe once or twice total. 

I wish the game was just shooting. The shooting is better, but the ammo is scarce so the game tries to push you to stealth and melee. Both areas of games I generally loathe. 

Switching between characters seemed like a neat idea, but I don't like it after about 15 minutes. I just want to build up one character and not have to micromanage every single person in the settlement. 

Also, the game seems to just take to long because the characters you are given just have the worst skills and you can't change them or give them new, useful, ones.  

I just gets kinda boring when every time you see a horde the best thing you can do is run.  Then when you see human enemies, if they hit you, you get stuck in a animation where you can never escape. Their hits stun you, then before you can regain control, they hit you again. I had one enemy do this until my character was completely downed. Got up, and had 3 of em doing it to me. The stupid AI that was with me was no where to be found, probably shooting at some zombies a plot over, doing their best to attract everything in the area. 

It's just very mid. If the focus was more on action and shooting, I would probably like the game way more. It's like if Dying Light (the first one, the second is absolute trash) had a terrible combat system. That game would suck too. Luckily the melee combat is one of the best in any game.  I just don't get why people make a game and make it melee focus, then put very little into the melee combat. It's literal button mashing and waiting for an animation to do the work for you. 

haven't had many bugs though, no crashes yet, but UI isn't very friendly. 

Just know that this is going to be a slog if you pick it up, and not the enjoyable kind. I really hope there is something on the horizon in this game that makes it all worthwhile, because right now I feel pretty let down.

I played through a campaign on Xbox Game Pass couple years ago and picked up the game on Steam now. Linking accounts didn't carry save progress or legacy pool for me, only achievements. SoD2 is one of the best zombie survival games I've played and by the looks of things, the Juggernaut edition is even better.

The multiplayer experience is also better than some reviews, especially the very short ones, make it sound like. You can still develop character skills, get loot and deposit them to your own supply locker, use basic base facilities like crafting and repairs and trade with enclaves. Your entire community is essentially an off-screen guest in your host's campaign, but you need to return to your own campaign to fully manage recovery of survivors and you can only gain influence, not standing, for guesting. In short, you can do almost everything you'd do in your own campaign and all players get a bit more out of the world with easier takedowns and more loot per location. I can't really see it as anything other than win-win, but if you're expecting to form a joint community with another player, that's not really possible, although you could still share valuable resources like blood samples by hopping between campaigns.

The only actual obstacle we experienced in multiplayer so far was having to spend some time to investigate and disable VPN to make multiplayer sessions possible. No other errors here. Most users experiencing them probably have something blocking the connection on their end instead of the service being actually bad.

Mediocre. Especially compared to SoD1, which I loved, this is a very action focused-game where zombies around the base always respawn so the world loses all sense of progression. Characters are in a strategic sense mainly just tokens for your base to be able to build certain improvements, so you will be nitpicky about them only for their 5th special ability. Also they look often the same as others (there are a few recurring phenotypes) and when they are in the base they just pretend to work something but it feels fake, since it has no effect at all. I don't get a sense of a simulated world this way. They also don't properly use the towers like they did in SoD1 where tower positioning meant a lot for defending the base and the surrounding.

Small and big boss enemies are bullet sponges and ferals are not even nearly scary anymore. The game feels like it is on easy mode compared to SoD1 with the exception that sometimes you or your ally will just suddenly die and you won't know why exactly. For example once i drove into a boomer and my ally then just died seconds later after i ran out of the gas immediately. I had just cured them beforehand, this was my last straw to uninstall because it felt extremely punishing but at the same time totally unpredictable. The juggernaut enemies are bullet sponges and you clunkily fight them in melee or use a lot of ammo and explosives on them, but they will also respawn anyway, so what's the point of even killing them? Let them stay around your base and graze the grass like cows. Apparently that's what the game designers wanted.

Fighting felt much better in SoD1- now it is just about hitting left mouse and dodge a lot. We are also missing cool moves in this game like kick jumps. In fact the finishing moves cost a lot of stamina and slow you down, melee just feels like a chore now. The companion Ai got  better and they shoot now! But the characters in your community won't go out to scavenge or anything anymore and need your help to get back, so overall the game and the side-mission and the world feel kind of dead, since all there is to it is to kill plague hearts and pimp your base or do main story missions to progress. The main campaign has no real story anyway, which is sad. Heartlands has a linear progression and story but all characters for the base are "unique" and you can't get new ones if they die, so you have to pick the ones that exist and there is no random encounters or random recruitment at all, unlike in SoD1.

I particularly hate the plague hearts in SoD2 and what they represent: I hate how they block the buildings around them from being claimable as outposts, i hate how they require me to get close to them to destroy them (bullet sponge), i hate the aoe effects on me when i m close and trying to kill them, forcing me to use explosives and bullets or cheese them from afar with long range, i hate how it just consistently throws 200 zombies at me while the heart is dying, which means I need to be super fast or I have no chance. Basically you just need to craft very strong explosives and nuke it at once, if you try to play stealth or tactical or smart, you will just lose. SoD has become a pure action game in that sense. Plague hearts on their own already kind of ruin the experience for me, it feels totally out of place and just like some grind-and-destroy crap. SoD1 was much cooler with a world that you slowly cleared out and expanded over instead of nuking some ridiculously overpowered spawn-point represented by a heart (if not insta-nuked, then they re ridiculously weak). SoD1 felt more like a simulation and more free and open.

SoD1 required you to sneak. In this game i never sneaked, it is irrelevant. Also boarding up windows is not possible anymore, but this was a cool feature! It felt like the survivors are actually smart out there for doing things like this instead of just idling. The friendly groups on the map now feel boring and annoying and if you recruit one of them the rest just.... runs off screen away and disappears (wtf??? are they afraid of my friendship? is this real life?) even though they may be "allied" by now with you.

The whole game is built around systems and crafting and honestly if you enjoy that go for it, but the whole survival-simulation feeling is gone with a world that just respawns bosses and zombies all over constantly and your outposts dont give any help with that at all. SoD 1 was a survival simulation, it was tactical, it was cool, it was fun. In SoD1 you could place outposts intelligently to burn all hordes approaching your base, that was so cool! And I often didn't just take the "biggest" base but one that is located well for this purpose.

SoD2 on the other hand feels like an action game with a coop feature, but it feels somewhat bland to me. Sad. A lot of features are great, improvements are great, but the stuff they ruined makes those improved and new features kind of worthless to me.

This is one of the best open world zombie survival game out on the market. I am a big fan of Walking Dead that's why I was looking for a game which is open world zombie survival and has base building and this is it. The game has a great community with a developer team who cares about feedback. There are dev and community streams. Still getting updates in 2023 after 5 YEARS! Before you think this game can do more than what is currently available, let me just say that it can, but the development team has limited resources because most of them have already left SoD2 behind to work on State of Decay 3 with the developers of Gears of War. They use this game to get feedback on things to create a better new game (SoD3) with these new features. Unfortunately because of the limit of the engine and the capacity of the team will lower the chances of big changes or updates I just say it to keep this in mind. You can play this game however you want. There are multiple maps, bases and customizable difficulty options. You can build your base however you want there are slots and in that slots you can build different stations. There is a 4 player online coop with limitations but at least we have and there is a chance that this will get a revamp because of a multiplayer survey. I don't wanna tell you more, there is much more to discover just get it and try it out! Definitely worth 30€, but if you can't buy it for that much, then wait for the sale and buy it then.

Update on September 21 - The developers confirmed this in a developer stream, I heard it and I am happy to hear this message. -> Wushu Studios will continue to support State of Decay 2 with new content moving forward, as most of Undead Labs is now working on State of Decay 3.

Undead Labs keep up this great work!

Thank you for reading my review, I hope I was able to help you make a decision!

State of Decay 2 is an absolute gem of a game that effortlessly combines the heart-pounding excitement of survival with the depth of character-driven storytelling. Undeniably, it's a must-play for anyone who loves the zombie apocalypse genre or simply enjoys immersive, open-world experiences.

First and foremost, the game's world is a testament to meticulous attention to detail. The environments are beautifully crafted, each with its own distinct flavor and challenges. Whether you're scavenging through abandoned houses or navigating the post-apocalyptic wilderness, the world feels alive, dangerous, and unpredictable. This dynamic setting truly immerses you in the struggle for survival.

The heart of State of Decay 2 lies in its characters. The game introduces you to a diverse cast of survivors, each with their own unique personalities, skills, and quirks. You'll find yourself forming genuine attachments to these characters as you lead them through the trials and tribulations of the apocalypse. The depth of character development is nothing short of remarkable, and it adds a layer of emotional investment that many other survival games lack.

What sets State of Decay 2 apart is its emphasis on community building. You're not just trying to survive for yourself; you're responsible for building and maintaining a thriving community of survivors. This mechanic adds a strategic layer to the gameplay that keeps you constantly engaged. The decisions you make have real consequences for your community, making every choice feel meaningful and impactful.

Combat in State of Decay 2 is gritty and intense, offering a variety of weapons and tactics to suit your playstyle. Whether you prefer stealthy takedowns, going in guns blazing, or running for your life, the game accommodates your choices and keeps you on your toes with the ever-present threat of zombie hordes and hostile human factions.

Furthermore, the game's co-op multiplayer mode is a blast to play with friends. Team up to tackle the challenges of the apocalypse together, sharing the highs and lows as you build your own stories of survival.

In summary, State of Decay 2 is an unforgettable survival adventure that will keep you hooked for hours on end. Its richly detailed world, compelling characters, and strategic gameplay make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a veteran zombie slayer or new to the apocalypse, this game offers an experience you won't want to miss. Dive in, build your community, and see if you have what it takes to survive in this thrilling, post-apocalyptic world!

A fun and quite addictive team management, base building, zombie battling game.

It's not perfect, but it does keep drawing you back in to try different maps, and different difficulties.

On Standard and Dread difficulty, it's actually quite easy when you know what you're doing. You could stockpile pipe bombs and clear the maps even without a full team. Or sit back and explore the game without worrying too much about sieges, etc.

On Nightmare difficulty it becomes more challenging and you really need to plan.

It can be frustrating. Bases limit what you can build. Skills can be hard to come by - but there are often multiple ways to gain a skill so....

It did keep me coming back to explore other maps though, and overall, it was fun and quite addictive.

Somehow State of Decay 2 feels like it has no soul. It's not particuallary a bad game, no. There are several things I liked about it: It was fun looting the sights I explored, the characters level fast but not too easy, the combat felt good and not too difficult and I really liked to explore my surroundings. Also the infections seem to be a challenge but nothing you can't fight.  

But there's so much I miss, too: The characters felt like empty vessels to me, they don't really engage with each other like people do, they don't really talk, they felt like puppets. There's no real story or plot in the game, other than surviving (which wouldn't be bad if the people I play felt real to me). 

I also got bored pretty soon. I upgraded my base and had to start talking with other survivors, maybe recruiting them: But really, I couldn't care less about more lifeless puppets in my base! And all of them wanted food! Food I carefully collected! 
Maybe there's more to the game but I give up, because spending my time in a world like this isn't really entertaining for me.

Detailed Review (kinda long)

I'm a long time player of this game (since launch), but only recently started playing again after update 33 (i stopped updating game at v29 because i didnt like the way things were going and no way to reverse any updates)

So players like me who had to turn off internet and all things to avoid updating SOD2 can rest easy as Update 33 clears most annoying problem- the infestations

i always play at Nightmare difficulty  (sometimes standard to farm things) and currently on 4th playthrough after the update, what's amazing about this update is you can completely clear a map, without having a single infestation (barring mission ones) there will be missions in plague territory to make you go there and cause ruckus like - builder and pillage (for materials) or a survivor who shows up to destroy a plague heart..

in short avoid any mission in which you have to disturb a heart unless you are ready to kill it and the adjacent hearts (in NM and lethal hearts are clustered so killing one wakes the nearby hearts, avoid screamers as their screams can wake a heart as well.

also killing the screamers now clears infestations which clears a lot of trouble, as you can you a arrow or bullet from a distance and infestation cleared!

all in all the game now gives you breathing room, as long as you dont screw around hearts no sieges or infestations will bother you.  

stealth has become a major skill for all survivors, without it you will barely survive now, you can even stealth kill as many zoms as you want in plague territory and the heart will not wake (not applicable for freaks). 


TL'DR- the update 33 made this game more player friendly, less stressful (annoying enclaves are still present but ignore them or feed em to zoms lol)

[h1]A Unique Zombie Apocalypse Experience with Room for Improvement[/h1]
by Aidanator (with help)

State of Decay 2 is an awesome game, offering a captivating experience that immerses players into the heart of a zombie apocalypse. While it has its shortcomings, the game's overall fun factor (based almost entirely on the unique community-building aspect), and replay-ability, make it a worthwhile investment.

[b]Fun Factor (4/5): [/b]
State of Decay 2 delivers an incredibly enjoyable gaming experience. The constant struggle for survival against hordes of zombies keeps the adrenaline pumping, making every decision a matter of life and death. Whether you're scavenging for supplies, fortifying your base, or exploring the post-apocalyptic world, the game offers an engaging and addictive gameplay loop.

[b]Community Building (4.5/5): [/b]
One of the game's standout features is its community-building aspect. Building and managing a group of survivors adds a layer of depth and immersion that sets State of Decay 2 apart. It truly captures the essence of surviving in a zombie-infested world, where every member's skills and traits matter. Forming bonds and facing moral dilemmas as you lead your community is a unique and satisfying experience.

[b]Customizable Difficulty (4/5): [/b]
The game caters to both new and experienced players with its extensive difficulty customization options. Whether you're seeking a more relaxed, story-driven experience or a hardcore survival challenge, State of Decay 2 allows you to fine-tune the gameplay to your preferences, ensuring that everyone can find their ideal level of challenge.

[b]Map Variety (3.5/5): [/b]
While I appreciate the diversity of maps, Trumbull Valley stands out as the most memorable due to its unique missions and distinctive character. Unfortunately, the other maps tend to lose their novelty after a couple of playthroughs. I hope the developers introduce new maps before the release of the third game to keep the experience fresh.

[b]Voice Actor Diversity (3/5): [/b]
One of the game's [u]glaring issues[/u]is the lack of voice actor diversity. Multiple community members often share the same voice, and the absence of regional accents feels odd. Adding more variety in voice acting would significantly enhance immersion and make each survivor feel like a unique character.

[b]Clothing Options (3/5): [/b]
While the clothing options in the game are decent, I wish there were more choices. Creating distinct outfits for all community members becomes a challenge when you desire both uniqueness and personal style. Expanding the wardrobe options would improve the customization aspect of the game.

[b]Supply Collection and Automation (4/5): [/b]
The mechanics of collecting supplies and the impact on your home site's functionality are well-executed. The gradual automation of supply collection is a satisfying progression element, making resource management a crucial part of the game's strategy.

[b]Leader Types (3.5/5): [/b]
The option to choose from leader types like builder, sheriff, warlord, or trader adds replay-ability. However, it does become repetitive once you've experienced each leader's missions multiple times. Adding more leader types or varied mission outcomes would enhance the game's longevity.

[b]Conclusion: [/b]
State of Decay 2 is [u]undeniably[/u] one of my favourite games, offering a unique and captivating zombie apocalypse experience. While it has its flaws, including limited voice actor diversity and a lack of map variety, the game's fun factor, community-building mechanics, and customizable difficulty options more than compensate for these shortcomings. It's easy to get into and definitely worth the price. I can't wait for the third game in the series, but I'm frustrated by the lack of information about it. State of Decay 2 is a [u]must-play[/u] for anyone looking for an immersive survival experience in a post-apocalyptic world.

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] This review was generated with the assistance of ChatGPT, but it reflects my genuine opinions about State of Decay 2. I genuinely enjoy the game, but I struggle with expressing my thoughts in writing. The review accurately represents my personal experiences and feelings about the game.

[h1]State of Decay 2[/h1]
Currently my favorite zombie game. Legitimately open world, nothing holding you back. Very relaxing and fun to scavenge for supplies while driving around a large area.
[list]
[*]Story content is limited. You can play Heartland for a good story, and then the Trumbull Valley map afterwards to continue it somewhat, but then other than the tutorial missions there isn't a coherent story revolving around your base.
[*]Spawns are annoying. Zombies are created spontaneously by noise, so there isn't a good way to clear an area and then loot it carelessly. Any blind spot is an open spawn location for new zombies.
[*]There are only 4 types of 'freaks'. Feels like I'm in the first Left 4 Dead again. Hopefully they'll make more in the next game.
[*]State of Decay 3 was announced awhile ago but apparently it's in development hell. May never see it.
[*]State of Decay 2 still has infrequent content updates. The most recent one was 'Heart Attack' which overhauled the way plague hearts, infestations, and sieges work.
[*]Some aspects of the game are too game-y and immersion breaking, like the Bounty Broker and most radio calls. I'd avoid them if you're looking for an immersive zombie survival experience.
[*]Multiplayer is good and bad. It's host based, so be prepared for lag. And when you want to play with friends (not in Daybreak) you only have the option to join their world on one of your characters and help them out - only one player can really progress in the game in one multiplayer session. Hopefully we get real multiplayer in State of Decay 3.
[/list]

This game is amazing, especially after all the quality of life and improvement updates! The DLCs are fun, Heartland brings us back to the beloved Trumbull Valley with a story that keeps you invested throughout the play. Daybreak is your typical survive increasingly harder waves of enemies DLC, but State of Decay edition, and it does not disappoint at all, not only is it fun and challenging, you unlock items for your normal playthrough in the campaign. And the Campaign has a whopping 5 maps, which you can freely explore as long as it is on the map which is fun, the combat mechanics are extremely fun and easy to learn. This game is definitely worth the try if you're into open-world zombie games. My only issue is once you make it to a certain point, more complex difficulties like Nightmare and Lethal zone become way too easy, there also isn't that much of a difference between zeds and freaks from the first and second game, there isn't much of a variety and Lethal Zone should be getting increasingly more challenging like the Breakdown DLC from the first game. State of Decay 2 is a great zombie game and has room for improvements! a 9/10 from me

It is such a boring grind no matter how you cut it.

I remember it being a blast on my Xbox the very first time I played it. Having a survivor catch the plague, his vehicle explodes back when night time was *night time.* Breaking my melee weapon and exhausting all of my ammo as dozens of blood plague zombies hunted me down. *Finally* escaping and running to the other side of the road hiding inside bushes while turning off my flashlight, seeing literally nothing but their deathly glowing red eyes as they charged ahead trying to hunt Jontraye down.

Basically no health, no stamina, completely alone, completely helpless. Yet after 10 minutes of desperate survival, quietly hoping above all else that they wouldn't spot me, I found a car for Jontraye, barely getting him back.

This was back before the difficulty modes, when you had 3 entire hours to fix the plague. Jontraye had 50 minutes left, a dead man in today's meta.

But it didn't matter, it was exhilirating, almost as great as my experience with STALKER.

Annd then I kept playing and figured out all the mechanics, making it braindead easy.

I eventually got this on PC, setting it to nightmare as I realised dread and normal just didn't cut it. And found it to be the most ridiculously challenging, annoying thing I've played in a *minute.*

My mistakes don't feel like mistakes. Anywhere you go, anything you do, zombies will literally spawn out of thin air at random to surround you. You helped a survivor literally 50 meters from your home base? Here's 3 f*cking juggernauts out of nowhere because f*ck you!

Doesn't matter that I destroyed every single plague heart around there (the siege system is one of the few new things I can say is actually great). The game treats me like I just wandered dead center into the most infected area of the map.

There is no planning. Because planning would imply that you could somehow circumvent and outsmart the hordes. Tailoring your playstyle to your survivor. You arm yourself to the teeth *every* single time because no matter where you go, the game treats you the same.

I go to clear an infestation barely 200 meters from my base and I'm getting hordes of Ferals and 3 screamers to attract an incomprehensible amount of zombies.

*How the hell* are we still alive if *that* many zombies are wandering around our home turf? Why is there no such thing as actual *territory* where we and our enclaves clear out chunks of land to hold and maintain to give us breathing room to scavenge and explore?

There is difficulty, and then there is bullsh*t difficulty. This is the latter. There isn't a way to utilize the game mechanics in a clever way to avoid these threats and keep missions simple/quiet. Legimately you know the best way to get around these annoying mechanics?

Cheese the hell out of the game and quit so they despawn! I am not joking. The game actively incentivizes this, because what the hell am I supposed to do if I have 3 juggs wandering right outside my base at all times? On *nightmare* difficulty I would like to add once again. I didn't make a mistake that the game punished me for, like making way too much noise or allowing the infestations to grow out of control, the game just decided that's what needed to happen.

The game does not punish you for mistakes, it punishes you for *existing.* It'll no doubt be fun for some, but for me this is ridiculous. Punish me because I screwed up and didn't respect and pay attention to the mechanics. If I die in Doom Eternal or Turbo Overkill it's because I overextended and failed to pay attention to the enemies attack patterns.

If I lose in XCOM 2 it's because I screwed around with my technology and didn't research enough or gather the resources needed and fell behind.

I cleared every plague heart, and root out every infestation that pops up near my base as *soon* as it arrives. What did I do wrong to draw such extreme reactions?

Also, Juggernauts and Ferals suck. Ferals I you can at least headshot, but Juggs are literally just swing and shoot a massive healthbar until they slowly die... When they can kill you in like 3 hits.

A unique, one of a kind zombie survival game that brings innovative features to it's genre, much to the likes of what Dragon's Dogma did for RPG's. There also is very few, if any games like State of Decay on the market at this current time. The game is centered around you and your community and the different personally unique events and stories that unfold, similar to a "Walking Dead" experience. There is very little in the way of a main story (unlike it's predecessor), other than idle chatter about the lore through radio messages. You can "beat" the game by completing a final set of objectives on each map (of which there are five) after destroying all the "plague hearts", which is the main driving force and threat for building up your community. After completing a map, you can choose to continue to another map with your current community, or just start fresh with new survivors. The game is pretty much endless.

 The core gameplay loop of looting for supplies, killing zombies, and base building is satisfying, if a little bit repetitive, but is good enough to keep the player entertained for 10-15 hours minimum on a first playthrough, and potentially hundreds more if the loop clicks with said player. Combat is simple, but effective, with a satisfying blood and dismember system and punchy gunplay. There are special "freak" zombies such as screamers and ferals to help break up the monotony of the basic zombies. Combat difficulty is also freely adjustable along with a slew of other aspects of the game's systems, such as resource scarceness and community management difficulty, far more customizable  than some other games.

The game is currently, and has been on a live service dev cycle for the past 3-4 years, with regular content updates that improve on and deepen the already unique gameplay systems. Undead Labs has stated they don't plan on stopping support anytime soon, with several "new" features already in development at this time. It is unknown if support will cease once State of Decay 3 is released.

Overall, if you like sandbox survival games, State of Decay 2 brings a unique take on the genre that has certainly fostered a small but dedicated playerbase that will only grow larger once State of Decay 3 comes out. Despite how unique State of Decay 2 is, it certainly doesn't get everything right and has a handful of flaws that can be fixed with updates, or iterated upon in a sequel. It is not a 9/10 game, but it doesn't have to be. it is a perfectly entertaining and serviceable 7/10 game, which is why i draw the comparison with Dragon's Dogma, as that game is a very similar unique 7/10 RPG that earned it's fanbase for it's innovation to the genre.

Here is my assessment of the game, highlighting its strengths and weaknesses:


Pros:

- Challenging Gameplay: The game provides a unique challenge. Encounter with 3-5 zombies can be fatal.

- RPG Element with Permadeath: The inclusion of permadeath adds depth to the RPG aspect, making each character's survival vital, as losing a character means losing all the progress made.

- Expansive Open-World Environment: The game boasts a vast open-world map, providing players with ample exploration opportunities.

- Base Building Mechanics: Players can engage in base building activities, adding strategic elements to the gameplay.

- Engaging Quests: Some of the quests in the game are well-crafted and offer an engaging experience.


Cons:

- Limited Inventory Capacity: The inventory, particularly backpacks and cars, has a maximum capacity of 8 slots, and certain items cannot be stacked. However, it's noteworthy that 8 guns can be carried in a backpack/car, which raises concerns.

- Lack of a Substantial Storyline: The game lacks a comprehensive storyline, which may diminish the overall narrative experience.

- Repetitive Gameplay: The gameplay can become somewhat repetitive, with a cycle of looting and returning to the base frequently.

- Limited Interactivity with Enclaves: Interactions with enclaves (neighbors) tend to be one-sided, with requests for assistance or assistance turning hostile if not met.

- Weapon Durability Issues: The durability of weapons seems to be a concern, as they tend to break easily.


Overall Impression:

Despite its shortcomings, I find myself still enjoying the game. I anticipate dedicating approximately 50-100 hours to the gameplay, after which I may take a break. I do recommend the game to those seeking a challenging and immersive survival experience, despite its limitations.

A nice immersive experience in a post apocalyptic world. I love the exploration, you need to find supplies to equip your survivors and improve the base. During these supply runs, you navigate around hordes of zombies, trying to pick them apart or just sneak past them.

You're also expected to liberate zones of the map by destroying plague hearts, pillars of flesh which draw zombies and create harder zones. Usually it's a head on charge where you unload explosives on the heart and roll over zombies with your SUV. 10/10, would recommend.

There is one drawback that hampers the experience: Two of the special types zombies, ferals and juggernauts, are more annoying than anything. They proliferate during your playthroug and after a while the map is harder to navigate. I wish there was a way to disable them.
Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle but still fun for a few hours.

Definitely recommend this game if you like Survival style Zombie Shooters with a lot of action, base building, character development and getting bigger badder stuff to kill bigger badder zombies!

If you are new to the game, it is pretty tough from the start and all characters are perma-death. If they die - they die. Do not let that sway you though - it adds a solid amount of tension to the game and forces you to make good choices. Running in blasting may not always be wise. Pay attention! You can become overwhelmed in seconds.

I have had this game for a while now, and recently returned to check out the Update 33 goodness! They keep on adding more and more to this game. Love the changes personally, after you have 'end gamed' it a couple times, it can tend to get a bit easy, but Update 33 added a lot of challenge. 

While end game can be a bit easy sometimes though, even on higher difficulty; I was just watching a video with a streamer and some devs who were discussing Update 34 and the extra 'curveballs'/challenges they are planning that should spice up the end game quite a bit.  

The game runs well, no issues with crashing. Don't think it's ever crashed on me at all. Although sometimes in multiplayer, people who join up will get occasional frame rate slowdowns. They are kinda bad (but usually very short), and they don't persist long for me. Just a few 'here and there'.

Changed my mind about this game. Since they fixed the Xbox live thing it's been easy to run ever since. Besides that... This is the best zombie game I think I've ever played. There is so much freedom to do what you want. I enjoy the fact you can take over any place and make it into a base/outpost. Making you feel like you can really make do with what you can in the zombie apocalypse. Furthermore I enjoy the atmosphere. The random ambiance/sounds I hear in the distance during the day and night definitely gives it a huge immersive feel. The level design/maps are done very well. They look like something out of a zombie movie or comic you can actually explore!

My only complaint about this game is the fact whenever I join a friend's game. For some reason I lag or hitch even on a high end PC which shouldn't happen. My friends even on console say they have the same issue as well joining games. For some reason it seems laggish and I'm not sure if it's because of the huge world or something else?

Last but not least for complaints. I'm going to tell you now... I'm refunding every game that forces automatic controls from now on. Anything from climbing, opening doors, reloading guns, anything related I will refund the game instantly if I even see it. If there isn't a way to disable it. Because I've lost multiple survivors because of the auto climbing system. IT IS ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE and a lazy way to do something for games. I'm so tired of seeing auto climbing in games because it's just a frustrating thing that shouldn't be in the game. 

Besides that... If you're the type of person who wants a free roam zombie game with a ton of immersion and a lot of places to explore. This is by far the best zombie game I've found. About time a company did it right for once!
Character development, multiple maps, vehicles, realistic weapons, and base upgrades. This game checks almost all the boxes for an immersive survival game.

Do you enjoy zombie survival games? If u do then you’ll enjoy this one for sure

(RELEASE DATE) #the dark ages

When this game came out day one let me tell you it was ROUGH AND SCARY it was full of bugs that were game braking like cars going crazy after crashing or just driving normally, zombies spawning mid air and invisible zombies… that was fun

Now all those bugs have been fixed so thank god :)

(CONTENT)

So if you’re familiar with the first game, state of decay 2
isn’t so different which is not a bad thing at all. sod 2 is pretty much a more improved version of the first game with better mechanics, visuals and graphics 

• Survivors 

Survivors have different skills, traits and special skills like mechanics or electronic and more

Survivors sadly don’t feel like important characters they feel more like resources that you gotta keep around

If a survivor dies and they had a special skill you liked you can just find a new one later and hopefully they have the same skill or you can read a skill book

• Leader types 

Sod 2 has different leader types is something that sod 1 didn’t have

Each leader type provides different facilities you can build and my personal favorite is the trader, trading can come in handy once you looted the whole map or at least half of it 

NOTE: You can only have one leader at a time 

(Sheriff) allows you to make field hospital facility 

(Builder) allows you to make sniper big pp tower facility 

(Warlord) allows you to make a armory facility 

(Trader) allows you to make a trading center facility 

• Base building 

The building in here is not like let’s say fallout 4 where you can place things anywhere it’s more like building in certain spots the base has to offer

You can build anything in said spot as long as you meet the requirements and have the required materials

• different building spot sizes 

Sod 2 offers two different building spots size, small and large 

• Base supply Locker 

The locker is where you put all the things you find while looting, you can put weapons, health items, misc and maybe even a zombie if u want 

• Clothing 

Sod 2 offers different types of outfits they aren’t nothing special but it’s nice to be able to change your survivors clothes 

• Bounty challenges 

These are mostly to keep the player entertained, you unlock certain things like weapons, cars, weapon mods, clothing and certain facility mods 

These things you unlock are exclusive to the bounty 
challenges only 

• Morale 

your survivors will have a morale system this is a pretty big thing when it comes to survivors 

Morale is important to keep up cause if you don’t your survivors will start arguing with each other and it can lower everyone’s morale this can lead to survivors wanting to leave the community

How do i raise morale?

You can raise it by having certain facilities

(Kitchen)

This will allow you to cook a meal for all survivors in the base 

(lounge facility)

With this your survivors can play board games, watch movies, have a few drinks and maybe some sweet butt sex afterwards 

(Having enough beds)

Survivors don’t like to cuddle with each other :( 

(Having power and water)

Important for certain facilities to work 

Or just kill everyone and problem solved 💀

• Outpost

These are little checkpoints that carry over your home supply locker and can also provide small benefits such as raising morale

• Different types of Outpost and benefits 

(House outpost) gives you two extra beds in the community 

(Food outpost) will give food daily 

(Power outpost) will give your base power plus morale 

(Water outpost) will provide water plus morale 

(Ammo outpost) will give ammo daily 

(Medicine outpost) will give everyone hardcore drugs to get wasted

(Gas station outpost) will give gas daily

You can upgrade outposts to increase the benefits but it will require materials 

(ENCLAVES) 

These are survivors that will appear in the game after some time, they are really needy which it can get annoying and they’ll request for help almost every day

• Enclave missions 

When they request for help they mostly want something like food or materials sometimes even a power generator cause apparently the game made u their lord and savior and they need u 24\7

• What do they offer? 

They offer benefits for your community they aren’t all that great but some can be good

• How do i friend them?

To friend an enclave you just gotta help them when they request for you, after a couple of missions you’ll become allies 

• Can I trade with them?

Yes you can trade with enclaves as long as you’re in good terms with them

• Enclave status 

Enclaves will have like a relationship with you, if you keep helping the relationship goes up but if u don’t help them it will go down and if u keep avoiding them they will become hostile 

• Hostile survivors

This wasn’t a thing in sod 1 it was kinda unexpected that we got to see that in sod 2 

Sadly they only appear as enclaves or from a mission so you won’t find them in the open just looting or walking around 

(MULTIPLE MAPS)

Sod 1 only had a single map but sod 2 offers 6 maps

(GAME DIFFICULTY)

At release there wasn’t any difficulty choice which at first it didn’t felt like a big deal but later on it started getting easy and kinda boring that you could just play the game with zero consequences 

So they added 5 difficulties 

(Green zone) The easiest 

(Standard zone) the normal mode

(Dread zone) pretty much the standard zone but a little harder 

(Nightmare zone) hard mode

(Lethal zone) for crazy people like me

• What’s the difference between each difficulty?

Each difficulty increases zombies, less enclaves, increases the human enemies damage and the zombies, your community uses more supplies like food cause they wanna be fat B I T C H E S, certain buildings have already been looted and less cars

(SPECIAL ZOMBIES) 

the special zeds aren’t something we haven’t seen before we have the Screamer, Juggernaut, Bloaters and Ferals

(ONLINE MULTIPLAYER)

Online was a massive deal for sod and a lot of people wanted the first sod to have it but they couldn’t sadly but sod 2 offers online. At lunch it was buggy but now it’s probably smooth and i say probably cause I haven’t played it with another player in some time 

(MAIN OBJECTIVE)

The main objective is to survive but also to destroy something called plague hearts, special zombies that can infect you with their blood if they scratch you or bite you, keep getting bitten and your character will get infected 

What happens if your character is infected? You’ll receive a meter that shows you how long you have until you make a cure cause if u don’t you’ll die and turn into a plague zombie 

• How do i make a cure

You need a infirmary facility there u can make a cure but u need to collect plague samples you get it after killing plague zombies, they don’t always drop it when u kill them, best way to get samples is by destroying a plague heart

• How do i destroy plague hearts? 

Simple just go up to one and then say hi to it then you BEAT THE S H I T OUT OF IT UNTIL IT SCREAMS AND DIES FROM SO MUCH PAIN!!!!

Just be aware that hitting the plague heart too much will call plague zombies to its location, I recommend that you hit it like 5 times and wait until zombies come, kill them and then continue on with your BDSM play with Mr. Plague heart or Mrs plague heart or whatever 

(Do i recommend this?) 

Yes absolutely the gameplay will get repetitive over time but it’s not so bad if you play with higher difficulty making u play the game a bit more tactical

(Rating) 8/10

Props to Undead labs for listening to the community and adding countless updates since day one.

There are elements of a good game here but minimal  improvement over SOD 1 in terms of mechanics.     I had much more fun with SOD 1 and the Breakdown DLC which gradually ramped up the difficulty over time and gave you a reason to play with a team for a longer time.   

Pros:    Prettier than SOD 1

Cons:  Lifeless  NPC enclaves.     A tiny indie game like Survivalist: Invisible Strain did this so much better
           No scaling difficulty as you clear levels which limits your play time with any group.
           Repetitive,  not much changed from SOD 1.
           Quick levelling means you max survivors quickly,  like SOD 1,   which adds to the short term feel of the game.
           
Verdict:   Buy on a deep sale if you really need a short term zombie fix,
