I came in with an expectation that this game is different, that this is a zombie game more about community building, resources and base building/defense. I was dissapointed.

This game does everything well enough, and just barely good enough, and that's the problem. Everything is mediocre. There's nothing in this game that's unique. It has no direction to what it want to be so they just sprinkle a little bit of everything into this game.

Game is also too easy. I feel like permadeath really hurt this game because the devs are forced to make this game as easy and predictable as possible to make sure players don't die....

If this game insist of having permadeath, then the main progression should not be with characters but with base because losing character in this game is a huge setback on progression.
This game is very recommended for those who want to scavange along with their AI companion.
The co-op mode is a sham. As a host you can do everything and the guest almost nothing. That is not how co-op should work. So much potential wasted. I hope part 3 delivers a proper co-op mode here.

It's not a bad game, everything is very simply done system wise - like it was done by some one fresh out of game design school, but the systems seem pretty bug free and work so far as I can tell. 
Combat and base building are ok, not amazing, but ok. Once more, simple, like some one fresh out of school put them together and were following a template from class. 
Graphics are pretty decent. The story is ok - with heart land - with the normal maps/game I'm honestly not even sure there is a story. 
Then there is the defend the hill scenario - which by the way kicks out other players when doing it with friends for no apparent reason in the middle of a wave. So, that's kind of broken.

All this aside, the game works more or less bug free. It's very simplistic and unrealistic with zombie spawning, since they always appear behind you and attack from your blind spots when there was nothing there before. 

There are minimal maps to choose from and no real randomness. Base editing/building is very simplified and some things are cemented in place. All base upgrades are not standard across the game, heartland has better/different things and a bigger base than the rest of the game. There doesn't even seem to be a point in doing things on the random maps. . .get a base, recruit people, kill zeds. . .and nothing. . .so yeah, it gets boring super fast. 

But anyone playing it should get a few hours of zombie head popping fun I guess. I hope the third one is better and less like some class room beta project. . .
I know there was some big to do about sexual harassment or some other horse dung going on with the devs, but to be honest I wonder if it was more along the lines of 'you can't do your job properly so you're not getting any more credit' and then some one cried wolf. Judging by the absolute student level work on the game I can't imagine that gender played a role in how it was developed, but more of inexperience and un-inventiveness, and when they got chewed out for it they got mad. 
Either way, I do hope the next one lives up to the video footage put out, though I am doubting it will be such high quality given the inept display of coding and system design skills displayed in this one. 
 
Do I think it's worth the price, yeah. I got some hours of fun out of it. But I'm not going to talk it up as if it were some amazing game when it wasn't. It was simply enjoyable for a short time and then got boring really fast.

Played the heck out of this one. I am a huge fan of zombie fiction, as outright trite and over-saturated it has become, and this game is one of the best zombie experiences I've had. I played the original State of Decay, and while it had some good ideas it was entangled in a lot of technical issues and felt unfinished. SoD 2 is a far more polished, enjoyable experience. There is a lot of replayability here too as you have several vastly different maps to get your sandbox on, a shorter special campaign, and a ton of content to go through overall.

There's even a multiplayer mode where you just fight zombies. It's decently fun, but all of the best stuff is locked behind it, so you have to grind it to unlock everything. it does get quite tedious, but there are tools online to unlock all of its content quickly.

Recommended if you like zombies or sandbox games in general.

Brilliant zombie apocalypse game and would describe it a little bit like GTA with Zombies. You have the ability to build your own base with a small community of survivors (All playable) albeit with some restrictions and have outposts to support the base. Be warned though the main game is in Iron man mode so doing something stupid with a character to get them killed is permanent unless of course you download the SOD2SAVE mod from Nexusmods.

This game is one of my favorite Zombie-games to date . An even 5 years after release they bring updates to the game ,cudos to the devs . I like the community managment aspect of the game , wish you don`t find in any other zombie survival games . Instead of a building mechanic , like in most survival games today , the focus here lies in choosing the right settlement place to build your facilities of your choice to get you through the game . You always start with 3 people and a small standart base , after that you have to grow your cummunity of surviors in order to occupie a better or bigger base . You don`t can have everything at once , you always have to choose wish direction or wish facilities match your playstyle or current situation in the game . 
This game is a revised version of their of the first one . If you are new to state of decay and don`t know what game to choose . Take this one , it plays the same but has more functions and community interaction than the first one .
And if some things are not your liking , for almost everything you can find a mod to remedy that .
Can`t wait for the SoD3 :)

Even though this game is over 9 years old it still holds up as being one of, if not THE best zombie game on the market. It's not only fun playing single player but it's hilarious when you can get three more friends to join in the zombie killing.

There's of course the standard Easy - Hard difficulities (Here being Easy, Medium, Advanced and Expert). So if you're looking for some mindless slaughtering to do you can put it on easy or if you and your friends is a tatical squad preparing for the zombie apacolypse this is a great way to start!

Also you don't have to play the first game to get into this one, all the maps and more from the first game is in this one. Even if you want to play oldschool there is a mode for that. Speaking of modes, there's Versus mode which is exactly what it sounds like, you control both the infected and the survivors in rounds. The one who ends the final map with the most points win. There is also a realism version of this mode which means the survivers can't see the green/orange/red glow around them as they used to.

There's also Survival which is aslo what it sounds like. Survive for X amount of time and you get bronze, silver or a gold medal depending on the requirments for the map you're playing.

Scavanger is the last major gamemode, here you play as survivor and infected and the objective is to fill a generator with gas. Who wins depends on which team's the fastest.

Then, finally, there's something called mutation. These are pretty much fun little mini modes. For example you have to try and survive an entire campaign on your own, you and all your teamates have katanas and can't get other weapons, you need to carry around a lawngnome to win etc.

My favorite rogue-lite community zombie survival game of all time. On Microsoft Store/Xbox, I've dumped just over 1k hours, and I don't plan on stopping.

I have three pieces of advice for new players:
1. Always keep these consumables on you: Health, Stamina, Ammo, Throwable, and Plague Cure. Everyone needs them.
2. Amp the difficulty until taking fights seems like a bad idea. Turn the difficulty up until having to make hard decisions becomes like breathing. You won't really enjoy the game until you do.
3. Play with friends; It's always better with friends.
4. The Staging Area Large-Slot is worth it. Source: Dude trust me.

Great game but one main issue. For some reason when I link my xbox account it doesn't have any of my save progress or communities. I'm not sure how to fix it. It works fine on xbox.

First off, this game doesn't allow you to save when you want.  There is no reason this feature shouldn't be in every SINGLE PLAYER open world game.  I own the game.  If I want to reload a previous save, rather than live with the results of poorly explained mechanics, that's my choice.

To that effect, barely anything is explained in the tutorials and you often end up losing a large amount of time and work just because the game decides to spring an unexplained mechanic on you.  One wrong turn and you're screwed with no chance of actually understanding why it happened.

For instance, when confronting an NPC in an early mission, the choices you are presented with are "I'm happy that you murdered a bunch of random people, come join our community." or varying other responses that tell the person to leave with "potentially" dangerous results.  In the end, "may become hostile" ends up being entirely random because there's no explanation as to which choice has less of a chance of causing something to happen, which (in my case) entirely ruins your effort and hard work.

It's a very graphically beautiful game, but that's all the appeal there is for me here.  The morale system, time-restricted base building, super slow scavenging, and micro-management of every person in your community that is required to "play" this game makes it feel more like a job than a fun exploration experience.

I have wasted 6.5 hours on this game and I have zero desire to play it again.  The character I really enjoyed playing is permanently dead, and there's nothing that I can do about it other than start over.

Tbh, I wasn't that impressed with this game when I first tried it out for about 20 hours. I wanted a team base-building game and found more of a survival action game.

130 hours later, I think this maybe is one of the best games in my library. This game is HARD (play on Lethal, don't give up, the challenge is addicting and makes the game much more engaging). The devs are constantly improving the game and ratcheting up the challenge. 

It now has a very tactical level to it with plague territories and sieges that make it almost impossible to feel safe. I've lost dozens of communities at this point and I've never "beaten" the game. I think I'm starting to get close to hitting my stride, but that's what makes this game really special. This is "real" difficulty. Not simple bullet sponge cheese.

Don't mod, don't give up, and don't complain. Challenges like these are rare in gaming... relish it!

State of Decay 2 is a soulless, bland, directionless game that wears its mediocrity on its sleeve.

While technically functional, you can see how virtually every design decision made in the game was the result of indifference and apathy.  From the uninspired and inconsistent UI design, to the counter-productive map design meshing poorly with quests, to the clumsy game economy that breaks itself incredibly quickly, it's clear the ethos behind this game's design was "let's just get it out the door so we can put it behind us and move onto the next thing".

The encapsulation of the game is a menu option to become unstuck by teleporting you the nearest flagged "good" location; a concession clearly made because it was easier than fixing the locomotion mechanics.

All in all, State of Decay 2 is the manually wrapped gas station ham sandwich on white of video games; it meets all the technical requirements to be legally classified as a video game for people looking to play a video game.

There are many, many, many zombie games to date in this era, but I find it rather funny that not many of them take the approach of a home-based strategic defense build-your-defenses kinda game. Most zombie games involve a story, such as the Last of Us and Telltale's The Walking Dead, both tell a game about a father and their adoptive daughters and the upbringing of them, being close with them, and ultimately dealing with the loss of their fathers. Or Resident Evil, a game franchise where several hot protagonists stop the concurrent evil, be it zombies, cults or viruses. This game does none of that.

This game is interesting in the sense that it feels more like what one of those Walking Dead mobile games feel like; a tower defense. The goal of the game is that objectives of the appointed leader must be completed if you want to finish the game. Along the way, side quests would be unlock where possibly some things may relate back to the characters you play as, or objectives about helping other survivors or their groups. It feels, and probably is, random encounters, which I absolutely can applaud the game for doing so. It adds a tenseness to it which sets you on your toes, making you feel unsafe at times. On one hand, you have to deliver a cure to a sick survivor of a neighboring site. The next moment, you have to rush back to your base to defend against a hoard of zombies trying to enter. The beauty of it is that your main objectives are the story. 

The environment feels big. I don't necessarily think that it's big, I think it feels big. Overall, if you want to expand the area, clearing of plague hearts are important. If an area is close to a plague heart, it means that that place is dangerous and can't be claimed. Fortunately, plague hearts can be destroyed and "harvested", although I wouldn't recommend going in alone. Recruit someone before you defeat a plague heart, and reap the spoils of war, which is usually exceptionally great loot dropped by plague hearts. Unfortunately, with the affect of plague hearts, there are plague heart zombies. While usually not a threat if attacked once, your character will get infected, and constant damage by plague heart zombies will result in said character requiring help, either to be put down, or given a cure. Fortunately, those zombies drop the exact thing to make a cure for the infected, which also makes you actively want to search out for said plague hearts. Fortunately, several vehicles and amenities are open for your use to be occupied. Use bigger and better bases with more amenities to gather resources for your growing base. Use vehicles to cover more ground in this relatively big playground.

Characters have their own traits, and most have advantages and disadvantages, but ultimately everyone and anyone can become different kinds of leaders. The traits can then be further refined when used multiple times. Characters aren't exactly expendable, and so are the tools you carry. Your weapons are the next line of defense, as you wouldn't want to be fighting zombies bare handed (unless you're Chris Redfield, and even then [b] HE [/b] has guns), so your best options are to find a weapon, and go long ranged too. Guns are great, but use them sparingly, as ammo is hard to find at times. And remember, always aim for the head. Many zombie threats are present, but the common infected is the least of your concerns. There are screamers, which alert zombies of your position. Then there are bloaters, zombies which, once killed, release a toxic gas which damages your character, and vehicles too. Ferals can be dealt easily with a headshot, just like the rest of the zombies above, but once you hear it's screech, let's hope your character gets out alive. But none compare to the fearsome juggernaut, a zombie the size of your mum (I'M SORRY, IT WAS RIGHT THERE), and hot damn is it hard to kill. 

Overall, State of Decay 2 is an awesome game which I can definitely recommend to the avid zombie apocalypse fan. Two things, however; 1. I would recommend getting it on sale, and 2. There are a few bugs, but mostly minute and ignorable. So, strap on your shotguns, wear multiple long sleeved clothes, grab the nearest and most suitable weapon you can find, and remember to always count your bullets. It's zombie hunting season.

State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is an expansive and thrilling zombie survival game that builds upon the original State of Decay 2 with significant updates and improvements. As an avid fan of the genre, I can confidently say that this game is a must-play for anyone looking for an immersive and challenging experience. Let's delve into the reasons why State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition deserves your attention:

Vast Open-World Survival: The game's open-world setting presents a dynamic and living environment filled with undead hordes, hostile human factions, and scarce resources. You'll have to manage a group of survivors, ensuring their safety, gathering supplies, and establishing a sustainable base amidst the ever-present threat of zombies. This constantly evolving world adds depth and tension, keeping players engaged and on their toes.

Meaningful Choice and Consequences: State of Decay 2 excels in offering meaningful choices, creating a sense of agency and responsibility for your actions. Decisions made during encounters with other survivors, handling resource allocation, and managing base defenses can significantly impact the overall gameplay. The game's mechanics lead to tough choices, which adds to the sense of realism and emotional investment in your community's well-being.

Cooperative Multiplayer: The Juggernaut Edition improves the cooperative multiplayer experience, allowing you to team up with friends and face the challenges of the apocalypse together. Collaborating with other players brings a new level of excitement, camaraderie, and strategic coordination, making the game even more enjoyable.

Challenging Combat and Stealth: State of Decay 2 features combat and stealth mechanics that require skill and precision. Each character has unique traits and abilities, adding an element of diversity to gameplay and making character selection crucial. Engaging in combat can be exhilarating and intense, especially when facing powerful enemies like the Juggernauts.

Base Building and Resource Management: Base management is a crucial aspect of the game, and Juggernaut Edition expands upon it with additional options and upgrades. Constructing and fortifying your base allows for better resource management, crafting, and overall survival. The need to balance supplies and secure your community keeps the game engaging and strategic.

Regular Updates and Support: The Juggernaut Edition demonstrates the developers' commitment to their player community. Regular updates and bug fixes indicate ongoing support and improvement, ensuring that the game remains enjoyable and polished.

However, despite its merits, State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is not without its flaws. Some players might find the graphics and animations to be less than cutting-edge, and occasional technical issues can disrupt the immersion. Additionally, the game's difficulty can be punishing, which might discourage players who prefer a more casual experience.

In conclusion, State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition is a standout game in the zombie survival genre, offering a vast and dynamic world, meaningful choices, cooperative multiplayer, and challenging gameplay. Its immersive mechanics and regular updates showcase a dedicated development team, making it a compelling choice for anyone seeking an authentic and gripping zombie survival experience.

The game is generally not bad, but it lacks long term motivation. Yes, I'd give a resounding thumbs up to this game. Could it do better? Well mouse deceleration needs to die as a baked in mouse sensitivity trait, so I'll be pissed if that shows up in the next game, and I hear a lot of people echoing that sentiment. What this game does well is probably that it's the right level of broad. They design wide without going so far overboard that there's no hope of them fixing this or that broken or awkward or poorly optimized aspect of gameplay (I'm looking at you, 7 days 2 die). It's design is tight and at it's foundations the gameplay mechanics are fun. I'd REALLY appreciate the ability to fortify bases rather than just build amenities in them, especially considering upon scouting a potential base location one of my guys said 'with a little fortification this could be home' or something to that effect. The zombies just pouring over walls from all directions with no way to actually effect the defenses is a pisstake when there are planks and sheet metal and tool trollies brimming with gear lying all over the place. Too easy? Tie fortification into a separate skill tree so only guys who're forty can build forts.

All that said, this did it for me during a time where I was thoroughly disenchanted with gaming and struggling to find anything that'd catch my interest, so support these guys until they sell out and then we can burn them with the rest.

Good job, Undead Labs. You've made a genuinely good game and don't think I haven't noticed you continue to update it. Glad to see Microshaft's hiring policies exhibited in their tech support department haven't carried over to their choices of game devs.

State of Decay 2, developed by Undead Labs, is a game that flawlessly combines the thrill of survival with the heart-pounding intensity of a zombie apocalypse. As a fan of the first game, I was eagerly awaiting its sequel, and I can confidently say that it exceeded all my expectations.

The game's open-world setting is a breathtakingly immersive landscape teeming with danger and opportunity. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the decaying buildings to the hauntingly beautiful landscapes, creating an atmosphere that truly feels post-apocalyptic. The graphics are stunning, bringing the world to life with vivid colors and realistic animations.

What sets State of Decay 2 apart is its emphasis on community and resource management. As you navigate through the world, you'll encounter diverse survivors, each with their own skills and personalities. Building and maintaining your base, managing resources, and making tough decisions that impact the survival of your community add a layer of strategic depth that keeps you engaged for hours on end.

The gameplay itself is a perfect balance of action and strategy. The combat mechanics are fluid and satisfying, and the variety of weapons and vehicles at your disposal makes every encounter a unique experience. Whether you choose to engage in stealthy tactics or go all-out guns blazing, the game offers ample freedom to play your way.

Multiplayer integration is another highlight of State of Decay 2. Collaborating with friends in the vast open world, sharing resources, and tackling missions together is an absolute blast. The cooperative gameplay adds an extra layer of excitement and creates memorable moments of triumph and survival.

State of Decay 2 is a masterpiece in the zombie survival genre. Its immersive world, engaging gameplay, and emphasis on community and strategy make it an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a fan of the genre or new to the series, this game is a must-play. Brace yourself for a thrilling adventure that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

If you're a fan of survival games like DayZ or Project Zomboid, you'll probably like SoD2.

The game boasts a handful of systems that play off of one another quite well. I think this game lends its strength to the fact that the developers didn't try to add [i]too many[/i] mechanics like some other survival games try to do. The combat is decent and even on standard difficulty, I found myself having to be tactical with how I approached hordes and infestations. Throw in some random events, basic faction relations, and character skill progression akin to RimWorld, and you've got dozens of hours worth of content to enjoy.

My only "complaint" about the game is that it lacks the polish of most triple AAA titles - the voice acting is a little hit or miss and the character models are... interesting.

Even so, Juggernaut Edition is well-worth the $30 price tag. I give SoD2: Juggernaut Edition a solid 8.5/10!

Really enjoyed State of Decay 1 but felt like it was a prototype. Played this a lot on Game Pass soonish after release and felt it was more of the same at that point, with a bit more polish. I love zombies, so always enjoyed it but after completing my community goals found little reason to go back. The latest update has completely changed how the game feels, I really love how Plague Hearts are handled now, there's much more reason to be stealthy, even on lower difficulties, as entering Plague territory now comes with a risk you'll unleash total hell upon your base. It's really comes leaps and bounds since release and the inclusion of the map from the first game is very nostalgic for those of us who have followed along since before the first game came out. This is one of the few experiences that really makes you feel like you're surviving after the end of the world (besides Zomboid, which can be a little intense with how realistic it is) Very granular difficulty options are highly welcome, making it very accessible! Highly recommend!

Surviving the Undead with Mixed Results

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐½

State of Decay 2 Juggernaut Edition presents an ambitious open-world zombie survival experience that has its fair share of strengths and weaknesses. Undead Labs has made notable improvements with the Juggernaut Edition, but a few persistent issues prevent it from reaching its full potential.

One of the standout features of State of Decay 2 is its focus on community and resource management. As a player, you are responsible for building and maintaining a group of survivors, each with their own strengths, weaknesses, and personal goals. The need to scavenge for supplies, fortify your base, and make tough decisions regarding the survival of your community adds depth and urgency to the gameplay.

The Juggernaut Edition brings several enhancements to the game, including improved graphics, bug fixes, and additional content. The updated visuals, while not groundbreaking, offer a noticeable improvement over the original release, making the post-apocalyptic world more immersive. The inclusion of all previously released DLC and expansion packs provides extra missions and challenges to extend the gameplay experience.

However, despite these improvements, State of Decay 2 still suffers from some technical issues and repetitive gameplay elements. The game's performance can be inconsistent, with occasional frame rate drops and glitches that can disrupt the immersion. The combat mechanics, while serviceable, lack depth and can feel repetitive after a while. The missions and objectives also tend to follow a predictable formula, leading to a sense of repetition in the overall gameplay loop.

The multiplayer aspect of State of Decay 2 adds an interesting dynamic, allowing players to team up with friends or other survivors online. Cooperative play brings a sense of camaraderie and shared responsibility, making the experience more enjoyable. However, the lack of meaningful player interaction and limited cooperative activities can leave the multiplayer experience feeling somewhat shallow.

On the positive side, the game world of State of Decay 2 is expansive and diverse, with multiple maps to explore and scavenge. Each area has its unique challenges and resources, encouraging players to venture out and discover new locations. The unpredictable nature of the game's AI-controlled survivor NPCs and the emergent events that occur throughout the world add a sense of realism and unpredictability to the survival experience.

Overall, State of Decay 2 Juggernaut Edition is a mixed bag. While it offers an engaging survival concept, solid multiplayer options, and some improvements over the original release, it falls short in certain areas. Technical issues, repetitive gameplay elements, and a lack of depth in combat mechanics hold it back from achieving greatness.

If you're a fan of the zombie survival genre and enjoy managing resources and building a community, State of Decay 2 Juggernaut Edition can provide hours of enjoyable gameplay. However, if you're seeking a more polished and refined experience, you may find yourself frustrated by its shortcomings.

"Kotaku interviewed 12 current and former employees for this article, all of whom requested anonymity because they feared sharing their concerns publicly would doom their careers in the video game industry. Many felt very positive about certain aspects of the studio. A few said it still has room to improve but has overall been a very good place to work. Most considered the last few years since the acquisition a period of crisis, and are worried management hasn’t learned the right lessons.

At first, some employees were worried the Microsoft acquisition would change the indie studio for the worse. Now they worry the $2 trillion company’s incredibly “hands-off” approach allowed dysfunction to fester, leaving some of the studio’s more vulnerable employees to fend for themselves. As one former developer put it, “We were afraid they would come in and change our culture but our collapse came from within, and we could have used [Microsoft’s] help.”

I feel I've gotten everything I could of this game. I played the crap out of it and played a couple games on the harder difficulties. Blood Plague Ferals are the stuff of nightmares! The devs are constantly updating this game and I may come back down the road. They took State of Decay 1 and really improved on things. If the base game isn't enough, there is a decent modding scene for the game as well which adds some longevity to it before you get bored. I sunk 138 hours into it so I'd say you could get your moneys worth. There's some good stories to follow, one of them returns you to Trumbull Valley from the first game. Combat is pretty entertaining when you get your people fully trained up. You'll feel like a zombie terminator, but be careful because there are new zombies in the form of blood plague, which can infect and turn your survivors. Always have an escape plan and know when to bail and live to fight another day. There are several maps to play on which is a big improvement from the old game's single map. Each map has multiple bases that you can occupy, some are better then others. Each map has unique buildings that enhance your community in a certain way, that can be occupied as an outpost. Speaking of which. Outposts are back and recently, the devs added back the ability for outposts to take out hoards in their influence area. One cool feature is cars can be repaired and upgraded into apocalypse versions with armor. 

I could go on but the tldr version is that SOD 2 is a worthy successor to SOD 1 and well worth your time.

It is probably one of the best zombie games i've ever played. Now, of course there are cons to it as well.
The maps are good and fun to explore, each map containing different types of bases and outposts you can get. The game is pretty solid, but theres a few things to keep in mind:

- Zombies: There are quite a lot of zombies in the game, and they are good. The more noise you make, the more zombies you will bring to your base. However, the zombies will hardly focus any other enemies than you. Sometimes you will encounter hostile NPCs in game (usually a group of 3) and most of the times the zombies won't even do anything to them, even if they are making way more noise than you in that moment.

- Multiplayer: One of the main issues i have with this game is how the multiplayer works in it. It is very "limited". Unfortunately if you don't have solo progress, and you are joining a friend's base, you will be limited to do things in the multiplayer. For an example, if your base doesn't have an infirmary, that means your characters will basically never heal, even if the person you are playing with has an infirmary in their base (doesn't matter if its upgraded or not either). Map exploration is also limited.

- The combat: Combat in this game is pretty fun, there are a lot of different weapons in it (for both melee and ranged weapons). However, keep in mind that you can't cancel combat actions, and most of them always play an animation, leaving you to get hit by the other zombies around you and there's nothing to do about it.

- Quests: There aren't a lot of "side quests" in this game so most of them end up getting repetitive after just a few hours of gameplay, so don't expect a lot of different events and things to do in them all the time. It's a similar thing for the main quests, but they will change depending on which leader character type you have in your base.

- Skills: There are 4 main skills (they are always the same) however there are a lot of different "extra" skills you can get. Some of those skills are mostly useless, and some are pretty good. You can learn those skills by reading the books you may find while exploring, or sometimes survivors will already have one of those skills.

Overall, its a good game and i love it, if you don't mind the few issues it has, it is quite enjoyable.

Title: Echoes of Decay: The Undead Perspective

Once upon a time, amidst the desolate landscape of Trumbull County, there existed a world unseen by the living, where the undead roamed in search of sustenance. From the perspective of a lowly zombie, this tale weaves a story of hunger, decay, and unrelenting survival.

In the relentless pursuit of their insatiable appetites, the zombies stumbled through the ravaged remnants of what was once a thriving human society. The world, a playground of decay and ruin, served as a somber backdrop to their existence. With vacant eyes and an unquenchable hunger gnawing at their decaying flesh, these creatures forged ahead, their collective moans creating a haunting symphony.

As night fell, the world of State of Decay 2 transformed into an eerie abyss, where shadows danced and the undead found solace in their ceaseless existence. The moon cast a pale glow upon the desolation, guiding the way for these lost souls. It was in the darkness that their primal instincts took hold, driving them towards the flickering lights that signified the presence of the living.

Amidst the relentless pursuit of survivors, the zombies faced numerous obstacles. Barricades, traps, and fortifications erected by the living posed challenges to their insidious advances. It was a game of cat and mouse, where the undead sought to breach the defenses of the living, craving the taste of warm, pulsating flesh.

But not all zombies were created equal. Some, cursed with decayed limbs or plagued by slower reflexes, found themselves at a disadvantage in this bleak world. They lingered on the fringes, mere spectators to the dance of survival. It was a hierarchy of sorts, where the strongest and fastest reigned supreme, their relentless pursuit posing a constant threat to the fragile existence of the living.

Occasionally, amidst the chaos, the zombies would face unexpected opposition. Survivor groups, armed to the teeth and fortified in enclaves, fought tooth and nail to preserve their humanity. These encounters were brutal, a clash between the unfeeling undead and the desperate resilience of the living. The clash of steel and the deafening roars of gunfire punctuated the air, creating a symphony of violence.

Despite their undying hunger, the zombies of State of Decay 2 were trapped in a perpetual cycle of futility. They sought the sustenance that could never truly satisfy them, condemned to roam an unforgiving world that mirrored their own existence. Their existence, devoid of purpose or redemption, served as a reminder of the horrors that befell humanity.

And so, as the sun rose once more, painting the sky with hues of orange and pink, the zombies retreated into the shadows, waiting for the night to fall once more. In their twisted existence, they remained a constant threat, a chilling reminder that even in a state of decay, there was a dark beauty to be found in the twisted landscapes of Trumbull County.

Has some peculiar quirks but so do most great games. Between it's three game modes there's something for everyone. Play it one difficulty harder than you're comfortable with and you'll have a great time.

I liked the concept of State of Decay, but felt that the game was too monotonous and grindy for my taste. Hoped that State of Decay 2 would improve in that sense. Well... let me put it this way, I spent 53 minutes with the game whereas the net playtime was around 35-40 minutes.

During this time I:

- Had to spend like 5 minutes resetting my Xbox Live account, setting up my appearance over Live and whatever. No Xbox Live, you won't play that game, in 2021.
- Encountered a handful of bugs and glitches, e.g. zombies stucking in ladders and whatever. None of those were deal breaker, but for the love of god, it's been two and half years after release. Yet another reason to not buy games at full price anymore.
- Started the campaign, but realized that the night time is exactly double (60 minutes) of the day time (30 minutes). Now, night time is fucking dark, not impossible to navigate, but for me it's pretty annoying. I don't know whether it tries to promote stealth (which feels like a drag to me, gameplay wise), or increase tension (not working, it increases frustration), but I find it fucking annoying. There is no chance to sleep or fast forward time, so I'm going to refund.

PS: Dear @devs, if you want to learn how not to fuck up day/night cycles, then play Dying Light. It actually encourages players to go out during nighttime, but never forces them. Not like your shitty system.

A surprising good take on zombie survival, open world game.

**Good
- Nice, Large Maps that are fun to explore, and scavenge,
- Both ranged and melee combat feels good,
- Mostly very good performance (some weird texture flicker happens sometimes)
- Game has a soft stamina system so you have a reason to cycle characters,
- Driving feels good and has a nice selection of cars,


**Bad
- Story isn't exactly great,
- All non story missions have hidden timers - its often impossible to get all done, before other expire,
- Non story missions can get very spammy every time you load the game, they can get really annoying if you just want to go and do something on your own,
- Can only have bases in fixed locations and bases have fixed buildings and slots available. You can decide what to build in slots but you cannot expand or fortify bases more,
- Outpost feel stupid - you claim them and they magically produce resources, you don't even have to assign any workforce
- The fact that you have unlocked doors around your base which zeds can just open is a tad silly...

I have to say, this game is way over hyped. I hear so many reviewers rave about how good of a zombie game this is yet I can not for the life of me have fun with it. The game loop goes as follows:  Find a base > Find some supplies > Craft explosives > Find plague heart > clear map of plague hearts > move on to a new map scenario. Once you've finished your first map, you're allowed to "legacy" a character which I still have no idea what it does. That game mechanic is not really explained in game. You then take your community you built into a new map, and do the same thing over again. There are also timed missions in the game. Some have an invisible timer on them. You should never pressure your players into a feeling of racing against the clock. I thought we learned this back with Dead Rising. Your AI team mates never understand what you're trying to do. I remember once I was trying to place C4 on a plague heart before it started spewing out zombies and my AI team mate looks over, and starts shooting it, activating the horde. Like come on, what horrible AI. Over all, this game is like a 6.5/10 would not recommend.

If you're looking for a zombie survival game that offers a lot of freedom and challenge, you might want to check out State of Decay 2. It's a sandbox-style RPG where you can switch between different survivors, build your own base, scavenge for resources, and fight off hordes of undead. You can also play with your friends online and help each other out. State of Decay 2 is not a perfect game, though. It has some bugs and graphical issues that can be annoying. But if you can look past them, you'll find a fun and addictive game that will keep you on your toes.

State of Decay 2, developed by Undead Labs, is an open-world survival game set in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by zombies. As the follow-up to the original State of Decay, this highly anticipated sequel promises an even more immersive and expansive experience. With a focus on community-building, resource management, and strategic survival, State of Decay 2 offers a unique take on the zombie survival genre.

One of the standout features of State of Decay 2 is its emphasis on community dynamics. Players are not just responsible for their own survival but also for managing and protecting a group of survivors. Each survivor has their own set of skills, strengths, and weaknesses, making the process of building and maintaining a diverse community both challenging and engaging. This aspect adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, as players must make tough decisions to ensure the survival of their community members.

The game world in State of Decay 2 is vast and varied, offering different locations to explore, each with its own resources and challenges. From small towns to military bases, the environments are well-crafted and help create a sense of realism. Scavenging for supplies, fortifying bases, and venturing out into the dangerous world to complete missions all contribute to the immersive experience.

State of Decay 2 features a comprehensive resource management system. Food, medicine, fuel, and ammunition are all vital for the survival of your community, and it's your responsibility to gather and distribute these resources wisely. This adds a constant sense of urgency and keeps players engaged in the struggle for survival. However, the resource management mechanics can sometimes feel a bit overwhelming, and the game could benefit from improved user interface and more intuitive controls in this regard.

The combat mechanics in State of Decay 2 are satisfying and realistic. Engaging in melee combat or utilizing firearms against hordes of zombies can be intense and thrilling. However, the combat system could benefit from a bit more depth and variety, as it can feel repetitive during extended play sessions. Additionally, the enemy AI could be more challenging and varied to keep players on their toes.

Graphically, State of Decay 2 delivers a mixed experience. While the environments and character models are well-designed, some technical issues, such as occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-ins, can detract from the overall visual quality. However, these minor graphical flaws do not significantly impact the gameplay experience.

One of the major highlights of State of Decay 2 is its cooperative multiplayer mode. Playing with friends and working together to survive and thrive in the post-apocalyptic world greatly enhances the overall experience. The multiplayer mode allows for shared resources, strategic planning, and cooperative combat, adding an extra layer of excitement and camaraderie.

In conclusion, State of Decay 2 offers a compelling and immersive survival experience with its emphasis on community-building and resource management. While the game has its share of technical issues and could benefit from some gameplay refinements, it provides an engaging and challenging journey in a post-apocalyptic world. Whether playing solo or with friends, fans of the genre will find a lot to enjoy in this zombie-infested adventure.

State of Decay 2 while is initially pretty engaging eventually runs into mediocrity thanks to the raw repetition of things  but it'll take you quite awhile to get to that point. State of Decay 2 on the right difficulty will leave you with dramatic scrambles to deal with hordes of zombies or special zombies if you manage things poorly or do not bring the needed supplies to deal with it and absolute success with reasonable planning and patience. It's a really solid zombie open world shooter if you're into that thing.

The biggest standout feature is the community system, which is new as well as having multiple maps to play on. The character generation is fairly big with different survivors having different sets of skills that they can bring to your base, meaning that they aren't divorced completely from your base like they kinda were in the first SOD. Each base has it's ups and downs, even if it seems like a straight upgrade. Some bigger bases are just frankly utterly terrible for dispatching hordes and juggernauts, they'll flood in and everything turns into a bloodbath. The key is picking the one that has many good spots for survivors to dispatch zombies while having key faculties that help manage your community. The upgrades aren't as essential as they seem, some quests and outposts you can setup in the openworld provide for the spaces in your base development you cannot fill. It's just way way way way better than the original State of Decay, which was a very annoying system to deal with. 

Another big part is the dynamic nature of the game as a sandbox. Survivors are generated randomly, whole other communities are randomly generated too. The game invites you to make your own player driven stories through those interactions often finally peaking with a designated leader and their ultimate goal for the community. This is essentially your endgame. It's a great way of pacing the game out a little and you get bonuses for completing a "community" every time you do this. Then you can take survivors from your current playthrough and save them for future playthroughs, so if you like that mechanic guy who you saved from a juggernaut and he learnt to build all your badass cars for you and you want him to come along for another ride? You can totally do that. It's pretty flexible and adds a level of meta progression that grows stronger with you being invested emotionally and gameplay wise. It's generally a pretty fun system.

The problems with this system is repetition, you will start to see the same sort of events happen over and over around your third playthrough. The community's overall goal and that questline of sorts rarely changes. It always sorta rolls out the same way which doesn't hurt too bad because most of the time your community progression is built towards making the area you are in safer from plague hearts (essentially red zombie disease) first and foremost. Be it through allying yourself with other communities and trading for supplies or them directly assisting with dispatching them. 

The moment to moment gameplay isn't spectacular, especially as other third person shooters go but it's serviceable. There are a looooot of guns. A lot of weapons. There is a lot of loot to collect and find. If you like grabbing everything in a building that isn't nailed down, this might be your game. Zombies are fairly intense to fight as well, they aren't pushovers especially on your own. If you're on a weak character and the difficulty is high, watch your ass because it won't take much to kill you. If a feral shows up and you're low on health? Your character is dead. The game appreciates stealth chiefly of all but it has the drawback of being a slow way to play the game and frankly kinda boring even if it's a really strong way to play. Go in guns blazing, slashing everything. It's a zombie game after alll! 

A short piece of coop, it's a really flawed unfun system that i am surprised is this halfbaked. It's not good. I hope to see maybe coop communities (maybe set it up similar to stardew valley?) in a third game out of Undead Labs because the sheer amount that you are locked out of doing as a coop partner is aloooooot. It's really not great. Don't get this as a coop game.

I think there is a lot here in State of Decay 2 to enjoy, not for as long as other games but it's an immensely fun journey if you're the right person for it. The foundation here is a lot stronger than SOD1 and i can see this evolving into something really awesome if they nailed out the game's design issues. Think 7 Days to Die but you're managing a whole group of survivors, your friends included. That would be insanely awesome. Undead Labs has put a lot of effort into the post-release content and understanding what people want from this game. I can't recommend this game if you're obviously lukewarm on the genre or open world games in general but if you are then you're gonna have fun for at least 10-30 hours. That's a good sell for a game pass game.

[h1]【[i]State of Decay 2[/i] Review】[/h1]

[i]State of Decay 2[/i] is the sequel to the zombie action/RPG/Community manager title, sporting tighter controls, more maps, and additional activities.

I initially bounced off of it the first time through (and I was an AVID SoD1 fan), but 33 updates later, this one finally hews closer to what made the original fun, in my eyes.

[b][u]"Hey…I'm young, quick, and I got a big ass wrench! What could go wrong?"[/u][/b]
+[i]More Maps+O.G. Trumbull[/i]
4 new towns + Trumbull Valley w/a facelift are available for you to pillage. Each different from the last, and with the inclusion of Forever Communities, are able to continue to game with your favorites for as long as the enjoyment of that lasts.

+[i]Co-Op[/i]
Definitely has it's limitations, and is not a friend taking over a member of your community, nor is it their community neighboring yours on the same map. It's more like a member of their choosing from their community guest starring in an episode of yours. There is a tether, but I did not find it as constricting as the concept would imply - I simply don't feel the need of inviting someone into my world and being on the other side of the map from them.

+[i]More Combat Options[/i]
Tons more than the first, with different takedowns and fatalities, as well as weapons (both melee and firearms). Different character traits yield different combat options, and even further tweaked with choosing specializations.

+[i]Human Enemies[/i]
I was a little shocked when a neighboring enclave heel-turned on me. Then I was delighted. If not properly disposed, be prepared to deal with their undead remains.

+[i]Defining a Leader[/i]
Being able to define a leader within the community further helps you to decide how you will play. Clearing the game with different leaders on different setting nets you "Boons" - basically community modifiers that you can use on restarts to further enhance gameplay. Each leader has a path with quests and an ending (so freaking lame - no spoiler but keep expectations super low-to-no). 

+[i]Soundtrack[/i]
Beautiful soundtrack. The music compliments the scenery well, be it quiet gentle lilting tones as you serenely scavenge, or more tempered beats as the action around you reaches a crescendo. A true standout in overall direction of this title.

+[i]33 Updates Later[/i]
I was surprised to see that this game has been updated as often as it has. Meaningful, game-changing/enhancing updates, too! As well as bounties and cosmetics. Far more support than the first title, and having bounced off it initially, totally a better product for it.

[b][u]SoD OFF[/u][/b]
-[i]Lack of Character Creation[/i]
Nothing. Nada. Zip. Zilch. The big goose egg. Thank Heilos for the community manager, so you can get to sorta create your own. But even then, it's cumbersome.

My main community is with characters customized from [i]Evil Dead[/i], and it is freakin' groovy.

-[i]Lack of Meaningful Building[/i]
I loathe the base-building in this one. Something about it just does not look as good as they did in the first. Also, can't barricade windows? I found the base-building in this title to be more restricted than the first, and that's at odds of the momentum of sequels.

-[i]Far TOO Far FOV without DutchGuyMike's Combat FOV Mod[/i]
It looks like [i]Dragon's Age[/i], but it isn't. It is the worst thing ever. The zoom is real. Thankfully, there is a mod that more than amends this - check out DutchGuyMike's Combat FOV mod on SoD2 Nexus.

-[i]Static/Eyerolling Freak Spawns[/i]
The winding road on Providence? Set your watch to a feral being there. Sometimes, 2 juggernauts "because difficulty". When it's not natural to the world, and seems like it's triggered per a spreadsheet, it really makes it hard to feel organic. Somehow, SoD1 did it better. They REALLY need something like L4D's A.I. director.

-[i]Ambient Goals Frequency[/i]
It's great there's a lot to do! But it pops so frequently, as soon as you log in, that it is a bit maddening. It's one thing to say "Well, it's the apocalypse"! But it feels more relative to the issue mentioned above. At least an option to lessen the frequency would be nice, especially on enclaves you recently assisted.

-[i]Community Animation Bug -STILL-[/i]
There is a bug that has been around that does not trigger the standard animations for your community (tinkering at stations, checking crops, etc). Instead, everyone wiggles their legs in-place like they all have to go poop right now. It's distracting, to say the least, and makes you not really want to hang around home when you realize that it does not stop. Ever.

-[i]Highlighted Containers[/i]
I do not like that there is not an option available to disable containers being highlighted. When it's dark, it looks so goofy to see glossy white flashes on objects.

-[i]Low Hope for[/i] State of Decay 3
I just don't have hope for SoD3. In addition to seeing some incongruent design philosophies here, the trailer presentation and the setting being in winter made me think of [i]Wasteland 3[/i]. And [i]Wasteland 3[/i] was terrible. Also, no further news has been given, so it's either super awesome! Or super NAWsome.

I hope it means seasons, as you do notice the lack of any weather in this title. But I am not confident this team is learned/disciplined enough to make that.

Also, the inclusion of animals this late into the series is narratively spurious. I initially got a very moral finger-wagging by the art director on the UL forum for even hinting at having zombie children in the first game (though there are playgrounds and swingsets in backyards), but zombie deers are different.🙄

[b][u]TL;DuuuuRRRRRRR:[/u][/b]
I find [i]State of Decay 2[/i] more enjoyable now than when it first released (now more enjoyable than even SoD1) and if you're just looking for long-term monster mashing, this is a pretty safe bet, albeit the caveats mentioned above.

With SoD3 still off in the future, and with what fleeting news we've seen - [i]State of Decay 2[/i] may be the best arcade-y community manager we'll get. And that's just fine, cos it's really good!

I’ll start with the cons:

- Zombies are more an annoyance than a challenge or fun. And affects the pace of the game too much in a negative way.
- Stop with the radio please.
- Quest system is poor. And it is a shame that side quests needs to pop up again every time you restart the game. Also, sometimes you lose a quest by changing characters and this is just not a good system.
- Combat against humans are bad, just bad. This game would be hugely better if exchanging gun fights were better.
- It is a sandbox, I know, but the way you interact with stories should be overhauled in the next SOD.

[code]These are problems that has been brought by the previous SOC game and I hope they address all this to the next SOD because this franchise has a huge potential.[/code]

[h1]Leaving the rant behind, let’s point out the good stuff:[/h1]

+ SOC2 is unique. It is a mix of sandbox survival and community management in a certain casual triple A experience with in depth systems and mechanics that makes this game something else. Definitely my favourite “Xbox exclusive” so far.
+ The constant updates and upgrades are a common thing nowadays, even so  it’s impressive how the devs are still adding stuff, upgrading and rebalancing the game.
+ The DLC Homecoming is an upgrade for those looking for a more story driven experience - without losing the sandbox uniqueness of the game. 
+ Replayability.

Conclusion:

The sandbox experience as a main focus is the main selling point for me. No drama and cinematographic bu11sh1t. No save the world bu11sh1t. There is no hero and death is permanent. 

Community managing is something I would like to see in other open world experiences as well. 

[code]Enough of construction simulator on survival games, please, lol. Just follow what SOC2 does, please - and improve upon that, of course.[/code] 

If you have never played give it a try - or have played before but a long time ago, give it another try. The game has its problems but it is a delicious casual experience without losing deepness for those who enjoy a bit more. 

Looking forward to SOC 3.

Despite it's flaws and bugs, the game is a pretty good zombie survival game that emphasizes on survival, base building and community building, whether solo or in co-op, you can navigate through 5 different maps and 5 different difficulties with an option to customize.  It's definitely a labor of love for the developers as they still keep on improving upon the game adding new aspects to the gameplay that keeps the game fresh.  

Now there will be a lot of people crapping on the co-op aspect of the game.  Is it perfect?  No it's not, but it's definitely playable between friends and quite enjoyable.  The co-cop is limited to having a host game and friends/other players joining the host game to help out with his map.  The reason for this is mostly because the devs want the game to be playable still in multiplayer in the future without the need of servers.  There is a tether system in place so that visiting players cannot wander too far from the host since the host is hosting the game on his PC, this is in place so that it won't strain the system rendering the open world map.  Hopefully this review helps with people who are interested in the multiplayer aspect of the game.

Don't be fooled; the game trailer doesn't tell the whole story. When I saw the game trailer, I immediately bought it. But what I didn't know is that when you play multiplayer or coop with friends, you'll see that you can't heal your people in the base; only the host server can heal his own people. While collecting resources for your community, stats will increase only for the player who is on the host's server. For other players, it will remain the same until they run out of food or any other resources. The only way is for the other player to go to his server and look for resources, and when he fills up the stats, he will return to a friend's server every time after a while. In the end, I asked for a refund, but they didn't accept it.

I sent a new recruit, Goat, to do a job for another enclave. For experience, of course. Unfortunately, the job carried him to an active plague heart, and a simple bodyguard mission turned into a hellscape of freaks and plague zombies. The client died, and Goat ran out of medicine and bullets, blew up his car while trying to escape, and fled down the street on foot with only a sliver of health and stamina, a horde of zombies on his heels.

By sheer luck, he found another vehicle abandoned in a residential driveway. The zombies were so close that they swarmed the vehicle as soon as he got in. A screamer on the nearby road shattered all the glass as he pulled away, and the rest smashed the hood and ripped off all the doors. He barely managed to shake them off and GTFO before they wrecked his new ride.

Goat made it home, nearly dead, unable to walk upright, and less than five minutes remaining on his plague infection timer. The crew had exactly one cure in storage, so he survived.

I love this game.

CON:

- Sometimes janky as hell.

- I've had multiple missions break, one of which made the main story impossible to finish even after multiple restarts.

- The game always spawns zombies behind you in combat, even if you've meticulously cleared the surrounding area.

- On Dread difficulty and higher, the zombie spawns are excessive—e.g. dozens of zombies at a time continuously spawning, even after I've already killed dozens or hundreds. There's no break. There are times when I literally can't speak with relevant mission NPCs, because the zombie spawns won't stop and let combat end. I usually have to quit the game and redo the mission when this happens.

- Partial mission progress is not saved, a design flaw which truly rears its ugly head when jank breaks the game. Missions also seem to be kind of random, so any mission you have to quit might never come up again. This hasn't happened to me a lot, but it has happened more than once.

- Vehicle physics are awful, like constantly skidding on ice. I got used to it, but man....

- Hit detection in melee can be iffy. Certain swings at certain times will just ghost through zombies.

- Human enemies can be too resilient. I ran out of ammo putting a guy down seven or eight times. He kept getting up, even when I mag-dumped his skull while he was in the "help me" state.

- Low number of character models and voices, so you're bound to wind up with repeats and sometimes outright clones.

- Multiplayer can be fun, but the guest player is just a hired gun for the host. You can't have your community and your friend's community operating on the same map, nor can you actually join someone else's community.

- Higher difficulty settings work in part by making resources very rare, by making vehicles very fragile, and by making base management very expensive. With corresponding increases in zombie strength and combat difficulty, Dread mode and beyond started to feel less satisfying to me. You get less for doing more.

You can set difficulty for Combat, Community (base building) and Map separately. However, turning any slider down will reduce your achievement awards to that level, which is obnoxious. I don't mind massive hordes of infected freaks who all hit like Thanos, but I don't want my armored van to blow up because I backed into a wooden fence.

On the other hand....

PRO:

+ For reasons mentioned previously, the game is wildly addictive.

+ Combat is fun, with good weapon variety. Gunplay is simplistic (crosshair only, no ADS), but has nice oomph. Melee is brutal and well-animated. Flanked zombies can be grabbed/assassinated.

+ Stuff to kill—you've got regular zombies, plague zombies, several types of freaks (screamer, feral, bloater, juggernaut), plague versions of the freaks, and also living humans with clubs, blades and firearms.

+ Radio system for calling in vehicles, medical advice, artillery strikes and other services based on your outposts and relationships with other factions.

+ Nice clean interface.

+ Legacy pool that lets you move characters between communities.

+ Permadeath. Given that some deaths result from glitches and bugs, this isn't always a good thing, but I'd rather have it than not.

+ Several maps, each a few kilometers square and representing a rural town. There's high replay value.

+ With exception to explosive fender benders and oppressive resource scarcity, higher difficulty settings make the game pretty challenging.

+ I haven't completed the Heartland story mode yet, but the organic "stories" than arise in the main campaign are enough to get me invested in my characters. It reminds me of Kenshi, which is also janky, and one of my favorite games of all time.

State of Decay 2 is highly recommended, and a no-brainer on sale.

What an absolutely lovely game. There are some issues and limitations of what you can do in the open world, but all in all the game excels in areas where many others fail. The replayability, sound design and combat is perfectly balanced, even though some of the quests can get a bit repetitive.

Here are just a few of the things I like:

* Online co-op: to play with a friend is awesome, and they can jump in whenever you need a helping hand.
* The continued support by the developer: Even after so many years the updates keep coming with new and improved content. 
* Reasonable launch price: with a 30 dollar price tag you cant complain for what you get.
* Character deaths matter: after investing in a favorite character and upgrading them it really stings when they die. This just makes it more fun since all your actions matter.
* Friendly and supportive community: when asking for help you find a happy group of players willing to assist, and the same goes for the games support team.

Amazing zombie survival game where you get to feel like you're actually making your own decisions :)
Great game. Be careful letting strangers in your session. Losing a survivor to a griefer is brutal.

if you like stabbing or shooting a never ending stream of zombies; you will probably like this game.

yes there are some annoyances like the sometimes dorky AI followers but their behavior is very predictable so it can be overcome by simply adjusting to their behavior. for example, it happens a lot that when i enter into a building to clear it of zombies, the AI follower will run right through me to attack a zombie which is inside the building. after that happening for a bunch of times, i just let it happen or simply avoid taking a follower with me. but they can be great "gear mules" so i tend to take one of them with me.

overall though, i think this game deserves my money. there is a clear attention to detail and the game perform well although i get the dreaded Unreal Engine stutters. but other than that, it runs great.

my gripes; VERY few inventory slots on characters and vehicles. i had to get a mod for increased vehicle storage because there are too few slots even on the huge trucks. yes there are skills for improving the character slot count but that can only be had with certain types of skills. i dislike that.

i like the fact that this game allow a friend to join you in your offline campaign. there is plenty of fun to be had that way.

overall, this game has some very satisfying aspects which gets me to come back and play again. yes i have my gripes but those are mostly subjective things.

the good:
- MANY weapons available. it is a huge list. anything from .22 to .50 caliber. all sorts of variations and even classic weapons like WW2 types and repeater rifles. i think it is very likely that anyone will find a weapon they like a lot.
- the selection of vehicles. although the driving is a bit wonky, even with controller. the performance also seems a bit off in comparison to the RPM. some cars are very dramatic in terms of sound although they are still very slow.
- the multiple ways of killing a zombie. it can be done quietly or 100% gore mode. i like that.
- the UI works very well and right clicking to exit is very useful.
- weapon sounds. there is a clear difference between the guns and the sounds make sense to me.
- graphics are decent. at ultra i must say. anything lower than that will quickly turn it into something bleak.

the bad;
- weapons wear too fast for my taste.
- character inventory too small.
- character needs rest too quickly.
- friendlies are crying for help too often and they will go away too quickly when they are ignored ( even when there is good reason for it )
- community AI characters will constantly bump into each other in some bases where the space is less. accompanied by a very annoying UGH sound.
- the amount of AI voices is limited, so it will absolutely happen that a character with completely different looks will have the same voice. i understand that hiring more voice actors is costly and complex though.
- a lot of game mechanics are never explained so it is easy to miss out on some functionality until it is discovered by accident. a proper tutorial ( at user request ) would be nice.
- NEVER take a nice car to the last legacy mission. you WILL lose it. i found that out the hard way damn it!
- too much repetitive character dialogue that gets old too quickly.
- there is probably lots more to complain about but i will leave it for now.

The game is really great for solo gameplay. The concept of finding ressource trought a world ravaged by the apocalypse is pretty fun, I recommend the game. Since there's a lot too do. Obviously it is kind of repetitive since well your pretty much always looting, fighting or destroying plague's heart. In the end the game is worth it with the daybreak mod which allow you too buy some member of the red talon team for your community. The worst thing about the game in my opinion is definietly multiplayer. If you join someone else, you basically risk your character's life for nearly no reward... as the host get most of the best (which is kind of normal but instead could just make it so both player get reward. The players that are not the host cannot walk too far away from the host... which is kind of stupid since it makes it annoying when your trying too loot a place or even run away from a horde (or any other type of threat). Basically , the multiplayer mode is kinda nice but could be WAY better in any term of optimization such as making it possible too have equal loot and not being limited in where you are going on the map. It could also be nice too add the option too let a player go trough my base's storage as when someone joins you they need too use their own ressource... adding on the fact they don't get as much ressource as they would in their own game.. so unless you just wanna play for fun (or help your friend if you already play the game or anything) then multiplayer is really not worth... so yeah. the game is really good, great concept, good looking graphic, run pretty well on my pc (it doesnt struggle much which is good), and as a lot of content which is nice. so yeah I recommend the game but avoid buying it if it's only too play with your friend (that said, it is my opinion so maybe you would love it even if it'S only to play with your friends).

Great fun game. It certainly feels a bit 'last-gen' in terms of its scope, and its co-op play is play fun but is also a bit limited as you only 'help' the host player and don't actually get to properly interact with the story or base locations of a game that you join.
The melee combat is slick, but I've lost count of the number of times I've pressed 'E' to perform a take-down of a zombie, only to open or close a door instead, or start a chat with an NPC.
Gun-play is also really good, although the guns don't feel hugely different from one-another with a .22 calibre pistol just as likely to pop the head off of a zombie as a .50 cal.
The game does start to get repetitive faster than I would like, even when playing as different leader types, there is not a huge variation in the game. Base building is a pre-fab arrangement with only minor variations each base location.
This review is probably more negative sounding than it should be...SOD2 is a worthy purchase, especially if you can pick it up on sale like I did.

If you don't do the "quests" for other enclaves they leave...honestly wish they weren't in the game to begin with and you got survivors another way.  I just want to loot, kill zombies, and build up my base/team, not baby sit other guys that can't survive on their own.  Still a great game but can definitely tell why it isn't worth a $60 price tag.

I spent hours and hours on this game; there were so many good moments, so many angry moments, and so many rage moments. Sometimes you lose your main character because you made some stupid mistake or the AI made a stupid decision, sometimes you get plague and think, "yea I can loot one more house and head back.".... no... u can not. On harder difficulties, it's literally a nightmare, I played my fair share of games, but I have to admit that SoD2 on lethal is one of the hardest playthroughs I've ever done.

Gameplay is very good, long lasting, addictive, and repetitive without falling into stereotypes.
Graphics are fine, and I cannot say many bad things (a few bugs here and there)

AI (as mentioned above) is one thing that has made me rage quit it a few times in the past (I hardy ever RQ) as characters dying cuz stupid mistake or decision, progress lost, items lost, but most importantly, memeber of the community is gone (best if your most skilled person dies). However, it didn't happen very often, so it was bearable. And ofc it's not the end, but a stepback (a long one tho)

Overall, I would give SoD2 8,5/10 as I like challenges (plenty here) and zombie games, and this is definitely one of my favorites next to 7DTD, Zomboid, and Dying Light.
One thing that's shame is that there is no "normal" co-op here, only helping someone else in their save and progress. Otherwise, it is definitely worth those few bucks. Grab the Juggernaut edition while you are at it, and you are good to go. Show us all how you survive (often for a few weeks) in this blood soaked zombie world. oh and I forgot to mention, blood plague ---> run home. Trust me, I was there.. and no, I did not make it to the car, nearest outpost, or a base, and neither will you.

PS: I had a pause with SoD2 for a year but came back for update 33, definitely looking forward to those new mechanics with plague hearts.
PSS: One advice, leave your followers at home, they are more in the way then help + they can die too :) (and they will)

Edit: 27h later, lethal is cancer AF
Its just fun. Bust up some zombies and build up a little team/base.

I had played 1500 hours of this game, it speaks volumes on how much this game meant to me.

I was a Reddit Moderator for a year for this game, attained Hero role on the official Discord server, got to know a few of its biggest Youtubers especially Git Gud Fox, and I was a wiki editor for the game as well.

Thank you, SOD2. You'll have a special place in my memories now that I move on to other priorities. I just hope Undead Labs listen to the players and focus on fixing bugs brought in by new updates instead of working on new changes that divides the community.

So let me preface this by saying it isn't a bad game at all, solid 6 or 7/10 if you're generous enough.

State of Decay 2 is pretty much State of Decay 1 but packaged better with some [now new] features which give the game a few helpful twists.

Zombies as a whole aren't hard to deal with, on higher difficulties they'll swarm you but its still doable, the freak zombie will still wreak you if you're not careful but all in all its very hard to lose someone in this game unless you get careless or very unlucky which has only happened to me about once in the entire time i've played this. 

Its base building mechanics are fine I guess, they're not very inspired even with the most recent updates but to give the undead labs team their due they've worked quite well on implementing the new features such as a key location on each map and the new plague heart features which lock you out of claiming surrounding areas and spawning way more plague zombies.

The issue with this game is its ability to hook you in. Sure it'll do it for the first 3 to 10 hours but after that you've done it all before and its just about trying the new maps out, sadly even those aren't too great but the overall diversity is decent and the limited customisation options are a nice touch too albeit a bit simple.

All in all its not really a base builder, not really an RPG, and not really base management game, its a hybrid of all the aforementioned that handles them well enough but not so good enough that you'll be wanting more once the game stops being fun.

That said the multiplayer bit is a nice touch, enjoyed that but again locking stuff behind it and rewarding those who actively play it is a bit of a poor design choice. Some of us don't want online features to unlock offline aspects, sure carry over is nice but make it so you can get it from the normal offline methods otherwise its having no respect for your players time.

Edit: Undead labs have now implemented a few changes to how plague hearts work and now allow you to get multiplayer rewards via the normal campaign which is a good quality of life review but a little too late in my opinion as the multiplayer stuff should have been around since the start in my opinion rather than locking it behind a "you got to play with others" wall.

The games still worth a purchase but only on sale.

I can’t get enough of this survival game that combines base-building and zombie fighting! The game’s mechanics require players to gather resources, build and fortify a base, and fend off hoards of zombies while managing the needs of their character. The constantly evolving gameplay, weather patterns, and resource scarcity make each playthrough a unique adventure. The game’s graphics and atmospheric sound effects keep me on edge and add to the intensity of the experience. The survival elements are challenging, but the addition of zombies adds an extra layer of excitement. Overall, this game is a must-play for anyone who loves a good survival game, with a zombie twist

EDIT: Update 33 really hit the nail on the head! 
We can now actually avoid the formation of infestations by being careful around sleeping plague hearts and infestations are no longer constantly popping up randomly all over the map. However... wake up a heart and it will now send infestations directly our way... which makes them more dangerous oc, but it's no longer a sisyphean task. It's something we can deal with.
------------

Original (negative) Review:
Infestations. I hate infestations. The next update will make dealing with infestations mandatory. Why? Why do you hate us devs? Why do you think so many players take the morale hit and ignore infestations? Maybe, just maybe because it's bland busywork, possibly the least fun part of the game? And now we will get wiped if we ignore this sisyphean task? Wow. -.-

Otherwise the game is fine. It has a couple odd changes compared to the first game, but still fine. The whole infestation business... no way, Jose!

When I was a child, my father never took an interest in my hobbies. He was always out, at work, or just doing ‘adult’ things. Due to this, I vowed that when I had kids, I would take an interest in their hobbies, whether they be sports, gaming, or whatever else! And that’s why I became a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am the father to my son, Alfred, who is now 14. Recently, my son downloaded this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was devastating for me, as instead of bonding over ping pong, he was locked away in his room. As a result, I decided to make a Steam account, and get this game and take an interest in his hobbies, as my father had never done. I loaded into the game, and had no clue what to do, so I asked my son for help, and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it, as he hadn’t seemed this happy since we went rock climbing together in 2018. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again, and now we spend time together on hobbies that I grew up with, such as fishing. This game reminded me that there’s fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both I and my son many happy memories.
