It's a good singleplayer game, it's a good coop game. People worried about tether, base sharing limitations, etc, prevented me from trying it as a coop game at first. Well, the tether is really quite large, like a sixth of the map, and other issues are solved by taking it in turns hosting; also, your coop partner loots separated containers and has access to their base inventory from your base/outposts.

Mechanically the game is great, and if you're looking for a solo zombie survival this will scratch that itch. Unfortunately I downloaded it with the intention of starting a new game with a friend, which the game is not designed to do. Multiplayer works as a "Host" and "Guest" system so the host gets all the supplies and upgrades from looting, the guest cannot. Refilling your supplies is just collecting duffel bags, which are auto-deposited into the host's base.

Long story short its an awesome game but unless the Guest of multiplayer is already 10-15 hours ahead of the host, it isn't really playable as a multiplayer survival.

*Update: Looks like this last patch did something to fix the bug that I had with achievements popping and can now recommend this game and give it a proper score of 7/10. The reason it loses several points is the fact the achievements are still buggy, but at least most of them pop when completed, and the story missions and side missions are severally lacking in the base map of Providence Ridge / the base campaign. However; it is a great zombie game, even in single-player, and is one I would recommend to pick up on-sale due to it being one of the better zombie games out, even 5+ years later.

Achievements do not pop, and apparently this is a bug that has been reported to the developers but a hotfix has still not been issued, it seems. Thus, even though State of Decay 2 is miles ahead of State of Decay 1 in every single way, the achievement system at least worked in the first, and I sadly cannot give this game a positive review as a result. Hopefully this gets fixed in the future (*it did).

I'm editing my review to positive, as the latest update ( 33 ) has finally fixed the major issue I had with the game. Namely the infestation mechanic is no longer random and arbitrary but actually something the player control over. Also it's not a total resource sink as you can actually get rare drops out of it.

The rest of the game is serviceable as well. The game loops fold well into each other and combat is acceptable. No one aspect of this game blows you a way. But it keeps your attention well enough and has enough variety in activities to not become boring too quickly. As such it's a solid 7.5 / 10 game.

I hope that the next update overhauls the enclaves as they are rather random and arbitrary just like the infestation was. But at least they can be ignored with minimal impact, unlike the infestation previously.

State of Decay 2 is an open-world survival game developed by Undead Labs and published by Microsoft Studios. Here is a review highlighting its pros and cons:

Pros:

Vast Open-World: State of Decay 2 offers a vast and immersive open-world environment to explore. It features diverse landscapes, including towns, forests, and countryside, providing players with plenty of areas to scavenge for resources and establish their bases.

Survival Mechanics: The game excels in its survival mechanics, requiring players to manage resources, build and fortify their bases, and make tough decisions to ensure the survival of their community. It offers a satisfying and immersive survival experience.

Permadeath and Character Progression: Each character in State of Decay 2 is unique, with their own set of skills and abilities. The game incorporates permadeath, meaning that if a character dies, they are gone for good. This adds a layer of tension and strategy to gameplay, as players must carefully manage and develop their characters to ensure their survival.

Cooperative Multiplayer: State of Decay 2 allows players to team up with friends in cooperative multiplayer, enhancing the experience by enabling collaboration in building bases, completing objectives, and surviving together in the zombie-infested world.

Cons:

Technical Issues: State of Decay 2 has been criticized for its technical issues, including performance hitches, frame rate drops, and occasional bugs. While some of these issues have been addressed through updates, they can still hinder the overall experience.

Lack of Variety in Missions: The game's missions and objectives can feel repetitive over time. There is a lack of diverse and engaging quests, which can make the gameplay experience feel monotonous.

Clunky Controls and Combat: The controls and combat mechanics in State of Decay 2 have been a point of criticism. The combat can feel clunky and unresponsive at times, impacting the fluidity and enjoyment of combat encounters.

Limited Character Development: While each character has unique traits and abilities, the depth of character development and customization is somewhat limited. There is a lack of deep narrative arcs or significant character progression beyond basic skill upgrades.

Overall, State of Decay 2 provides an engaging open-world survival experience with its resource management, base building, and permadeath mechanics. Despite some technical issues and repetitive missions, the game offers an immersive cooperative multiplayer experience and a challenging survival sandbox for players who enjoy the genre.

I tried it out during a free weekend on Steam, sort of liked it, and decided I'd use my trial of Game Pass on PC to play it some more. I think I logged maybe less than a hundred hours in it there and beat the Heartland DLC campaign.

There *is* a story DLC campaign, but it's not really what you'd expect or want from a story mode.

I think they tried a little too hard to maintain the mechanics of the game and didn't do anything to make the story mode its own thing. They should have nixed all base building elements and open-world elements in favor of some diverse mission-based maps or something. I know that sounds strange considering this is a survival community-builder zombie game, but the point of a story mode should be to focus on the characters, the events surrounding them and to give a change of pace. It shouldn't just be a neutered version of the core gameplay. You don't choose what base to build in, you get the one you're given. You don't choose who to recruit (just whether or not to recruit them, which is a bit like choosing not to kill a zombie about to eat your brains or to do what you're expected and shoot it), you recruit the pregenerated NPCs they created. You *do* choose your characters, but only out of two pairs and honestly they should have just let you play all four at once instead.

I can safely say, though, that the core gameplay itself is very fun. In the main game, ignoring the tutorial that you're forced to do at least once (which forces preset tutorial characters on you and doesn't let you choose your map, but is fun to do at least once and gives a good sense of the game's mechanics, plus two unique randomly generated NPCs with rare preset voice-sets), the game is pretty open and lets you build up your own community however you want. You choose who joins and who leads, which conversely changes the overall demeanor of your group (and may cost you members if you ignore them on the more touchy subjects like helping escaped convicts, though these events are rare and are tied to your leadership missions, which you *can* skip if you want, but I think the rewards are worth dumping that whiny survivor over).

It's a true survival game, so you'll spend most of your time scrounging up rucksacks of supplies, managing your ammo, health items, vehicle health and gas supply while trying to improve your base and, with time and enough community growth, replace it for one that looks better and can fit more. There are usually two small bases, two medium ones, two large ones and at least one huge base for you to choose from and if you think you can manage it, you never have to upgrade at all. There are downsides to this, but if you like a certain large base, it's totally viable to stick with it instead of moving into an uglier huge base.

And there's a lot of automation in the game to help you get by, as well. If you don't care for gathering specific supplies like, say, ammo, you're expected to build outposts and they'll help with this. Each supply type has an outpost type that matches it and will give you +1 per day of that resource. Expending 1 ammo a day because of a defense tower? Want to gain more ammo? Go find an ammo store and claim it as an outpost. It makes a safe zone, gives you ammo per day and you can even upgrade it up to two times to get more ammo out of it and access to other perks like training in chemistry (a community skill, all survivors have one slot for it).

To try and sum this up, the game fits a very nice niche. I love building up cities, empires, communities, etc. and games that offer this tend to get my attention. Without these mechanics I don't know if I'd like the game quite as much, though that's not to say I think the combat mechanics are in any way bad, they're just not enough on their own to draw me in. Thankfully it has much more to it that and you'll no doubt enjoy the depth that the game has to offer in community management and combat if any of this has intrigued you.

And if there's anything you don't like, check out the Nexus for mods. Someone has probably already had the same thought and fixed it and mods do not affect your online compatibility at all. You can play with others even with mods enabled, though it doesn't install for them or anything like that, so they probably won't see those weird custom clothes you put in your game.

I should add a small note that the online for this is not that great. I enjoy it, don't get me wrong, but you are essentially a helper in someone else's world when you join them. You can't build things, you can't set up a base or contribute in any meaningful way. The best you can do is drive around with them, carry their rucksacks (as well as donate them to their storage), and give them stuff you've collected to help them progress in their world. You gain influence by doing this, which is the game's trading currency and is used for all sorts of stuff, but it's not a huge gain and you'll probably waste a ton of ammo and health items along the way that almost makes it not worth it. Still, it's fun, so I can't complain. I think we all wished it could have been better, though.

There's also a Daybreak mode which is basically a zombie wave defense multiplayer mode. You and up to three other players protect a technician from increasingly difficult waves of zombies and try to recover in-between waves with drops. The reward for this is new gear unlocks for this mode and the main game, as well as up to 9 special rewards usable in the main game only (base building stuff, basically), all of which is obtainable using prestige (also obtained from playing Daybreak) with the vendor. You can also use prestige you earn here to recruit Red Talon members to your community. They have unique community skills and are quite powerful, but do come with various drawbacks. Worth it, though.

not sure what everyone hates so much about this game. I play it single player and love the game. It is very immersive. The game has a lot of depth to it too. It's not just about going around scavenging mindlessly. You have to plan what you are going to look for, build up your camp and recruit the right survivors. The fighting animations are good too. Reminds me of watching the walking dead sometimes.

This is an open world survival camp simulator where you take your survivors out to scavenge or do missions to help people, fight bad guys, kill zombie hordes etc.. It is great.

The camp management has some depth to it too. You need to plan gardens, craft items, setup some towers to help reduce the zombie threat. At times you could be out scavenging and your base is under attack by zombies.

This is probably the best zombie game I have ever played.

EDIT: coming back to this game later and it needs to be noted that the developers have consistently built on what they have. It is even better than when I first reviewed the game.

Other reviews have already touched on the unique experiences you can have, especially on the harder difficulties and especially if you haven't optimized the hell out of your gameplay, so I'll leave that aside in my own review.

The core gameplay loop of State of Decay 2 as a zombie survival sandbox is certainly rewarding. Managing your base and your people, bringing back supplies, and curtailing threats all activate the hunter-gatherer neurons efficaciously. 

I also clocked in a lot of hours just figuring out how things ticked. Even more hours just putzing around and experiencing the world despite it only being three maps for most of the game's initial shelf life. I'm [i[still[/i] surprised on occasion by the odd things you can find by exploring (extremely rare, bizarre guns like the AKM with an obscene curly-fry magazine stuffed into a tube with 150 rounds of ammunition), references to Stephen King's IT, lawnmower shenanigans, etc. 

I will say one thing I really appreciated is that with the Juggernaut edition you get everything rolled into one, and Undead Labs is still updating the game without charging for it, which is very, very rare to see. Great kudos goes to them for that - and despite not having touched SoD2 in a little while, hearing about the newest substantial update 33 inspired me to write this review. 

If you like zombie survival sandboxes that reward exploration, preparation, quick thinking, improvisation, progression, and which have a sardonic but amusing sense of humor peppering what writing there is, you'll like State of Decay 2. I'm very much looking forward to the State of Decay 3 whenever it releases.

This is another game where I'm split between enjoying it, and actually recommending it to other gamers, and questioning if I still have any standards in stability and playability.

In short, this game is still just a poor port of a console game. I don't know what it's like on console, so I couldn't tell you if it's more playable on it.

There are so many broken things, such as your survivor refusing to use ladders and falling to their death for no reason, or getting launched into the air by a curb. Dumb deaths like those, or having your car go from 100% to zero because it was stuck on invisible objects would be a lot less frustrating if there were console commands or saves, but it's not fixable. If you lose somethings, the game saves the loss. I have liberally used the "stuck" option, but I have just as often had to use Ctrl+Alt+Delete to close the program when the stuck button wasn't accessible.

The computer version does have mods and there are tons of unfixed exploits that somewhat make this game playable, but I'm sick of just expecting all of the games I play to be broken and trying to fix them while I play. Leave it to Microsoft to make a game that's hardly playable on Windows.

In addition to the bugs, the game seems overly commercialized. They added overpowered assets to the game that ruin the more appealing storytelling aspects of the game. I can't imagine that the original developers would have liked this, if they're still involved in decisions or if they were somehow overruled. Another odd thing about the storytelling aspects is that the story takes place in the US, but the majority of riffles are chambered in 7.62, with the usual bias. I'm not interested in the debate involving the differences between 5.56 and 7.62, but I really don't get how 7.62 is all of the sudden the most dominant round in the US, and preferred by all of the elite Soldiers. It would have made sense if they just removed the distinction altogether and labeled them "riffle rounds".

Oh, and there are positive aspects about this game, but you can look at other reviews for those.

Ambitious Guppy's review:

Posted: Aug 30, 2021 @ 11:27am

"In a sentence: this is the best zombie-survival game I have ever played, with hands-down the best dev team of the genre.

It was day 27 of the zombie apocalypse, and I was taking my favorite character out for scavenging. I'd recently ran out of gas, so I decided, what the heck, I'll just run to the nearest potential gas site... over half a kilometer away. This may not sound that far to you, but in the zombie apocalypse, half a kilometer on foot is like the journey your grandparents traveled to and from school back in their day: uphill both ways, in 5 feet of snow, with only a raw potato for lunch. But I'm no dummy. So before heading out, I grabbed a vial of plague cure, along with a bunch of stimulants, in case I happened to get into trouble...

Flash forward about 45 minutes. My favorite character is sprinting back to base, having contracted blood plague for a SECOND time this trip, after using up the one vial of plague cure I brought along. The timer at the bottom left of the screen is counting down the seconds until my guy drops dead from the plague. Meanwhile, there are three. Count. THREE Ferals (cat-like zombies that run on all fours and hate you and everyone you know) sprinting after me. My dude is downing stimulants like they're fricken Tic Tacs, while hauling butt back to base. He's bobbing and weaving like he's the star of a new Rocky movie, as these ferals hurl past him every couple seconds trying to slice through him like warm butter. But my guy has quads of steel, glutes that could crack open a walnut, and enough stimulants in him to kill a small country, so he just keeps on trucking. I'm on the edge of my seat, actively shouting at the screen, squeezing my controller to death, and implementing any other proven tactics I can think of for increasing the speed of my character.

Finally, I throw the door open to my base as my other community members gather to beat the ever-living heck out of these stupid ferals (it was a joyous moment). The timer has three seconds left on it as I down a vial of plague cure from my supply locker. My guy was safe. The relief I felt was better than having a scheduled phone call be canceled. Pure bliss.

The next day, my favorite character ran into a bloater while driving, contracted blood plague, and was then beaten into the ground by a Juggernaut. Devastation... like going over to a friend's house for a sleepover and realizing you forgot to bring an extra controller.

I will never forget you, favorite character, whose name has escaped me.


Thank you, Undead Labs, for giving me this experience. This is my favorite game of all-time! :)"

I'd say that the game is for a certain category of people. It doesn't do much to appeal to new players. I had a hard time at start but slowly got into rhythm. It takes time. If you like zombie survival genre then at its current state, it's a very good game. Unlike other companies; Undead Labs have been constantly updating and adding new features/contents to the game. There are still few bugs here and there but nothing game breaking to sour your experience.

The main story isn't good or memorable. The first game had better story and characters. Outside of Heartland DLC, barely any story exists in main campaign. The multiplayer co-op part is very lacklustre. If you want to enjoy a whole playthrough with your buddy then you'll soon find out that the invited friend has very little to do. Despite all, I'd still recommend this game to players who like this genre and want to try something new. Base building, community management and collecting the many different weapons the game has(it has a lot) are some of the best aspects of the game.

Pros: There's a decent variety of weapons and the randomness of the characters will have you managing your community for the most useful survivors over the course of the game. There are 4 maps to be had here each with their own unique look and, more importantly, layout. Each map has several bases that also have some unique bonuses. After a character has gained enough standing, they can become a leader; a leader can have 4 different archetypes that also lead to different buildings. Once you've eliminated all the plague hearts in a town you enter a kind of "phase 2" of the game and begin to complete your leader's goal which can vary depending on the aforementioned archetypes. Other settlers will also have goals and missions that come up as you play where you can learn more about them and earn some unique gear or even other survivors. The game is also even more fun with friends and is just glitchy enough to be hilarious but not game-breaking. It's also HIGHLY replayable because of the random nature of the community and area. It's also recieving consistent updates, with the newest (FREE) content drop coming May 10, 2023.

Cons: The bad things I have to say about this game are far and few between. 1) The control scheme is a little unintuitive on PC, this is definitely a controller game first and foremost. It's not anything too crazy though, just takes a bit to get used to. 2) Difficulty falls off (and becomes a bore) once you get yourself a few guns and explosives and a decent base. Dread and Nightmare are definitely the go-to difficulties after you've learned the mechanics. 3) NPCs talk a little too much and it does feel a little impersonal. Once again a minor issue but in a game focused on building a community it can be an issue for immersion. The people on the radio NEVER shut up, even about things you've done already or rumors you've already heard a thousand times before. Definitely could us an option to shut off the radio or at least mute it.
Addictive gameplay loop. Im shocked this game is still getting support honestly, but props to the devs!

Pros: Perma-death feature is nice for zombie game. Lots of weapons to use each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Multiple vehicles with different handling and storage creates uniqueness. Lots of replay-ability with multiple maps and bases to choose from.

Cons: AI is stupid beyond reason. Too often will you have a mission with a follower to clear an area, but the moment you exit a vehicle they start blasting away with whatever firearm they have. This in turn attracts more zombies, which in turn has them fire more. This creates and endless cycle of zombies flowing into your area which is exacerbated by the fact the zombies are consistently spawned instead of just attracting nearby zombies. Wouldn't be so painful if shots just ATTRACTED nearby zombies and didn't cause them to spawn. Some things block character movement which makes no sense (aka stalks of corn, cause you can't push them out of the way I guess}. Controls can be a bit sluggish with multiple actions being bound to the same key (aka space bar is jump/climb over/kick) which can cause your character to preform the wrong action at a crucial moment

Overall if they had a feature to let you to command your followers actions this would be a 9/10, without it I have to give it 7/10. Being a zombie community building game not being able to bring members of your community or others with on quests due to the poor allied AI writing detracts of the game. All they really needed to add was a HOLD fire command for followers using firearms.

What a fun game.

Wasn't a fan of these type games but a friend was playing it a lot and I got it on discount in one of the steam sales.

To be honest what a purchase,fun,makes you jump from time to time LMAO (mainly the damn ferals rugby tackling you haha) 

Building a base,community and generally running about looting everywhere.

You will at times probably lose a member of your community it happens to us all but you can recruit others so its not a big problem. My advice to prevent it happening avoid big hoards when your player is weak or tired,always take painkillers or meds with you and always have at least 1 plague cure with you. Make sure you use silencer on rifles or use crossbow as this is cheaper option to craft arrows through materials and bow doesnt make as much noise. 

Avoid the juggs as they can only be killed with rifles generally they can be killed with other things but takes alot longer. Big tip for them is to jump on containers/buses as they cant bash these and makes it easier to shoot them in the head.

Always run over them damn screamers (hitting them with door open is better option and saves vehicle getting damaged) or reverse into them.

Upgrade a van with heavy vehicle upgrade kit,this will help with looting runs.

Plague hearts dont like molotovs or fire bombs,pipe bombs. So throw one at heart then jump on top of your van to deal(shoot) the hoard of zombies and not get jumped by feral(s). You can in some situations stand on van and throw the bombs at plague hearts through windows of houses and saves you trying to run away alot. But be careful as if theres Jugg about he will bash your van and you'll fall off. If there is a jugg around i tend to beep the horn and get him to chase you up road so hes out of way of your plague heart destroying. This is normally a 2,3 or 4 wave thing. You can make it alot easier to destroy hearts using other methods of bombs but cost effective. So i did molotov method alot of the time. 

 I also use standing of van method to deal with infestations,try shoot or bow screamers 1st as they'll attract more zombies,ferals,juggs,bloaters in. Ah,yes the bloaters.....avoid these also shoot them as soon as you see one as they're sneeky and hide behind objects,cars,and other things and can be a bit of a pain.

Heartland is another good story mode and brings another side and story to the game. You'll also build a seperate community there with some advanced stuff on offer ie,better members abilities,base upgrades and other things. Anything gained from this looting wise doesnt end up in your main community locker so once story is done its done. You can do it over again and recruit new people if you like. 

Daybreak is another fun mode where you deal with waves of zombies,bloaters,ferals and juggs while defending a guy in the base. Make sure the walls are always repaired and dont let the guy in base get hurt always top him up with bandages to keep him full health and team up on juggs to get them beaten up quickly. Playing this mode will earn you reward tokens which can buy things that can be used in normal campaign community so the more you play more perks you'll earn and can buff up your base,community. This is probably best played with team of friends as you can assign jobs for each you,1 repairs walls,1 gets cleo drops,plus you can spead out outside to defend base better and stop zombies even reaching the walls and destoying them.

Like i say a very fun game which i didnt think i would be into but thanks to my friend for tips and getting me into this as its worth a buy when its on sale for sure. 

And be careful of angry AI in game as them upset people hit or shoot hard and hurt alot so shoot from beside vehicles or walls and use rifles as my advice as pistols i found didnt do the damage needed to deal with them.

Happy Zombie Killing.

So I have been "on the fence" about buying this game for a long tome. I finally purchased it and after about 4 or 5 days I already have 84 hours into it. Its addictive and has a lot to offer. I am on my second play through because there are 4 maps (I believe) and each choice you make changes your goals for the whole game. For example as your base camp grows you have to choose a leader from your group. Different characters offer different goals. You can be a sheriff trying to help others on the map, or you can be a warlord and build an army, or even a builder who is trying to clear the zombies and rebuild civilization and I believe more. Depending on who you encounter and how you interact with them brings new possibilities. For example I had this girl asking me to help her retrieve an AI trapped in a satellite, so I did. Then we went our own ways, but as I'm playing I would hear her on the radio talking to this AI. Then later in the game she shows up at my home base and asks if she can set up the AI's heaven program on my base. I wont tell you what happens if you allow it but its AWSOME and its only one of many interactions. 
Now while I'm obviously a fan the game  could be better. So I play a lot of game like I am sure you have as well, but this one has a bit of a learning curve. I am still figuring things out. I wish the base building was more actual building. Instead you have to find survivors with the skill to build what you want, for example you need an auto mechanic in order to build an auto shop to fix up or trick out you vehicles. That would be OK except you can only add like 3 to maybe 5 different shops on your base. Depending where you set up your home base there will be some stuff there like a barracks or a kitchen already there. Then you have to choose, from about a dozen shops you can build. Things like a clinic to heal your folks or a garden to grow food or work bench to fix weapons. Now these are all important but like I said you can only have a few so you have to decide what is critical to the way you are trying to play. Basically building is just to limited. 
Play through isn't really long but its definitely replayable because you just want to see what happens if you had done things a little different and being that you can change the map and the people, I'm not sure that you could get the same play through a second time if you tried. 

 Is this game going to amaze you, probably not. Do I recommend, definitely! Just keep in mind its a sand box style game so theres no real story beyond the one you make as you go. They do offer so many missions that you won't be able to do them all and find the time to work on your base, meaning you cant help everyone who asks. Also while this does have a multiplayer option I have played completely single player due to slow internet where I live, so I'm not sure how playing with others may improve the game.

The multiplayer implementation changes everything for SOD series. It's much more fun to play with friends rather than soloing with a brain dead AI follower, but the downside of the multiplayer was both player are tethered with each other. Went too far and you will be teleported back to the host. If only the game have 2 separate in-game community, singleplayer and online co-op community, it would be much more fun. And also remove the tether features to allow both players to cover up more areas in search for resources etc. or completing missions.

As much as I looked forward to this sequel after the first game, SoD 2 is a piece of junk and the community is nauseatingly toxic.

The influence system has thankfully been overhauled since the first game. You never need to worry about coming back to the game after a week to see the game has depleted your resources or a character’s influence down to zero. 

The same can’t be said for the controls. Movement is easily the worst aspect of this game. State of Decay 2 feels like an extremely cheap indie game. Whether on foot or in a car, the controls are often unresponsive, as if it is ignoring your input every fifth button press. And, no, it isn’t my hardware. Simply turning around is frequently impossible because the game seems to have tank controls. You often have to turn your body around 180 degree then hit the forward button to move out of a corner. 

Vehicle handling alternates between feeling too stiff, randomly stalling out in the middle of driving, or cars twirling around in circles like they are on ice whenever you make the slightest turn while backing up. It's shocking this game is so unpolished after four years of updates. Just to annoy the player, you can fix cars but there are hardly operational cars around to find unlike in the original.

When I was a child, my father never took an interest in my hobbies. He was always out, at work, or just doing ‘adult’ things. Due to this, I vowed that when I had kids, I would take an interest in their hobbies, whether they be sports, gaming, or whatever else! And that’s why I became a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am the father to my son, Alfred, who is now 14. Recently, my son downloaded this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was devastating for me, as instead of bonding over ping pong, he was locked away in his room. As a result, I decided to make a Steam account, and get this game and take an interest in his hobbies, as my father had never done. I loaded into the game, and had no clue what to do, so I asked my son for help, and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it, as he hadn’t seemed this happy since we went rock climbing together in 2018. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again, and now we spend time together on hobbies that I grew up with, such as fishing. This game reminded me that there’s fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both I and my son many happy memories.

I would recommend this game... but it's going to make you mad at times too.

I just lost my best character, a maxed out builder named Bree.  I was driving her to a map exit so I could change maps and bases...  The menu to change areas came up, but I could hear zombies in the background attacking her.  I drop out of the menu to see what is going on just as she gets ripped in half by a juggernaut, surrounded by a crowd of zombies.  Yup, the game murdered my best girl without a chance while I was in a menu.  I immediately Ctrl-Alt-Del'd the game hoping to avoid an autosave and save Bree, but when I logged back in all I got was a menu forcing me to switch characters.  Well, that sucks.

This game is janky but fun.  It lacks good AI for your survivors and it lacks some basic quality of life features.  For example, the character you control always HAS to drive, and you HAVE to bring your current ride and follower back to base.  Your AI companions will not drive, and they don't fight particularly well either.  I lost another nearly maxed character a stone's throw from my base despite her being fully kitted with several full slots of meds and great gear.  Frustrating.

If you enjoy driving games you'll like this game better than I do.  I actually hate driving games and don't like driving very much IRL either.  And this game isn't the good kind of driving... it's stressful, with barriers, roadbloacks, zombies, etc.  And the game seems like it's night time more than day time.  I hate night driving.

That being said, it is quite a fun little game for a while.  Replayability is near infinite and you can reuse favoritie survivors for another playthrough as long as the game doesn't cheapshot kill them as has happened to me a few times.  There are many different bases, vehicles, and a lot of weapons to choose from.  It's a bit grindy.

Really fun game from a Zombie Survival fan's point of view. 

Hard working studio that grew and learned from the first game and slowly turned this sequel into a truly well done addition to the franchise.

If you already played the original SoD, you know what to expect. There's no real story, but that has the benefit of keeping things open and not annoying the player with constant cut scenes (like Days Gone - a far more story-driven experience). 

Unlike Days Gone, SoD is far more about community building, and SoD2 improves on the first game with a much bigger world split into 4 seperate game maps for greater variety, and with improved graphics. It still fires missions at you faster than you can deal with, but they are optional, so its simply a matter of prioritising. There will be many missions that you end up ignoring just so you can focus on your current task, whereas story missions will wait for as long as you want. The player is able to switch between any of the characters in your community more or less at will until you leave base, you can still switch between yourself and another partner via outposts you have claimed, letting another character take over if your health/stamina is low. Outposts also provide you with access to your community inventory if you need to restock on ammo/meds etc. With proper planning you can do some really long scavenger runs. Choose your kit wisely because the decisions you make regarding what you bring with you will make the difference between mission success and failure, e.g. life or death.

SoD2 brings some new mechanics like the plague hearts, which produce plague zombies that can infect your survivors, meaning they will require treatment within a certain time to stop any bitten community members from turning into zeds.. Those plague hearts need to be destroyed in order to claim nearby outposts, and can drop a decent amount of loot.
Infestations (basically hoards centred around buildings) also keep reccurring. Failing to do so will impact on community morale, though you can never eradicate them completely and tackling them can seem never-ending. The more infestations on the map however, the more you will regularly be called back to base to fight off zed attacks. 

Your community of survivors is ultimately your most important resource, so you gotta look after them. Keeping on top of infestations and destroying plague hearts will help boost their morale. It's also important to be mindful of their skills when letting new members join your community, as certain skills are required for certain types of facility and any upgrades to them. You may find yourself seeking out a mechanic (vital for keeping your vehicles in check via the auto-shop facility) or a survivor with agriculture to max out your farm facility. 

A good new feature is the legacy pool, which basically saves favourite survivors for a later playthrough, though sending them to the legacy pool does mean losing them for the reminder of your current game, so consider only banking survivors with duplicate skills. If a survivor dies in-game however, they are lost forever, whether they are legacy-pooled or not.You will gain attachments to a few favourite survivors, while others will be z-fodder, depending hoe you feel. Exiling some survivors with skills you don't need (or sending them to the legacy pool) is necessary now and again to make available space for survivors with the skills you do need. There are also training manuals dotted around that can be used to train up survivors with existing skills, or a new skill if they have an empty skill slot available.

Characters, other than those you pick at introduction, are relatively random, with a different playthrough beyond the introduction sequences producing different sets of characters. Losing a particularly favourite character with useful skills can be a painful experience, so try not to bite off more than you can chew. You can team one survivor up with another, which is always advisable when leaving base. While the characters can put up a good fight, they will tire and and may become quickly overwhelmed if you run out of luck.

While there's a lot to do, and it can take some time to get established, it's fun whiling away the hours building up a community of survivors, and with four map regions to choose and even switch between when you've grown tired of the same map, it provides many hours of fun.

It's not all perfect though. Don't rely too much on AI to cover your ass. The dev also decided on a really annoying 'one key for everything' system (E on keyboard, Y on xbox controller) which does everything including talk/open or close door/enter vehicle/search lootbox/repair vehicle/refuel/sneak attack....so quite often you're trying to do one thing but end up doing another because of you're in close proximity to another character, object or zed etc....really frustrating if you're close combat against a hoard of zeds, fighting for your life, and instead of sneak-stabbing a zed in the head the moment the opportunity arises, you open interaction with your nearby buddy instead, like ''hey lets have a chat while 20 zeds are trying to eat our throats.''

That issue aside though, I'm having a lot of fun hours on this game because its one of those games where the decisions you make all matter...whether its deciding what kit to take with you each time you venture out of your base, to deciding what facilities your base needs, to deciding on your leader...everything shapes your community in a way that makes every playthrough on every map a different experience each time, and that's what keeps me coming back.

THE BEGINNING OF MY EXPERIENCE WITH STATE OF DECAY 2 AND THE ORIGINAL GAME

Had this game on Xbox a while ago, and finally decided to purchase here on Steam during the recent publisher sale that hit the platform. Coming from the original State of Decay back when it released, I was introduced to the sequel when it came out during it's time as well, and it is still pretty fun to play. In my eyes, both games are. Granted, they have their differences, and the sequel seems a little buggier in some areas, but they're both good Zombie survival horror in all. 

WHAT IT FOCUSES ON

The strong suite of State of Decay is it's focus on creating Apocalypse communities, where you take control of, manage and direct your survivors as you build your community bases from decisions you make throughout the game. While the system of decision making stems deep in this game, I do wish in some areas it were deeper. For instance, being able to actually intervene with survivor conflicts as the leader, and developing personal relationships between different survivors to create different scenarios. 

IN A NUTSHELL

All in all, this is a solid title. It boasts a huge weapon arsenal, and there's always something to keep you busy in it. If you're a zombie fan I recommend checking this one out if you never did or had the chance to.

I've only just started playing it but what you have hear is basically a "community building RTS" with oh by the way, zombies.  This is not an FPS and to be honest, the fighting is kind of bad in this game.  Its in third person and when you get into close situations (as you will) the viewpoint often goes wonky.  It feels like the fighting might be better with a controller over keyboard/mouse but I haven't tried.

So forget zombie slaying, it's really not the game.  The game's forte is in simulating what it would be like to rebuild a community after an apocalypse.  It is sort of like Days Gone but with the emphasis on complex management of resources and less (so far) emphasis on being a bad ass horde killers (yay, Days Gone).  


The real-timeish nature, zombies, time, random events, other NPCs, etc. combine to put pressure on the player and often you have to accept that your strategies can quickly go to [cuss word].  So you have to improvise or go home and get stronger or pick a different survivor or gun or whatever  if you can't complete a mission right away.

You start out with about a half dozen survivors - they are always different and have their own personalities and moods (which you can deal with if it gets bad).  As you use them to complete missions and scavenge, they get infected or need to rest so you go back to base and activate another survivor to do the next mission.  You can try to build those survivors into specialists like scavengers vs. zombie killers vs. traders using the skill trees that you get access to with experience and so forth.  You can retire some of your survivors in order to pick up new ones with latent talents.  Another factor is building a home base and claiming outposts.  Outposts cost money to claim but bring other benefits such as better radio comms or running water (a morale booster).  There are a ton of different outposts and home bases to choose from so each game could take a different path.  There are also other non-affiliated groups you can trade with.

State of Decay 2 is an incredible survival game that offers players a unique and engaging experience. 

One of the standout features of State of Decay 2 is the cooperative multiplayer, which allows players to team up and work together to survive in the harsh post-apocalyptic world. The game also has a strong emphasis on player choice, with every decision you make affecting the world and the characters around you.

The graphics are impressive, with realistic character models and stunning environments. The sound design is also fantastic, with a haunting soundtrack that perfectly captures the atmosphere of the game.

Overall, State of Decay 2 is an amazing game that will keep you hooked for hours on end. Whether you're playing solo or with friends, the game offers a unique and immersive experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression. Highly recommended!

The game's not bad as a concept, in fact State of Decay has a special place in my heart as a - now series - that puts me in the place of a survivor just trying to make way in a horrible land dead and desolate. The premise is great, the idea of clearing out and making a place better before leaving is a nice sentiment that is often unseen in a genre that's mostly about survival and escape.

But the developers almost seem to have gone out of their way to make this a chore instead of fun. Almost every mechanic in some way makes the game more annoying, or more tedious.

A great example of this is the inventory system. It's incredibly small. In theory this might lead to you picking and choosing what you want but the loot isn't gone so you can just kind of come back, adding to the loop.

Another is the quest system. You'll very frequently get quests to help others, even while you're doing what you're supposed to do, and if you ignore the quests those people will eventually shoot you on sight. It doesn't feel like I'm helping communities it feels like I'm babysitting children who eventually throw temper tantrums. At one point I did a quest just to get them off my back and I got two new quests before I was done.

The spawning system is so blatantly a spawning system you never feel like it ends at all. They have no problem spawning right in front of you, and at one point I was driving at top speed and two hordes spawned under me, flipping me into the air like a spinny top and dropping me down on someone who was following me. Luckily they didn't take any damage and honestly this was hilarious, but after I was done laughing I realized my car had taken a ton of damage and I had no part in that penalty.

All in all, tedious, badly designed, glitchy garbage with a great premise a younger me could get behind. An older me wants the game to shut up and let me kill the damn plague heart already.

As of now the current Infestations system is a little annoying and RNG but there are promising developments being worked on by developers. I used to enjoy this game but after a few hours it turns into an endless tiring quest for supplies.

Your home base is constantly under attack and constantly surrounded by zombies, mostly the "special" kind. Ferals, juggernauts, and bloaters are nearly as common as regular zombies which means you spend all of your time fighting zombies and 9 of every 10 missions expire or fail because you constantly get called back to your base or have to deal with half a dozen juggernauts going a half a mile across the map and burning a full tank in a vehicle that can barely hold anything (a cargo van can only hold 7 pistols, or books). It's overkill and just gets tedious.

Vehicles use an insane amount of gas and the controls are terrible. You can take things out of containers, but you can't put things in them. You can't let go of a locked door. Once you find out it's locked you have no choice but to bash it in and alert all the zombies instead of just backing off and trying another door.
The story is awful but man the gameplay is awesome and challenging (Lethal). This game is a walking dead simulator with tons of free updates. Totally worth it.

SoD2 is so close to being the perfect zombie game, but it still falls short in a lot of ways. 

THE PROS:
• Multiple large and immersive maps that are fun to explore and gather resources. 
• The characters are well-designed with decent voice acting. 
• A nice variety of weapons and explosives. 
• You can drive and have different types of vehicles. I haven't seen that in most of the zombie games I've played, so it's definitely a nice addition. 
• Your actions have the potential for real consequences when it comes to losing survivors, or hostility towards other enclaves. 
• The ability to pick and choose what missions you want to accept. 

THE CONS: 
• The inability to create your own character or change the appearance of an existing character 
(outside of superficial outfit changes).
• Even though the voice acting is good, it seems the entire cast of characters share the same 3 or 4 voice actors. 
• Base building is EXTREMELY limited. You only get a small, handful of slots to customize your base. There's no way to rearrange any preexisting structures inside your base, either. 
• Even though you could infinitely keep playing this game by moving your survivors to new maps and bases, there's only a handful of missions before the finale and you're forced to start anew. 
• Maybe it's just me, but I feel like the zombies or "zeds" could look scarier. They look cartoonish and goofy compared to the realism of the survivors. 

With all that being said, I'd still recommend this game. It's addictive and unique enough to keep me coming back for more.

SoD1 is still worth playing. But I would say SoD2 is the better-made game. It has more maps, offline progression was removed, etc. But it's also the easier game, which can make the mid-late game rather boring. But Undead Labs is still releasing updates for SoD2. They seem to be really dedicated to making SoD2 the best game it can be, even 5 years after its initial release. That's the kind of game developer every gamer should support.

I've heard SoD2 had a rocky start. I don't know how bad it was back then, but I don't think there has been a better time to get into SoD2. The last few updates introduced some major features, like being able to save and transfer your favorite survivors into new sessions. The upcoming (at the time of writing this review) Update 33 is also expected to make some major improvements to infestations and plague hearts by making how you deal with them much more strategic, interactive, and meaningful.

The co-op suffers greatly, and I think a lot has already been said before me, it's so bad that even zombies laugh. The gameplay becomes repetitive quite quickly: gather resources, build various structures at the base, expand the base, move, and repeat. It gets boring faster than a zombie can eat you.
 Characters lack diverse personalities; in my opinion, they were better distinguished in the previous installment, but they can still be improved. It's understandable that unique personalities cannot be created for all, but some can be worked on to enhance the gaming experience and make the loss of characters feel more significant, rather than just "darn, I have to level up a new one again." There's no empathy for the lost character. Add various activities to the base that would allow characters to improve their stats, assign characters to work permanently at different buildings, and have non-playable characters (NPCs) fill these roles, but still allow the possibility to take them on expeditions. When there are no more survivors, NPCs, like a cook for example, could become the main characters, either to revive or join another group. It would be nice to have the option to join other groups if there's no main group left. It would be great if hostile groups attacked the base, stealing supplies and killing NPCs.

More diverse locations are desired, such as shopping malls, ski resorts, hotels, remote bases away from cities, bunkers, military bases, etc. In houses with a roof, it would be nice to have an attic to hide from zombie hordes if cornered. Also, it would be great to be able to drag large items like sofas, refrigerators, TVs, and cabinets back to the base if they are appealing, using disassembly and vans for transportation. It would be nice to learn how to collect a library from literature found in the game, so new characters can improve their skills faster to a minimum level, and then further improve them through practice, or have literature or movies provide a boost to skill growth. Skills should be more diverse, such as welding to access certain areas or disassemble cars on the road. Lockpicking would also be useful for silently breaking into houses or cars without attracting zombie attention, as you never know which car has an alarm. An electrician skill would be useful for assembling or upgrading the base's power system. In general, it would be nice to apply the principle of car customization to other aspects, as well as change the visual design of the base, providing more space for creativity. Draw graffiti on the walls of houses so your friends in co-op can easily find the place you're talking about.

I'm not even talking about construction skills, which could change a lot. Additionally, hunting, gathering, and many other features would be great to see in the game.

Moving certain gameplay elements from Project Zomboid to State of Decay can enhance the gaming experience of State of Decay by making it more engaging, realistic, and immersive. Here are some elements that can be borrowed from Project Zomboid:

In-depth character customization: In Project Zomboid, players can choose from a variety of professions and traits to create a unique character with specific abilities and drawbacks. Implementing a similar system in State of Decay would allow players to experience the game through different character builds and strategies.

More robust crafting and building system: Zomboid offers an extensive crafting system that allows players to create various items, weapons, and structures. Introducing a similar level of complexity in State of Decay would give players more ways to interact with the game world and create a more immersive experience.

Farming and cooking mechanics: Project Zomboid has an in-depth farming and cooking system that encourages players to be self-sufficient. Integrating these mechanics into State of Decay could promote long-term survival and provide an added layer of depth.

Expanded medical system: Project Zomboid has a comprehensive medical system, including different types of injuries, infections, and illnesses. Incorporating a more advanced medical system in State of Decay could make surviving and taking care of survivors more challenging and rewarding.

Dynamic weather system: Project Zomboid has an immersive weather system that can impact gameplay. Adding a similar feature to State of Decay would make the environment feel more alive and introduce new strategic considerations for players to deal with.

Stealth and distraction mechanics: Project Zomboid emphasizes the importance of stealth and using distractions to avoid or manipulate zombies. Implementing these mechanics in State of Decay could add more tactical options for players and increase tension during gameplay.

Longer-term survival challenges: Project Zomboid is known for its punishing difficulty and the need for long-term planning. Incorporating more complex survival challenges in State of Decay could make the game feel more intense and rewarding for players who enjoy a challenge.

Mod support: Project Zomboid has a thriving modding community that adds new content, features, and improvements to the game. Encouraging mod support for State of Decay could give players the ability to tailor the game to their preferences and extend its replayability.

More realistic zombie behavior: Project Zomboid's zombies have a more realistic and slower movement pattern. Adjusting the behavior of zombies in State of Decay to be more in line with this could create a more immersive and strategic gameplay experience.

Larger map and exploration: Project Zomboid features a massive map with a variety of locations to explore. Expanding the size and variety of State of Decay's map could provide players with a more engaging open-world experience.

State of Decay 2 is an open-world survival game developed by Undead Labs and published by Microsoft Studios. It was released in 2018 and is available on PC and Xbox One.

The game takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where the player must lead a group of survivors and build a community while fending off hordes of zombies and other dangers. The game has a strong emphasis on resource management, with players having to scavenge for food, water, medicine, and other supplies to keep their community alive.

One of the standout features of State of Decay 2 is its permadeath system, where if a survivor dies, they are gone for good. This adds an extra layer of tension and strategy to the gameplay, as players must carefully manage their resources and make tough decisions about which survivors to send on dangerous missions.

The game's graphics and sound design are serviceable but not particularly impressive. However, the game's strength lies in its gameplay, which is engaging and challenging. The combat system is satisfying, with a wide range of weapons and skills to choose from, and the base-building mechanics allow players to create their own unique communities.

The game also has a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends to take on the zombie apocalypse together.

Overall, State of Decay 2 is a solid open-world survival game that offers a challenging and engaging gameplay experience. While the game may not be for everyone, those who enjoy survival games and the zombie apocalypse genre are likely to find a lot to love in State of Decay 2.

Old review from 2020 when game released on Steam:

Overall, i've played this game like 50 hours on  Xbox Game pass. I really Like it and will continu to play. However, I cannot post a good review due to two things:

1- All my save files were NOT transfered in steam version. I know that I could have transfer manually my saves in the steam folder, however, when I uninstalled the game from the xbox app on Windows 10, it also deleted the save files. Since I dont want to pay a month of gamepass just to get my saves back, its pretty bad.

2- Multiplayer was bugged on Windows 10. Invisible zombies for guest players, guest players loosing connexion. All these bugs WERE NOT fixed on steam either, making multiplayer, the main attraction of the game, not working as it should. If at leat this problem is fixed, i'll think about changing my review for a good one.

When a valuable character dies in this game, it can be a funny or thrilling end to their epic story. And the game goes on.

When you lose a valuable character because they hit a bloated zombie and the gas cloud kills them twice (once to take them down, then immediately after they recover) -- because the animation of getting out of a vehicle takes too long, well. That's painful. That's a consequence of bad game design, not skill.

When it happens a second time, it's a punch to the heart. And since I was already depressed when this happened to me, I kind of spiraled a bit. I downloaded the source code off of a torrent, printed it out, and used it as kindling in a secret fire ritual, deep in the mountains. It was the only way to cleanse the stench of this absolutely mediocre game from my spirit.

I am sorry, however, for the unintended consequence of burning Malibu to the ground.

This is one of the games that if you really let it. It will not be a short session. This game continues to get new updates since its inception and continues to put out quality of life changes. I bought this game on sale not knowing what to expect.  It was on a list of best survival single player games. And after putting in the hours I can for sure see why.  There is building, a large variety of guns, ammo types, vehicles, base upgrades, character stats, community stats, everything you want from a zombie survival.  And having watched all of the Waling Dead, this is the closes game to the TV show.  With MANY parallels.  If you like zombie survival games, then give this one a try.  You will not be disappointed.

PROS:
- Wonderful Graphics
- Detailed Sounds
- Fun gun play
- Fun melee play
- Satisfying micro management/community management
- Variety of maps, characters and stories which help replay value
- Soundtrack

CONS:
- co-op is not true co-op and is limited.  Although better than nothing can be improved. 
- Map time lines can feel short at times.  For example as soon as you hit endgame base stuff and weapons you are prob finishing the last mission on the map
- Enemy variety is not terrible but i do wish there was a larger roster of types

[h1] One of The Best Zombie Apocalypse Game I've ever played! [/h1]

[u]Before I started, if you're looking for fully co-op zombies game. This game may not the best idea for you, and you friend[/u]

[Pros]
This is the Zombie Apocalypse, Open World, Survival, Base Building & Resources Management, during the gameplay, you may encounter a lot of event that related to life and death. You need to reclaim the town you've arrive with zombies-free zone. You can choose your own path and define your legacy in this game.

[b]"ALL SURVIVORS ARE UNIQUE"[/b] It's mean if you lost them or get them killed. They're gone forever.
Traits Feature is the most things I love this game! All of each survivors will have many different traits for both Positive and Negative. There are over 1,000 traits in the game. each survivors may have up to 4 or more traits in the game. So, every survivors you encountered. [u]They are unique[/u]

Skill and Upgrade progression for Survival also remarkable! All of your playable survival may have different skills. For example if your survivor have traits (or background)....
[u]Your survival was a Bus Driver[/u]: Drive any vehicle with more efficiency
[u]Your survival was an Army Veteran[/u]: Shoot with weapons with more accuracy, may use auto-rifle with more efficiency, etc.
Your survival was a Barista[/u]: Yup, they can brew some coffee for you! lol

[u]This game is not endless survival game[/u] But it's not just like One Time Play only! with the feature called "Legacy" this is what I may used to addicted this game so much!
During the gameplay, you may choose 4 path in the apocalypse world that lurking with zombies.
Builder: You believe that your base is everything to survive. Grow your own food, craft your own meds, and weapons!
Trader: You believe that trading is the key to survive. With fair exchange, may able to survive this apocalypse together
Sheriff: You believe that apocalypse like this need Laws and Orders. Thief and Murderer ain't welcomed here. And will tried to stop them or kill them if you had to. Not just for your own communities but all people in this town.
Warlord: Boom! Bang! RATATATTATATA! MOTHERF**KER I DON'T GIVE A F**K, YOU ALL DIED, I SURVIVE, B*TCH!!

After you finished your legacy path. You may have benefit to choose when you start a new game. such as Free Power and Water in base if you had Builder boons, Free Guns, Bullets and Grenades at start of the first base if you had Warlord boons. which will impact for your new game too.

Overall, the game is really cared about Unique Survivors the combat is somewhat satisfy. There are difficulty to choose, easy to lethal. This game is repeatable. With the base building. This game feel more alive in Zombie Apocalypse.

[Cons]
Multiplayer! If you thought you can play in the same team and the same world. Nope. It's not.
You may play with your friend and you became host. Your friend need to create his own Community to join your game. The survivors you played cannot be shared to your friends. Your loots and your friends loots are not shared. So, your friend can keep their loots without impact on your world. Though for joined player may not able to deposit some special resources. They need to log off to his own world to deposit them.
Your friend cannot do mission for you. Cannot move too faraway from the host (even though it's openworld game?). etc!
Your friend may not interact some base (like upgrade, spending resources to do some base action) for some reason

There are also bugs and game crash to be expected. And minor glitch too.
Well, let's called it a features.

Overall, State of Decay 2 ain't ideal for multiplayer. Though I played multiplayer like 100 hours with my friends and it's not that bad. But for other people may find it worse experience during multiplayer gameplay.

I enjoyed a lot of my time playing this game, and I'll say it's fun the first time you play through a map.  Unfortunately there are enough poorly thought out design choices and game-breaking bugs that I have to recommend you stay away from this one.  If you do play it, stay away from higher difficulties, or resign yourself to frustration.  Also be warned that the game's multiplayer is only for the two least-played modes (Daybreak, and the special story mode).

There are a lot of good things to say about this game.  The gameplay loop is fun - the balance of zombie-killing action, resource-gathering and base-management is a great combo.  The characters and their dialogue are diverse enough that it takes a while for them to get stale (though I eventually found myself turning off the characters' spoken audio).  I personally didn't get into the Daybreak mode - I find there are better games for fighting zombie hordes.

The game features perma-death, which ramps up the tension of survival.  It's heartbreaking when a character succumbs to the zombie plague just seconds before they can reach the cure.  It's triumphant when a survivor stuck deep in zombie territory survives the long Odyssey home after their vehicle blows up on the wrong side of the map.  It can be frustrating, but ultimately the game gives the player enough tools to mitigate the risk and come back from character deaths that it doesn't feel entirely unfair.

What does feel unfair is when challenges ramp up or deaths occur as the result of game-breaking bugs.  I won't list all the (numerous) bugs I encountered, but I will say that my last game had a series of increasingly frustrating bugs that ended in a soft-lock.  The game loaded with my character in an inaccessible place, with no way out.  I struggled to get my character killed rather than lose the more than hundred hours I'd spent on the save file.

Though, for that matter, why play a game where that's a genuine possibility?  The game advertises replayability, with stacking rewards for multiple playthroughs.  That is greatly undermined when you can lose everything for no reason, and with no recourse.  The difficulty of your game should not come from unfair game-breaking bugs.  Players should not be frustrated that one mis-click on a poorly-designed menu will lock them into a map where their only options are to abandon their save, or slog through a few dozen hours of grinding gameplay.  When you advertise multiplayer, it should probably be included in your main game instead of just the side modes.

Though the game wears the clothes of one that can be played for a long time with increasing difficulties and rewards, that's an illusion.  The game-breaking bugs will stymie the otherwise strong gameplay loop.  If you decide to play this game, know that it'll be fun for a little while, but won't hold up at higher difficulties.  Also know that the game's open-ended story doesn't really have a conclusion (at least not one meant to provide any meaningful resolution).

Its kinda a good game, a lot of fun if you ignore all of the quests, survivors and install few mods.
I personally use only 2 .. 900 storage and 100 vehicle inventory. 

If you play the game as it is, you will be doing a lot of driving. It will be more like "DRIVING SIMULATOR" but bad driving simulator and you wont be able to focus on the game that much. 
There really isnt any story, just some minor story quest line. Rest of the quests are totally optional, you either do them and get good neighbors you can maybe recruit if you want their skills, or dont do it and they leave, new ones will come later or become hostile but wont actually do anything, they just stay in their home, wont assault you.

The world isnt really alive, everything is scripted, predetermined. If you want more zombies, increasing difficulty wont actually help, they are just harder to kill. If you ignore the world, they wont spread, multiply or something. Zombies protect their "homes", lets say hives called heart .. if you destroy it, thats it. No new will appear. 

You can walk or drive the car, problem is, your inventory is bigger than car's inventory. You can have up to 12 spaces for items, cars have only like 4. 
Your base storage fully upgraded to like 80 can barely hold 10 days worth of food .. depends on how many people you have. If you store more, you will start losing it on its own. You are not allowed to save it in any way, you can put them into cars but then you would need to have 100 cars around your base. Thus the mods.
The put everything into the storage and the car so you can actually spend some time exploring and fighting zombies.

Zombies sometimes do SIEGE on your base but its pathetic, 5 zombies will try to attack you. The attacks needs to lot more savage. I can completely ignore the sieges on my bases when exploring, no one ever died in my base. I died few times by not paying attention :) 

Game even on lethal is kinda super easy, currently looking for mods that makes the game much more difficult. More zombies, more hearts, more infestations, bigger siege attacks, something that makes the game more challenging and actually makes me think for a second.

Missing any kind of PHOTO MODE or a key to hide HUD for convenience.
Some more GPU options would nice too .. like turn off film grain. 
Option to allow more zombies in your vision, to chase you longer etc.
Pratice for next Pandemic

In a sentence: this is the best zombie-survival game I have ever played, with hands-down the best dev team of the genre.

It was day 27 of the zombie apocalypse, and I was taking my favorite character out for scavenging. I'd recently ran out of gas, so I decided, what the heck, I'll just run to the nearest potential gas site... over half a kilometer away. This may not sound that far to you, but in the zombie apocalypse, half a kilometer on foot is like the journey your grandparents traveled to and from school back in their day: uphill both ways, in 5 feet of snow, with only a raw potato for lunch. But I'm no dummy. So before heading out, I grabbed a vial of plague cure, along with a bunch of stimulants, in case I happened to get into trouble...

Flash forward about 45 minutes. My favorite character is sprinting back to base, having contracted blood plague for a SECOND time this trip, after using up the one vial of plague cure I brought along. The timer at the bottom left of the screen is counting down the seconds until my guy drops dead from the plague. Meanwhile, there are three. Count. THREE Ferals (cat-like zombies that run on all fours and hate you and everyone you know) sprinting after me. My dude is downing stimulants like they're fricken Tic Tacs, while hauling butt back to base. He's bobbing and weaving like he's the star of a new Rocky movie, as these ferals hurl past him every couple seconds trying to slice through him like warm butter. But my guy has quads of steel, glutes that could crack open a walnut, and enough stimulants in him to kill a small country, so he just keeps on trucking. I'm on the edge of my seat, actively shouting at the screen, squeezing my controller to death, and implementing any other proven tactics I can think of for increasing the speed of my character.

Finally, I throw the door open to my base as my other community members gather to beat the ever-living heck out of these stupid ferals (it was a joyous moment). The timer has three seconds left on it as I down a vial of plague cure from my supply locker. My guy was safe. The relief I felt was better than having a scheduled phone call be canceled. Pure bliss.

The next day, my favorite character ran into a bloater while driving, contracted blood plague, and was then beaten into the ground by a Juggernaut. Devastation... like going over to a friend's house for a sleepover and realizing you forgot to bring an extra controller.

I will never forget you, favorite character, whose name has escaped me.

Been playing for awhile. Good game. One of the better survival horror, open world, build your base/community zombie games out there. My first game, I played the first few hours with settings: Action = Nightmare & Map = Lethal. Lost a guy, got depressed and figured I'm ready to restart with a new community on Lethal on a different map LOL. Haven't looked back. Good times! 

Pros: 
- Scratches that itch when you're lookingn for base building survival horror, without the PVP BS shenanigans. 
- Survivors with their own quirk skills/trait to make them more unique. 
- Build up your base/community. 

Con: 
- Random BS spawning. 
- Need Microsoft Xbox Live account... which is free to get and is only needed to start the game, can turn off your internet afterwards. Tested it myself. 
- Game save is cloud based so no cheating.
- Wish the base building was more detailed and elaborate. 

Recommendation: Yes. If you like SURVIVAL HORROR, OPEN WORLD, BASE/COMMUNITY BUILDING, ZOMBIE/MONSTER games. 

Note: 
- Base building/crafting is simplified so you don't lay down blueprint and build your own layout and stuff.
- There's multiple difficulties so don't complain that you suck and it's hard. Just stick to GREEN MODE.

I can easily sink 4-5 hours before i need a break to refresh myself for the next gaming session. With 100hrs in this game,  i can still see myself playing this game for a few hundred more. 

This game is worth it at full price.

I liked the first State of Decay, so I gave this one a fair shot (2 shots, actually). In the end, it's still NO from me.

Reasons:
- [b]Bad performance[/b]: Game is unoptimized. Low GPU usage means low FPS on a decent rig and frequent stutters.
- [b]NPCs[/b]: AI is clunky, "people" in enclaves just stand around, spitting generic quests and the dialog system is a joke.
- [b]Bugs[/b]: Stuck in looting animation, zombies can't cross invisible lines, hordes inside terrain... That sort of things.

With State of Decay 3 being in the works for a while now, I doubt any serious issues will be addressed, so just skip this one.

One of the most generic open-world zombie games ever that somehow manages to do (almost) everything extremely well. Depending on the difficulty you play on it's either going to be a boring, repetitive experience  or a thrilling, high-stakes survival horror game that keeps you hooked for hundreds of hours.

Multiplayer works like a charm 90% of the time. Performance could be better at times and the game's potential is slightly handicapped on PC because of the console version. It's not perfect but comes ever so close.

Because other reviews seem to like to whine about it:
Requires a FREE Xbox-Live Account to play (which is clearly stated on the store page). However, this is not an Xbox-Live SUBSCRIPTION. You do not need to pay to play Singleplayer or Multiplayer!

A rare completely justified and masterfully executed open world game. SOD 2 is a fully simulated zombie survival experience. You scout out for supplies, make reasonable guesses about what you might be able to find where, and can scavenge a town dry, then needing to transport all your people to a new base. Your people can die permanently, get sick, etc. There's base construction and dynamic events. It's all completely cohesive. And if you want to give up on your current state, you can move to another one (or the same one to reset it).

Alerting a horde, having a panicked dash back to base, getting overwhelmed - these all happen organically or not based on how you interact with the environment.

State of Decay 2 is a top-tier systemic simulation game.

This is one of those games where I wish Steam had an "It's okay but not great." option.

The game has a lot going for it.  Game play, graphics, and concept all work well.  I liked a lot of what I saw and how the game worked.

Unfortunately, I would say give this game a pass unless you really like zombie games and REALLY like grinding.

The game starts strong but, while I played over 30 hours, most of that felt repetitive and a little tedious.  I found little reason to experiment with new strategies or weapon load outs.  I ignored about 90% of the features and options (radio stuff etc.) as either ineffective or not worth the bother to click on it.  I also found that I quickly started to ignore side missions, especially as all my survivors maxed out their various stats/abilities.

Even the driving feature of the game wore out it's welcome almost immediately.  While the cluttered roads are very appropriate, I found that I actually dreaded having to use vehicles as the "fast travel" option they were meant to be.  I tended to use them only for trips to the opposite sides of the map and then only after I had already explored most of the map on foot.

The base building aspect is also very underwhelming, simply filling slots with whatever options fits your needs best at that point in time.  Again, many options getting ignored simply because it wasn't worth the trouble.

A expandable starter base with missions to loot other abandoned bases for expansions and new facilities would have been a more interesting and engaging way to go.

So, if the concept appeals to you then you could probably get you money's worth out of the game (especially on sale).  Just don't expect anything too grand or in depth (it is a $30 - $40 game after all).

While on Steam I only have 8 hours, I have logged close to 1000 on multiple communities on the Xbox version of the game when it initially released. 

This game is addicting first and foremost, finding weapons, managing your community, finding survivors to join the cause and just smashing zombies is just fun and keeps you engaged. While there are some features I would change in the game, the overall principle of the game is great. When playing on harder difficulties is where the game shines. The lack of materials, the absolute threat of a horde or a feral lurking about is truly terrifying and could cost you tons of time invested in a character and the community. It's this more hardcore difficulty that makes me really enjoy the game, but also one that makes me wish there were some new mechanics either implemented in a patch or hopefully in the third installment of the game.

If you are on the fence with this game and have Game Pass, I highly recommend you give this game a try and play it on a harder difficulty and with a mindset of pure survival. If you are a fan of just zombie games, open world survival games this is a game you will like.
