This one is a mixed bag for me, I love post-apocalyptic open worlds, the crumbled society, the loss, the tragedy of it just gets me. Anyway, this game is set in a beautiful post-apocalyptic world with so much to explore and uncover, I love sneaking around hordes of zombies to explore the buildings, uncover the story of that building, what happened there, what can I salvage to help me on my way. This is where the game fails first, there is no story to uncover, just loot and maybe you'll find some survivors that want you to help them destroy a horde and then trade. That is as deep as it gets.

Still, even though the story is handed to you rather than uncovered, I really enjoy the exploration aspect. The combat is great too, you get an amazing sense of satisfaction from dropping a bunch of zombies. The combat is well thought out too, you can just go charging to a horde and expect to make it out, you can get overwhelmed quite easily. 

There is a base management aspect in this game, you have to select a home and then build defences, gardens, beds, and an infirmary, ensuring you and your group have what you need. You have to manage the people, some of them will be trouble or grow weary and it is your job to manage that.

This is the second big problem for me. The game is constantly telling me something else needs doing, every single time I leave the home camp to go exploring a new area I get notifications that the base is under attack, or a new survivor has radioed in for help, or one of the group is arguing etc. When a survivor group asks for help and you don't go to their aid, you will lose their trust, and after a while, they become an enemy. There is a core concept of plague zombies, these are zombies that are under the effects of a plague heart in the nearby area. When you or your community get attacked by these zombies in close combat you will get infected. You can cure this by collecting 'samples' dropped by the infected and then using these at the infirmary to create the vaccine. If you take a community member with you on a mission as backup, they will be guaranteed to get infected, so once again, the burden is on you to ensure they make it back to camp in time, brew up a vaccine and apply it. Grind....

It is too busy, with too much happening at the same time. It feels like the game is trying to be several games in one, a city manager, an exploration game, and a good ol' third-person action game. Most of the time I just ignore the survivors unless I'm in the area, they get all upset with me, so when I pass by I will make a load of noise to draw a horde in and voila, no more mardy survivors.

Don't get me wrong, I like the game, I will keep going back to the community that I've created to advance it a little more. But I will always get frustrated after a while and put it down. If you like post-apocalyptic games set in an open world with some excellent combat, get this game. It is good, it is excellent in fact. Just be prepared to grind a little. I'm sure there are methods of reducing this, maybe just exile everybody in your community and go lone wolf.- hmmm might try this in a fresh game.

BEST COMMUNITY ZOMBIE SURVIVAL GAME

So, is this game worth it? Well, if you ask me, I could write about this title for hours but... you don't have hours to spend, do you? So, tell you what: let's cut to the chase and you go check my game time! Isn't that enough of an answer?

Also, [i]Undead Labs[/i] gets points from me for still updating this game to this day with various degrees of new content and with some new mechanics as well, even when deep into developing State of Decay 3. It has a solid fan base despite not having the best multiplayer options. I mean, it is fun to play with friends and with random players but it is hardly rewarding if you simply join someone else's game as you are just helping the other guy around and not developing your own community at all (if not with some totally forgettable loot). But still, it is an experience I suggest you to make.

If you want to feel all the thrills this game has to offer, you have to go for [b]Lethal Difficulty[/b] [i](Hello, permadeath!)[/i]. It's way beyond hard if you are not used to the game mechanics but if you learn the ropes well it will eventually become the only game mode you will want to experience with your community.

Ahhh, if only we could have workshop support or a good world editor! You know, for when the five maps included in the game become a little too familiar. There's absolutely nothing in that department.

Some tips too: go for [b]Marathon[/b], [b]Stealth[/b], [b]Swordplay[/b] and [b]Gunslinger[/b] specializations and you won't have much of an hard time trying to keep your survivor alive. Even lethal difficulty will be manageable, in my experience. You can also hire some [b]Red Talon[/b] contractors using the currency earned by playing [b]Daybreak[/b] mode (not the most fun game mode, in my opinion, but some things you unlock there will be made available for your community to use). Oh, and travel light. I mean, really light. Equip some [i]ultralight[/i] backpack if you find any. It stores less stuff but you will be quick if paired with a Stealth/Marathon specialization. This combo has saved the neck of my survivors many times already!

Have fun, ok?

REVIEW UPDATE Jan.2023
I've recently been back to SoD2 and I do LIKE what is see:
A lot of bugs, that kept me from playing in the early stages have been solved. Graphic and game mechanic updates over time renewed my love for the SoD serie as a whole.
PC port is so much more reactive and on point, then it has been, physics bugs (like your car driving over a zombie, becoming an uncontrollable spacecraft tumbling across the map) still happens, but very very rarely.
Some things are still a bit fuzzy, or difficult to understand (like some survivor skills) or NPC behaviour (aka the AI for combat), but that's just a quirk.

So Overall: At start SoD2 was a mess, and xbox features only made them worse. But now this game is quite enjoyable (as solo player game), and Dev updates indicate, that although they are working hard on SoD 3, there are planned updates for SoD2.

Therefore I also change my recommendation from "hell no" to "Yes please".
State of Decay 2 Juggernaut Edition is worth the money!
Happy Zombie slappin, survivors!



******* below old review ******

I love State of Decay - bugs, glitches, weird mechanic and all.
It always felt much more like a good zombie survival + building game then a lot of the other games out there, and it sure felt engaging and immersive. Learing about your small community of survivors and misfits - story mode or beyond - was just awesome. So I spend a lot more hours in SoD1 then a buggy game would usually deserve.
So when SoD2 finally hit PC I just had to get it!

Apparently lots of youtubers talked about how much better the 2nd part is and how much the Devs worked on it. How much more there is to build, explore, and experiance... and there sure is.

BUT here starts my review after 19 hours of SoD2 in 2 different game modes on 3 different maps with 4 different starter characters:


With SoD2 YOU GET THE SAME BUGS/GLITCHES as in SoD1!! Period!

They are occuring much less often, but they do. It took me just ~1 hour into the game, when I drove my car over a regular zombie and lift off the ground propelling like a boomerang. Then, about 1 hour later, I had a Screamer that was stuck in a car wreck right outside the first base - glitching there like in a Bethesda game. Screaming on and on and on, spawning in so many zombies I lost 2 of 4 survivors.
Zombies spawning inside environment (and being unkillable) is a constant problem in SoD2 - as well as the fact, that zombies just spawn behind your back. You clear a open piece of land, you turn around, and you get new spawns right away. Zombies just grow out of the blue... 

Beside this the story pace is a bit off putting in normal story mode.
If you haven't played SoD1 (where you learn about the diff kind of Zeds), you will learn about them in this part only by running into them. The Tutorial and the popp-ups ARE really helpfull teaching you basic mechanics, but everything else is not explained (unless you count the kind-of-encyclopaedia, you might find by chance in the menu).
Also the general threat advances far more rapidly then in SoD1 - in each session (normal mode) zombies kept spawning near by although each infestation were delt with in minutes (btw: cars are still the way to go, to deal with large numbers).
Same goes for social problems. My second group kinda broke apart after 4-5 hours because of inner-group disputes (between the 2 start characters, mind you!!).

A problem on top is, that the characters are far less endearing then in SoD1. The survivors' story (building a base then dealing with zombies) is very generic - and there is no problem with that - but when your characters don't keep you involved, and they are just tools to solve certain mechanics, the character's story becomes obsolete - a bit of a problem in a RP-element Zombie survival game.

Don't forget about the control bzw - SoD isn't the first PC game, that uses a wibble wobbley console control conversion. unnecessary turn arounds (because your frikken characters can't take a step back, like you are used to in every PC game aiming a range weapon) ends you up presenting your neck to a zombie almost every time you're in a fist fight. And btw you can fly... er... i mean fall off a cell phone tower ever so often, when you step next to a ladder, and your character steps on and not net to said ladder. Wheeeeeeee SPLORT!
I wish you could at least re-assign all of your keys...

On the very positive side...
..I need to mention the new skill feature - which is really neat! You can find books around the world, so characters without special skills can learn one. Got no mechanic in your group?? Read "How To Become A Mechanic 101" and you're ready to pimp that ride!

Also UN-STUCK option via map UI - this is really something the game needed!

Also a nice thing are cosmetics you can find around the map. Open a random container and maybe you'll find a stylish cowboy hat, or a fancy ninja outfit. Doesn't change stats but sure makes your fav character look rad!

And the diff game modes/maps are REALLY neat. You can even return to the overrun and blood plague infected map of SoD1 - and if you played SoD1, just driving through it is worthwhile!

+++++++++++++++++
Overall: 
I will keep playing SoD2, at least till I finished the main story, but giving the development and conversion time for PC, I have to admit I am dissapointed by the gameplay and occurence of year old bugs/glitches.
Sure, some things will always turn up in one way or the other, still self propelling cars, stuck enemies and weirdly generated zombie hordes on top of rocks, cliffs and buildings you cannot get up to or even aim up to, because you can't aim straight up or down in this game, are redicolous.

So my recommandation to all who played SoD1: if you loved the game, you can check out SoD2
To all who didn't play SoD1 or didn't like it: get yourself another game!

++++++++++++++++++

edit (OUTDATED)

about 6 hours after I wrote this negative review the game itself had severe connection problems.
(that happens when you design a game, that needs 24/7 internet connection for it's single player OFFLINE content. Didn't Microsoft learn about "It's not a bug, it's a feature" before?)

Anyway: 2 hours later Microsoft locked my account down for "suspicious activities", meaning normal single player gaming WITHOUT any kind of mods, loosing connection because of bad servers making one log in every few minutes (mind you I'm working with a steady 2000kb glass fiber connection here), which xbox bots deem as "suspicious activity". *sigh*

Anyway - That is the second time I got problems with the Xbox / Microsoft account service after writing a negative review about a Microsoft game. Of course this is just coincident, but it shows me, that my negative review was on point. And for all this game is (not) worth, I actually don't care about trying to regain acess of this 'game'.

State Of Decay 2 is just a polished rebrand of the original State of Decay 1 with a inferiour UI, less story, less engagement, an unfinished and not thought through coop-mode. It will most likely leave SoD1 veterans with a sour taste in their mouths - after throwing 30€ into the gutter for a buggy game. 

edit edit: just learned you cannot play co-op over Steam, but you need to pay the 9,99 monthly fee, to play the game with your friends (who also need to pay 9,99 per month) via Xbox-client. So if you're not in the Xbox-Club, don't buy it.

"Keep your friends close, keep youre ZOMBIES closer AHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAAHAHAHAHAHAHAAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHA" - bLADE from Blade 2

Even though this game came out in 2020, It is totally relevant by todays' standards. I only have a dash over 28 hours into the game, But let me tell you some GOOD take aways that I have gotten from State of Decay 2. (Worth noting) I DID NOT play state of decay 1. So my take will be a fresh take on playing this series starting with "State of Decay 2".

1. SOD2 has a really decent RPG aspect to the game. You can have multiple survivors (Up to 12 total) with DIFFERENT traites to help the entire community. I believe there are over 25 different traits (including passive traits). The More you use the skill, the higher the skill ranks up. You can even make your citizens "heros". this is a good thing. then, when your time is up and you are ready to move on to a different map, you can upload your characters, (up to 50) to the legacy pool and us these heros again in another map. VERY COOL.

2. SOD2 has a DECENT base building aspect of the game. You build your base and defend the base and the people in it from zombie attacks. ALTHOUGH this IS a MINER aspect of the game, it is still fun and relevant to the game at hand. depending on how you build your base and defenses. also determines on how often you will be attacked. there are things you can build and put into place to lower your awareness to the zombies. this can be useful depending on your play style.

3. SOD2 IS a sandbox AND a completion story all in one. I beat the game and I am still playing on the same map. So, I would equate this style of game play akin to "KENSHI" (Another REALLY GREAT GAME). 

I know this is not really an indepth game review, but I would like to say this as a final thought. IF you are THINKING about trying a game that has RPG elements, Could be a sandbox, You WANT to sink a lot of hours into, You can try Multiple DIFFERENT ways of winning, And you CAN have a REAL challenge OR you can be VERY casual....then this game is REALLY calling to YOU. Try it out. You WILL be Happy that you did.

This review is from the perspective of a casual gamer that mostly plays action RPGs, enjoys some level of difficulty and always solo. I have close to 200 hours of gameplay, but I am no way an expert in the game.

Not into survival games esp ones with perma death, but I'm glad I gave this one a try and now I cannot stop playing. It's a great game, but I'll have to start off with one of it's biggest sins. IMO you get to end game way too fast. The campaign ends too abruptly so it's kind of a bummer later on when I have a lot of resources and items but can't really enjoy them coz I know it's about to end. Sure you get your boons and you can continue on with your community to a new map and even save your leveled up survivors for later use, but it's not enough to make me feel like the reward is worth what I'm losing at the end. This plus the fact the maps are kind of small, the story is more of an afterthought and the zombies a bit underwhelming esp mid-game, eventually make the game feel pointless and I have to actively slow down my quest progression just to be able to enjoy what I've built. For a sandbox game, it feels like a DLC and I wish it wasn't like that.

Heartland is a nice little extra if you want something with more of a story and a chill introduction to the game's mechanics. Don't expect too much of the story tho. Just think of it as a long intro/tutorial mode with a sort of linear path. I would recommend new players to start with Heartland before jumping into the campaign.

Daybreak is too repetitive and grindy for me. You get nice rewards that you can use in your campaign which is cool, but I just personally don't enjoy the game mode.

Customizable difficulty is a dope feature and I'm glad it's there.

One minor gripe that kind of turns me off is how large some of the weapons look esp assault rifles and submachine guns on female survivors, but this is just me being nitpicky.

Combat is better than I expected. Guns sound and feel great, which is a big plus for me and I was pleasantly surprised to discover some depth to melee combat. Blunt weapons can CC, bladed weapons do high single enemy DPS, but degrades faster, etc. You can execute different moves depending on both the weapon type and skills you choose to upgrade. Pretty dope. Weapon customization would've been awesome, but whatever.

Follower AI is not good. Just go out solo or you'll risk getting one of your survivors killed. Learned that the hard way. Watched my first favorite survivor try to melee 3 hostiles with guns and got wrecked. She was the lover of my warlord leader and that made him cold and merciless. It sucked that she died, but great for role-playing lol.

Some game mechanics are frustrating, like timed side missions or if when your survivor gets fatigued during a main quest and needing to switch to a different survivor will make you abandon that quest. Maybe there's a way around this that I don't know about, otherwise I just either abandon the quest and wait for it to restart or push thru it with no stamina. Sucks.

I do not play multiplayer, but if you're into that then you'll probably enjoy it like a lot of people seem to do.

Visually, it's alright. It's not ugly, but it eynt that pretty either. Some textures look great and sometimes it looks cartoony, which isn't a bad thing. It works. Night time is really dark, which is realistic I guess, but it's still too dark in your base even if it's powered.

Please add weather cycles. Be nice to see rain, snow, fog or even thunderstorms every now and then.

Performance is good. Consistently runs 60fps at 1080p running max settings with my Ryzen 5600G and RTX 3060 and have only had a couple of very minor bugs overall.

Vehicles are alright IMO. Good handling, upgradable and I've never had any issues with running out of fuel or totaling the vehicle. With some care, of course. The vehicles could use more item slots tho. It's kind of dumb that some backpacks have more item slots than most vehicles. Traveling back and forth from a looting area to an outpost is just tedious. Some of the special vehicles look corny as hell, but that's completely subjective and I'm fine with it since I have plenty of simple vehicles to choose from. Please please please add motorcycles.

Base building and management is fun and satisfying. Plenty of facilities to choose from with different and very specific functions that can be changed or unlocked depending on your survivors' skills. Then there are base mods that you can install to either add or augment a facility function. Pretty cool. I just wish there was a way to make your base completely zombie-proof. I mean, you're capable of having all these high tech stuff (which I won't spoil), but zombies can still just casually open your gates and jump your fences? It doesn't make sense. Parking cars to block doorways isn't something players should have to resort to as a defensive strategy. If we can build watchtowers then we should be able to build higher walls and for the love of god, locked gates.

There's a lot to love about the game. Just keep your expectations in check and you should be able to enjoy it without getting too disappointed when it ends. That having said I still do recommend trying it out if you're into this sort of game. Looking forward to future updates and more from Undead Labs.

There are many problems with this game that I would like to comment:

· There is no actual plot the game does not keep the player entertained throughout the whole game. All you have to do is complete some boring missions that are pretty repetetive. Your main goal is to just survive and grow your community which at certain point of the game becomes pointless. Since you are in a very small limited map

· The game for me is more like minecraft in survival mode with many limits and issues:
- Very bad building system, I have only few slots to build something on my base and no matter which map I choose I will be still have that limit. Also, takes too long to build them sometimes.
- Constant bugs or glitches where either my car or npc just get stucked in and then I just have to leave it as it be since there is no way of fixing it
- The command center does not allow to control more than 5-6 outposts which creates a huge limit and you just have to take much more time looking for resources than focusing on your missions. Since outposts are the only place that can give you constant resources and since you need many different resources like food, medicine, electricity etc. you have to look for the rest of the resources that the outposts can provide you with.

· A wrong multiplayer regime!
Players can only join to the game of their friends help them gather resources and aid them during raids but can not really interact in the missions (which are again very repetetive) with you. Also, they have to leave their resources in the storage if you want to use them. Basically, you can't play with your firends propperly since you can't initiate the game with them and still they have no rights when they play with you. I mean like building stuff in the base or even play while you are out. They can only join when you are playing which makes no sense.

· The zombies keep surrounding you base which affects the community mood and in the end you have to waste time killing them all to maintain a good mood in the community. 

· It could be way better if there were servers, or if in the game the communities were real (played by real people). Instead its just bunch of npc in constant need of resources or help with zombies who do not even help you in any way they are just pointless.  

· The only way to entertain a bit is to play on high difficulty level since on those levels it takes few seconds for you to die.

There many other issues with this game that I could write about a whole book but I just don't want to spend anymore time on this game

Tbh its better to play many other alternatives of zombie games like dying light, left for dead etc. The game just doesn't have anyhting unique in it.
The game just sucks at certain point and it doesnt get better.

Great game.

The game is not perfect and certainly has its rough patches, but it delivers really well on a particular type of experience that is generally hard to come by, so if you crave what it's trying to do, you're gonna have a pretty good time despite the flaws.



NEGATIVES/GRIPES:

--How enemy spawns work can be a little bit irritating. Zombie spawns center around two things: the player's location and your base's location. On one hand, this adds excitement in the sense that there are ALWAYS zombies around to endanger you. And yet, it does sometimes result in a feeling that a horde of zombies materialized out of thin air behind you (though the game mostly hides it well) and something that could only be described as "spawn creep". When you first load your game, there are a reasonable number of zombies outside your base. But the longer you play, the hordes and super zombies outside your base grow in number and strength to the point it starts to get a little ridiculous. It's like the zombie spawn equivalent of a memory leak. You can just reload your save to reset the spawns if it gets too obnoxious. I find myself questioning if the spawn creep is by design or if there is just something wrong with spawning behavior. The standard difficulty says the super zombies ("freaks") should be mostly isolated threats, but that's not really true once the spawn creep progresses enough. You will have two juggernauts, three ferals, 2 screamers, and a bloater outside your walls before you know it. 

--You will definitely have to google some things. Sometimes just because the game doesn't explain it when you need it, sometimes because the game doesn't explain it thoroughly or clearly enough, and sometimes (rarely but sometimes) something makes no sense or isn't explained at all and you just plain have to ask reddit. One example is if your group leader is the BUILDER leader type, you get a story mission (i.e. mandatory to beat the map) that tells you to build or upgrade a facility. But if you are already at max facilities with max upgrades, it doesn't count it. Reddit confirms: in this case if you have already completed the objective, the game doesn't know. You have to destroy a facility, then build it back in order to trick the game into thinking you just built it. Stupid sh** like this happens in this game, so you're gonna have to meet it halfway sometimes.

--Other humans are a little annoying. Different groups of survivors populate on the map, and they will radio you and ask you if you'll do things for them CONSTANTLY. It is CONTANT. If you do it, they become friendly, stay on the map, and become a kinda permanent trading post and potential recruitment pool. Cool. But if you are working on something else, like eliminating plague hearts or infestations, and you just ignore them because you're busy, they will accuse you of being a monster and an a***ole and only caring about yourself and they might even becomes hostile toward you and attack you on sight if they see you. This seems a little absurd. "Both our groups are struggling to survive out here, and I know you're technically helping me by clearing the infestations that are endangering my life, but could you drop everything you're doing and bring me a pencil sharpener in the next five minutes? No? WELL F*** YOU THEN. YOU BETTER HOPE I DON'T SEE YOU." You just have to learn to ignore it and live with it.

--Similarly, the game constantly nags you to "clear infestations". Your allies in your base nag you with voice lines about it, you get notification nags about it, and you get morale penalties for having too many on the map. But even if you go out and clear 3 or 4 of them from the map, they'll immediately respawn before you even make it back to your base. The spawn rate on them is so obnoxious that you'll just end up ignoring them and accepting the morale penalty. They are extremely not worth your time, despite all the nags. 

--Some stuff I just plain don't understand why it is like it is. for example, if a zombie latches onto your car door, there is a button you can hold or tap to either hold the door open (to slam them into something) or to shake the door (to try to shake them off). If you don't remove them, they eventually pull off your door, and the next zombie to latch will pull you out of the driver seat. But if a feral type zombie attaches to your door, the door-shake button no longer functions, and so they pull your door off every time. Is this deliberate? A bug? I have no idea.

Positives:

--Cocaine for loot goblins

--The combination of action, stealth, looting, and management is excellent and all I want in a game. I love that mix. Combat could be slightly better in some places but is extremely good enough. Management stuff takes a while to understand in full, but it's deep enough and customizable enough to be satisfying. The game encouraging you to occasionally move your entire base of operations to a new point on the map is pretty cool, and I appreciate that it makes this easy to do (from a management perspective.... there are still zombies.)

--The maps are very large and great to explore. You can go inside of almost every building and loot them, and securing different vehicles that still function and trying to get them back to base is a great hook for base management. (They add transportation, but are also weapons, but also augment your storage in unique ways.)

--The legacy survivor system and leadership boon system after "beating the game" on a map is pretty cool and generously implemented from a QOL viewpoint. I had trouble understanding their explanation of it, but it's nifty.

--Survivor settlement system is what you wish the Fallout 4 settlement system was like. 

--Being able to control every individual members of your group and instantly switch between them is pretty awesome.

--Trying to slowly assemble your ultimate survivor squad via the legacy system as you beat map after map is a great long term goal to keep you playing new maps. Trying to win with every leader type is also a great hook to keep you playing through the entire campaign again and again.

IN SHORT:

It's not perfect. It's got some rough edges, and I definitely have my gripes, but even so, it's got a great gameplay hook and I've been having an awesome time.

So I got 45 hours out of this game, and I wouldn't have done a fraction of that without the Heartland expansion (that's included.)   The Campaign isn't really one at all, but rather, a sandbox with a lot of gathering side missions and clearing maps.  You can bring all your toys (people/gear/etc) and go to another map, but it feels empty.  You can keep manually increasing difficulty if you like, but?  I like progressive difficulty with a story and steps toward the end.  Once you have a full auto shotgun and some bombs, you can zip through plague hearts in the Campaign.  But its good (and I felt necessary) training for Hearland.
Heartland is a story driven no-looking-back approach and I had some close calls, and some heartbreaking fails (I lost my master gunsmith to a feral and juggernaut combined attack) and that meant I lost all those gun making abilities.
Unless you're on a gather/defend mission, a companion was more of a liability than a help, as they could be overwhelmed if you're near any kind of zed concentration, and then you lose more abilities back at base.  Deaths are permanent, and it adds to the thrill,  but your companions fight to the bitter end, making it hard to pick who COULD die from my roster.  I guess its part of the challenge, but I went solo on "shoot the bad red thing until it dies" missions because the hordes coming to stop me would always nail my companion.

I still look forward to a happy and horny SoD part 3.  Days Gone, which is more of what I favor,  DEFINITELY gets the award for best zombie horde mechanics in a game, but SoD2 is does well.

If you're looking for:

- a Difficult Zombie Survival game
- In depth basebuilding
- Interesting multiplayer mechanics

This is not the game for you.  Seems solid singleplayer but as somebody who bought this to play with friends the multiplayer mechanics leave a lot to be desired.  

Theres no cooperative basebuilding, the host is the only one that can make decisions and upgrade the base, etc.  The game is in no way difficult, we were playing on the second highest difficulty for almost 5 hours and did not have a single death.  Ammo isnt super scarce, very easy to get a car up and running and the difficulty doesnt scale with multiplayer.  I could tell that if I had been playing singleplayer these encounters would be challenging but with three people everything was a breeze.  Overall, the 5 hours were enjoyable but I cant see myself ever touching this game again.

The best zombie sandbox out there. Geared with different systems that fills the scenario your group is in making unique moments throughout the experience.

You can control anyone in your group while taking care of expeditions outside your survivors fort to feed and keep ammunition stock.

It is amazing the systems in place to simulate a community fighting for survival against nasty zombies populating the outside.

The zombies feels different enough to keep the experience fresh. The same zombie model, may not behave always the same. Some run, some move sluggish, some jump at you. And there are the specials zombies, like in all zombie games, they have special abilities that you should beware at all times.

Playing in the Nightmare difficulty (one bellow the maximum) on my first run. It begun insanely difficult but immensely rewarding. Every action there is a consequence and often the consequences are permanent. One wrong turn, you can say goodbye to your leveled up survivor and having to bring someone else over to grab back the weapons lost.

It is an amazing sandbox experience in the likes of Mount&Blade, without the world map section.

Everything is made by systems talking to each other. Expect little to no handcrafted stories besides radio chatter giving away lore and context.

I'm just scratching the story part, still, but had a pretty good entertainment for the entry fee and it is a complete game out of the gate.

Co-op with a friend has been very entertaining and funny as well. Besides a few quirks on how the multiplayer is made, I can understand a few things. You'll join your friend as one member of a community you have on your single player part of the game. If your friend joins you, he will be one of the members he has on their single player campaign and he will help your community as an outsider. 

Saddly being an outsider in a co-op, means the base management is only enabled for the host to interact. Every item that's not a rucksack brought by your friend will be deposited on their community unless he drops the item making it a donation.

Overall experience is been a blast and full of adventures.

Making long distance scavenge runs on foot is insanely tense.

High Risk, High Reward type of game.

[b] Achievements.A lot and long achievements. [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
Like killing zombies? Establishing a base? Building a community with different characters? Then this is one of the best (almost exclusively single-player) game for you. With customization of difficulty and maps you can tailor the game to suit your own playstyle. Other modes include a more story-driven campaign-map and a horde-survival mode which you can play by yourself or others. 

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
There are only some harder achievements in the game, some that require coop and some that will take a long time to complete based on grind or even time alone. I can only recommend this game to other fans of these types of games: open-world, some base building, community building and zombie-themed. If you enjoy these games then this game will provide a massive experience to complete. Estimated time to complete: about 250+ hours.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
This game provides a massive and very enjoyable experience for the fans of the open-world survival games. I strongly recommend the game on itself and for the achievement hunters I cautiously advise to be aware of the long completion time required to finish the game.
I like killing other humans

It's a fun game that takes a lot from the first State of Decay and takes it on for a new spin. The integration of a COOP possibility is nice, albeit it is extremely unrewarding for the guests of the host, who will make little to no-progress throughout the game. It's a better COOP experience if you've previously beat the game, otherwise you'll be stuck with starter characters and so on so forth. It's a fun game nonetheless, just very poor COOP integration. The game also just constantly crashes at every opportunity it gets, and it being a game made for Windows performs very poorly on Windows, and doesn't support even built-in native Windows features.

2023: a lot of things seem to have gotten better. But if you like to have your Windows taskbar at the top of the screen, everything in the game will be offset.

The game seems really exciting at first but quickly becomes repetitive. There's not much of a story around it. It is an open world in one sense but the world isn't that big (there are several maps, you can switch between them in a less than ideal way). 

Your basic objective is to clear all the plague hearts (and I think infestations) on the map. On regular difficulty you just get 2 survivors, some painkillers, some cures and some mines and drive over near it and clear the nearby area then use the mines to blow it up (3 needed; craftable). Clearing infestations can be done by getting any vehicle and using the sirens or horn to attract the zombies outside after which you just drive them all over with the car. Occasionally there is a juggernaut on-site by coincidence so you can't use the car for that (same with bloater).

There are also side events that can happen such as "mysterious broadcasts", "survivor activity" and so on. Some of these can entail helping someone get revenge on a set of survivors who killed their partners, or someone who left a relative behind that they are looking for. There are also radio requests that can be made that can offer a few options that will feel repetitive over time (I personally stopped using it after some point).

The morale and base building system is pretty basic IMO. Each character can have 0 to 1 special trades (eg gardening, mechanic, utilities) so you can neither replace a person's skill nor can you add a second. The only option you have are to exile or kill the survivor and get another one in it's place since there is a maximum you can have. I did find with some quests it ignored the maximum and allowed me to still recruit more survivors. Even having at least 4 gardeners out of 9 survivors I got very far in the game. Beds are almost always a limitation because you would typically need other facilities at the base. Even with a lack of beds it's not very hard to keep the morale very high if you choose the right facilities and mods.

It is a game you can go back to from time to time, but due to it's repetitiveness you would want to dedicate consecutive gaming sessions to finishing the game.

Note: I did not try the co-op experience. I've read good things but just don't care to try it.

In terms of price value I would only recommend getting this when it's on sale.

A very addicting but HEAVILY flawed game. Managing your community, melee, and shooting are all very satisfying. When it comes to your AI followers, leave them at home when taking care of serious business (plague hearts, human enemies). They are borderline suicidal and will rush towards their death. Losing a member you may have liked a lot is very gutting, especially when it really isn't your fault.

There are lots of minor annoyances. If the game wasn't so fun it would be death by 1000 cuts. Occasionally your base will be attacked by zombies and there's a little message on screen to tell you so. However, you most likely wont notice it if you are looting or in combat. By the time you do notice, you may have 3 or so minutes to drive all the way back to your base.

It's not a huge deal as you just lose some ammo if you don't make it, but I feel this represents a lot of the problems this game has.

I hear State of Decay 3 is coming out soon. If it gets its shit together it very well may be the best zombie survival game ever made.

This is a console action/shooter game. It is not a survival game, and it is not a base builder.
90% of this game is shooting/button-mashing. That doesn't make it a bad game. Obviously plenty of people love it. But I do not enjoy those types of games, and I feel a little misled.
It kept showing up in my Steam recommended list under "Survival" and "Because you enjoyed The Forest, Valheim, etc.", but it is not a survival game or a base builder by any stretch of the imagination.
Playing this game is like playing the ADHD version of Red Dead Redemption or GTA. Popups constantly scroll up, down, and sideways across the screen: "Visit the wandering merchant", "Help the enclave", "Hold E to finish an enemy", "Mission expired". It's just endless. There's zero time to catch your breath or wander around.
As for the "base building" aspect, that just boils down to choosing which type of room you want to put in an empty space. Again, not a base builder.
The gameplay is a set loop: get supplies, clear zombie spawner, move base to new area, repeat.
Not for me, and not as advertised. But I wish everyone who loves this game joy - kill those zombies and have fun!
Great Game!

A fresh spin on a classic recipe. I feel that this game does not get nearly enough praise for what it does. 
+ Skill trees allow for a more dynamic experience in every aspect of going about the day-to-day survival. When leveling up a certain skill, you will receive the option to specialize in another subset of that same skill. To match your playstyle or to add more of a variety, your characters will eventually max-out their cardio and can then specialize in backpacking or acrobatics, for instance, one focused on carrying capacity and the other on reduced stamina drain. 
+ There is a wide variety of weapons to choose from; some of them much sillier or satisfying than others. This option actually impacts your playstyle heavily and can really make the difference in how you set the pace for the game. Bladed weapons can dismember limbs, which is very fun. This comes in handy when you're helping out a friend; just cutting off zombies' legs quickly rather than trying to kill every bit of a horde. In contrast, going the blunt melee route, swathes of enemies will be caught in a single swing and the [i] clunks [/i] feel tremendously satisfying. 
+ Maybe the funniest part of the game has everything to do with the driving. Depending on which seat you're in, you can hold open the doors of your car to slam into every part of a massive crowd. Whenever you enlist a follower, they will automatically do this for you without a word. On top of that, the zombies can latch onto several parts of your car unless you pull some funny business and swing them off by swerving or straight up crashing. 
-+ The multiplayer is.. confusing. It's a neat idea that I've never seen where whoever is visiting the host will pull from their own resources back home to be there. This includes anytime your character gets fatigued or sick; you will have to rely on your own base being up to par and able to sustain some of your people being cycled through and beat up. That's mostly good, however, my main complaint with the multiplayer is that only half the containers will be available to loot. Often times, the biggest difficulty then becomes inventory management for you and your partner. In any case, this completely changes up the experience you have by yourself. 
This game can be played for free with gamepass; but I think the price is still completely fair. Pick this game up with a friend and have a blast helping each other build some pretty unique communities over some vastly different maps. 8/10.

While this game is decent, I felt like I was in a constant conflict to have fun with it.

On one hand, on higher difficulties, the moment to moment gameplay is very engaging and challenging. You will lose people if unprepared, or you make too many mistakes, or just get a little too unlucky. While it's fun to play this way, it really sucks for your overall progression. As fun as it is to get stranded far away from your base and try to figure out how to get back alive, as you are doing that, you are getting people hounding you on the radio about helping them, people getting angry at you, you start failing missions and your supplies start to dwindle, ect, as you seem to move in slow motion just trying to get back on track. I really enjoy how challenging the gameplay is on difficulties harder than dread, but it's so hard to play with an end goal in mind.

Now on the other hand, playing on "dread" difficulty, one step above normal, the game just felt too easy. Sometimes I could make a bunch of mistakes and lose a person, but other than that the game felt like it was going too smoothly and it barely took any effort to take out a plague heart (the ultimate goal is to destroy all of them) and I felt as if I had beat the game, except that I have to repeat the steps of destroying the plague hearts 20 more times. And once the game starts losing the challenge, the progression and goals really starts to lose appeal.

So...I don't know. It's a decent survival game that reminds me of This War of Mine but in 3d with zombies, which is great, but it just feels like it overstays its welcome and it doesn't try to keep things interesting. In This War of Mine, every night I thought "man, what is tomorrow going to bring?" and in State of Decay, I never had reason to think that.There is not enough going to really make it compelling to play after putting it down. However, I think players who don't care about being particularly challenged by a game and have more fun in progressing set goals will enjoy this more.

This game is amazing, there really isn't anything else like it. 

1. Exploring the world is very satisfying, a perfect balance of risk vs reward.
2. Base management that doesn't feel like a chore, rewarding enough to keep you out in the world looking for more stuff. 
3. Fun combat, the combat itself isn't difficult. The difficulty is set before your first swing is swung meaning that things like being prepared, and choosing the parameters of the engagement increase your odds of victory vs twitch shooting and rapid clicking. 
4. Fair number of maps to choose from, you can travel freely between them with your survivor group. 

So what will you be doing here? Simply put, you'll get to recruit a roster of survivors each with their own unique traits which could help with either building stuff, killing stuff, or looting stuff. You'll get to play each one individually as survivors get tired and need time to rest, as you slowly find yourself getting attached to these knuckleheads you will also be on the look out for new locations that you can claim as your base. Each location has a fixed number of facilities that can be created there, some will even have facilities ready to go once you move in. You'll make friends and foes as well, other groups of survivors can become great trade partners or another problem that needs to put down. 

If you're into survival games, picking through trash for loot, and indiscriminate killing of zombies this game might be for you.

Can't really recommend it, but don't really hate it. Not really my kind of game.

The game has no story, just random quests every now and then. If you had a few hours and can acclimate to a new game reasonably fast, you could beat standard difficulty on your first sitting. 

The gameplay revolves around looting buildings to survive, with no real depth or variation in procedure. You hold down a button to loot, can hold down a second button to loot faster with a chance of making noise. This leads to my biggest issue with this game:

Zombies continually spawn from noise. Even if you cleared out a place before looting, if you make a noise from speed looting zombies will spawn anyway. There is no "winning the fight for good" if you take longer than a minute to end each interaction, as the noise of the combat will just spawn up more zombies. This can be incredibly frustrating when fighting a juggernaut or a plague heart; anything which needs noisy weapons. The noise doesn't just attract nearby zombies, it spawns them in. This kind of defeats the purpose of meticulously and stealthily clearing out a place before going loud on the HP sponge. 

There really isn't much else to do besides loot and kill zombies. It got pretty repetitive pretty soon. You can probably eke out a few more hours of playtime by trying to build a great base, but I got burned out before I could reach that point. 

Still, it's an okay game, and I got my money's worth on it. Daybreak is a pretty fun mode.

The world space is well laid out, giving off some creepy vibes especially during the night.  The AI behavior is well balanced. I've only played it SP so can't speak on the MP although I would imagine its fun with friends.  Solid 8.5/10

I honestly do not get all the positive reviews, there's a lot of console BS in this game.
Seaching takes forever, but if you use the fast search even in the middle of a completely fucking empty road it has a 33% risk of making noise and then *POOF* spawns zombies right behind you.
Night is really long, it doesn't make much difference, you just can't see fuck all, so have fun running around in darkness 50% of the time.
Switching between ranged and melee is too hard for console gamers, so it's if you aim with right click your weapon turns ranged, and if you just left click without aiming it's melee.
Shit respawns constantly.... Clear a whole area, loot stuff and then drive back to base with your tiny inventory, and once you return 1min later (Because the map is pretty small) there's suddenly zombies back in every room of the house you just cleared.
There's also a lot of random little animation bugs, and the voice acting with strange quiet moments is very cringe to listen to.

I have spent countless hours playing State of Decay 2, and I have to say, it is an absolutely fantastic survival game. Set in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by the undead, players must gather resources, craft items, and build bases in order to survive against the various dangers that roam the land.

One of the standout features of State of Decay 2 is its immersive gameplay. The game is set in a beautiful, procedurally generated world that players can explore and discover hidden secrets in. The crafting system is also robust, allowing players to create a wide variety of items and structures in order to survive against the dangers of the world.

One of the most enjoyable experiences I had while playing State of Decay 2 was building and managing my own base. The base-building system is deep and satisfying, and it was a joy to see my base grow and thrive as I gathered resources and recruited new survivors. I also enjoyed the game's combat, which is challenging but also very satisfying.

In terms of presentation, State of Decay 2 is solid. The graphics are good, with detailed character models and environments. The sound design is also well-done, with realistic sound effects and atmospheric music.

Overall, State of Decay 2 is a fantastic survival game that offers an immersive gameplay experience. Its open-world environment, beautiful graphics, and robust crafting system make it a must-play for fans of the genre. The game's challenging combat and deep base-building system add to the replay value. I have spent countless hours playing this game, and I have no doubt that I will continue to do so for many more.

I have played various zombie games, and this one is by far my favorite. It combines all the elements I could ever want in a zombie game, truthfully, and the game has elements of many different types of games. The community management appeals to people who enjoy those types of games-the combat is reminiscent of Dead Rising, and the weight of your decisions shine through strongly, which would appeal to people for a choice based game. You make your own story, and you truly live in the apocalypse. People in your community DIE, and they will never come back. You hear their yelps and screams, and its visceral. You get attached to your closely knit group, and you have to try to gather new survivors every time one is lost. Your group morale wavers when you lose people as well. If you are too slow in helping someone, you will find their dead body and the character you are playing as will make a sad remark that you were too late, or the potential recruits will simply leave and you wont be able to recruit them. This game is the only zombie game I can think of that has elements like this. Even if you have developed a character to have strong skills, a strong reputation, they can die so easily if you aren't careful. While the game has many other elements to it, the choice and the weight of your choices are an integral point to the game play for me. Fantastic game.

Only had that happen twice in a lot of play hours but anything is possible with this game.

This game is "the" definitive zombie survival game and it's been honed to perfection. Forget the other games, this is the standard and "7 Days to Die" runs a close 2nd. This isn't about a single player, it's about a multitude with their own skills and it's as much a sandbox management as exploration or zombie slaying.

WARNING: This game (because of certain bugs) has a major (what i call) "BSBBS" (BS Beyond BS) factor where it almost seems like the game will punish you for playing "too" well. I think it's the bugs in the game but, sometimes, it feels like the game doesn't want to embarrass it so badly.

Your AI community: To be honest, you would be better off EXTERMINATING them ALL. Why? The game "expects" you to help them and, when you don't, they either turn on you or leave. Killing them after getting what you want (out of trade) is WAY better because you don't have to "persuade" or earn respect of AIs that have NO gratitude/loyalty unless you give them everything they want "first". Personally, i slaughtered anyone who got an attitude with me. I walked in, like a spec ops team, and just head-shot them when they turned (and i don't mean zombie) against you.

It's not about how well you shoot, anyone can do that crap, it's about how well you can kill silently. OR taking on a rogue faction with nothing but a knife and a crossbow when they have guns. It's about making that near impossible shot from half a football field away with a crossbow or a pistol. Or perhaps using a more powerful crossbow and taking out 9 zombies with one well-placed arrow. Yes, i'm talking about THAT good.

The game has many scenarios and I've beat it on several and i'm nowhere near "the best" but i'm pretty good. If you can deal with the bugs, until they're fixed, this game is very addictive.

Multi-player is a bit crappy, the 2nd player is treated like a 2nd class citizen by the game.

That being said: Don't let "my" opinion persuade/dissuade you from playing any game. You and i may have completely different tastes and i'm a 40+ year gaming veteran and some of my opinions are (a bit) "jaded" because of years of some bad experiences with some gaming situations.  A "real" gamer makes up their own mind and "never" lets someone else do it for them.

If you like it, PLAY IT :)

Why i don't allow comments: A review is MY take on the game and no one else's so i don't need other people's critiques turning it into a "discussion", otherwise there would be a "discussion" button and not a "review" button. Allowing comments is a mistake in reviews. It just gives an opening for people (who disagree) to "snipe" a person's review and they often snipe in "ignorance".

I enjoy this game. Here are my pros and cons to the game.

Pros
* 5 maps that offer plenty of looting and scavenging as well as areas that are hidden
* Plenty of missions and optional side missions to keep people busy should they choose to do it
* Difficulty levels are fair depending on which playthrough you want chill/serious
* Higher difficulties make choices/events matter more
* Character traits/skills can help make gameplays easier/harder. Watch who you recruit
* Plenty of base options available 
* Plenty of vehicle options that can be upgraded with the right kit
* Graphics and acting are good
* Two more game modes, one with it's own unique storyline with unique characters and one where you defend an objective as long as you can

Cons
* The game can feel very repetitive with the side missions
* You're communities allies don't search for their own stuff, even when what they want you to get is literally in the area next to them
* Game has an occasional glitch where characters become unreachable on top of objects and you can't complete certain missions
* Lethal mode (highest difficulty) is absolutely unenjoyable. Zombie spawns are terrible in this mode. Seemingly popping up as soon as you clear an area and has times where what you thought was a group of 5 suddenly turns to 50 with freak zombies.
* Human enemies in the higher difficulties are very tanky and in turn leads to massive groups of zombies coming in.


All in all though once you get the hang of the game and know what you're doing the cons can be dealt with.
If you are looking for a challenge while still wanting to have some fun I recommend playing on Nightmare mode.
Lethal mode isn't too bad with the right character skills and game items. It's just time consuming in my cases. Overall I'd give this game an A and recommend it to anyone who wants to play zombie games.

One of the Chads of the zombie survival genre. Initially played it last year (free in Xbox Game Pass) and got it again here on Steam (because I can't get enough of it). It's not your typical "me, myself, and I" set up where you'll only take care of yourself since you're going to manage a Community of survivors.

Some of the highlights in the game:

• Random survivors to encounter and recruit. And yes, you get to control and gear them up once you have them in your Community. Could be a grindfest for others, but it's actually rewarding once you unlock their Specializations which make them unique. Not to mention the Community and Quirk skills.
• Regardless if you're blowing up heads or dismembering zombies, combat is very satisfying! There are loads of weapons to acquire and to try. Some unique gears can be obtained through bounties, and they are awesome!
• You'll get to enjoy customizing your survivors with outfits, as long as you acquire them. Looting is the key.
• Once you're done with a single playthrough, you can actually choose some of your Community members to be a Legacy Survivor where you can utilize them in a new game.

Cons worth noting:

• Missions could get repetitive.
• AI feels annoying and terrible at times.
• Feels like you're doing a lot to the point where you lose the freedom to explore and absorb the experience.

Don't feel like a drawn out paragraph post so here ya go.

o Community base building with random survivors
o Grow from a small home to full fledged multiple bases and one HQ.
o Ally yourself or make enemies with other communities [npc]
o Fight off special infected.. especially feral.. feral.. just run em over.
o Scavenge resources which is tedious but the more time you spend the more you don't care. At least I didn't.
o Constant updates/expansion/etc like heartland. The devs could of stopped by now but they haven't.

Compared to State of Decay 1 this sequel is bad on all levels, it released in May 2018 as a Microsoft only exclusive had caused a division in the OG community as many players on PC didn't trust windows games to deliver as promised and who could blame them after whole libraries had been deleted forever by MS years before. SoD2 a cross platform guaranteed both windows and Xbox players they could play together in the now co-op game, but that didn't work on day one or on day 2 and in fact many days came and went before co-op cross platform would work. The game was immediately entered into the Xbox game pass upon release so anyone could play it without actually having to buy it. There was no date given as to when it would be released on Steam. Undead Labs promised a better game experience, survival experience and fighting experience with several new maps and a new special zombie, they also promised a flare gun that every character would have if they needed assistance if overwhelmed that could be used to call in help. 

When State of Decay released on the 5th June 2013 as a Xbox 360 arcade game it was an immediate hit, It had a story that tugged at the heart strings and characters that the player loved and since permanent death was a thing players did everything within their power to keep these characters alive. Characters consisted of powerhouse's, nimble's and ordinary folk, but they all could do a drop kick, which always knocked down a feral giving the weaker survivors a chance to kill it. There were three types of weapon skills, heavy, blunt and blades all three contained their own skill sets, there was also gun skills for those eagle eyed survivors who with focus aim could kill anything in slow motion. Setting up outposts was imperative for the survival of the base and if placed correctly they gave a zombie free zone because every outpost was trapped which used fuel, sniping zombies from the base watchtower gave a higher ring of safety and there was no cap on how many survivors you could have at the base. Replaying the story was usual and it also helped in getting to know every survivor within the game, knowing them by their clothes you would know if a survivor was a medic, powerhouse, nimble, leader, cook, gardener, researcher etc., characters you needed to survive. As the story progressed everyone in Trumble County was in danger as a new plague had entered the water called black fever and so everyone had to leave Trumble as it was no longer habitable. Eventually Undead Labs gave an update giving us the prequel called Lifeline and the much awaited breakdown with higher levels of difficulty each time the survivors left on a RV. State of Decay also came to Steam, opening the way for a huge fanbase. In 2015 Undead Labs did a complete graphic overhaul and put State of Decay and all the dlc together in State of Decay Year One Survival Edition (YOSE) and Breakdown became more deadly with 99 levels of difficulty, and CLEO drops were added at that point. One update was given to that game. 

I bought the Windows Xbox edition of State of Decay 2, thinking I was entering into a story mode with the two chars I picked, being introduced to the red skinned plague zombie that had no explanation as to where it came from and escaping that camp, wondering what else was to come, I and many other players realised there was no story just a new form of a weird and alien Breakdown, the graphics were bad, the combat was bad and heavy weapons had been removed completely, outposts did nothing, they were only a place to dump non rucksack supplies and where a char could be changed, drop kick was only reserved for certain characters and all the characters were forgettable. Then the plague heart entered which made so sense, it looked alien even though each one had the rib cages of at least three humans wrapped up in it, killing it was as boring as the cleo drops of YOSE and like the cleo drops they used up too many supplies to yield nothing. A cure was also introduced which also made no sense, how could the infected glands of a red zombie cure anyone? It only injected the infection into the character which in time proved not a cure as if again infected another cure was required. Legacy's were introduced which meant nothing as once the so called story was completed you had nothing to go back to, all that hard work was lost as the characters were placed into a legacy pool to use again, it was a boring game of rinse and repeat. 

I bought the dlc Heartland with the hope it would be interesting, it was set in Trumble Country, there are two stories to choose from depending on which two characters you use, but again these stories made no sense, both The Wilkersons and Ray Santos left Trumble County with everyone else at the end of State of Decay 1, so why have them in it? The army had also left Trumble County in SoD1 and only Eric Tann and his men who were abandoned by their superior officer were left to help the survivors and without Eric Tann all the survivors we loved would have died. It seems Undead Labs had forgotten their own story, while telling the OG community that survivors from SoD1 could not be in SoD2 as they could have died in our playthroughs. Trumble County was completely ruined by the red plague seems Undead Labs also forgot black fever, while trying to convince us that cleo an AI had caused the outbreak, every OG player knew the plane crash was the site of the outbreak not cleo that only arrived in 2015 with no explanation given as to why cleo was in the story.

 In March 2020 the Juggernaut Edition was released and was now on Steam to buy, no game passes there, I fell for it again and bought it, with several updates applied since 2018 I rationalised it might be better, it wasn't, it got a little interesting with the Trumble County map as it is the best map in the game, but more was to come, endless updates of moving the goalposts which makes even the regular difficulties more difficult (especially for those new to the game), adding plague territories where plague hearts have dominion that are covered in red fog. Another huge update is on the way, where the plague hearts are now dormant till a screamer wakes them up, where infestations and hordes are spawned from plague hearts, where a siege on the base could result in every survivor dead if the character your playing doesn't get back in time and much more. The game is over four years old and personally I think it is almost at it's alpha stage as the rush release of 2018 was clearly NOT the finished game as much of that release does not exist any more.  I understand updating servers but to completely change the whole game over four years tells me this game was not ready in 2018 and now; even though I have played many hours of it, I'm not interested it at all.

Thumbs up or thumbs down? I only play SP, so it could have gone either way as SoD2 is a flawed gem. Why?

Let's start with the BIGGIE - the gameplay 'loop'. There is a sort of iterative pattern players have to go through with most games (grinding, levelling, exploring, building, upgrading etc etc) each cycle through you get tougher, better gear, more options etc. That is true to a degree with gear in this game but the loop in SOD2 for everything is both very shallow and short (pick up some gear - help an enclave - get a person - get a bigger base - repeat). What is worse, do this 5-8 times and you are done, 'end game' - at this point you either start fresh (new game) or move to a new map with a couple of your survivors and....start fresh. In essence, there is no end game, no ultimate goal, you just grind and struggle so you are allowed to reset the grind and struggle (albeit with a leader bonus and 3 experienced characters to start the next map - which is actually a negative because being a small, weak, easily overwhelmed group when you start is the most exciting and fun part of the game. 

Now the quirky stuff:
A tiny country village with a pre-apocalypse population of maybe 100 (going by the houses) has a zombie population of several times that - a zombie count that never decreases for any length of time no matter how many you kill. (this has had a patch to improve it but meh....still endless zombies re-spawning everywhere). 

A 4 door pick-up truck with a flat bed tray has 6 storage slots, each slot can be taken up by as little as 1 item - so your truck may be full if loaded down by 6 pieces of paper (which don't stack). A small backpack also has six slots ,also filled by 6 bits of unstackable paper, but it could also hold 6 fully automatic assault rifles if needed.

Some of the roadside curbs in Spencer's Mill (a town on one of the maps) need you to jump to go from the road to the footpath.

Wear and tear on equipment:A machete only 'works' for about 60 seconds of use, a kitchen knife driven repeatedly into human skulls works forever and ever and ever and ever.

AI is broken, it's just broken, followers refuse to fight (you die) or they refuse to stop fighting and run with you from unwinnable fights (they die). Replacing people in this game is slow, boring, frustrating and just generally painful. Replacing a skilled specialist is...(hmm, I don't have a civilised word for that, insert your own adjective here)

A fortified base designed in the apocalypse to protect survivors from zombie assault has 4 or 5 entry points, each 'blocked' by an unlockable, unreplacable and generally useless flimsy wire gate. Apparently 'fortification' and 'defensibility' are just long, meaningless, complicated words in this game world.

The game has cars. Great !!!! One such car is a Pilato - arguably the best all-round vehicle in the game - it's a mid-sized SUV largely 'comparable' to say a Chevrolet Traverse. Chevrolet tells me the Traverse has a gas tank that holds around 20 gallons (90 litres) of fuel and on highways gets about 26 miles per gallon ( about 9.3 km per litre) so a Traverse has a maximum range of about 520 miles (830 km) per tank. The Pilato has range of about 6-7 km per tank...that's 4.4 miles in the 'old money'. This kinda makes 'Dieselgate' look like a storm in a teacup. 

Heartland DLC, 6 hours into a game on easiest setting, 3 people in my base, just completed first story-line mission and my base was assault by 3 Juggernauts, 2 ferals, 4 screamers, 4 bloaters and what I think was about 30+ regular Zs - WTF is insane difficulty like?

My co-survivors CONSTANTLY complain about too many infestations - even when 90% of them are 2-3 km away on the other side of the map (they virtually reappear as quickly as you clear them) - who gives a s**t, we've got no food, no meds and 2 juggernauts patrolling our neighbourhood and you're worried about half a dozen Zeds setting up house in a ruined garage 3 km away ???!!! Go live somewhere else moron.

Radio: 'Emergency, please help us...we're in trouble.' You get there and there's 3 guys kitted out with machetes and guns standing around in a garage, they ask you (and your companion if you brought one) to go to location X and get them some food. It's the apocalypse, I'm looking for food as well, why should the ONE or TWO of us go into the infested house when you THREE gun-toting dudes won't? Toughen up princesses !!! Call me for help when your base is being overrun by a horde of ferals because you only used wire gates to block the entry points - like we all did apparently.

Missions flood in by radio. And I mean flood. Ignoring them loses you allies and/or damages morale. With your maximum 8 survivors you can only ever use 1 character (with optional companion) to do missions. It is literally impossible to help the whining, princess survivors all around you, clear infestations, deal with endlessly spawning hordes, repair and fuel vehicles, build the base, fix weapons and....so on. It's a shame, you feel like you are being constantly pushed into doing things you have no interest in doing when you really want to explore the map, hoard stuff, or whatever. Even taking the time to checkout the extensive wardrobe options for all the characters makes you feel like an ER doctor who just steps outside in the middle of an Earth-shattering crisis to update his/her Facebook page.

Finally, there is the 'base building' - hmm...copy-paste limited is a good description. Each map has only 5-7 base locations, these are all abandoned houses or commercial properties, each with a set number built-in (and unchangeable) facilities and a number of empty 'plots' which can be used to place a facility of your choice. After a while you get your favourite base locations which you want to use and build the facilities that suit your game play style, end result.....this play through's base looks and actually is identical to the last play through. Both the appearance of the base (survivors never clean out the debris and detritus) and the one-click-to-build process are super unfulfilling.  

There's a lot to like in this game (multiple maps, runs well, really beautiful to look at, good voice acting, atmospheric, solid animations and suitably gooey head splat sounds etc - and it's still getting significant content and gameplay updates which are improving most aspects of the game) but the above issues coupled with other problems (e.g., path finding and collision boxes) mean that for me the auto save dooms you to repeatedly wasting hours and hours of game-play only to have the game hit you with what seems like a stupendous moment from which you can only recover by significantly more hours of grinding (or easier if you are less than say...15 hours in, just start again). Challenging, but not my idea of fun. Nevertheless, having said all that, it's bloody addictive and I am persisting.

1st clear at around 12 hours game time. Had experience with State of Decay 1.

Honestly, the AI still sucks in the game. Was expecting a marked improvement, but felt no significant change compared to SoD1. They stand around while a zombie approaches you as you unload cargo, they open doors to zed infested rooms, smack shit at melee range while you want to throw a molotov/pipebomb at a clusterfk.

By the way, a lot of explosives dont have a significant charge timer, so it means that once it leaves your hand, the retarded AI is not going to get out of the way. So it just soaks the damage like a sponge. You can't shove out of a gangbang like SoD1, so if you get surrounded and you don't have a specialization that can shove, you're fked. The game goes trigger happy with zombie spawning so no matter how many times you try to clear an area out, it just fills back up.

The massive downside to the game is that its not "at your own pace". More of you are free to gain/lose allies/territory at your own pace. In terms of conveyance, the game is asking you to run around willy-nilly and really slaps methodical players that want to clear an area and then move on progressively. Even when you get a massive base, well stocked armories and roided up survivors, some 3fag half-assed survivors sitting pretty at home will think that they can "extort" you for supplies. Thankfully, the game gives you the option to put one between their eyes, which is a welcome change.

BUT, its still one of the best open-world survival scavenge zombie games out there. Pretty much nothing comes close. I played 16 hours in 3 days and still want to play more. So even with all my frustrations with it, I still want to play it. That speaks about the gameplay loop, that even the busy-work tiresome random chores the game devs decided to put in can't seem to tire out my inner squirrel as I scavenge the map and farm up.

Edit: Currently into my 2nd Nightmare Run, and only then does it become apparent that this game has SERIOUS bug issues. Impassable terrain, random freezes, zombies popping in at random, slow render times means you have little to no reaction time to swerve out of the way while driving, bullshit collision formulas, instawrecking cars, cheating AI, HS aimbot enemy humans, and HOLY FUCK TONNES of artificial difficulty. Like GR Wildlands levels of fuckery where enemy humans become fking bulletsponges in a "realistic sim".

Like fookin hell mate, if ya gonna crank up the difficulty, at least have your devs play the damn game for extended sessions and you know, actually complete it? So many other issues like "ghost" followers, crappy AI, nightmare zone player auto-priority targeting, mass freak spawning and juggernaut spam... I'm sorry but its become abundantly clear that its fking painful to play at times... Eventhough its a good game, I expected more from undead labs to actually bug fix, but apparently small things like the scentmask use bug hasn't even been fixed yet, so I cannot recommend a product that they DO NOT intend to fix.

PermaDeath + Random Bugs = Frustration. I now know why I was pissed, in that you die because of how the game decides to randomly fuck you over things outside your control. Mix in artificial difficulty, and it becomes an issue of textbook game design problems ruining an otherwise stellar product.

Further edit: Changed to do not recommend. Their new updates with the plague territory just feels like ass to play now. Lethal mode just is a bitch to play because the developers seem to love nerfing everything smart players do, to the point you just don't even want to play anymore.

It's one of the best survival games I have played.

Fun game.

The good: Combat can be engaging and intense. Good variety in the items you could use. Item management is great and really forces you to consider your options on what to do next. Graphics are pretty,

The bad: Everything is extremely scripted, from spawning mechanics to quests and a lot of them are so obviously done for game mechanics that they ruin your immersion and even limit what you can do. Just a couple of examples are:

-  Zombies spawning every 50 meters no matter what and have no consideration about where you are. This can lead to them spawning in really weird places. It also makes no sense for a survival game, you'd think you'd meet less zombies by staying away from major town centers but it is pointless. You can go to the most isolated part of the map and you'll meet just as much there as you would in a town because mechanics™.
  
- Human NPCs are inhumanly straight forward and interactions with them are very legalistic. So let's say you meet another group, they try to extort you for stuff and you don't like them and they don't like you. Can you make the first move and travel to their camp and just shoo or shoot them? No, you have to formally reject their offer instead and officially piss them off then wait several real hours till they give you the quest that will let you choose to shoo or shoot them. Until then they are invulnerable to anything you do.
The worst multiplayer experience ever., You also need to go into SETTINGS , to enable hosting a server. That alone is one of the most boneheaded UI choice I have ever seen.

Its an Ok game at best. No real story line. Each Hero character has a few missions but nothing to really add to anything. All it is is just a game of going into buildings and looting them and occasionally killing a plague heart.  No challenge at all on normal or dread difficulty.  Will end up having a huge abundance of resources which then will disappear when you have to much. Whats the point of scavenging when you don't need anything? That's pretty much the only point to this game. Tried a couple settings on nightmare are where a bit more challenging. But bugs on nightmare or higher make it very hard to impossible to stay alive (maybe just for me). Anytime you go to clear one of the never ending infestations (have to clear them to have good moral) or missions, a horde of 10 zombies come but before you can kill half them them another horde of up to 10 will show. Happens 60% of the time. Another thing that is an issue on nightmare or higher difficulty is the invisible bloaters. Nothing like driving down a clear road and all of a sudden you are struck with the cloud they leave after death. Then after jumping out you get attacked from 5 plague zombies and a horde moving in on you at the same time. All in all it is a fun game but one of the worst for repetitiveness I have seen for a game.  Probably best to get it on sale.
