Im honestly having way more fun than i thought i would. First glance in to the trailers and some gameplay i thought the combat was boring and clunky, including how the zombies looked, got the game anyway because i needed something to play with friends, ended up liking the game way more than i imagined.

The game on "normal difficulty" is pretty easy and relaxing, easy to solo and have a good time. been trying harder settings. Tunning up the difficulty will make the coop experience way more engaging, of course, it will make the game way more challenging and punish you a lot for your mistakes, but team play can be more well explored in this manner. 

the main criticism i have is that the "coop" resembles "dark souls" in a few ways. 

You're "summoned" in to someone else world with a limited range of how far you can be from the host, you cant really create a base in there yourself or even gather resources for yours, but you can help the host gather resources for his base, complete quests and explore. Things like your personal stash is still accessible and you can take or put things away normally, which kinda breaks the coop a bit, because i can get in a begginers game with my fully upgraded character and powerful weapons making the game a bit trivial, which you dont have to if you dont want.

But overall the game is very cool. as every zombie survival game, once you get too much loot or a stable/solid base things will end up calming down, but thats avoidable with difficulty settings and challenging yourself, as always.

I am a fan of State of Decay, I loved the first game. This an excellent continuation of the setting and mechanics of the first game. The game play is easy to master, and the environment well done with lots of detail. Difficulty has several settings for those of you who really love to have to fight tooth and nail. Its a survival game, its that magnificently. I recommend it for survival fans and fans of third person play.  Strong Four Stars!

This game just suits those who likes survival and post-apocalyptic games. You get to explore several types of maps, search for supplies and resources to survive the catastrophic world, form a community based on morality, and the hardest of all is to destroy plague hearts. The one that captivates my mind is that you can interact with other survivors in specific enclaves. Once you've worked with them for a period of time, they will offer themselves to join your community with a lower amount of 'Influence', a type of currency used to recruit survivors. They will also offer a lower price while trading with them. You can also abandon their request, which will influence your relationship with them that doesn't bring any benefits of all. The best part of all is that you can get to play with friends and survive together, too bad you can't join their formed communities, or vice versa. Overall I'd give it a 8.5/10, a good survival game I'd say.

I transferred my save from the Xbox game pass, DO NOT pay for the Xbox game pass. It is NOT worth it. I say this because this game is one of the staples of what the Xbox game pass offers. You are better off actually owning the game and just buying it full price. Even at full price you still save money because 10$ a month adds up quick. I spent over 200$ on the Xbox game pass. I could have bought all games I played on it at full price and saved money. 

Also, transferring saves don't always work on Xbox game pass because they LOCK some of them. Avoid at all costs. Any game that makes it impossible to transfer saves is a red flag.

A lot of reviews complain about how the multiplayer is setup but I think a lot of people go into the game with expectations of what the game should be vs. what it actually is and emerge disappointed.

What State of Decay 2 IS:

- INFINITELY Replayable
- You make the story - and the adventure - for yourself, it's not handed to you (with the exception of Trumble Valley Map)
- The multiplayer is setup in a way that allows the host's base to progress. As someone joining another person, you can't make changes to the host's base, but you can use all of their facilities and you earn experience and rewards on the characters you play with other people. It's an anti-grief system setup to protect the integrity of the host's game.
- A game with consequences for your actions, hence the way multiplayer is setup.
- A game that plays more like a dungeon crawl experience that is perpetual and ever-increasing in difficulty.
- Hard as fuck at max difficulty.
- A game that will make you think about your choices a lot, and force you to either get better habits or keep dying.
- A game where you can play solo or with your friends.

What State of Decay 2 IS NOT:

- A base-building game.
- A game where you can be in the same lobby as another person with complete autonomy (you have to be within a certain range of the host).
- It's not for griefers. Seriously if you're gonna join multiplayer and grief other people (throwing zombaits and distractions to get them killed), seriously just go away. It's like DRG. The majority of this community is positive and wants to help, but man, one bad apple can absolutely ruin a run if allowed to run rampant.

Recommend playing with only friends you trust on any difficulty higher than Dread. It's a very punishing experience past that point, and I don't feel like you want your people dying because of random people you don't know :P

I also recommend Green Zone to new players. No one will think less of you. This is the ideal way to figure out all of the game's mechanics, which skills you like to use, how you enjoy playing the game, etc. This is the best place to do that. Starting on Lethal or Nightmare is just going to make you hate the game and get frustrated. Learn what everything does, then increase after that. It'll also let you build up a legacy pool of survivors to use once you're ready to spice things up a bit.

Another multiplayer recommendation... Build up some recruits in your communities before joining other people's games. Or alternatively, just make brand new communities and then you have 9 people you can switch between for minimal effort. This will let you rotate your character more often so you can keep progressing something while you're with the other person. Also recommend taking turns hosting so that everyone can get that experience and learn the game. It's admittedly not the most new player friendly multiplayer system, but it's not a horrible system alltogether. There's a lot of salt over it and I don't think there needs to be. Most of it makes sense, at least from the base progression standpoint. 

The ONLY Thing I Wish They'd Change About Multiplayer: I do think that guests should receive outpost bonuses and base buffs. That's the only thing about the multiplayer I don't agree with at all. Fortunately, it's not that big of a deal in most cases.

In the end, you have to ask what the experience is that Undead Labs wanted to sell people, and that experience was "An Apocalyptic Survival Simulation" - It does this EXTREMELY well, despite any perceived shortcomings with multiplayer. There's a lot of adventures you can have alone AND with others if you don't get so hung up on the details.

Still love this game, have dumped a lot more time in since writing this review. Nominated for Labor of Love. Keep the updates coming UL! Can't wait for infestations to be improved!

I have an embarrassing amount of hours in this game on Xbox One, and wanted to get it for PC when I saw the new Lethal mode.  I completed every boon on nightmare mode on Xbone pretty easily, so I thought lethal mode would be "EZ GG NO RE".  I could not have been more wrong.  Lethal mode is bonkers.  It is the SoD2 equivalent of Tom Cruise jumping on Oprah's couch.  It is Lindsay Lohan on drugs.  The sheer amount of plague freaks and plague hearts is equal parts amazing and terrifying.  The difficulty makes it a challenge worth grinding, and I'm very thankful that Undead Labs put out this update.  I've been pulled right back into SoD2 after being away from the game, and I'm very happy to be playing it again.

For anyone new or interested in the game, I highly recommend you try it.  The management of your community and the different interactions that you can take with outside enclaves makes this game a sandbox that you can dictate at all times.  The zombie freaks are all unique and will give you heart pumping moments when you run into them.

One of the best zombie survival, base building, exploration, and strategic game out right now in Steam. Haven't played the first one but I can pretty much confidently say that if I assume correctly, this sequel must be much better than the first game, at least as far as I've heard online about the first State of Decay game. I love the graphics, the gameplay, the survival aspect, the strategic aspect that I always wanted to see in a game like this one. I always loved the concept of Clash of Clans and such games on mobile but wanted that same concept implemented into a game where I can control a character manually or control multiple characters. This game, in fact, does just that. It has strategic elements that will keep you thinking about what move to make every second, and will leave you thinking if the move you made was the right call. The only main problem I can see with this game is that none of the choices have any depth to them. For example, when you decide to build a sheltered bed that provides two sleeping beds for your survivors, you just simply build it, you don't need to gather too much material, you don't need to grind hard for any kind of specific material, it's just plain and simple, you choose to build it, grind for "materials" which is alone a resource that covers basically all the building supplies you will need. I love the simplification of the features in this game but sometimes, at least a little bit of depth to certain aspects of the game can make the game more interesting, or challenging for some gamers who love challenges. Thanks for reading this rant, and hopefully you decide to support the developer so they can keep this game hopefully alive and keep sending out awesome new content our way.

A survival game that puts the basic needs of survival before combat and flashy fights. Plunder, sneak and build to grow a community of survivors where everybody has a purpose but nobody is irreplaceable. 
Manage your limited resources, explore lovingly crafted maps and level up your base and survivors to better survive the apocalypse. If all that sounds like a commercial its because there are very few games that combine these elements as good as this one and I love the developers for that. That and the constant free content and upgrades years after release.

I thought the story line is linear but really you can just ignore the story line and do looting and base building while trying to learn the ropes. Its an open world survival base building game, what I like about it is that it is on 3rd person GTA Style, survival like The Forest, and Zombies altogether in one.

So yeah, money well spent on this one. Still struggling on that juggernaut though.. *ouch*

I'm one of the few people who have been playing State of Decay since the first game was in the beta. I've seen this franchise undergo so many changes that it's been a real roller coaster ride. The beta was the original and I remember being hooked on it. There were a lot of bugs, they'd done a bunch of things wrong but the germ of the idea was there and I knew they had something special on their hands. Then came the gold candidate release and things got better. Then came the much needed DLCs to breathe fresh life to an already addicting gameplay loop. Eventually, they remastered it and called it YOSE. And in time, came along SOD 2.

Now back when SOD 2 launched, the whole point of the game was everything that I hated about SOD 1 i.e. The Breakdown DLC. Essentially, SOD 1's BD DLC threw storyline out the window and allowed for a pointless grind with no real end to the game. You just... survive and rinse and repeat. SOD 2 took that idea and ran with it for it's main concept. But, since YOSE, they'd learn a lot of things so the mechanics and graphics were now objectively better. As such, I got the game through my Gamepass and played it on release; got bored like I had anticipated and quit relatively quickly. Over the years, they released some DLC updates, some QoL upgrades, and tonnes of hotfixes and patches that continue to this day. I continue to be super impressed by the level of care and support going into this game, since even at the time of writing, more than 5 years after it's release, we're seeing constant updates for the game. For that alone, I've wished for this game to make it into the nominations for Steam's Labor of Love award category but alas it never makes it. Which is a bummer.

So why HAVE I played the game for 180 hours at this point, you ask. Well, that's an interesting question. You see, years after playing the game on PC Gamepass, I recently noticed that they'd clubbed all the DLCs into a single package, renaming it as "The Juggernaut Edition" and sold it as a bundle containing the first game on Steam and as you already know, anyone who owns the first game, usually gets a discount on the bundle. Throw in a sale discount and it was too sweet a deal to pass on. But what REALLY got me interested was how much smoother and content rich the game was this time around when I played it. The Heartland and Homecoming updates, in particular, which added what I always wanted from a SOD sequel - actual stories - was the main selling point for me. Sure, you can go ahead and accuse UL for "fanservicing" the OG fans for putting in Trumbull Valley but I think even the newcomers stand to benefit from the addition of actual storylines. Ever since Lifeline, I wanted some real storytelling in the SOD universe which has limitless potential for storytelling whereas the devs just kept on focusing on repetitive gameplay loops for some reason. Don't get me wrong, the loops are good, it's just that at their core they've always been the same and I don't agree with sacrificing the story aspect for them.

However, as I played through the new DLCs, it quickly became clear to me that the devs have completely lost the plot when it comes to storytelling in SOD 2. Compared to the first game, the story in SOD 2 is there for just that- fanservicing. It's short, anti-climactic and raises more questions than it answers about the outbreak. To top it all off, there are a bunch of plot holes in the story and that just boggles my mind. It feels like the writers just can't make heads or tails of what they want to do with the SOD lore. IMO, it's overflowing with potential. Sure, I get that an open-world sandbox where choices matter and permadeath is a thing, stories are hard to linearize and subsequently told. But the plot holes are just too inexcusable for a game of this calibre.

As for the gameplay, like I said, it has surely improved a lot over the years and it just feels like a brand new game compared to what I played 4+ years ago and it's still as addictive but the nature of the beast is such that the grind becomes pointless as you "git gud" at the game. That's been SOD games' issue since the beginning and IMO, the devs need to sort this out if they want the franchise to survive. The recent forever communities update is something I'd been wanting for a while but it's implementation is flawed. I never understood them "concluding" a community everytime legacy goals were completed and taking the option away from you of continuing with that community to begin with, but even after the update, you can keep your community but they force-reset the map and make you switch maps. I mean... why? I have a self-sufficient community going, I like my friendly enclaves and I want the vehicles where they are. Is it too much to ask when keeping a community? There are still bugs in the game but the modding potential and ongoing official support for this game is [i]chef's kiss[/i] so that's generally not a big issue... until it is, because both Heartland and Homecoming DLCs still have potentially borderline game-breaking issues. Everything else seems fine though.

Finally, this review wouldn't be complete without the mention of the Daybreak DLC. It's this unimaginative repetitive grind of a gamemode that's real unpopular with most players. You're on a "map" which is really just a small base with a tech working on something noisy and you gotta protect him from 7 waves of increasingly difficult zombies. That's it. You get some supplies airdropped every few waves but it's the same damn "map", same waves, same airdrops every single time so it gets old fast. But, and there's more, they've tied all this to a currency called prestige which allows you to buy some special/cool stuff which is a the real problem here. Daybreak is just bad and forcing us to play it to unlock cool stuff is wrong. Thank god for mods though.

Overall, I'd recommend this game, especially if you own the first and get the bundle on a sale. It's dirt cheap for the amount of content you get and there's enough to keep you interested for a long time if you're into zombie survival games! It has it's flaws but between the official patches rolling out every now and then and an active modding community, you won't have to worry about anything but the post-mastering boredom.

EDIT: It's open for nomination. Please vote this game for the Labor of Love award people!

State of Decay 2 is an Open-World Zombie survival game with a mix between undead horde action and looting for supplies to keep your community safe and help out the other communities. (and they're not all friendly)

Has permadeath but with enough difficulty modes to find a good spot for most players. Good balance of "go kill zombies" vs community/base tuning vs scavenging and inventory management.

Can roll base inventory/survivors over between maps and there's enough variation in map/stories/characters/etc. that it hasn't felt too fetch-questy or gotten stale yet and I'm 70h in with ~3 maps played through; haven't touched the actual "story" mode yet and only briefly played with the Daybreak (siege defense) mode so should still have a bit left.

TLDR; Fantastic game. The blend of basebuilding, scavanging, and action/combat is great. Granular control over difficulties makes for an accessible experience no matter your skill level. There are some frustrations, which I hope to see addressed in SoD3. But overall this is a must play.

Pros-
--Granular control of difficulties allows you to adjust the game to your own playstyle.
--Balance of game elements keeps things fresh and moving.
--The community mechanic is a one of it's kind that really makes the game stand out.
--Base building is fun, with visual consequence to things, and help elevate the game rather than drag it down
--Crafting is detailed enough to be fun, without so overly complicated I don't want to touch it.
--Community/moral management adds a layer that brings immersion, instead of just adding mechanics for the sake of it

Cons-
--No multiplayer pause. Being able to both agree to a pause so you can take a break without killing the session (and thereby causing quest to temporarily go away) would be great.
--No true multiplayer. While I can have someone come in and "help", and we can set some rules to make it feel like"our" community... the inability for coop players to be permanent community members that add/subtract/benefit/etc... to the base, the moral, the community, etc.. is a HUGE missing gap.

The gameplay in this game is not super special, and the graphics are fine but showing their age. There are other third-person action survival horror base games with crafting, scavenging, and base building elements. What makes this game shine is the difficulty. 

Playing on Lethal (Normal difficulty +3) is so fundamentally different from the Normal game settings that they are basically two entirely different games that share maps and assets. To be honest, even Normal to Dread (Normal +1) will force you to change your tactics, be less wasteful, and be smarter about how you go about literally every activity in the game. 

So if you buy it, put it on a difficulty setting where you can barely eke out a win. Then turn the screws on yourself and make it harder.

I was never into playing any kind of zombie games until a friend of mine showed this to me last year. What really got me convinced to buy and play this is when he showed me the scavenging / looting mechanics. How there's so much you can do (search for materials, fuel, weapon, healing items, stamina, repairs), so many things you should consider (forming alliance with other enclaves, choosing the right survivor, leveling up skills, decision making), how you should go about in terms of surviving and killing zoms (melee, guns, crossbow, punching, kicking, explosives, vehicles), and lastly, how to build your base with the essentials and defense you need while keeping the community happy and united (as your community is affected based on the status of your base and environment situation). The game has so much to offer. As a result? It's totally worth every penny.

I love how the difficulty level is very customisable in order to fit your preference. It really helps the player adjust slowly into a more challenging level once they're used to the initial settings they started in.

The Developers continues to update this game which is great because it shows how they care and hear the community's feedback regarding the work they've done. I also joined their Discord Server and the people there are so nice and so helpful too! I look forward to seeing State of Decay 3 and I hope that it's as awesome as this or maybe more ^_^

State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition pretty much plays the exact same way as [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/329430/]State of Decay: YOSE[/url] did (which is appreciated), but in many ways this game is bigger, better... and deadlier! I love this game to bits! It has everything I want in a zombie game: resource management, base building, stealth and leveling up your characters. The biggest difference is that you are now dealing with the extremely deadly blood plague and so-called plague hearts.

There is an endless stream of unique characters, each with their own traits and backgrounds that can influence your community's morale positively or negatively. On top of that, you can also customize your character's looks. Also, just like in the previous game, death is permanent! I had my heart broken several times when I lost one of my favorite survivors. I literally feel numb and sour for 30 minutes straight when that happens, lol. The cool thing is that you now have a Legacy Pool which saves up to 50 characters that can be used again in new communities!

Normally, I hate games with time limits and countdowns, but in this game I don't mind at all, because it makes sense. The world is dangerous and chaotic and as much as you want to help everyone, sometimes you just can't. It adds to the drama.

Lastly, I can say that this game has a LOT of replayability. Contrary to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/329430/]State of Decay: YOSE[/url], this game has several maps and even more places to build a base. With over 800 hours invested in this game, I STILL get missions with twists or missions I've never had before!

So are you ready to experience action, sweaty palms and emotions? Can you handle a nerve wrecking pursuit by a pack of (blood) ferals, the despondency you feel when you are infected by blood plague and no cure is in sight and the heartbreak you experience when you lose someone in your community you spent hours and hours with? Then get this game. I can't recommend it enough.

[b][u]State of Decay 2: Heartland[/u][/b]
Heartland is an amazing addition to this game, especially when you've played the first game. You're going back to Trumbull Valley! I do recommend you play Heartland first before you play the Homecoming map of Trumbull Valley (storywise that makes more sense).

Contrary to the other maps, this is much more story driven. However, none of these characters end up in the Legacy Pool upon completion. It's one and done. Hey, but... dinosaurs. :-P

[b][u]State of Decay 2: Daybreak[/u][/b]
Daybreak is best played online with friends as the NPCs are as useless as a pair of reading glasses on a camel. In Daybreak you play as a Red Talon soldier tasked with protecting a Technician, as he or she is doing technical stuff to some CLEO Relay. The longer you survive, the more points you earn and weapons you unlock that can then also be obtained in the base game. With enough points, you can even recruit some highly skilled Red Talon soldiers into your community.

Personally, I don't like playing online and Daybreak is very repetitive. On the other hand, if you play it a lot and long enough, it does give you a lot of cool stuff.

It's base management with zombies. Pretty cool stuff and you can tell that the team behind it was pretty diverse. 30 bones may be a lot to drop on a pretty unknown indie game but this game is wicked fun alone and even better in co-op (no couch co-op, unfortunately, you need to have separate settlements and travel to your friends' bases with your characters). All I'm saying is games ask a lot more and deliver a lot less. Plus with most of the limited time items being yearly releases and bounties always changing you always feel like you have something to work towards even if your settlement is doing great currently.
The closest to what I would have wanted for a zombie survival game I've ever played. If this just had one more QA pass, it'd likely be perfect.

All in all, A GREAT GAME.

State of Decay 2 is a fun game - it is made in such a way that each of your survivors feels like a unique person with hopes and dreams and until you learn better, you're going to get attached to them and be heartbroken when they get ripped in half by a juggernaut or succumb to blood plague because you couldn't get the cure to them fast enough. The game allows for a variety of play styles - you can go assault-heavy and use grenade launchers and suped-up AK47s to plow through wave after wave of zombies or you can choose a stealth style and sneak around the map, scoped crossbow in hand racking up head shots. Survivors will call for help and you can choose to ignore their plight or to rescue them from starvation or perhaps an imminent zombie attack or even other, not-so-nice survivors. Travelling merchants allow you to buy rare goods which power up your base in ways that you get to choose. Maybe you'll focus on gardening and learn how to be self-sufficient, maybe you'll install a shooting range and fighting gym and focus on the ferocity of your survivors. The choice is yours and one thing is certain: the zombie apocalypse is NEVER boring.

(ENG) At the start, the game was hated for the fact that it had little content and it did not differ from part 1. After a while, many major updates were released in the game in which they added new maps and with them new story quests, with this a new mode came out that introduces us deeper into the lore of the game. Despite this, the game remains one of the best zombie survival games. It has everything you would like to see in a real zombie apocalypse simulation. With the latest updates, new gameplay features have been introduced into the game and old ones have been updated. Although the game has changed, its goal remains the same.
You need to provide your community with resources by type: medicine, food, materials (resource for building rooms), ammo, fuel. You also need to maintain the morale of the squad, if it is low there is a chance that 1 of your survivors will leave the group.

I love zombie games, probably played every notable zombie game you can think of and State of Decay 2 is the absolute best zombie game you can play. 

- open world 
- 3rd person shooting is nice 
- survival elements 
- base building 
- crafting 
- team management, all playable characters are unique with different playstyles and personalities 
- character customisation 
- base management 
- supply drops with unique gear 
- bounties that unlock unique weapons and customisation options 
- many difficulties to suit your playstyle
- different game modes, horde mode and story
- online coop
- plenty of decent mods 

And many many more, it's a survival game that feels deep and complex whilst also streamlining the elements that make survival games a chore. Quite frankly if you like zombies games you owe it to yourself to play this game.

I think I'm enjoying this game - the gameplay loop hooked me for sure. Still, I'm getting tired of some of the tricks the games pulls again and again - zombies spawning out of thin air behind you; juggernauts showing up when you're trying to recruit one of the NPCs in Heartland (achievement hunting) and killing them outright; your car getting stuck in the roadblocks and choke points when negotiating the roads in Trumbull valley, just for that feral that was nowhere to be seen to show up and rip you character out of the car; bloaters that suddenly spawn with a horde while you are trying to weave through the wrecks in the city; and so on.

I bought the game heavily discounted and played for almost 80 hours, so I guess I can recommend it, with caveats, but I hope they improve on these issues with the third game; I'm looking forward to trying it again...

I have spent a lot of time on the first one as the bugs and overall gameplay was extremely different and enjoyable. Loved it, admired it. When playing this one, they changed so much and slapped so much together without proper bug testing that it follows so much of the way of Bethesda and not Cyberpunk. 

So many game breaking bugs and glitches that you can't progress the stories in both the main campain and DLC's which makes it very irritating to play and impossible to progress. Multiplaying with random people who exploit the game with duplication makes it obvious that they aren't even fixing this game. Follower AI is trash and they move themselves right in your line of fire. They are dumb as a bag of rocks and are best used as camels for loot. Fighting hostile civilians is interesting but fails as well. You fight them with melee and can't finish them on the ground or kill them. They just get back up and continue killing you and whatever idiot follower you have.

Freak zombies have been designed to be OP and for whatever reason, some people enjoy it. But that enjoyment for me ends when you get obliterated by a feral and can't defend yourself or even remotely fight back because every time it hits you, it makes you flinch. Again, even with a follower, makes the game seem more terrible. As for other zombies, they have been programmed to be based off of what I like to call "pre firing." Zombies hit you before you hit them and have been made to be that way so you have to heal and use consumables. Dodging can be used as an excuse to move out of the way, but if you have a fully developed character, you would expect stamina to follow suite as well. Stamina in this game compared to the first is a joke. There is also a "soft lock-on" system that makes fighting very clunky and not very fluid from the first one. And if you accidently hit a button trying to finish a zombie and make amistake, your character goes through this stalling animation until it either ends or a zombie hits you.

Now, what the game did right was visuals and content additions. The graphics look amazing along with the terrain. So much of an improvement than the first one. And the looting system is still in it from the first one which I enjoyed. PLenty of different maps and places to visit. Also, I love the character system they made in the game. So many different personalities and looks that it makes a lot of immersion for the story.

Base building is similar to the first but better. And the ability to have so much customization by having different facilities is awesome. one thing I wished they would have done was made a minigame within each station you build to help speed up the time it takes for a facility to perform an action, but not make it mandatory. Like for example, cooking could have you put different ingredients for a feast, or shooting can make you play a little shooting minigame to build up shooting. 

All in all, this game has a lot of terrible gameplay mechanics, but a lot of great foundation to it. It's terrible they haven't fixed so many bugs with this game as it would negate me not recommending this. Butplaying games you can't progress a story due to game breaking bugs in is not something I will ever recommend anyone to spend money on. Buy it on a massive sale, not full price.

A more streamlined survival game. No active eating and drinking mechanics, farming is a passive that requires no planting of crops, medical kits are not a constant juggle between different medicines per type of injury, base building is simple as finding an existing one in the map and securing it. One may argue this game is like a thin soup lacking taste, but the resulting lack of more hardcore mechanics did not turn every gaming session into a 10-hour cycle of mindless menial tasks; and for that, I am grateful for.  

The usual gameplay loop of survival games exist still. Secure a base. Go outside your base, find resources while avoiding or fighting zombies then go back to your base and improve on your equipment. Rinse, repeat. Zombies are varied enough, and can be scary and challenging in higher difficulties. However, free roaming is largely boring, so some random NPC encounters to spice up that part of the gameplay is sorely wanted.

First of all, I am absolutely amazed that this game still receives huge updates, even tho SoD 3 is already in development — huge props to the developers.

The core game is simple. Loot, build up a base, take care of your people, and finish the main objectives (or not, your choice). It is done brilliantly, and most of the things I disliked in SoD 1 were fixed or heavily improved.

The only weak link is the looting. Your inventory is not that big (and for a good reason), so looting becomes more like a logistics problem where you have to make sure you can go back to your base or an outpost quickly so you can go back to looting ASAP. I would improve upon the inventory system; for example, little pieces of paper with story content do not have to take up a full inventory slot – make a paper bag or something. 

The game contains two other full modes. One for more story-driven experience with lots of new content and one base-defence with more action and shooting. I love all of them.

Multiplayer could be improved; instead of joining another player's world as a helping hand, it would be nice if two people could merge their worlds and have their bases. But I understand that would be a whole other bag of problems. It is still a lot of fun with your friends.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, if you are looking for the following,

-epic and long form story with lots to say about zombies and society

-a rich and wide variety of voice actors (pretty sure MS only gave this team a budget to afford like 4 unique ppl in this whole game)

-super polished red dead levels of canned animations (you know the ones, mounting and dismounting horses super realistically, carving off animal stuff, polishing yer 'gun')





i can't really say this game is an extension of the first one, nor is it really it's own game. MS clearly rushed the inital release out, but they have allowed at least some of the team to remain dedicated to providing free updates to the game that fix many things that were unfinished or just missing when it first launched.

If this game had another two years in the oven and were only releasing now, with even more polish and all the content they probably wanted to, it would be a very different value proposition.

But they didn't and you can blame MS for taking the easy way as they have done in the past, of acquiring small studios, pushing them to their limit and releasing their games far before they are ready.

This really reminds me of Crackdown, the first was a cult classic and ppl loved it, the second was also very fun and more of the first, but not really enough on it's own to justify being a whole game release. MS seems to be operating under the old way of doing things that every single major update to a game has to be it's own release and there is a lot more work that goes into that than simply releasing an expansion.(and also a lot more price tag, which is probably the real reason they do this)

But I digress, the game is fun, just don't expect anything super deep, there are plenty of zombie games in the works from indie devs that will scratch that itch. And even maybe big triple a studios will get back in on the zombie action with movies and shows gaining worldwide popularity. (no not walking dead trash that has nothing to say about anything)

Train to Busan, We Are All Dead, Hellbound (all anti-imperialism btw, learn up on your Korean history to fully enjoy those works)

It is a great game, but it has some very frustrating parts that makes the game feel rushed and unfinished.
Controls are needlessly poor. Especially noticeable when driving. You have one speed, and that's full throttle which just doesn't jill for a game where you need to be careful, where cars are fragile and requires fuel. Often you will find yourself crashing into things or failing to simply reverse because your character wants to be a hardcore stunt driver at any cost.
Same goes for on foot when there's needless duplication use for the buttons. Picking up an item, searching a container, executig a zombie and open/close door is the same button. This is especially frustrating when you are in a stressful combat. Instead of killing the zombie you just put down, your character calmly turns their back on the zombies to close the door...
The interface for talking with NPCs is also frustrating as it takes a bit to load and the answers seems to jump around. Twice now I have ended up accidentally threatening a friendly faction when I simply wanted to trade with them. This is especially frustrating in a game where allies are hard to make and they can be made bitter enemies with a single wrong click.

Lastly the game crashes. A lot, like once every 2 hours of play.

Even with all those terrible bugs/design choices, I still enjoy the game though and can recommend it. Just be prepared to be very frustrated at times.

In short, this game is mindless and basic, and the PC port is lazy and janky. I played 9 hours and I cleared the entire first map, that should give you a good idea on how casual this game is. 

Here is the basic loop to the game: select a survivor and a follower->grab vehicle->head out to objective or loot area->fill your inventory WAY too quickly->head back to deposit resources->craft/upgrade base. Repeat.

Exploration is killed because you can't stay in the world very long because you can only carry a dozen items. Instead of making meaningful choices on what to take and what to leave behind, it's faster to make multiple trips in the vehicles and just horde everything you find. The inventory system is uninspired; your character has some pockets and the size of backpack you have determines how many slots you can carry. The problem is that, while items have weight, they have no size determination. I can carry a full exercise bike in one slot, or one small knife. You can see the problem with this. 

Your base feels restrictive and annoying, rather than safe or liberating. Base areas will have a select amount of slots that fall into 4 categories: large/small, outside/inside. You aren't exactly building a base so much as deciding which resources you want to have access to. Once you build a facility, you gain +1 food, or fuel, or meds, etc. Even a sizable base will feel too small. Beds are always a problem even if you take a Builder as a leader - beds essentially equals how many survivors you can house. The game artificially restricts you in order to funnel you into a grind. This is NOT a free building game. You can't even create better defenses like sandbags or parking vehicles together for road blocks, you just have to suffer repeated zombie attacks and there's nothing you can do about it. I constantly had 4-5 specials and a couple hordes around my base. As soon as you clear them out, you'll do one mission and zombies will be swarming your base again. If you have a watchtower, your NPCs are always shooting at zombies which makes noise and gets extremely annoying. Imagine constant gunfire in the background when you go back to your "safe haven."

Your characters' attributes don't feel unique from one survivor to the next. You unlock some handy fighting abilities like quick-snap targeting, but if a character is good at mechanics for example, they don't need to be the selected character in order to repair vehicles or craft repair kits. Simply having one character with the mechanic skill will allow all characters to use the autoshop to craft auto related items. It's convenient, sure, but does nothing to make you feel connected with your survivors. In short, it doesn't really matter who you play as at any given time, it only matters which attributes you have as a collective. 

All survivors run at the same speed and carry the same amount of loot aside from upgrading their skills. There is no uniqueness here. Even shooting and fighting with a ZERO skill character is not hard and you won't feel much difference between a zero skill and a 5+ skill. 

Leveling skills is way too easy and way too fast. Everytime I selected a new character I had a skill to upgrade. It doesn't feel like you work for it and you level up so fast it feels like an inconvenience rather than something to celebrate or look forward to. Oh, reading 3 books on a subject will make you an instant 5+ expert lol. 

Survivors will say the same damn thing, over and over, when selected. Literally they all have one line of dialogue, and you get to listen to it a lot because you have to select them in order to give your follower items out of your inventory. 

The menus are janky beyond belief. You can't rearrange items in your inventory, you can't remap your controls on MKB, you can't view all survivors in a list with a list of available attributes, the game won't tell you how many of a craftable resource you have (like chemicals, ethanol, etc.) when you are crafting, you have to cycle through every usable item in your inventory in order to "throw" or "use" it, sheesh, the list goes on. You will feel like you are fighting the HUD and menu at every step. Min/Maxers will instantly hate this system. 

If you like mindless grinds, basic combat and the occasional cinematic camera zoom when beheading zombies, you might like this game. This game isn't punishing and it's the opposite of realistic -- I navigated the map by driving full speed in rivers, because there were less obstacles than the roads. lol. It's an okay time waster, but I think there's plenty of better options on Steam. 5/10 stars.

I was hesitant when my friend asked me to get this game but after playing in his survivor community, creating my own, and finishing my first story, I'm glad he got me playing. The short of it is: if you're looking for a fun solo or co-op open world zombie game, this is one to consider. Read below to get an idea of the game.

State of Decay 2 in so many words is a zombie survival, third person combat game. It features a huge and expanding arsenal of recognizable firearms and melee weapons such as the Glock 17 9mm and Crowbar but also had unexpected things the more savvy would recognize such as KSG shotgun or APC9 submachinegun.

I had a few issues with the game in the form of performance. Often when the game cloud-saves, it would freeze my screen for a moment and this was bad for a game like this where zombies are charging me. Gameplay-wise, zombies could occasionally counter my attempts at takedowns with ridiculous reaction speed (I.E. takedown starts and fails because the zombie instantly changes direction to face me) that would cause me to take damage. Some game elements are unclear. When I started, I was unaware that completing a community's story would end that community and they were lost forever. This was luckily changed recently but it still forces you to move to a new area. Weird choices but overall a great experience.

The game caters to a wide array of playstyles and skill levels. You can independently choose how difficult combat is like how much damage zombies dish out and take, how generous or rare loot can be, and how difficult or easy it is to run your survivor community. (I play on Lethal zombies, Green map, and Green community, so combat is always a challenge but the rewards are also great and my community isn't too hard to run for me.)

The game world feels full of stuff to do. You assign a leader to your group and, depending on the character, they can become a type of leader and that dictates the sort of attitude your community has to the world. This is very customizable, too, because even though you are given the choice of two characters who then get two more in the tutorial, you can completely trade out anyone. Often you'll be visited by someone wanting to join your community and you can say yes or no. You can dress up your survivors, give them weapons, you can even recruit one to follow you if you're lonely and they have unlimited ammo as an AI. You could be driving on a supply run and get a call on the radio to go help a neighbor but you don't HAVE to, though they might die forever or turn into a hostile group. Bandits might move into town.

One of the big gameplay elements is how you layout your home. Where you make your home matters and there are different ways to lay it out based on what you need and want. You might not need to find a power source because your home has power built-in.

The big core combat challenge is clearing the "Blood Plague" from the area. Several spots on the map will be super dangerous to go to because blood plague kills quickly and makes zombies stronger. It's a decent challenge and incredibly cinematic the way it plays out clearing them. Oh and also this game does perma-death so if you lose a character, they are gone and that adds to the tension greatly. On Lethal combat difficulty, I was always cautious but it never felt like I died instantly. This is a play smarter not harder game.

Give it a try and if it's on sale, maybe bring some friends.

This is the first game that actually made me feel like a scavenger. It took me three bases before my survivors became somewhat self-reliant, but before that it was just me and my follower looking for scraps to drive home and sustain my base with. And when I mean scraps I really mean scraps, because even with your own inventory, that of your ally, and the one of your car, you can never carry everything you want with you. And that's on standard difficulty, can't imagine how it would be on the higher difficulties.

The zombies didn't prove much of a problem once I got all my survivors some guns and cars. Though I think with every day passing the difficulty goes up. Suddenly Bloaters started chilling on my roads, making perfect mines for my cars. Ferals left and right started pulling off my doors, pulling me out, and dodging my shots and melee attacks. Juggernauts coming up at the WORST possible time when I have 0 ammo left after clearing out Plague hearts. After day 11 it felt like my base was constantly on the verge of being run over. It's not like the zombies themselves are very difficult, but it does feel like you have to be prepared or you'll lose a survivor, thus adding to the feeling of being a scavenger. Never underestimate them.

I love the community system. I only started two communities so far, but their experience has been intensely different. The leader of the first community was a hothead Mexican guy who turned out into a warlord, making the game about us vs. the others. The second community leader hasn't been picked yet, but it seems like trading is becoming more of the standard. I only wish the personal goals were different, since most of the personal missions I have in the second run, I've already had in the first run.

Talking about missions, it's the only thing I'm in the middle about. You are constantly being spammed with people needing help, or survivors wanting to do something. Together with the scavenging and trying to clear the map of Plague hearts, there's just not enough time. And because I don't do the personal missions, the morale of my people goes down. It feels annoying, but I guess it makes sense from a scavenger perspective as well. Even time is limited, and you have to make choices.

All in all, it's a really fun game so far, and I haven't even touched the DLCs yet. I really want to try coop, but being tethered to the OP and not being able to develop your own surivors in another person's map just seems odd to me. If you view this game as a single-player game it's the best experience, hands down. I hope they make the coop a better experience in the next game.

This is a great game, and really, it's the same game it's been since the release of the first game. Similar to Valve's approach to Counter-Strike, the devs of SoD have recognized that they have something special in the core mechanics of this game and have left them alone and focused on content and QoL improvements. The devs are continually improving the game experience and, this is rare, listening to player feedback when deciding which areas of the game to improve. AND THEY DON'T CHARGE FOR IT! Even after the hours that I've put into this game, it's still enjoyable. Well made, fun and interesting stories. With that being said now comes the negatives. I feel that being the second game in the series, the creators could have improved in areas such as the types of monsters to encounter as there wasn't really anything new in that department. 

I think that story could have been developed more and leaves much room for improvement, i.e. at the end of the first game the creators made it out like once you broke out of town that had been cut off from the rest of the world that we were going to possibly see how the rest of the world had fallen. 

Weapons could have vastly improved upon especially with the military, throw super advance weapons in there somewhere even a laser gun or two. Multiplayer aspect could/should have been where players could enter other players world and towns. With updates it would have been nice if the developers added new missions to progress the story further.

Overall I give this game a 7.5 out 10. Hopefully the developers work on a better story should there be a third instalment.

Lacks the level of depth I'd like to see from an apocalyptic, zombie survival game, but it's still a fun romp in an infected wasteland with somewhat satisfying shooting and looting.

My advice to anyone playing, would be to play the game on Dread and above for every slider. This isn't for the sake of stroking your e-peen, more so because I feel any difficulty below truly trivialises the experience, to the point where you'd may as well be playing Dead Rising.

Not a fan of the bounty system and having things on rotation, it's a weak and cheap way to encourage player retention on the basis of FOMO. Sure, the game doesn't have a store and isn't littered with MTX, but FOMO regardless of where I see it will forever do my nut in.

Co-op is solid. Dealing with a tether is never nice but it's usually pretty fair. I don't understand however why there is no option to unlock all loot containers for your party. Having a coloured loot allocation works for random play, meaning people don't just hop in and jack your stuff, only to dip, but if playing with your SO, mates, family, why can't I turn that off and let them go nuts? It adds unnecessary mini-micro-management of locations, requiring everyone to enter every building when one person could effectively loot all on their own.

I played it with my wife mostly, was a fun time, worth buying. Big praise for having cross-play, meaning I could play from Steam with her on her Series S.

So I would assume that, like me, most of you enjoy playing "The Sims" from time to time, and some of you like to build your Sims a swimming pool after which you proceed to dismantle the pool ladder once enough Sims are swimming, thus trapping them and ultimately killing them.

And again, like me, I presume you crack a cold one, sit back, relax and let nature take its course. Or maybe you enjoy the finer things since "The Sims" does offer a plethora of ways to mess with and inevitably kill Sims for your own pleasure.

[b]Long story short[/b] - I know that there are a lot of psychos like me out there, but this review is for everyone. "Normal" or not.


Now then, that having been said, imagine this. You have one or maybe multiple strangers or even allies that you're maybe not that fond of for different reasons. Maybe you even hate them. Maybe they have outlived their usefulness or are just a constant burden. Maybe they're annoying as hell. Don't know, don't care, won't judge.

So what then? Well, transfer your Sims approach here, but this time, experience the downfall of whomever you don't like in the glory of a third person camera as you either infect people and watch them turn only to be killed by their own friends or by you, either using blunt or sharp instruments, or perhaps courtesy of a bullet from a Revolver the size of a cannon right between the eyes, blow 'em up, set 'em on fire, direct hordes of zombies towards them, drive them and leave them next to a Juggernaut which will literally rip them in half. I mean, trust me - the sky's the limit in terms of what you can do to people and how you decide to savor it.


As for the overall game in terms of graphics, mechanics, sound, story, modes and whatnot, well, not gonna lie, it's a really solid experience overall.


[b]9/10[/b] - "I've done a lot more for a lot less." ~ Creed Bratton [i](The Office)[/i]

Edit: Here are my thoughts on what I want from State of Decay 3 

Multiplayer - Hopefully state of decay 3 will improve on multiplayer no longer limiting your friend to only a certain area before being tethered and hopefully they'll make the game fully offline never needing internet in the first place. 4 player co-op would be amazing too

Map - I would also love a far bigger and better map something similar to the size of gta 5s map and then add more with updates make zombies and infections more threatening to justify this combined with a far larger map with more to do and more base options would be amazing then other maps that are unique but the same size or bigger would make far more interesting content and enjoy-ability in this game. allow an option for the game to progressively get harder the longer you stay on a map. ADD A WEATHER SYSTEM in SOD 3 please for atmosphere and also add a option to increase view distance  

 Base - I want to see a more improved and intractable base building system with more things to do or help out with inside your base. I would also like a base expansion system allowing you to make bases bigger and better if you meet the required amount of survivors and resources needed you can also allow us to add onto outpost such as and upgrade system beyond tier 3 that allow you to build things such as a generator or watch tower and assign survivors to stay there and manage it expanding the options we have (this should be a harder and more tedious system more end game based)

3rd person - Make 3rd person more fluid and smooth feeling along with gun combat. add more interesting zombies and an option for you to fight against and making the game a more horror styled experience 

Communities - Allow us to have a bigger community cap also allow other communities to expand their bases and threaten us and others for supplies making them a real threat and make survivors from those communities and others into a random event while scavenging  I.E you enter a building see nothing to loot begin looking through the building and meet said survivor who attempts to kill you for being an enemy or allow us to threaten or kill them for loot or they do the same to us. Same goes for other communities allow us to use the friendly system in a way where we can be a threat to every community and they work together to attack our base and attempt to execute our leader for their crimes or whatever survivors in our community who have the highest infamy. This allows a more interesting villain or hero system that has consequences for our actions.

TL:DR 
I'm going to pre-order State of Decay 3 the second I can and I'm not in the slightest concerned that it'll disappoint me although I do have ideas that in my head if done right could improve the games core and allow a more in depth community and base system which will add more replay-ability and an even more dedicated player base so I listed them read or not the games good I 100% recommend it to anyone who loves zombie games

Pros:
- A light GTA with zombies.
- Fun music and gameplay
- Addons to buildings being scavengable  is a neat idea.
- Places, once cleared, not producing zombies is a great idea.
- Infections slowly spreading is neat.
- Outposts idea is good.
- Interactions with and existance of enclaves is a good idea.

Cons:
- I dislike that you need to move constantly to throw in extra shitty beds. There is space but you can only build in designated zones.
- Having only a single person to follow you unless you cheese the game with side quests sucks. Plague hearts would be easier with extra hands but no.
- Most games with magic zombie/enemy appearance is not cool. Once you clear an area, new zombies should only come from uncleared areas and spread around if left unchecked. You should be able to basically push them back. What happens is you go to a plague heart, clear the area around it before attacking, your base 300ms away calls for help, you go fix that and come back in 2 minutes total to find the previously cleared area overrun again. You clear a wide area again, hit the plague heart and immediately new magic zombies by the 10s appear right on your face.
- The cars are paper thin and this is done on purpose because it's actually fun and relatively easy to clear masses of enemies with it. Not cool.
-  All cars have 6 spots at the back. It doesn't matter if you put a single bolt or a massive bag with building materials lol.
- The companion AI is weird. My dude dissappears for a while right near plague hearts sometimes and tells me to wait for him lol. Also, I escape to the roof thinking we might live but my dude goes down the ladder to fight 20+ plague zombies alone. Sometimes goes right into the room with it to fight things while I'm chucking bombs.
- The tutorial is lacking. It doesn't tell you that the plague heart is not in places marked with the symbol but has its own thing somewhere else. It doesn't tell you it's not destroyable by melee hitting. It tricks you into spending influence points on a meaningless ammo dump. It never tells you you can't aim grenades but they just get chucked.
- Outposts idea is great but HOW do outposts generate resources, there is noone there? Instead of limiting my command center level, it should have been by the number of survivors we assign. Lvl1 should have been run by 1 dude, level 2 by 2, level 3 by 2 + power etc. If you have the manpower, you could get whatever resource you wanted. But now, we are limited to magic things appearing.
- Before I understood that I HAD TO do the main questline, I came across some mindlessly running around people in a house who didn't interact with me at all. They just ran around in a house near a plague heart. Later on, after the questline proceeded they interacted but what for. The game tricks you here again to recruit them while you think you can prob build more beds in the available space around but No. For some reason, you cannot. Apparently you have to pick and choose your peeps but that's allright because the game expects you to replay after your first learning playthrough. After all, why would you recruit useless people if you knew what was happening right?
- There is a supply limit of 20 unless you do upgrades. I had the bikergang place and there were empty spaces all around but no. 20 it is. Also you can't place shitty wooden beds around LOL
- Apparently in this game, guns without silencers are a no no. When you fire a rifle in an empty place, even a mountain, you suddenly get 20-30 dudes running at you. This is way worse in a plague heart location.
- Everytime I see zombie movies/games with sound being used as a distraction mechanism. I always wonder WHY can we not build a 3-4 meter deep hole, add some gasoline at the bottom, dangle the music thing at the top of it and just wait to light it up after enough has fallen. After the initial light up, the fire would prob go perpetually until the area clears itself.


TL;DR; After seeing all the positive reviews, I feel cheated out of my money. No base building, so far no story, 0 meaningful interaction with other survivors. Weird game mechanics all around. I had way more fun with a similar (loosely) game called `Days Gone` than this. It's just consuming time without giving aything back. Requested a refund.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend State of Decay 2. On paper, this sounds like a fantastic time - coop zombie smashing with some resource gathering and base building mechanics in an open world? Sign me up! The execution, however, is sorely lacking, beginning with...

...Getting into multiplayer. It's... it's awful. It uses the old Xbox multiplayer service thing and it's clunky as all hell, bordering on broken. It took me an hour to get this thing working, and when I finally did, I learned that progress only counts for the host. So that's... pretty bad, and ruins the potential that lies within a game like this. Logically, you'd think it'd be fun - you and a friend level up your characters, upgrade the base, etc. But your friend is going to be stuck using whatever underdeveloped character they have in *their* campaign and won't be able to progress... at all. They also can't perform core actions, like building said base, or like... using certain functions like the medical system. Baffling decisions were made here.

In short, the multiplayer sucks, and needlessly so.

How's the singleplayer? It's fine! It is... an open world zombie game. You love it, or you get bored and move on. It doesn't help that none of the systems within SoD 2 truly stand out on their own - middling combat, an okay open world, mediocre character customization... As much as I hate putting numbers on these things, It is the definition of a 6/10 game.

So - is this worth playing? Maybe if you LOVE zombies, but even then, you're probably already playing something better. And dear god, don't purchase this for the multiplayer - it's not great at best, and unendingly frustrating at worst.

For over the last 10 years we have been inundated with zombie media. Usually, the zombie apocalypse is bleak and violent with a common motif that the "real monsters" are other humans.

State of Decay 2 bucks that trend for the better. It is a zombie survival game but the focus is on building your community. You don't have to lone wolf if, but you can recruit fellow survivors to help you build a sustainable community. Most of the NPCs tend to be neutral or friendly with the occasional violent human NPC.

The focus of the game is finding resources for your developing community. You also have to juggle morale, safety and survivor needs and this be accomplished through trading or scavenging incentivizing  the player to form alliances with other enclaves to trade with.

The combat is fun. Ranged combat has a variety of fun weapons, but the melee is done really well. It is satisfying to take down a bug juggernaut zombie with a cool killing blow animation. 

Fully recommend this game.

Fun game, especially with friends.  It does, however, show its age. Game engine only allows for 7 characters to exist at once, so having a community with more than that is pointless for base defense. Also, when playing with friends, game forces you to do things together, with a limit of 400 or so meter range that you can play in, centered on the host active character. It does, however, allow for a wide range of play styles, with weapons and abilities to match. Base building is also a key strength of this game, with an almost endless combinations for your base. Base locations on the maps are also diverse and interesting, with few exceptions. Other than a few minor bugs, like zombies getting trapped in cliffs, it's a blast. Well worth the buy, and I can't wait until the new game comes out.

if you played Project Zomboid and thought, "man this is so cool, but also it's way too complex for my attention span. how will i ever manage all these possibilities??" then SoD2 is for you. well, it was for me anyway.

i wanted so hard to like Zomboid but i don't know if it was the overwhelming amount of things or the perspective or the controls, but it quickly lost my focus. an hour or two into SoD2 i realized that it's a more streamlined kind of experience than PZ, and i fell in love. i am actually inspired to give PZ another shot once i exhaust SoD2 :)

anyway, i really enjoyed the many systems at work here. i'm the kind of gamer who feels like he has to do *everything* -- i burnt myself out of Skyrim because i wanted to visit ALL the tombs, e.g,. in State of Decay 2, that's not really feasible. *technically* you could do it, but between the zombie threat, the timed missions*, taking care of everyone, and especially inventory management, there's not really time or need to do that. i like when a game can break me out of my habits!

sound is great, voice acting leaves a little to be desired but i didn't find it to be too distracting. graphics are terrific, and i'm able to max everything on my 2070. there are improvements to be made with the UI but it does a good job of not getting in my way.

as far as difficulty, i feel capable of tackling any challenge, but not so capable that nothing is a threat. i would say any threat so far is manageable because i've been hoarding. there've definitely been some OH SHIT moments though -- usually related to unexpected hordes of plague zeds. i'm playing on normal difficulty, which at the start was perfect but i may increase it soon.

overall i feel like i got good value for the money. this game is an easy "yes" buy.

If you're looking for an Open World Survival Crafting FPS with Base Management then look no further. I've played Days Gone, 7 Days to Die and other zombie games and honestly this is one of the best I've played because it mashes everything up so well. This game is definitely worth the sticker price, but if you can wait, it frequently goes on sale for $15 USD. Either way, highly recommend!

Also, fyi that you're probably gunna restart the game/"community" a few times as you learn the game. No matter how much you Google online, there's no substitute for getting into it. I once spent my whole Saturday on my second game. I made one stupid mistake and that was it. I started over and also lowered the difficulty to Standard for my third run. It's MUCH more enjoyable. 

Trust me, unless you're some hardcore gamer with tons of time on your hands, just start with Standard. If you want to up the difficulty later you can do so anytime in game without restarting the game via their difficulty slider.

This game was rendered completely unplayable after 1300 hours of gameplay by a corrupt save game file issue. The Steam cloud gets checked even when bot selected. How had I not heard of this game until 2022? It's like someone combined  FarCry, GTA and L4D. Gameplay is fun, base management is fun, driving is fun, stomping zombies is fun, gunplay is fun. The granularity of the  difficulty settings allows me to inch it up ever so slightly every time I go to a new city, so it never gets old. THEN in 2022 they release a patch that fixed 8 out of the 10 complaints I had... for free... 4 years after release. More save slots, character saving, and keeping your gear after the final mission. I would end this review with "I can't wait to see what they cook up for SoD 3." but, honestly, after 178 hours, I still have 4 or 5 more combinations of harder difficulties to try. It's just a delight to play, every time.
not bad

TL:DR I love this game so much I bought it twice.

There are all kinds of great zombie survival games out there, but usually they focus on only a few things. State of Decay 2 doesn't do that. It has a little bit of everything. Which, incidentally, is the reason I love this game so much.

If you like base building mechanics, it has those. If you like resource management, it has that. If you like RPG elements like skills and traits, it has those as well. It also has zombies, but I figure that's probably not too much of a surprise. It also has multiplayer, a horde defense mode, and a mini story mode as well.

The only real issues I have with the game are with the AI and the maps. The AI can be a bit dumb and frustrating at times, but isn't too bad overall. The maps are fine for the most part, but you will occasionally encounter an invisible bump while driving around, sending you tumbling. Oh, and the Devs gave hostile NPC's hacks on the harder difficulties. Those darn cheaters!

Edit: Oh yeah. And the game continues to receive LIVE support and new content to this day.

TLDR: Refreshing sequel with a lot of new features, maps, and mechanics (and even co-op)! A lot of new things to explore and experience, but can still get boring and repetitive after a while.

Gameplay-
☐ Very good
☑ Good
☐ Nothing special
☐ Okay
☐ Bad

The gameplay is improved from the first State of Decay, while still keeping the core game mechanics. This game has more to offer than the last game in terms of of gameplay features, but it still feels very much like a State of Decay game. There are more maps, more things to build, more zombies, and a lot more cool features that make you go "oh! that's new!".

For the average player of games, this game can get tedious after a while (as do most games). But with multiple maps to explore and heaps of new base locations, if you get bored you can just move somewhere new and check out new locations. Of course, after a while this gets boring too. Although State of Decay 2 does get tedious, it has hours and hours of gameplay that is worth experiencing and a bunch of new features that distinguish it from the previous game.

Graphics-
☐ Masterpiece
☐ Beautiful
☑ Good
☐ Will do
☐ Bad
☐ Awful

The State of Decay franchise has never been known for it's graphics and/or visuals, but it doesn't fall short really. I've never played this game and thought it looked horrible, nor have I played it and thought it looked amazing. The graphics are what they are, nothing special, and I'm okay with that. 


Audio
☐ Amazing
☐ Very good
☑ Good
☐ Decent
☐ Not too bad
☐ Bad

The sound affects in this game can be quite comical at times, but it goes with the theme of this game, its graphics and its play-style. The sound of the zombies are great and interesting, but not very scary (I'm not sure if it is supposed to be that way?), the voice lines are really impressive and immersive, and the SFX of the world is nothing special, but it all works well together.


Story-
☐ Lovely
☐ Good
☐ Average
☑ Not great
☐ None

For this I decided to put 'Not Great' because I'm not too sure if there is a story at all, perhaps a hint of a story. If you can class 'there's a zombie outbreak and we have to survive' as a story, then this game has a lovely story. However, comparing the survivors stories to the previous game, there is no introductory scene or explanation as to what happened. All we can do is guess that this is the same outbreak from the previous instalment. 


Difficulty-
☐ Just press a bunch of buttons
☐ Easy
☐ Significant brain usage
☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☐ Not so easy
☑ Difficult
☐ Dark Souls

This one depends on the difficulty that you play at. I play on the average difficulty and so far only one of my survivors have died, so it is enjoyable but only slightly challenging. However, bumping this up one difficulty, I really struggled to do anything! There were barely any guns/weapons out there and I was being sent on rescue missions in a town plagued with zombies. It seems to jump up in difficulty quite a lot, so I decided not even try the hardest.


Grind-
☐ Nothing
☐ Only if you care about leaderboards/ranks
☐ Isnt necessary to progress
☑ A bit grindy sometimes
☐ Average grind level
☐ Too much grind
☐ Insanity

Again, this all depends on your difficulty preference. Playing on average, I had to grind quite a bit for supplies to keep my base running and my survivors fed. Both looking for supplies and finding weapons are about the only things you will grind for, unless you find the quests grindy too.


Price
☐ Just buy it
☐ Worth the price
☑ Wait for sale
☐ Maybe if you have some spare money left
☐ Not recommended

Solid game and a solid sequel. It has it's issues like having to have an xbox/microsoft account, various bugs and what not but those issues are all pretty minor compared to how fun the game is.

If you are looking to be immersed in story and characters, this isn't the game for you. Go play State of Decay 1. You'll get a decent run there. HOWEVER, if you liked the gameplay in State of Decay 1 and just want to have blast with the replayability, then play State of Decay 2. It is more polished than the first game in every way.

It feels like the devs have polished every feature from the first game except the story. So far in the zombie game market, this is the only one that truly brings about the survival simulator from the Walking Dead where you constantly have to scavenge for supplies and work with other survivor communities. There's nothing out there quite like it.

Pros
- Lots of replayability
- Good looting zombie survival
- Combat is fun and has a few different fighting skills.
- Lots of quality of life updates over the years.

Cons
- Micro managing between resources, Infestations, and missions can feel tedious.
- The Co-op tether system is awful (You have to stay near host) 
- Some zombie/creep spawns in this game are just rigged. 
- Prepare to have your time wasted when your level'd survivors die due to unforeseen circumstances.

State of Decay 2 is a mish-mash of survival horror and maintenance simulation. You control a group of survivors who each have their own personalities, desires, and needs. You can choose who you play as, who you prioritize, who thrives and who succumbs to the elements. The game starts out giving you 3 survivors who have unique skills and traits, and you have the option to grow your group as you play.

Cons: Always on DRM requires that the Xbox live service is not currently down when you want to log in to the game for the first time, or after logging out

Pros: Xbox live is not currently down anymore (09/09/22), so vague internet problems half a world away on a totally unrelated microsoft web-service are no longer preventing me from playing the single player game I paid for, because it broke the DRM service

If you like a game that has a DRM service that relies on Xbox Live, in order to progress passed the title screen - this game was made for you 

10/10 digital rights management service, i look forward to the inevitable day you arbitrarily decide that I can just no longer play this single player game that i paid for, forever 

E: now with 5 hours in - the game's fun, it's good. It's a fun chill game that I enjoy dipping in for an hour every so often.

It's more of a Strategy game than a straight shoot em up. If you like the slow build overtime, learning everything and picking your best base/characters. This is the game for you. I have over 100+ hours so I'm brand new but I am having a blast. Co-Op is a lot more fun than people make it out to be IMHO.
