It’s too many zombie games in game market, and the game is not the first game of the type, unless it has more interesting features than others, or it can’t become another classic apocalypse surviving zombie game.
I won’t speak more introduction, what players care about is the gameplay, right?

Expert game reviewer will speak about the pictures and sound&background musics, the story etc, but I only speak about the gameplay, because I’m only interested on the gameplay so I apology.
Now I first the villain then the gentleman, talk about the defects.

Defects:

1. Zombies respawn too fast.

Almost every time players left the area and return to the place from another area, those zombies that killed by them reset and even re-appeared zombie hordes and freaks.

2. Limited loot-able resources in every maps.

It’s not like other open world games, all loot-able items in all maps in the game set to unable respawn, even though maps in the game are large map, there has many places and buildings can be loot by players, but still it’s limited, one day players will looted all contains in the map. Only about time.

fortunately there has the main quest in the game, if players can finish it before spent all the resources then their survived characters can be saved in the community.

3. NPC’s AI is too stupid.

Every time they saw zombies in the sight, they always rush to attack them without any hesitate, even what they saw was zombie horde with freaks. If it’s no car nearby the player, and the player decided to run away, these NPC companies won’t follow the player and stayed to fight until slaughtered by them.(They only forced follow the player when the player enter a car)

And the best way to break through the situation is to throw firecrackers then throw grenades on those zombies what gathered by firecrackers. But these AI companies never trying to avoid those grenades, they always stayed in the blast area and attack zombies until knocked down by the explosion. This is very non reasonable and players tactic will seriously hampered by their stupid actions.

The worse point is when the player tried to sneak attack zombies in the infected zone, sometimes NPC companies jumped through the window in the house and attack zombies first before you do anything, they often bugger something up and made things more difficult.

And when the player stepped into a house who trying to loot some stuffs, AI companions sometimes will also jumped into the house and broke the window, it seems they fear zombies didn’t notice the player was inside the house. Is NPCs too stupid or just the developer of their AI is lack of intelligence?

Otherwise, AI companies sometimes kept idle until got claw or got bitten, even zombies came from their front. And of course when the player got bite, their idle won’t stop(they only made fighting stance without any action). This is inexplicable design.

In the last, AI companions often open the home site’s door and rush to zombies when the home site under siege, abandoned their benefit defense position. Even idiot know that zombies entered the home site the battle will very easy become out control.
And AI companions guarded on the tower in the home site, sometimes will come down to fight zombies in home site siege event, it’s really too stupid.
I suggest Undead Lab to refer the classic nuclear war apocalypse game “Fallout”, allow players to order their AI companions to change their stance to enemies like “aggressive”, “passive”, “never attack”, and allow players to order them “stand here(guard here)” or “follow me” etc.

4. It still has many bugs remained in the game even passed 2 years on the market.

For example, the player character randomly stuck(this often happened when the player opened a locker or container), unless he/she jumped or he/she cannot move.

For example, when the host player driven the car away client players and each client player entered other cars, then their cars will teleport to the host player’s location then explode, because their cars will reduplicated in the same place and crash to explode(and their characters will dying)!

For example, one player is fixing his/her car, another player stand near him/her, when the player done the fixing then the player stand near him/her sometimes will blasted to another street by nothing, and the player character will dying for that(in a few of rate).

For example, the player cannot talk to his/her AI companion(so he/she cannot trade with his/her AI companion).

For example, the marked place will randomly moved to another empty location by the system, misled the player to the wrong place unless he/she often check his/her map and find the bug happened before he/she arrived the wrong place.(this often happened when a new random quest was given to the player by the system)

For example, some zombies in infected area that fell in the place below to the ground or stuck in some rocks, made players cannot kill them to clear the infected area.

For example, sometimes the player character can cancel his/her attacking action and dodge another zombie’s attack, but sometimes his/her character cannot.

For example, the player cannot check the remaining fuel of his/her car and the car’s model(if you cannot see how much fuel in it, you cannot know that is the time to refuel it or not).

5. Non realistic 3D physical calculation.

For example, if you drive the car and rush on a road but the car only hit a tiny rock, your car will fly to the air even possibly overturns…
For example, all broke abandoned cars are just hard like the mountain and concrete buildings, if you drive the car hit those broke abandoned cars, only your car will damaged and shaken back.
For example, when the player drives the car ran on the jumping platform, the car always hit the ground in 90 ankle

6. It’s no the line of lead prediction of dropping grenades. 

The player can only depend on himself/herself to drop his/her grenades precisely because there is no the line of lead prediction when he/she drops the grenade to help he/she to aim the right target point.

7. There has the random quest that lures the players into the death trap.

For example, sometimes the radio will call for help, even the player comes to the source of the radio call, those survivors cry for help in the last second but becomes zombies in next second before your own eyes! And they will rush to the player with many other zombies, even included some special zombies(freaks) like ferals, screamers! If the player tried to save their lives, will often runs into the center of those zombies.

Sometimes there even comes over 3 ferals or even worse, the battle sound maybe attracted another roaming zombie horde(possibility included a blood plague juggeraut) near the location! Maybe the player can survived but his/her AI companies possibly cannot.

Even the player survived in the death trap quest, the player will only earned 100 influences and some members of the player’s community pity. It’s completely not worth for the quest.

In the logic we all know that if the survivors killed by zombies, they are impossible to become zombies instantly, zombies will eat them alive first until they are all became skeletons. It’s very obviously no time for them to become other zombies. So we can think the random quest designed to trapped players to die by Undead Lab(the game’s developers).

The worst point is sometimes the player still has the chance to save survivors’ life in the random quest, they will not always instant die when the player arrived the place. So the player still cannot just abandon it or ignore it.

Not a good game at all, if you want a zombie survival game, then look somewhere else.
This game was fun for like the first 10-20 hours, then it started to dwindle down, cause you do the same thing over and over:
Bring this here, clear infestation there, escort this survivor.. it gets boring fast.

Even the new mode: Daybreak, gets boring after 2-3 playtroughs, cause it's again.. same thing over and over, just defend one person with the arsenal you have. After you get the strategy down, it's also very easy. That wouldn't be a problem, if the devs didn't make Daybreak SO GRINDY. There is around 50-60+ things you need to "farm", but each playtrough unlocks only 3 items, if you manage to finish the waves. It takes around 40 minutes to finish one whole playtrough, so you're stuck for hours doing same thing, just to unlock things you might want. Note: Most of the cool stuff you can unlock is unlocked near the end, the unlocks are not random, you have a defined rewards as you go. Most of the stuff is useless in Daybreak/SoD2 anyway.

The game is very unpolished, some obstacles look jumpable/climbable, but the character just jumps in air.
By default the key E is bound to a lot of actions, so often times you do something you didn't want to. 
You have a zombie laying down you can finish with a finisher, but the "autolock" makes you grab a different zombie which bites you. 
You can't climb tiny obstacles or rocks, so you often get stuck on them.
The inventory system leaves much to desire, when one sheet of paper takes as much space as a whole portable generator.
It all adds up eventually, making the game more and more frustrating as you find these issues.

Game could use a LOT of polishing to be considered good, but for now, it's kinda meh. Find a different zombie survival game.

Edit:
Played more, and discovered even more BS stuff, can only recommend it even less, if it's even possible. 
Save yourself money, nerves and time, and just avoid this garbage

Short answer is the game gets a thumbs up.

In a little more detail the AI are not going to hold your hand while they clear the area for you but they are not completely useless. Effectiveness is affected somewhat by the weapon you give them, especially the weapon fire modes the gun has. Generally on loot trips your pack mule (follower) will in my experience be more effective if the gun you give them makes them default to burst firing an automatic weapon with a decent sized clip (not all guns do you need to find that for yourself). Yes followers become less useful on the highest difficulties and even a liability at times but its your choice, take them on a dangerous mission (i.e. kill other faction) for extra firepower or leave them save and sound at home?

The game is not truly co-op but neither is it useless to play co-op. Some complain progress is not saved, materials not earned etc. This is not fully correct as you can swap characters from your own saves in and out at will and what they carry is swapped out to your save when you put them back on the roster. I will repeat that, they keep what they carry, including materials backpacks. You can therefore earn some materials, character xp etc and if your co-op player is a more advanced friend with good stocks you can with their permission take and store medical items, weapons, plague cure, ammo etc.

The default game-play delivers a particular experience but at 300 hours I do not play full vanilla with a realistic not op ammo stacking mod etc to make the game a little more shooter friendly but not ruin the experience. If you want you can make the default settings even harder if that is the route you want to take. So after completing many games you can still refresh the experience to give the game a new lease of life in a direction you want to take.

I exclusively played the game only on Lethal, I've never dipped my toes into any other difficulty, ever. The balance in terms of gameplay is honestly pretty good, you pay for your own mistakes most of the time. You sometimes drive over a bloater on a low-health character, or you fail to GTFO when SHTF, choosing to stay behind and risk your life, sometimes at the cost of it. It's easy to break line of sight and lose a horde of zombies, and while Ferals are vastly overpowered and unreasonable, you can cheese them by Dropkicking them or shooting their heads from atop cars. I suspect other skills effect Ferals the same way Dropkick does, too. Overall it's easy to survive if you're focused, and it's easy to die whenever there's a lapse. 

        But the NPC AI is deficient, sub-par doesn't even begin to describe it. The devs failed HARD in terms of their NPC AI, and although I truly love this game's premise, design, gameplay elements and lore, I feel very disappointed for thought of the AI that Undead Labs actually believed was passable. Sometimes you need to GTFO but your follower stops while running to the car, multiple times on the way to it. Other times you're trying to execute a zombie and a follower makes you stumble, interrupting your execution. Other times, your entire roster of survivors at home base will stand there while a zombie waltzes in and bites you. They literally just don't react to threats sometimes. It's baffling. You can't toggle passive/aggressive/neutral etc. They DO at least have unlimited ammo, but that's more of a pittance afforded the player to balance the game in light of the poor AI design. Similar to how Ferals can't climb on top of cars, because again, triple Feral packs on Lethal would be objectively unmanageable otherwise. Yes you can juggle a feral with a heavy weapon easily enough, but how will you go about juggling 3 of them? You can't. Cheesing their pathing from atop a car is the only way to handle the situation, and I despise it when games give you the solution of "cheese existing mechanics" as the only viable option for handling a situation that is common to the core gameplay loop.

        Hostile AI NPC's are a different story. They have magnificent aim, but in defense of the devs, it works well to crouch behind some sort of barrier, and slowly inch your way out until you can shoot them in the head. You can often shoot them before they can shoot you, this way. Another few headshots while they're on the ground, and they'll die. But I personally feel like killing a human should be like killing a zombie: One head shot only, and I would personally label this as a game design flaw. It doesn't fit. It just breaks immersion to shoot hostile NPC's in the head multiple times and see them get down and get back up, repeatedly. But honestly, you can just as easily honk your car's horn and lure infected to a hostile enclave to kill it. That works just as well. 

        Survivor creation was a major point of contempt for me. I rapidly realized that Never Been Sick and Hygiene were the best things to get; Moreover, I rapidly realized that you want Cleaning Chart or Hygiene Standards on as many starting survivors as possible, so I began only accepting characters who have Never Been Sick and Hygiene, with a likelihood of those aforementioned optimal hero skills. I died, a LOT. As expected, given the fact that I was playing Lethal difficulty as a complete noob to the game. As such I had to restart and create new survivors, a lot. The inability to create survivors to my liking basically meant I'd spend an hour randomly generating new characters between every Lethal run attempt, and I'd often accidentally skip over generated survivors that I wanted to keep, because of the mind-numbing monotony of the process. I feel like this is a dopamine trap that the devs put into the game to extend playtime. I guarantee you that at least 30 of my hours were spent in character creation, and I just feel like the current implementation of survivor generation pre-game is insulting to us all. It's literally a slot machine where you can get the dopamine rush associated with gambling, and I am in strong disagreement toward it as a game design decision. It's petty, it's lowly, it's a way for the devs to increase play time, yet while you're creating survivors, you're not actually playing the game. I should not have 30 hours of playtime where I was not even in the actual game. That is an objective game design flaw chosen by the devs on purpose, which is meant to capitalize on the human brain's dopamine production and ramp-up play time numbers, and I see right through it. While Undead Labs would tell you it's in the spirit of the game, it's actually just in the spirit of stimulating psychological addiction in you, but a really unfun and draining kind of psychological addiction. It is not a fun or engaging experience to generate characters. It is rather a period of torturous monotony that disrupts this game's overall potential for fun. I'd recommend they switch to a positive and negative traits-based system, similar to Project Zomboid, wherein you're only allowed to take positive traits if you have taken on negative traits first, to accumulate the required points for the positives. For example, giving someone a trait which makes them eat 50% more food per day gives you 15 positive trait points to spend on them, with Never Been Sick and Hygiene costing 20 trait points each to have, etc. 

(Edit: They added the ability to go backwards in character generation, so you can no longer skip past really good survivors, an EXTREMELY welcomed change to the game. It removed a great deal of the pain and monotony from survivor generation.)

        Anyway I like the game, but there are a lot of design decisions here that I'd deem to be big mistakes in the modern gaming industry. You know how food is often designed to be chemically more addictive, like through aspartame and monosodium glutamate? Games are often designed to be more addictive too, even at the expense of the player. Refer to loot boxes, random generation, etc. While random generation has a valuable place in games, I feel it's misused in State of Decay 2. While I'd recommend using Random Generation Algorithms to randomize the geographical locations of certain buildings, or the generation of loot and the patterns of weather in the game world, they have used it to create a survivor-generating slot machine to stimulate dopamine production in you. It just feels exceedingly cheap. This game is a masterpiece no doubt about it, and it stands alone in its genre, as the only game of its type. But it also falls into quite a fair amount of the common pitfalls associated with video games today. You can tell that Undead Labs cut a lot of corners in development, expect bugs to screw you over sometimes. Frequent autosaves mean you'll be paying for those bugs, too. I recommend you play it, but I don't recommend you start on the hardest difficulty. I personally believe they should gate Lethal difficulty, behind the completion of the game on a prior difficulty. Either that, or make it so we can create custom survivors with a point-based positive and negative trait system. They have to eliminate the monotony between game attempts, otherwise, starting on Lethal difficulty will always remain more a form of mental torture than a privilege for thrill seekers in the fanbase.

So much of these games revolve around fighting against the subpar game mechanics and annoying design choices.  So many of those design choices are incredibly cynical and obnoxious.  Dick-moves by the devs.

- There are many improvements and tweaks from SoD1, some increase fun, atmosphere, and immersion, but others create more hassle, more busy-work, and lots of frustration.  
- constant stuttering, motion-blur.  As bad as the original, if not worse.  That needs fixed.
- Your action button is also your 'talk to companion' button, so instead of opening/closing a door, you often talk to your companion.  Instead of picking up searching a container, you talk to your companion.  IN THE MIDDLE OF COMBAT, instead of using a killing-blow, you TALK TO  YOUR COMPANION.  (And no, you can't change keybinds to be different for those different actions as far as I can tell.  They seem to all be hard-coded to use the same input.)
- zombies SPAWN around you all the time.  This is lazy and a 'cheat' by the devs.  This is an open-world game; to have enemies just spawn around you is pathetic.
- companion AI is a joke for so many reasons there are too many to list, but they'll often just stand there as enemies beat down on them.  Literally just stand there.
- It's night twice as long as daytime; this hinders world exploration, since you often can't see and appreciate the world.  This really sucks if you enjoy the exploration and discovery of open world games.  
- Of course you're constantly being hit w/ missions on the extreme far ends of the map, often at the worse times.  If that happened sometimes, it would be great; if it happens all the time, it gets annoying and feels like a busy-work, resource-spending contrivance.
- Your map marker CONSTANTLY changes location for no reason.
- Teammates who often have the poor AI ; always making noise, getting into trouble, going out of their way to attract zombies, get swarmed, open doors and letting zombies in, etc.  They'll frequently just STAND THERE and let zombies wail on them.
- You go to open a wedged door... so the game puts you into "bash it open" mode (spam click L-mouse key) at the risk of making noise.  There's apparently no way to exit this mode.  Once locked in, you must bash the door.  You're screwed if there's a nearby hoard, you go to open a door... and you're forced into "door bash mode."
- many many many glitches in regards to missions; given missions that cannot be completed (or even started), campaigns where the missions break and you're given no more missions, etc.
- frequently falling off ladders, instead of actually using them
- As in the first game, it's easy to get vehicles stuck, but they added an "Unstuck" command that is helpful

While some of the changes certainly made the game more fun, other changes just create artificial contrived barriers to eat up more time.  However on the whole, it's a worthy successor.  Overall it's fun, great atmosphere, solid experience, easy to put a lot of hours into it.  However there are so many flaws and glitches that tells me either the devs were incompetent, didn't have enough time/resources, or didn't care.  Glad I waited and bought it on sale.

State of Decay (SoD) is a zombie base builder SIM game with survival aspect and some  story elements.

SoD 2 has the same SoD 1 goodness with a fair bit more challenge with the blood plaque mechanic.
Zombie behavior is also more aggressive and less cheese worthy vs their SoD 1 counter part.
The base game use to not have a, opting for an infinite survival mode (SoD1 break down) as its based game  but in 2022 a full fledge story mode is included both decently compelling and challenging.
Devs are still supporting the game 4 years after its initial release

That said... idk if this is a massive bug or not but gun aim mode is jank that constantly de-aim when I don't want it to causing frustrating combat encounters especially in CQB with guns. Fix that and I'll only see net win from here.

Fun and definitely an improvement over the first game. If there's one thing I miss from the first game though, it would definitely be the inclusion of all the other special combat moves for this game like the Double Kill powerhouse move and all the heavy weapons special moves.

If you're familiar with the first game, game mechanics will seem definitely refreshing for a first playthrough in standard difficulty. However, I am confident you will find that the game is extremely easy in any difficulty lower than Nightmare. I would recommend trying Nightmare if you want to match the same kind of challenge that was offered in the first game. State of Decay 2's highest difficulty, Lethal, is honestly way too much for a new or unfamiliar returning player.

The game also still gets substantial updates every now and then, and will seem to continue getting them as the devs work on State of Decay 3. Get the game on sale or after you're done playing State of Decay 1 and you're gonna see your hours stack up on this game in no time.

My buddy joins me for what is essentially a coop campaign.

About 5 hours in I meet a man named Brayden and have him join my settlement.

Brayden is a mexican who I made in charge of my garden. He really seemed to know what he was doing.

Maxed his stuff out and took him on a plague heart destruction mission.

It's Almost dead

A juggernaut comes into the house.

I hear him from the side of the house sounding a soul-siphoning scream.

Juggernaut throws his lifeless torso at my feet.

10/10 
RIP Brayden. You will never be forgotten.

While the singleplayer experience is pretty fun in my opinion, due to the exploration and looting system as well as the combat being decent, if you are looking for a multiplayer zombie game do not buy this for just that. 

The multiplayer is utterly disappointing, it just makes the game easier with no balancing in mind, my friend and I looted tons of good stuff so quickly because no zombies were an issue, and by we looted stuff I mean I looted stuff and he stood nearby because the non-host player exists solely to be another gun or baseball bat to hit things with, other players get MAYBE 1 or 2 boxes to loot per house while the host gets 4-10. So if you're looking for a fun singleplayer game, this is it, do not buy this for multiplayer, its a waste of time. 

Minecraft is a better Multiplayer Open-World Survival Zombie game than this.
